{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"John_McEuen","to":"John McEuen"}],"pages":{"14297144":{"pageid":14297144,"ns":0,"title":"John McEuen","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer-songwriter}}\n\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = John McEuen\n| image           = 10 JOHN solo John McEuen Deering Hi Res-31 conv copy 2 Deering, blue coat copy 2.jpg\n| caption         = John McEuen playing the banjo\n| birth_date      = {{birth date and age|1945|12|19}}\n| birth_place     = [[Oakland, California|Oakland]], California, U.S.\n| genre           = [[Country music|Country]], [[folk music|folk]], folk-rock, [[bluegrass music|bluegrass]]\n| occupation      = Musician, singer, producer\n| instrument      = Banjo, guitar, mandolin, fiddle, piano, accordion, vocals\n| years_active    = 1965\u2013present\n| label           = [[Warner Bros. Records|Warner Bros.]], [[Vanguard Records|Vanguard]], Cedar Glen, Planetary, Aix, Rural Rhythm\n| past_member_of = [[Nitty Gritty Dirt Band]]\n| website         = {{official URL}}\n}}\n\n'''John McEuen''', born December 19, 1945, in [[Oakland, California|Oakland]], California, is an American folk musician and a founding member of the [[Nitty Gritty Dirt Band]].\n\n==Career==\n===Solo work===\nJohn McEuen was born in [[Oakland, California]]. In 1964, at age 18, he became interested in music after seeing a performance by [[the Dillards]], and learned to play the banjo. Eventually, he took an interest in fiddle and mandolin. In 1986, after twenty years with the Dirt Band, McEuen departed to pursue a solo career. From 1991\u20131997, he released four albums for [[Vanguard Records]]. He composed music for movies and television and he appeared as a guest on albums with several artists including five albums with [[Michael Martin Murphey]]. He then returned to the Dirt Band in 2001.<ref name=\"Deming\">{{cite web|last1=Deming|first1=Mark|title=John McEuen {{!}} Biography & History|url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/john-mceuen-mn0000222298/biography|website=AllMusic|access-date=7 January 2017}}</ref> McEuen departed the band once again in late 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://bluegrasstoday.com/john-mceuen-leaves-nitty-gritty-dirt-band/|title=Bluegrass today|date=November 13, 2017}}{{Dead link|date=February 2022 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>\n\n===Steve Martin===\nMcEuen has known [[Steve Martin]] since high school, when he would give Martin occasional lessons on the banjo. In 1978, he was asked by Martin to provide the backing band for a comic, novelty song called ''[[King Tut (song)|King Tut]]''. With Martin on vocals, the Dirt Band recorded the song under the alias \"The Toot Uncommons\".<ref name=\"Deming\" />\n\nMcEuen produced and played on Martin's album ''[[The Crow: New Songs for the 5-String Banjo]]'' ([[Rounder Records|Rounder]], 2009). The album was Number 1 for seven months and won the [[Grammy Award for Best Bluegrass Album]].<ref name=\"Deming\" />\n\n===Other ventures===\n\nMcEuen published an autobiography in 2018 titled ''The Life I've Picked - A Banjo Player's Nitty Gritty Journey''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chicagoreviewpress.com/life-i-ve-picked--the-products-9781613738955.php|title=The Life I've Picked|access-date=13 September 2018}}</ref>\n\n==Awards and honors==\n* [[American Banjo Museum|The American Banjo Museum]] [[American Banjo Museum Hall of Fame members|Hall of Fame Inductee]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.americanbanjomuseum.com/hall-of-fame-celebration|title=American Banjo Museum|website=American Banjo Museum|access-date=21 November 2017}}</ref>\n*Independent Music Award for Best Americana Album, \"Made in Brooklyn\"<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://independentmusicawards.com/16th-independent-music-awards-winners/|title=The 16Th Independent Music Awards Winners}}</ref>\n\n==References==\n{{reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n* {{official website|1=https://www.johnmceuen.com/}}\n* [https://www.namm.org/library/oral-history/john-mceuen John McEuen Interview] at [[NAMM Oral History Program|NAMM Oral History Collection]] (March 6, 2004)\n\n{{Nitty Gritty Dirt Band}}\n{{authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:McEuen, John}}\n[[Category:1945 births]]\n[[Category:American country rock singers]]\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:American rock musicians]]\n[[Category:Country musicians from California]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:Singers from Oakland, California]]\n[[Category:Nitty Gritty Dirt Band members]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from California]]\n[[Category:American country banjoists]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Don_Amero","to":"Don Amero"}],"pages":{"49340081":{"pageid":49340081,"ns":0,"title":"Don Amero","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|Canadian music artist}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = Don Amero\n| image           = Don Amero in 2022.jpg\n| caption         = Don Amero in 2022.\n| image_size      =\n| landscape       = yes\n| birth_name      =\n| birth_date      = {{Birth date and age|1980|9|11}}\n| birth_place     = [[Winnipeg]], [[Manitoba]], Canada\n| genre           = [[country music|country]], [[folk music|folk]]\n| years_active    = 2007-present\n| label           = [[MDM Recordings Inc.|MDM Recordings]]\n| associated_acts = [[Brett Kissel]], [[Indian City]], [[Raquel Cole]]\n| website         = {{official website|http://donamero.ca/}}\n}}\n'''Donald Amero''' (born September 11, 1980) is a [[Canadians|Canadian]] [[country music|country]] and [[folk music|folk]] singer-songwriter from [[Winnipeg]], [[Manitoba]].<ref name=ready>[http://www.winnipegfreepress.com/special/ourcityourworld/first-nations/ready-for-a-breakthrough-185134261.html \"Ready for a breakthrough\"]. ''[[Winnipeg Free Press]]'', December 29, 2012.</ref>\n\nPrior to launching his career as a musician, Amero worked as a hardwood flooring installer,<ref name=ready /> and unsuccessfully tried out for ''[[Canadian Idol]]'' in 2006.<ref>\"Winnipeg-raised Idol judge has high hopes for city singers\". ''[[Winnipeg Free Press]]'', June 13, 2006.</ref> He released his debut CD ''Change Your Life'' in 2006,<ref>\"New Music\". ''[[Winnipeg Free Press]]'', January 20, 2007.</ref> and left his flooring job in 2007.<ref name=ready /> The album garnered five [[Aboriginal Peoples Choice Music Award]] nominations, for best new artist, songwriter, folk or acoustic CD, album cover and producer/engineer.<ref>\"'Toban musicians could dominate First Nations gala\". ''[[Winnipeg Free Press]]'', September 14, 2007.</ref>\n\nHis second album, ''Deepening'', followed in 2009. The album again garnered several Aboriginal Peoples Choice nominations,<ref>\"Sainte Marie leads nominations\". ''[[Windsor Star]]'', August 21, 2009.</ref> and Amero won the [[Canadian Folk Music Award]] for Aboriginal Songwriter of the Year.<ref>\"Joel Plaskett, former Ottawan tie for two awards each; Chris McKhool's solo project takes cake\". ''[[Ottawa Citizen]]'', November 22, 2009.</ref> In 2010, he performed on the bill for [[Aboriginal Peoples Television Network|APTN]]'s ''Aboriginal Day Live'' concert,<ref>\"Aboriginal Day Live is three events in one; Timing vital in co-ordinating performances from two sites\". ''[[Victoria Times-Colonist]]'', June 20, 2010.</ref> and released his third album ''The Long Way Home''.<ref>\"Singer Amero torn between the road and being home\". ''[[Winnipeg Free Press]]'', November 6, 2010.</ref> The album won the awards for Best Folk Recording at the 2011 [[Native American Music Awards]], and for Best Aboriginal Recording at the [[Western Canadian Music Awards]].<ref>\"Manitoba artists leave their mark; Seven out of 19 categories won by 'Peg-based acts\". ''[[Winnipeg Free Press]]'', October 24, 2011.</ref>\n\nIn 2012, he performed at a fundraising benefit concert for indigenous music pioneer [[Shingoose]],<ref name=stroke>[http://music.cbc.ca/#!/blogs/2012/5/Musicians-pull-together-for-pioneer-Shingoose-after-stroke \"Musicians pull together for pioneer Shingoose after stroke\"]. [[CBC Music]], May 14, 2012.</ref> and released his fourth album ''Heart on My Sleeve''. He also collaborated with Vince Fontaine of [[Eagle & Hawk]] in [[Indian City]], a band whose album ''Supernation'' fused traditional First Nations music with experimental rock.<ref>\"Vince Fontaine's Indian City scores seven nominations\". ''[[Winnipeg Free Press]]'', August 14, 2012.</ref> Amero won Male Entertainer of the Year, and ''Supernation'' won Best Pop Album,  at that year's Aboriginal Peoples Choice Music Awards.<ref>\"Aboriginal performers honoured\". ''[[Winnipeg Free Press]]'', November 3, 2012.</ref> ''Heart on My Sleeve'' garnered Amero his first [[Juno Award]] nomination for [[Juno Award for Aboriginal Album of the Year|Aboriginal Album of the Year]] at the [[Juno Awards of 2013]],<ref>\"Juno nominees\". ''[[Regina Leader-Post]]'', April 13, 2013.</ref> won the award for Best Folk/Acoustic Album at the 2013 Aboriginal Peoples Choice Music Awards,<ref>\"Manitobans take home hardware from APCMAs\". ''[[Winnipeg Free Press]]'', August 20, 2013.</ref> and was nominated for a Canadian Folk Music Award.<ref>\"Local musicians vying for national folk awards\". ''[[Winnipeg Free Press]]'', September 27, 2013.</ref>\n\nHis fifth album, ''Refined'', was released in 2015.<ref>\"Amero celebrating CD release at WECC\". ''[[Winnipeg Free Press]]'', April 15, 2016.</ref> In the same year, he collaborated with country singer [[Brett Kissel]] on \"Rebuild This Town\", a song about cultural reconciliation between Indigenous peoples and other Canadians.<ref>\"Changing the national dialogue; Aboriginal celebration has travelled all over Canada\". ''[[Edmonton Journal]]'', June 18, 2015.</ref><ref>[http://www.cbc.ca/radio/unreserved/bright-lights-small-city-stories-from-hollywood-to-a-saskatchewan-reserve-1.3391893/don-amero-calls-music-an-opportunity-for-education-reconciliation-1.3392477 \"Don Amero calls music an opportunity for education, reconciliation\"]. ''[[Unreserved]]'', January 10, 2016.</ref>\n\nAt the [[Juno Awards of 2016]], ''Refined'' garnered [[Juno Award]] nominations for Aboriginal Album of the Year and [[Juno Award for Adult Contemporary Album of the Year|Adult Contemporary Album of the Year]].<ref>[http://www.cbc.ca/news/arts/juno-nominees-list-2016-1.3430406 \"Junos 2016: Complete list of Juno Award nominees\"]. [[CBC News]], February 2, 2016.</ref>\n\nIn August 2018, Amero released his sixth album, ''Evolution'', which launched him into the country music genre. In 2019, Amero released the single \"Music Lover\" to Canadian country radio.<ref>[https://mdmrecordings.net/artist_press/don-amero/: Don Amero]. MDM Recordings, September 8, 2019.</ref>\n\nIn September 2020, Amero released his extended play ''[[The Next Chapter (EP)|The Next Chapter]]''.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://canadianbeats.ca/2020/10/01/multiple-award-winning-country-music-artist-don-amero-has-released-a-new-album-the-next-chapter-on-the-heels-of-his-other-successes/|first=Nanci|last=Dagg|title=Multiple award-winning country music artist Don Amero has released a new album The Next Chapter on the heels of his other successes|accessdate=November 19, 2020|work=Canadian Beats Media|date=October 1, 2020}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n*''Change Your Life'' (2006)\n*''Deepening'' (2009)\n*''The Long Way Home'' (2010)\n*''Heart on My Sleeve'' (2012)\n*''Refined'' (2015)\n*''Evolution'' (2018)\n*''Amero Little Christmas'' (2019)\n*''[[The Next Chapter (EP)|The Next Chapter]]'' (2020)\n*''Nothing Is Meaningless'' (2021)\n*''Six'' (2023)\n\n===Singles===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Year\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:16em;\"| Single\n! Peak<br />positions\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Album\n|- style=\"font-size:smaller;\"\n! [[Canada Country|CAN<br />Country]]<br /><ref>References for Canada Country chart:\n*Music Lover: {{cite magazine |url= http://charts.bdsradio.com/bdsradiocharts/charts.aspx?formatid=36|title= Billboard Canada Country National Airplay - Week of September 28, 2019|date=September 28, 2019|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20191001210340/http://charts.bdsradio.com/bdsradiocharts/charts.aspx?formatid=36 |archivedate=October 1, 2019|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |accessdate=April 1, 2020}}\n*Wasn't The Dress: {{cite magazine|url=https://www.billboard.com/charts/canada-country/2021-01-16 |title=Canada Country chart for January 16, 2021|magazine=Billboard |accessdate=January 11, 2021}}{{Subscription required}}\n*My Poor Mama: {{cite magazine|url=https://www.billboard.com/charts/canada-country/2021-11-20|title=Canada Country chart for November 20, 2021|magazine=Billboard|accessdate=November 24, 2021}}{{Subscription required}}\n*Let You: {{cite magazine|url=https://www.billboard.com/charts/canada-country/2022-07-23|title=Canada Country chart for July 23, 2022|magazine=Billboard |accessdate=July 22, 2022}}{{Subscription required}}</ref>\n|-\n| 2019\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Music Lover\"\n| 45\n| rowspan=\"4\"| ''The Next Chapter''\n|-\n| rowspan=\"3\"| 2020\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Morning Coffee\"\n| \u2014\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Wouldn't Be Home\"\n| \u2014\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Wasn\u2019t the Dress\"\n| 48\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 2021\n! scope=\"row\"| \"You Can't Always Be 21\"\n| \u2014\n| rowspan=\"3\"| ''Nothing Is Meaningless''\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"My Poor Mama\"\n| 46\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 2022\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Let You\"<br/>{{small|(feat. [[Raquel Cole]])}}\n| 28\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Ain't Too Late\"\n| \u2014\n| rowspan=\"4\"| ''Six''\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 2023\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Go Girl\"\n| \u2014\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Wheels Off\"\n| \u2014\n|-\n| 2024\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Can't Fix This\"\n| \u2014\n|-\n|}\n\n==Awards and nominations==\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n|+\n!Year\n!Association\n!Category\n!Nominated release|url=https://www.globenewswire.com/news-release/2022/09/12/2513625/0/en/TENILLE-TOWNES-TAKES-HOME-FOUR-WINS-AT-THE-2022-CCMA-AWARDS-PRESENTED-BY-TD.html|title=TENILLE TOWNES TAKES HOME FOUR WINS AT THE 2022 CCMA AWARDS PRESENTED BY TD|date=September 11, 2022|work=[[Canadian Country Music Association]]|publisher=Global News Wire|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220912031953/https://www.globenewswire.com/news-release/2022/09/12/2513625/0/en/TENILLE-TOWNES-TAKES-HOME-FOUR-WINS-AT-THE-2022-CCMA-AWARDS-PRESENTED-BY-TD.html|archive-date=September 12, 2022}}</ref>\n|-\n| 2023\n| [[Canadian Country Music Association]]\n|Innovative Campaign of the Year\n| \"Let 'Em Lie\" Release Highlights (with [[Kyle McKearney]])\n| {{nom}}\n|<ref>{{cite Manitoba]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"The_Browns","to":"The Browns"}],"pages":{"1605408":{"pageid":1605408,"ns":0,"title":"The Browns","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American country-folk vocal trio}}\n{{More footnotes|date=July 2016}}\n{{about||the NFL franchise|Cleveland Browns|other uses|Browns (disambiguation){{!}}Browns}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n|name = The Browns \n|background = group_or_band\n|image = The Browns.jpg\n|caption = Bonnie and Jim Ed (top) with Maxine in the late 1950s\n|alias = \n|origin = [[Sparkman, Arkansas]], <small>[[United States]]</small>\n|genre = [[Country music|country]], [[Folk music|folk]], [[Gospel music|gospel]], [[traditional pop]]\n|years_active = 1954&ndash;1968\n|label = [[RCA Victor]]\n|associated_acts = \n|past_members = [[Jim Ed Brown]] <br />[[Maxine Brown (country singer)|Maxine Brown]] <br />[[Bonnie Brown (musician)|Bonnie Brown]]\n}}\n\n'''The Browns''' were an American [[country music|country]] and [[folk music]] vocal trio best known for their 1959 [[Grammy]]-nominated hit, \"[[The Three Bells]]\". The group, composed of [[Jim Ed Brown]] and his sisters [[Maxine Brown (country singer)|Maxine]] and [[Bonnie Brown (musician)|Bonnie]], had a close, smooth harmony characteristic of the [[Nashville sound]], though their music also combined elements of [[folk song|folk]] and [[pop music|pop]]. They disbanded in 1967 and were elected to the [[Country Music Hall of Fame]] in March 2015.\n\n==History==\nJames Edward, older sister Maxine, and younger sister Bonnie Brown sang individually in [[Pine Bluff, Arkansas]], until 1954, when Maxine and Jim Ed signed a record contract as a singing duo. They earned national recognition and a guest spot on [[Ernest Tubb]]'s radio show for their self-penned song \"Looking Back to See\",<ref name=\"Larkin50\">{{cite book|title=The Guinness Who's Who of Fifties Music|editor=[[Colin Larkin (writer)|Colin Larkin]]|publisher=[[Guinness Publishing]]|date=1993|edition=First|isbn=0-85112-732-0|page=54}}</ref> which hit the top ten and stayed on the charts through the summer of 1954.<ref name=\"autogenerated1\">{{cite web | url = http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/browns/bio.jhtml | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20040604024139/http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/browns/bio.jhtml | url-status = dead | archive-date = June 4, 2004 | title = The Browns Biography | publisher = Country Music Television, Inc. |author1=Brennan, Sandra |author2=Manheim, James |name-list-style=amp | access-date = 2009-03-24}}</ref> The song would be a hit again nearly 20 years later for [[Buck Owens]] and [[Susan Raye]] in 1972.\n\nThey were joined in 1955 by then-recent high school graduate, 18-year-old Bonnie, and began performing on ''[[Louisiana Hayride]]'' in [[Shreveport, Louisiana]].<ref name=\"Larkin50\"/> By the end of 1955, the trio was appearing on [[KWTO (AM)|KWTO]] in [[Springfield, Missouri]], and had another top ten hit with \"Here Today and Gone Tomorrow\",<ref name=\"Larkin50\"/> which got a boost by their appearances on ABC-TV's ''[[Ozark Jubilee]]'', which Maxine Brown called \"our real breakthrough.\"<ref>{{cite book| author=Brown, Maxine| year = 2005| title=Looking Back to See: A Country Music Memoir| publisher=University of Arkansas Press| location=Fayetteville| isbn =1-55728-790-2 }}, p. 111</ref> Jim Ed and Maxine had first appeared on the show as a duo in 1955. Producer [[Si Siman]] signed them with [[RCA Victor]] in 1956, and soon they had two major hits, \"[[I Take the Chance]]\" (a cover of a [[Louvin Brothers]] composition that showed the Browns' close harmony) and \"I Heard the Bluebirds Sing\".<ref name=\"Larkin50\"/> When Jim Ed was drafted in 1957, the group continued to record while he was on leave, and sister Norma filled in for him on tours,<ref name=\"autogenerated1\"/> as did [[Billy Walker (musician)|Billy Walker]].<ref>{{cite book| author=Brown, Maxine| year = 2005| title=Looking Back to See: A Country Music Memoir| publisher=University of Arkansas Press| location=Fayetteville| isbn =1-55728-790-2 }}, p. 116</ref>\n\nIn 1959, The Browns scored their biggest hit when their folk-pop [[single (music)|single]] \"[[The Three Bells]]\"<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://digital.library.unt.edu/ark:/67531/metadc19759/m1/ |title=Show 11 - Tennessee Firebird. &#91;Part 3&#93;, Big Rock Candy Mountain. &#91;Part 1&#93; - All TracksDigital Library |access-date=2017-10-30 |archive-date=2017-07-09 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170709220959/https://digital.library.unt.edu/ark:/67531/metadc19759/m1/ |url-status=dead }}</ref> reached No. 1 on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] [[pop music|pop]] and country charts.<ref name=\"Larkin50\"/> The song also peaked at No. 10 on ''Billboard's'' Rhythm and Blues listing. Based on a song called \"{{Lang|fr|[[Les trois cloches]]|italic=no}}\", it was originally a hit in [[France]] for [[\u00c9dith Piaf]].  It was merely a coincidence that the hit rendition by the Browns chronicles the life of a character named \"Jimmy Brown\".<ref name=\"Larkin50\"/> The recording sold over one million copies,<ref name=\"The Book of Golden Discs\">{{cite book\n| first= Joseph\n| last= Murrells\n| year= 1978\n| title= The Book of Golden Discs\n| edition= 2nd\n| publisher= Barrie and Jenkins Ltd\n| location= London\n| page= [https://archive.org/details/bookofgoldendisc00murr/page/111 111]\n| isbn= 0-214-20512-6\n| url= https://archive.org/details/bookofgoldendisc00murr/page/111\n}}</ref> \"The Three Bells\" by the Browns was nominated for both Record of the Year and the Best Group or Vocal Performance in the Grammy award categories in 1959. Their version of \"[[Blue Christmas (song)|Blue Christmas]]\" reached No. 97 on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] singles chart in December 1960.<ref name=Whitburn2>{{cite book | last = Whitburn | first = Joel | title = Christmas in the Charts (1920-2004) | publisher = Record Research Inc | date=2004 | location = Wisconsin | page = 25 | isbn = 0-89820-161-6 }}</ref>\n\nThe Browns appeared on ''[[The Ed Sullivan Show]]'' and ''[[American Bandstand]]'', and followed up with \"[[Scarlet Ribbons (For Her Hair)]]\" and \"[[The Old Lamplighter]]\", recordings that also did well on both the pop and country charts.<ref name=\"Larkin50\"/> With an international following, they toured [[Europe]] extensively and saw further moderate success on the country music charts.<ref name=\"Larkin50\"/> In 1963, they joined the [[Grand Ole Opry]].<ref>{{cite web\n| title = Opry Timeline - 1960s\n| url = http://www.opry.com/about/Timeline_1960.html\n| access-date = July 6, 2012}}</ref>\n\nJim Ed began recording as a solo artist for RCA Victor in 1965,<ref name=\"Larkin50\"/> and these efforts quickly began overshadowing the trio's recordings. Maxine sang lead vocal on the group's final singles released in 1968, \"Big Daddy\" and \"I Will Bring You Water,\" with Jim Ed only supplying background vocals. The trio officially disbanded that year and Maxine signed with [[Chart Records]] in 1969, resulting in a small hit with \"Sugar Cane County\".<ref name=\"Larkin50\"/>\n\nIn the 1980s, The Browns began performing occasionally in concert for the first time in nearly 20 years. In 2006, the trio performed \"The Old Lamplighter\" and \"The Three Bells\" for the [[PBS]] special, ''Country Pop Legends''.\n\nOn June 11, 2015, Jim Ed Brown died from lung cancer at age 81.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tennessean.com/story/entertainment/music/2015/06/11/country-singer-jim-ed-brown-dies/71097224/ |title=Country singer Jim Ed Brown dies at 81|first1=Juli|last1=Thanki|first2=Cindy|last2=Watts|work=[[The Tennessean]]|date=June 12, 2015|access-date=June 19, 2015}}</ref> On July 16, 2016, Bonnie Brown also died from lung cancer at the age of 77.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tennessean.com/story/entertainment/music/2016/07/16/country-music-hall-famer-bonnie-brown-dead-77/74691904/ |title=Country Music Hall of Famer Bonnie Brown dead at 77 |website=Tennessean.com |date=2015-07-16 |access-date=2016-07-16}}</ref> Maxine Brown died on January 21, 2019, at the age of 87 from complications of heart and kidney disease.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wsmv.com/news/country-musician-maxine-brown-of-the-browns-dies-at/article_54cce3fa-1dd9-11e9-913e-f344fb787800.html|title=Country musician Maxine Brown of The Browns dies at 86|first=Joey|last=Gill|website=WSMV Nashville|access-date=22 January 2019}}</ref>\n\nThe Browns were honored with the \"Lifetime Achievement Award\" during the inaugural Arkansas Country Music Awards on June 3, 2018, alongside fellow Arkansas natives Johnny Cash, Glen Campbell, Ed Bruce, and Wayne Raney. The event was held at the Center for Performing Arts at the University of Arkansas at Little Rock.<ref>{{Cite web|date=2018-03-27|title=UA Little Rock to host first Arkansas Country Music Awards|url=https://ualr.edu/news/2018/03/27/ua-little-rock-host-first-arkansas-country-music-awards/|access-date=2020-07-23|website=News|language=en-US}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n|-\n! on Adult Contemporary charts.\n\n==Notes==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n==References==\n*{{cite web | url = http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/browns/bio.jhtml | archive-url = artists]]\n[[Category:Sibling musical trios]]\n[[Category:American vocal groups]]\n[[Category:American musical trios]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Chris_Scruggs","to":"Chris Scruggs"}],"pages":{"39046582":{"pageid":39046582,"ns":0,"title":"Chris Scruggs","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer-songwriter}}\n\n{{Use mdy dates|date=November 2014}}\n{{more footnotes needed|date=April 2013}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = Chris Scruggs\n| image           = Chris Scruggs.jpg\n| caption         = Chris Scruggs in November 2013\n| image_size      = <!-- Only for images smaller than 220 pixels -->\n| birth_name      = Christopher Alan Davies-Scruggs\n| birth_date      = {{Birth date and age|1982|12|16|mf=y}}\n| origin          =\n| instrument      = Vocals, guitar, [[steel guitar]], bass, [[mandolin]], [[fiddle]], drums\n| genre           = [[Country music|Country]], [[Folk music|folk]], [[rock and roll]]\n| occupation      = Musician, songwriter, singer\n| years_active    =\n| label           = Cogent Records\n| associated_acts = [[Michael Nesmith]], [[She & Him]], [[M. Ward]], [[BR549]], [[Gail Davies]], [[Kelly Hogan]], [[Rosie Flores]], [[Charlie Louvin]]\n| website         = {{URL|chrisscruggs.com/}}\n}}\n'''Chris Scruggs''' (born '''Christopher Alan Davies-Scruggs''' December 16, 1982) is an American singer, songwriter, and multi-instrumentalist who plays a variety of instruments including guitar, steel guitar, bass, mandolin, fiddle, and drums. He is the youngest son of songwriter [[Gary Scruggs]] and singer/songwriter and producer [[Gail Davies]]. His paternal grandfather is bluegrass banjo wizard [[Earl Scruggs]] and his maternal grandfather is the late country singer Tex Dickerson.<ref>McLain, Buzz, \"Chris Scruggs, Picking Out The High Notes\", ''Washington Post'', April 4, 2005</ref>\n\nScruggs joined the [[country rock]] band [[BR549]] in 2002 playing guitar and serving as the co-lead singer. While in the band, he wrote and performed the title track of their 2004 release, ''Tangled in the Pines''. Scruggs remained in BR549 until 2005 when he left the band to pursue a solo career. Scruggs released his first solo album, entitled ''Anthem,'' in 2009 on Cogent Records.  Scruggs produced the album and wrote 11 of the 12 songs;<ref>Wilkinson, Allan, \"Album Review: Chris Scruggs \u2013 Anthem\", Northern Sky News, September 26, 2009</ref>  [[Ron Davies (songwriter)|Ron Davies]], Scruggs's uncle (best known for having penned \"It Ain't Easy\" for [[David Bowie]]) wrote the remaining song.\n\n[[File:Chris Scruggs and Michael Nesmith.jpg|thumb|200px|left|Chris Scruggs performing with [[Michael Nesmith]] in April 2013]]\nAs a side musician, Scruggs has played behind many notable artists including [[Charlie Louvin]], [[Andrew Bird]], [[Ray Price (musician)|Ray Price]], [[Robbie Fulks]], [[Jools Holland]], [[Giant Sand]], [[Peter Noone]], [[Bobby Bare]], [[M. Ward]], [[Michael Nesmith]], [[She & Him]], Billy Walker, [[Suzy Bogguss]] and [[Marty Stuart]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.chrisscruggs.com/ |title=Home |website=chrisscruggs.com}}</ref>\n\nScruggs is, as of 2024, the bass guitarist in [[Marty Stuart]]'s Fabulous Superlatives band, taking over for Paul Martin in 2015.<ref>{{cite web|title=Marty Stuart - Band|url=http://www.martystuart.com/band-crew.htm|website=www.martystuart.com|accessdate=2 March 2017}}</ref>\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n* {{Official website|http://www.chrisscruggs.com/}}\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Scruggs, Chris}}\n[[Category:1982 births]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:Pedal steel guitarists]]\n[[Category:American country rock singers]]\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:American multi-instrumentalists]]\n[[Category:21st-century American singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:21st-century guitarists]]\n[[Category:The Fabulous Superlatives members]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Suzy_Bogguss","to":"Suzy Bogguss"}],"pages":{"538723":{"pageid":538723,"ns":0,"title":"Suzy Bogguss","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American singer-songwriter (born 1956)}}\n{{Use American English|date=June 2024}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=June 2024}}\n{{Infobox person\n| name             = Suzy Bogguss\n| image            = SuzyBogguss 2006.jpg\n| caption          = Bogguss in 2006\n| birth_name       = Susan Kay Bogguss\n| birth_date       = {{birth date and age|1956|12|30}}\n| birth_place      = [[Aledo, Illinois]], U.S.\n| alma_mater       = [[Illinois State University]] ([[Bachelor of Science|BSc]])\n| spouse           = {{marriage|Doug Crider|November 1986}}\n| children         = 1\n| occupation       = {{hlist|Musician|singer|songwriter}}\n| module           =\n{{Infobox musical artist| embed = yes  \n| genre            = {{flatlist|\n* [[Country music|Country]]\n* [[Folk music|folk]]}}\n| instrument       = {{flatlist|\n* Vocals\n* guitar\n* keyboards}}\n| years_active      = 1977&ndash;present\n| label             = {{flatlist|\n* [[Capitol Records|Capitol]]/[[EMI]]\n* [[Liberty Records|Liberty]]/[[EMI]]\n* Platinum\n* [[Compadre Records|Compadre]]\n* Loyal Dutchess\n* [[Proper Records|Proper]]}}\n| website           = {{URL|www.suzybogguss.com/}}\n}}\n}}\n\n'''Susan Kay Bogguss''' (born December 30, 1956) is an American [[country music]] singer and songwriter. She began her career in the 1980s as a solo singer. In the 1990s, six of her songs were Top 10 hits, three albums were certified gold, and one album received a platinum certification. She won Top New Female Vocalist from the [[Academy of Country Music]] and the Horizon Award from the  [[Country Music Association]].\n\n==Early life and rise to success==\nSusan Kay Bogguss<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.suzybogguss.com/bio|title=BIO|website=Suzybogguss.com|access-date=October 17, 2019}}</ref> was born on December 30, 1956, in [[Aledo, Illinois]], United States, the youngest of four born to Barbara \"B.J.\" (n\u00e9e Stewart) and Charles \"Bud\" Bogguss. Charles was an Army officer who served in the [[Pacific Ocean theatre of World War II]],<ref name=\"Bud\">{{cite web|url=http://qconline.com/archives/adl/print_display.php?id=76957|title=Obits 11-29-96|date=November 29, 1996|work=Quad-Cities Online|publisher=Moline Dispatch Publishing Company|access-date=June 3, 2013}}</ref> and later became a machinist who worked at an International Harvester plant at East Moline.<ref name=\"SOS1\"/> B.J. was a secretary-auditor for a Midwest grocery chain.<ref name=\"SOS1\"/> Her grandmothers played piano at theaters.<ref name=\"PHC2011\">{{Cite web|url=http://prairiehome.publicradio.org/features/interviews/bogguss_suzy/|title=Suzy Bogguss|date=November 23, 2011|publisher=American Public Media|work=Prairie Home Companion|access-date=May 23, 2013}}</ref> At age 5, she began singing in the Angel Choir of the College Avenue Presbyterian Church in her hometown. With her parents' encouragement, she took lessons in [[piano]] and [[drum]]s, and as a teenager picked up the [[guitar]] as well.<ref name=\"PHC2011\"/> In her youth, Bogguss would visit [[Roy Rogers]] and [[Dale Evans]] at their home in [[Apple Valley, California]], as they attended the same church as her grandparents.<ref name=\"Augusta\">{{cite web|url=http://chronicle.augusta.com/things-do/applause/2012-12-04/ramblin-rhodes-suzy-bogguss-perform-country-hits-holiday-classics|title=Ramblin' Rhodes: Suzy Bogguss to perform country hits, holiday classics|last=Rhodes|first=Don|work=The Augusta Chronicle|date=December 4, 2012|access-date=June 2, 2013}}</ref> She starred in several musicals at [[Aledo High School (Illinois)|Aledo High School]], where she was crowned homecoming queen.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.qconline.com/progress98/people/213.htm|title=Suzy goes from Aledo to stardom|last=Yadon|first=Kay|date=February 9, 1998|access-date=May 23, 2013|publisher=Moline Dispatch Publishing Company|work=Quad-Cities Online|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://archive.today/20130630044546/http://www.qconline.com/progress98/people/213.htm|archive-date=June 30, 2013}}</ref> After graduating in 1975, she enrolled at [[Illinois Wesleyan University]] in Bloomington, but later transferred to [[Illinois State University]] (ISU) in Normal. She graduated from ISU in 1980 with a [[bachelor's degree]] in [[metalsmithing]]. She would later use these skills to design her own jewelry.\n\nBogguss later recalled of her interest in music, \"Being from a small town I didn\u2019t realize that somebody had to make this stuff. I was so green. I also knew about [[Elton John]] and other big performers, but it never occurred to me that somebody like me from my small town could make a living making music.\"<ref name=\"Augusta\"/> Having sung and played guitar and drums in local [[coffeehouses]] during her college years, Bogguss embarked on a nationwide tour as a folk [[troubadour]] after graduating from ISU.<ref name=\"OS\">{{cite news|url=https://www.orlandosentinel.com/1987/08/09/luck-intuition-talent-propel-singer-suzy-bogguss-to-top/|title=Luck, Intuition, Talent Propel Singer Suzy Bogguss To Top|last=Hurst|first=Jack|date=August 9, 1987|work=[[Orlando Sentinel]]|access-date=May 31, 2013}}</ref><ref name=\"Herald-Mail\"/> At the time, she was drawn to other singers such as [[Emmylou Harris]], [[James Taylor]] and [[Bonnie Raitt]].<ref name=\"LATInterview\">{{cite news|url=https://www.latimes.com/archives/la-xpm-1999-oct-05-me-18923-story.html|title=Bogguss Steps Out on the Rebound|last=Roos|first=John|work=Los Angeles Times|date=October 5, 1999|access-date=June 1, 2013}}</ref> During this time, she produced her first independent album for Old Shack Recording: ''Suzy''. The LP was available for purchase at her shows and is now a rare collector's item. In 1984, while touring at the Huntley Lodge resort in Montana, Bogguss discovered that she spent most of her money on clothes for her later shows. She also realized that she had no health insurance, very little car insurance, and low chances of performing further, and there were no talent scouts.<ref name=\"SOS1\">{{cite news|url=https://www.chicagotribune.com/1987/07/19/secret-of-success/|title=Secret Of Success|last=Hurst|first=Jack|page=1|work=[[Chicago Tribune]]|date=July 19, 1987|access-date=May 31, 2013}}</ref><ref name=\"OS\"/>\n\nAfter moving to [[Nashville, Tennessee]], in 1985,<ref name=\"SOS1\"/><ref name=\"OS\"/><ref name=\"Herald-Mail\"/> Bogguss began working at the local [[Tony Roma's]] restaurant on her first day there.<ref name=\"WashingtonPostInterview2007\">{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/11/29/AR2007112900892.html|title=Keeping Her Options Open|last=Harrington|first=Richard|newspaper=Washington Post|date=November 30, 2007|access-date=June 2, 2013}}</ref> While there, she performed a three-day audition for entertainer [[Dolly Parton]] at Silver Dollar City, a theme park which would eventually become [[Dollywood]].<ref name=\"WashingtonPostInterview2007\"/> The following year, she became the first featured female performer at the park, playing four solo shows at the park's train station and appearing in the \"Jamboree\" show. On performing at the train station, Bogguss later recalled that \"I kept thinking, 'I'm going to get black lung disease [from the coal train in Dollywood].'\"<ref name=\"WashingtonPostInterview2007\"/> Bogguss said that performing at the park \"was the first situation where I knew that every time I introduced a song by a country artist, they knew who the artist's mom was, who his or her brothers and sisters were and who he or she was married to.\"<ref name=\"SOS2\"/> These performances prompted her to make a self-produced [[demo (music)|demo]] recording at a studio owned by folk singer [[Wendy Waldman]], who would eventually become Bogguss's first producer.<ref name=\"SOS2\">{{cite news|url=https://www.chicagotribune.com/1987/07/19/secret-of-success/|title=Secret Of Success|last=Hurst|first=Jack|page=2|work=[[Chicago Tribune]]|date=July 19, 1987|access-date=May 31, 2013}}</ref> Bogguss made several copies and sold them while performing in Dollywood.<ref name=\"SOS2\"/> At the time, she recorded a demo of \"Hopeless Romantic\", a song written by Doug Crider that would become part of her debut studio album. Crider and Bogguss met each other,<ref name=\"PPGInterview\">{{cite news|last=Sharpe|first=Jerry|title=A little bit western|date=May 28, 1993|work=[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]]|access-date=May 31, 2013|page=21|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1129&dat=19930528&id=qLFRAAAAIBAJ&pg=5606,7305207|edition=Weekend}}</ref> and eventually married in November 1986.<ref name=\"Herald-Mail\">{{cite news|url=http://articles.herald-mail.com/2000-02-02/news/25120351_1_doug-crider-suzy-bogguss-cowboy-s-sweetheart|title=Suzy Bogguss - Performing at Weinberg Center|last=Partington|first=Meg|work=Herald-Mail|date=February 2, 2000|access-date=May 31, 2013}}</ref> The demo soon caught the attention of [[Capitol Records]] president [[Jim Foglesong]], who offered her a recording contract on the Liberty/Capitol Nashville label.{{citation needed|date=March 2019}}\n\n==Liberty/Capitol recording career==\nIn 1987, Bogguss released her first three singles for Capitol, a cover of [[The Ink Spots]]' 1941 song \"I Don't Want to Set the World on Fire,\" \"Love Will Never Slip Away,\" and \"[[Come as You Were]]\". Two of these singles succeeded in making the lower reaches of the Billboard country music charts. Her debut studio album for Capitol, ''[[Somewhere Between (album)|Somewhere Between]]'' was released in March 1989. ''Somewhere Between'', with its blend of traditional and contemporary styles, drew positive reviews from critics. The album's second single, \"Cross My Broken Heart,\" became a top-20 hit on the country music charts. The same year, Bogguss won the award for Top New Female Vocalist by the [[Academy of Country Music]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://apnews.com/e55633900c6bceb10404c1c6a0b3be43|title=Winners of the 24th Annual Academy of Country Music Awards With PM-Country Awards|location=Burbank, California|work=Associated Press News|date=April 11, 1989|access-date=May 30, 2013}}</ref>\n\nFor her second album, ''[[Moment of Truth (Suzy Bogguss album)|Moment of Truth]]'', production tasks were taken over by new label-head and Nashville producer [[Jimmy Bowen]], who moved Bogguss's sound in a more polished direction. However, the album's two singles failed to rise beyond the lower reaches of the Billboard charts. A duet she recorded with [[Lee Greenwood]], \"Hopelessly Yours,\" went to No.&nbsp;12 on the country singles chart and received a [[Grammy Award]] nomination for Best Country Vocal Collaboration.{{citation needed|date=March 2019}}\n\nIn 1991 Bogguss released her third studio album, the platinum-selling ''[[Aces (Suzy Bogguss)|Aces]]''. The LP yielded four hit singles - \"[[Someday Soon (Ian Tyson song)|Someday Soon]]\", \"[[Outbound Plane]]\", \"[[Aces (song)|Aces]]\", and \"[[Letting Go (Suzy Bogguss song)|Letting Go]]\", the latter three reaching the country Top Ten. At the 1992 [[Country Music Association]] Awards Bogguss won the Horizon Award.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.chicagotribune.com/1992/10/11/bogguss-victory/|title=Bogguss Victory|last=Hurst|first=Jack|date=October 11, 1992|location=Nashville|work=[[Chicago Tribune]]|access-date=May 31, 2013}}</ref> In September of that year, Bogguss began designing women's leather apparel; the apparel was sold in stores on the West Coast.<ref name=\"PPGInterview\"/>\n\nHer 1992 follow-up, ''[[Voices in the Wind]]'', earned Bogguss her second straight gold record. The album's first single, a cover of the 1988 song \"[[Drive South]]\" by [[John Hiatt]], missed the No.&nbsp;1 spot but gave Bogguss the highest-charting hit of her career to date. Her streak continued the following year with another gold record, ''[[Something Up My Sleeve]]'', giving her two additional Top Five hits in \"[[Just Like the Weather]]\" and \"[[Hey Cinderella]]\". The latter, which she cowrote with [[Matraca Berg]] and Gary Harrison, has gone on to become one of Bogguss's [[signature song]]s. In May 1993, Bogguss appeared on the CBS television special ''The Women of Country''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.latimes.com/archives/la-xpm-1993-04-27-ca-27667-story.html|title=Morning Report - Television|last=Snow|first=Shauna|date=April 27, 1993|work=Los Angeles Times|access-date=May 30, 2013}}</ref>\n\nEventually, Bogguss became the sole producer of her sixth studio album, ''[[Simpatico (Atkins/Bogguss)|Simpatico]]''. The album consisted of duets with long-time friend and guitarist [[Chet Atkins]]. The album was released in 1994, and though it was generally well reviewed, its only single, \"One More for the Road,\" did not chart. That same year, Bogguss's ''[[Greatest Hits (Suzy Bogguss)|Greatest Hits]]'' album was released and went gold. Later, Bogguss collaborated with [[Alison Krauss]], [[Kathy Mattea]], and [[Crosby, Stills, and Nash]] to contribute \"[[Teach Your Children]]\" to the [[AIDS]] benefit compilation album [[Red Hot + Country]] produced by the [[Red Hot Organization]].\n\nUpon completing ''Simpatico'', Bogguss temporarily set her music aside to start a family. Bogguss and Crider's first child, Benton Charles Crider, was born on March 17, 1995.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://apnews.com/cbd7afd6499405460729c28196499064|title=People in the News|date=March 20, 1995|work=Associated Press News|access-date=June 1, 2013}}</ref> She also scaled down her touring dates as a result for three years.<ref name=\"Herald-Mail\"/> In May of that year, Bogguss performed at the [[White House]] with [[Kathy Mattea]] and [[Alison Krauss]]. This event later aired on [[PBS]] stations in September as ''Women of Country Music''.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://apnews.com/4a4e5e2b01bc01ffc8e3c2bbfecc65fe?SearchText=suzy%20bogguss;Display_|title=Like a Country Song, Hope Beats Out Despair|last=Knutson|first=Lawrence|date=May 17, 1995|work=Associated Press News|access-date=June 1, 2013}}</ref> In July 1996, she released her seventh studio album, entitled ''Give Me Some Wheels''. During her break, the climate of country music had changed considerably, with more pop-oriented female singers such as [[Martina McBride]], [[Faith Hill]], and [[Shania Twain]] dominating the charts. Bogguss's traditional, straightforward style failed to connect with younger listeners, and the record yielded low sales. In March 1997, Bogguss performed at the Every Woman's Challenge charity concert, which was held at the [[Palm Springs Convention Center]] in California.<ref name=\"LATInterview\"/>\n\nAfter her next album, 1998's ''[[Nobody Love, Nobody Gets Hurt]]'', also proved unsuccessful, Bogguss was dropped from Capitol. On February 18, 1999, Bogguss issued the following statement:\n\n{{cquote|I had a great tenure with Capitol, during which I weathered a lot of changes in both personnel and philosophy. From [[Jim Foglesong]] to [[Pat Quigley]] and everyone in between, I appreciate having been a part of the Capitol family. We celebrated a lot of successes together, including Grammy nominations, hit records, and platinum albums. I have a number of projects on my plate right now. This gives me the freedom to pursue those opportunities.}}\n\n==Indie label recording career==\n\nFollowing her departure from Capitol, Bogguss signed with Nashville-based fledgling label Platinum Records, headed by former Capitol executive George Collier.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/news-in-brief/1475850/bogguss-goes-platinum.jhtml|archive-url=https://archive.today/20130628214538/http://www.cmt.com/news/news-in-brief/1475850/bogguss-goes-platinum.jhtml|url-status=dead|archive-date=June 28, 2013|title=Bogguss Goes Platinum|date=May 28, 1999|publisher=CMT|access-date=May 31, 2013}}</ref> Within three months, she had released her self-titled ninth studio album, ''Suzy Bogguss''. Once again, the album was commercially unsuccessful, with her only single \"Goodnight\" making an appearance on the country charts.\n\nIn 2001, Bogguss founded her own record label, Loyal Dutchess. The label's first album, ''Live at Caff\u00e9 Milano'', documents three separate 1999 performances at the Caff\u00e9 Milano in Nashville. This release is only available for purchase at Bogguss's official website. In November 2001, she released the holiday album, ''Have Yourself a Merry Little Christmas'', a compilation of new and previously available material included through a special licensing agreement with Capitol.<ref name=\"Hartford Courant\">{{cite news|url=https://www.courant.com/2001/12/13/bogguss-fanatic-about-christmas/|title=Bogguss: Fanatic About Christmas|last=Catlin|first=Roger|date=December 13, 2001|work=Hartford Courant|access-date=June 2, 2013}}</ref> In addition to being available at her website, the album was also offered through [[Amazon.com]], select retailers, and at her live performances.\n\nIn March 2003, Bogguss and Loyal Dutchess Records signed a deal with [[Compadre Records]]. Her first release on this label was the [[Western swing]] album, ''Swing'', that she had been recording with producer [[Ray Benson]], the bandleader of Western swing group [[Asleep at the Wheel]]. Although the album saw only lukewarm sales (it reached No.&nbsp;6 on the jazz album charts, but failed to appear on the Billboard 200), it was well received by critics. Bogguss' next album, ''Sweet Danger'', was released in 2007.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1570099/suzy-bogguss-finds-herself-in-sweet-danger.jhtml|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080509115504/http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1570099/suzy-bogguss-finds-herself-in-sweet-danger.jhtml|url-status=dead|archive-date=May 9, 2008|title=Suzy Bogguss Finds Herself in Sweet Danger|last=Shelburne|first=Craig|publisher=CMT|date=September 19, 2007|access-date=May 23, 2013}}</ref> The album peaked at No.&nbsp;4 on the jazz charts. In July 2011, Bogguss released her twelfth studio album, ''American Folk Songbook''.  The album consisted of renditions of several American folk songs, such as \"[[Red River Valley]]\".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/news-in-brief/1668342/suzy-bogguss-john-hiatt-release-new-albums.jhtml|archive-url=https://archive.today/20130628214933/http://www.cmt.com/news/news-in-brief/1668342/suzy-bogguss-john-hiatt-release-new-albums.jhtml|url-status=dead|archive-date=June 28, 2013|title=Suzy Bogguss, John Hiatt Release New Albums|date=August 2, 2011|publisher=CMT|access-date=May 23, 2013}}</ref>  In addition to the CD, Bogguss and husband Doug Crider also produced a companion hard cover song book that included lyrics, sheet music, and a short history of each song.  A paperback version of the songbook became available in 2015.\n\nIn February 2014 Bogguss released ''Lucky'' a collection of songs written by Merle Haggard.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://shorefire.com/releases/entry/suzy-bogguss-recasts-merle-haggard-classics-with-lucky-feb-4|title=Suzy Bogguss Recasts Merle Haggard Classics With \"Lucky\" Feb 4|website=Shorefire.com|access-date=October 17, 2019}}</ref> To partially fund the promotion of the album she created a very successful Kickstarter crowd funding campaign which raised over $75,000 with the participation of nearly 1000 contributors.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/suzybogguss/suzy-bogguss-her-new-album-lucky|title=Suzy Bogguss: her new album, \"Lucky\"|website=Kickstarter.com|access-date=October 17, 2019}}</ref> The album was promoted through the Americana format and was well received.\n\nDuring the summer of 2016, Bogguss conducted a celebration via her Suzy Bogguss Music Facebook page, of the 25th anniversary of the release of her Platinum selling Aces Album in 1991.  Aces also was her break out album which brought her serious attention on Country Radio and secured her future on Capitol Nashville for several more albums.  On August 18, 2016, the actual 25th anniversary of the release of the original Aces album, she released a new re-imagined and rerecorded version of the album entitled ''Aces Redux''. A release party and concert was held that night at the \"3rd and Lindsley\" venue in Nashville. ''Aces Redux'' was recorded with the help of a number of the musicians that have toured with Bogguss over the years and included background vocals by friends [[Beth Nielsen Chapman]] and [[Kim Carnes]] along with several others.   The album takes a more acoustic and simpler production tack than the original which also reflects her more recent touring approach as a trio with Charlie Chadwick on standup Bass and Craig Smith on lead guitar.\n\nBogguss's 17th studio album, ''Prayin' for Sunshine'', was released on November 3, 2023. It marks the first time she is credited as a writer of all songs on one of her albums. [[MusicRow]] said the album \"captures the unvarnished essence of southern storytelling and the authentic roots of Americana music.\"<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://musicrow.com/2023/11/new-suzy-bogguss-project-prayin-for-sunshine-out-now/|title=New Suzy Bogguss Project 'Prayin' For Sunshine' Out Now|website=www.musicrow.com|date=3 November 2023 |access-date=November 6, 2023}}</ref> In a review for the lead single, \"It All Falls Down to the River\", [[American Songwriter]] called the song \"a lyrical gut-punch, shining a light on hard truths about life in the United States. From the site of Martin Luther King Jr.\u2019s assassination to the levees of New Orleans that broke during [[Hurricane Katrina]], Bogguss and [[The McCrary Sisters]] paint a powerful picture of our nation\u2019s complex past and present.\"<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.msn.com/en-us/music/news/listen-suzy-bogguss-and-the-mccrary-sisters-team-up-for-powerful-new-single-it-all-falls-down-to-the-river/ar-AA1j7jLB|title=Suzy Bogguss and the McCrary Sisters Team Up for Powerful New Single \"It All Falls Down to the River\"|website=www.americansongwriter.com|access-date=November 6, 2023}}</ref> In an album review, [[No Depression (magazine)|No Depression]] said the album \"showcases Bogguss\u2019 lyrical and musical ingenuity, her nod-and-a-wink humor, and her deep love for her community of friends and fans. And the album reminds us again just how radiant and transportive Bogguss\u2019 vocals are.\"<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nodepression.com/album-reviews/album-review-on-prayin-for-sunshine-suzy-bogguss-shines-light-on-her-songwriting/|title=On 'Prayin' for Sunshine,' Suzy Bogguss Shines Light on Her Songwriting|website=www.nodepression.com|access-date=November 6, 2023}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n{{Main|Suzy Bogguss discography}}\n\n==Awards and nominations==\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n|-\n! Illinois Rock & Roll Museum's Hall of Fame]\n|Founder's Choice\n|Suzy Bogguss\n|{{won}}\n|}\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n===Sources===\n* Bufwack, Mary A. \"Suzy Bogguss.\" In ''The Encyclopedia of Country Music.'' (1998). Paul Kinsgbury, Ed. New York: Oxford University Press. p.&nbsp;43.\n* \"Suzy Bogguss\" in ''Country Music: the encyclopedia.'' (1997). Irwin Stambler, Grelun Landon. New York: St. Martin's Press. p.&nbsp;40-41.\n\n== External links ==\n{{commons category}}\n* {{official website|https://www.suzybogguss.com}}\n\n{{CMA New Artist}}\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Bogguss, Suzy}}\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:American acoustic guitarists]]\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:American women country singers]]\n[[Category:American folk guitarists]]\n[[Category:American folk singers]]\n[[Category:American sopranos]]\n[[Category:Capitol Records artists]]\n[[Category:Fast Folk artists]]\n[[Category:Grammy Award winners]]\n[[Category:Illinois State University alumni]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from Illinois]]\n[[Category:People from Aledo, Illinois]]\n[[Category:Guitarists from Illinois]]\n[[Category:20th-century American women guitarists]]\n[[Category:20th-century American guitarists]]\n[[Category:20th-century American women singers]]\n[[Category:20th-century American singers]]\n[[Category:Country musicians from Illinois]]\n[[Category:Proper Records artists]]\n[[Category:1956 births]]\n[[Category:20th-century American singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:21st-century American women singers]]\n[[Category:21st-century American singer-songwriters]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"pages":{"1893493":{"pageid":1893493,"ns":0,"title":"Leahy","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|Canadian folk group originating from Lakefield, Ontario}}\n{{for multi|the surname|Leahy (surname)|other uses|Leahy (disambiguation)}}\n{{Infobox musical artist| <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject Musicians -->\n| name            = Leahy \n| image           = Leahy 2005.jpg \n| caption         = Leahy performing in 2005 \n| image_size      = <!-- Only for images smaller than 220 pixels --> \n| landscape       = yes\n| background      = group_or_band\n| origin          = [[Lakefield, Ontario]], Canada\n| genre           = [[Folk music|Folk]]/[[Country music|Country]]/[[Celtic music|Celtic]]\n| years_active    = 1980s&ndash;present |\n| associated_acts = {{plainlist|\n*[[Shania Twain]]\n* [[Natalie MacMaster]]\n}}\n| label           = [[Virgin Records]]\n| website             = [http://www.leahymusic.com/ www.leahymusic.com]\n| current_members = Donnell Leahy<br />Erin Leahy<br />Angus Leahy<br />Maria Leahy<br />Siobheann Donohue<br />Doug Leahy<br />Agnes Enright<br />Frank Leahy |\n| past_members    = Denise Leahy<br />Chrissie Leahy<br />Julie Leahy |\n}}\n\n'''Leahy''' is a [[Canadians|Canadian]] [[folk music]] group. The eight band members, all from the Leahy family of 11 siblings, are from [[Lakefield, Ontario]] and have been touring Canada and internationally since the early 1980s, when they were known as '''The Leahy Family'''. In 1985, they were the subject of a short film entitled ''Leahy: Music Most of All'' which received an [[Academy Awards|Academy Award]] in the category of \"Best Foreign Student Film.\"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oscars.org/awards/saa/winners/winners.pdf |title=Student Film Award Winners -- By Year |publisher=Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences |accessdate=August 22, 2010 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120229173821/http://www.oscars.org/awards/saa/winners/winners.pdf |archivedate=February 29, 2012 }}</ref>\nThe members of Leahy take significant pride in their Irish roots and Canadian upbringing.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://irishamerica.com/2006/10/leahy-staying-true-to-the-tune/ | title=Leahy: Staying True to the Tune | date=October 2006 }}</ref>\n\nThe line-up of the group varies depending upon the availability of its members, who are present or absent due to marriage, childrearing and other obligations. During the 1980s and early 1990s, the band recorded a number of privately released LPs and cassettes (most of which used the same title, ''The Leahy Family'') which were sold at their concerts and they were frequent guests at the [[Big Valley Jamboree]] concerts in [[Saskatchewan]] and [[Alberta]].\n\nIn 1997, the band resumed recording with their \"relaunch\" album, ''[[Leahy (album)|Leahy]]'' which also introduced the group's new branding. ''Leahy'' was an instrumental album, but the band also includes vocal performances in their live performances and subsequent albums have included both vocals and instrumentals.\n\nDespite their established history, they were awarded two [[Juno Awards of 1998|Juno awards in 1998]], for [[Juno Award for New Group of the Year|Best New Group]]<ref name=\"Inc.1998\">{{cite magazine|author=Larry LeBlanc|title=McLaughlin at top of Juno nominations|magazine=Billboard|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GQ8EAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA14|date=21 February 1998|publisher=Nielsen Business Media, Inc.|pages=14\u2013|issn=0006-2510}}</ref> and [[Juno Award for Instrumental Album of the Year|Best Instrumental Artist]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://junoawards.ca/database/artist-summary/?artist_name=leahy |title=(Juno Awards Database Lookup) |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110723180613/http://junoawards.ca/database/artist-summary/?artist_name=leahy |archivedate=2011-07-23 }}</ref>  The following year, Leahy took a third Juno Award, for [[Juno Award for Country Recording of the Year|Best Country Group or Duo]]. Also in 1998, Leahy were added as the opening act for Canadian country singer [[Shania Twain]]'s 1998 [[Come on Over Tour]] and were featured in two television specials from the tour, ''[[Live (Shania Twain DVD)|Live]]'' and ''[[The Specials (Shania Twain DVD)|The Specials]]'', performing with Twain on the song \"[[Don't Be Stupid (You Know I Love You)]]\".<ref>{{cite AV media notes |title=The Specials (Winter Break / Come On Over) |others=[[Shania Twain]] |year=2001 |url=https://www.amazon.com/Shania-Twain-Specials-Winter-Break/dp/product-description/B00005RIIO |at=Back Cover |type=DVD |publisher=Mercury |id=B00005RIIO |location=Nashville }}</ref>\n\nThe group's members are both instrumentalists and dancers, with several members skilled in fiddle-playing (most notably the band's most famous member, Donnell). The female members of the band often perform [[step-dancing]]-style routines and do most of the singing.\n\n==Members==\n[[File:Leahy.jpg|thumb|Leahy in concert at the Fergus Scottish Festival in 2009]]\nAll members of the band are siblings. Each member has a main role to play in the band; although most play more than one instrument and all step dance. Donnell Leahy is married to Cape Breton fiddler [[Natalie MacMaster]] and Frank is married to champion step dancer Chanda Gibson.\n\nIn 2008, Donnell Leahy and Natalie MacMaster were awarded honorary doctorate degrees by Trent University.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.trentu.ca/convocation/honorarydegree_2008leahy.php |title=Honorary Degree Recipients |publisher=Trent University |accessdate=August 22, 2010 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110609033850/http://www.trentu.ca/convocation/honorarydegree_2008leahy.php |archivedate=June 9, 2011 }}</ref>\n\n*Donnell Leahy \u2014 Fiddle\n*Erin Leahy \u2014 Piano, Guitar, Fiddle, Mandolin, Vocals, Bass\n*Angus Leahy \u2014 Fiddle\n*Maria Leahy \u2014 Guitar, Banjo, Vocals\n*Siobheann Donohue (n\u00e9e Leahy) \u2014 Bass, Vocals, Fiddle\n*Doug Leahy \u2014 Fiddle\n*Denise Flack (n\u00e9e Leahy) \u2014 Vocals\n*Frank Leahy \u2014 Drums\n\nThese three sisters are not currently active in the band's touring schedule.\n*Agnes Enright (n\u00e9e Leahy) \u2014 Keyboards, Step dancer, Vocals\n*Chrissie Quigley (n\u00e9e Leahy) \u2014 Keyboards\n*Julie Leahy \u2014 Vocals\n\n==Discography==\n\n===Albums===\n{|class=\"wikitable\"\n!rowspan=\"2\"|Year\n!rowspan=\"2\"|Album\n!colspan=\"2\"|Chart Positions\n!rowspan=\"2\"|CRIA\n|-\n!width=\"50\"|<small>CAN Country</small>\n!width=\"50\"|<small>CAN</small>\n|-\n|1996\n|''[[Leahy (album)|Leahy]]''\n|align=\"center\"|1\n|align=\"center\"|36\n|align=\"center\"|Platinum\n|-\n|2001\n|''Lakefield''\n|\n|\n|\n|-\n|2004\n|''In All Things''\n|\n|\n|\n|-\n|2006\n|''Leahy Live''\n|\n|\n|\n|-\n|2007\n|''Handmade''\n|\n|\n|\n|-\n|2021\n|''Good Water''\n|\n|\n|\n|}\n\nIn addition, the group released several vinyl LPs and cassettes in the 1980s as The Leahy Family. These self-titled releases were privately pressed and usually sold at their concerts, although ''Christmas with the Leahy Family'' was carried by retailers such as [[A&B Sound]].\n\n===Singles===\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\"|Year\n! rowspan=\"2\"|Title\n! colspan=\"2\"|Chart Positions\n! rowspan=\"2\"|Album\n|-\n! width=\"50\"|<small>CAN Country</small>\n! width=\"50\"|<small>CAN AC</small>\n|-\n| 1986\n| \"You've Got the Fiddle (I've Got the Bow)\"\n| align=\"center\"| 52\n| align=\"center\"| \n| ''On the Move''\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 1997\n| \"The Call to Dance\"\n| align=\"center\"| 26\n| align=\"center\"| 31\n| rowspan=\"2\"| ''Leahy''\n|-\n| \"B Minor\"\n| align=\"center\"| \n| align=\"center\"| \n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 2001\n| \"Down That Road\"\n| align=\"center\"| \n| align=\"center\"| \n| rowspan=\"2\"| ''Lakefield''\n|-\n| \"Mission\"\n| align=\"center\"| \n| align=\"center\"| \n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 2004\n| \"Chasing Rain\"\n| align=\"center\"| \n| align=\"center\"| \n| rowspan=\"2\"| ''In All Things''\n|-\n| \"Coyote Way\"\n| align=\"center\"| \n| align=\"center\"| \n|}\n\n===Music videos===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\"\n|-\n! Year\n! style=\"width:12em;\"| Video\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 1997\n! scope=\"row\"| \"The Call to Dance\"\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"B Minor\"\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 2001\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Down That Road\"\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Mission\"\n|-\n| 2004\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Chasing Rain\"\n|}\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n* [http://leahymusic.ca Official website]\n<!-- * [http://www.artsandlectures.ucsb.edu/pr/leahy.asp Profile] The same link is present at references -->\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n[[Category:Canadian country music groups]]\n[[Category:Canadian folk music groups]]\n[[Category:Juno Award for Breakthrough Group of the Year winners]]\n[[Category:Canadian people of Irish descent]]\n[[Category:Musical groups from Ontario]]\n[[Category:Canadian Celtic music groups]]\n[[Category:Juno Award for Instrumental Album of the Year winners]]\n[[Category:Canadian Country Music Association Group or Duo of the Year winners]]\n[[Category:Sibling musical groups]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"John_Paul_White","to":"John Paul White"}],"pages":{"31029369":{"pageid":31029369,"ns":0,"title":"John Paul White","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American musician (born 1972)}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=June 2023}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| background        = person\n| name              = John Paul White\n| image             = John Paul White - UNA (cropped).jpg\n| alt               = John Paul White in a recording studio\n| caption           = White {{circa}} 2018\n| image_size        =\n| birth_name        = John Paul White\n| birth_date        = {{birth date and age|1972|08|4}}\n| birth_place       = [[Muscle Shoals, Alabama]], U.S.\n| origin            = [[Tuscumbia, Alabama]], U.S.\n| instrument        = Vocals, guitar\n| genre             = [[Folk music|Folk]], [[Country music|country]]\n| years_active      = 2008\u2013present\n| label             = [[Single Lock Records|Single Lock]]\n| current_member_of = \n| past_member_of    = [[The Civil Wars]]\n| website           = {{URL|johnpaulwhite.com}}\n}}\n\n'''John Paul White''' (born August 4, 1972) is an American musician and former member of the [[Grammy Award]]-winning duo [[the Civil Wars]].<ref>[https://archive.today/20120731103543/http://www.gactv.com/gac/ar_artists_a-z/article/0,,gac_26071_6036481,00.html The Civil Wars Biography] Great American Country, retrieved March 2, 2012</ref> He restarted his solo career with his 2016 release, ''Beulah''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/aug/11/john-paul-white-beulah-review-spectacularly-gloomy-and-bitter|title=John Paul White: Beulah review \u2013 spectacularly gloomy and bitter|first=Alexis|last=Petridis|date=August 11, 2016|access-date=April 15, 2019|website=Theguardian.com}}</ref>\n\n==Early life==\nWhite was born in [[Muscle Shoals, Alabama]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.jambase.com/band/john-paul-white|title=John Paul White \u2013 Upcoming Shows, Tickets, Reviews, More|date=June 21, 2015|website=JamBase.com|access-date=April 15, 2019}}</ref> and grew up in [[Loretto, Tennessee]], on a chicken farm.<ref>{{Cite magazine|last=Leahey|first=Andrew|date=July 28, 2016|title=See John Paul White's Nostalgic 'What's So' Video|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/see-john-paul-whites-nostalgic-whats-so-video-112038/|access-date=August 10, 2020|magazine=Rolling Stone|language=en-US}}</ref>  He attended Sacred Heart School as well as [[Sacred Heart Catholic Church (Loretto, Tennessee)|Sacred Heart Catholic Church]] in [[Loretto, Tennessee]], as a child and graduated from Loretto High School.  He is the oldest of four children.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/502571/the-civil-wars-billboard-cover-story |title=The Civil Wars: Billboard Cover Story |publisher=Billboard |access-date=August 25, 2013}}</ref>\n\n==Career==\nWhite released his first album independently as the band Nuthin' Fancy. The album was recorded with Jeff Quillen at Rock N Roll Dawg Sound/Studio in his hometown of Loretto, Tennessee.\n\nWhite released the album ''[[The Long Goodbye (John Paul White album)|The Long Goodbye]]'' in 2008. The following year, White joined [[Joy Williams (singer)|Joy Williams]] to form [[The Civil Wars]]. The duo won the [[2012 Grammy Awards]] for Best Folk Album, and Country Performance by a Duo or Group.<ref>[http://www.grammy.com/nominees \"Joy Williams and John Paul White of Civil Wars win Grammys for 'Barton Hollow'\"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120503164723/http://www.grammy.com/nominees |date=May 3, 2012 }} Grammy.com retrieved December 2, 2012</ref>\n\nIn 2015, he contributed the song \"Kyrie\", a duet with [[Emmylou Harris]], to the album ''Mercyland: Hymns for the Rest of Us, Vol. II''.<ref>[https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/hear-emmylou-harris-and-john-paul-whites-spiritual-kyrie-20151112 \"Hear Emmylou Harris and John Paul White's Spiritual 'Kyrie'\"], ''[[Rolling Stone]]'', retrieved April 2, 2016</ref> Then in 2016, White released a solo \"Simple Song\" for the album ''Southern Family'' by [[Dave Cobb]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/therecord/2015/12/17/460056739/hear-a-new-solo-song-by-john-paul-white-of-the-civil-wars |title=Hear A New Solo Song By John Paul White, Formerly of the Civil Wars |publisher=NPR Music |access-date=December 17, 2012}}</ref>\n\nWhite is a co-owner of [[Single Lock Records]], which he founded in his hometown of Florence, Alabama, together with [[Ben Tanner]] (of the [[Alabama Shakes]]) and Florence financial consultant, Will Trapp.  The label has signed multiple artists from the Muscle Shoals area, including the legendary [[Donnie Fritts|\"Funky\" Donnie Fritts]], along with indie standouts like [[Lera Lynn]].  White often collaborates with the artists on the Single Lock label.\n\nHis album ''Beulah'' was released on August 19, 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/therecord/2016/06/09/481258114/songs-we-love-john-paul-white-the-martyr|title=Hear A Song From John Paul White's New Album, 'Beulah'|website=Npr.org|access-date=April 15, 2019}}</ref>\n\nIn 2017, White guested on the song \"It Ain't Over Yet\" with [[Rodney Crowell]] and [[Rosanne Cash]]. The track appeared on Crowell's album ''Close Ties''.\n\nIn 2018, White embarked on a house concert tour to get feedback on new material and in April 2019 released the album ''The Hurting Kind''. The album was a bit of a departure from White's Southern Rock and Americana roots, and was an intentional tribute to the country music he grew up listening to.  White co-wrote \"I Wish I Could Write You a Song\" with \"Whispering\" Bill Anderson, resulting in a distinctly Orbison feel on the track.  White toured in 2019 with several Single Lock artists, including acclaimed newcomer [[Erin Rae]].\n\nIn 2023, White and Williams individually participated in a [[Re-recording (music)|re-recording]] of \"[[Safe & Sound (Taylor Swift song)|Safe & Sound]]\" with [[Taylor Swift]], credited under their individual names.<ref>{{Cite web |last=MacCary |first=Julia |date=March 16, 2023 |title=Taylor Swift Is Dropping Four Unreleased Songs Ahead of Her Eras Tour Start |url=https://variety.com/2023/music/news/taylor-swift-unreleased-new-songs-eras-tour-1235556815/ |access-date=March 16, 2023 |website=Variety |language=en-US}}</ref>\n\n==Personal life==\nWhite lives in [[Florence, Alabama]] with his wife Jenny and their four children.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://observer.com/2017/01/john-paul-white-solo-beulah/|title=Life After the Civil Wars: The Reconstruction of John Paul White|last=Rosenschein|first=Ari|date=January 11, 2017|website=[[The New York Observer]]|access-date=September 24, 2021}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n===Solo===\n*''The Long Goodbye'' (2008) Arkam Records\n*''Beulah'' (2016) Single Lock Records\n*''The Hurting Kind'' (2019) Single Lock Records\n\n===The Civil Wars===\n{{Main|The Civil Wars discography}}\n*''[[Live at Eddie's Attic]]'' (2009)\n*''[[Poison & Wine]]'' (EP) (2009)\n*''[[Barton Hollow]]'' (2011)<ref name=\"thecivilwars.com\">{{cite web|url=http://www.thecivilwars.com |title=The Civil Wars |publisher=The Civil Wars |access-date=October 9, 2011}}</ref>\n*''[[Unplugged On VH1]]'' (2013)\n*''[[The Civil Wars (album)|The Civil Wars]]'' (2013)\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n{{Commons category|John Paul White}}\n\n{{Grammy Award for Best Song Written for Visual Media}}\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:White, John Paul}}\n[[Category:1972 births]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:People from Muscle Shoals, Alabama]]\n[[Category:Grammy Award Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Nora_O'Connor","to":"Nora O'Connor"}],"pages":{"5432652":{"pageid":5432652,"ns":0,"title":"Nora O'Connor","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American, Chicago-based musician (born 1968)}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n|name                              = Nora O'Connor\n|image                             = Nora_O'Connor_performing_on_2018-10-30_at_the_Hideout_in_Chicago_IL.jpg\n|caption                           = O'Connor performing at [[The Hideout Inn|The Hideout]] on October 30, 2017\n|background                        = solo_singer\n|birth_name                        = Nora O'Connor\n|alias                             = Nora O'Connor Kean\n|birth_date                        = {{birth date and age|1968|4|2}}\n|origin                            = [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]], U.S.\n|genre                             = [[Folk music|Folk]], [[Country music|Country]]\n|occupation                        = [[Musician]]\n|years_active                      = 1994\u2013present\n|instrument                        = [[Singing|Vocals]], [[Guitar]]\n|associated_acts                   = [[The Blacks (band)|The Blacks]], [[The Decemberists]], [[Robbie Fulks]], [[Andrew Bird]], [[Kelly Hogan]], The Flat Five\n|label                             = [[Bloodshot Records]]\n}}\n\n'''Nora O\u2019Connor''' (born April 2, 1968) is an American, Chicago-based musician. Though primarily known for her vocals, O'Connor also plays guitar and bass. For much of 2013, O'Connor toured internationally as a singer in [[Iron and Wine]].<ref name=iron/> She also records and performs with longtime collaborator, [[Andrew Bird]].<ref name=chicagomag/> O'Connor plays bass and sings back-up for [[Kelly Hogan]] (supporting Hogan's release \"I Like To Keep Myself In Pain\" on [[ANTI- Records]])<ref name=anti/> and in 2010, [[Wilco]]'s [[Jeff Tweedy]] enlisted O'Connor and Hogan as primary vocalists on gospel legend [[Mavis Staples]]\u2019 Grammy Award-winning album ''[[You Are Not Alone (Mavis Staples album)|You Are Not Alone]]''.<ref name=chicagomag/> In the studio and on the stage, O'Connor has backed (among others) [[Neko Case]],<ref name=Neko/> [[Jakob Dylan]],<ref name=billboard/> [[The New Pornographers]],<ref name=billboard/> [[The Decemberists]],<ref name=Decemberists/> [[Archer Prewitt]],<ref name=billboard/> [[John Wesley Harding (singer)|John Wesley Harding]],<ref name=billboard/> [[Hushdrops]],<ref name=Hushdrops/> [[Justin Roberts (musician)|Justin Roberts]]<ref name=Justin/> and [[Robbie Fulks]].<ref name=trib/><ref name=chicago.gov/><ref name=timeout/>\n\nO'Connor has released two solo CDs.  The first, ''Cerulean Blue'', was released by Uncommon Ground Coffeehouse in Chicago in 1996.  The second, ''Til the dawn'', was released by [[Bloodshot Records]] on August 24, 2004. NOTE: In 2022 Nora announced: \"My new album 'My Heart' comes out October 7, 2022 on Pravda Records.\"\n\nIn the mid-1990s, she formed the Nora O'Connor Band, with herself on lead vocals and guitar, Lisa Wertman Crowe on bass and vocals, Tony Ventura on guitar and Mark Cameron on drums.\n\nO'Connor has two sons, and lives in [[Evanston, Illinois]].\n\n== Other collaborative projects ==\n* '''[[The Blacks (band)|The Blacks]]''': Five-piece [[insurgent country]] band (1993\u20132000)\n* '''[[The Decemberists (band)|The Decemberists]]''', touring band: backing vocals, guitar\u00a0(2014\u2013present)\n''See also [[Kelly Hogan#Other projects|Kelly Hogan\u00a7#Other projects]]''.\n\n== Partial discography ==\n\n=== Solo ===\n*''Cerulean Blue'' (1996, Uncommon Ground)\n*''Til the Dawn'' (2004, [[Bloodshot Records]])\n*''My Heart'' (October 2022, Pravda Records)\n\n=== The Blacks ===\n*''Dolly Horrorshow'' (1998, Bloodshot Records)\n*''Just Like Home'' ANTI-)\n*''Tomorrow'' \u2013 [[Hushdrops]]\n*''Me, Myself and Wine'' \u2013 Lady Parts (2015, Bloodshot Records)\n\n== References ==\n{{Reflist|refs=\n<ref name=anti>{{cite web\n| title       = Kelly     = Feb 6, 2014\n| website     = [[Chicago Tribune]]\n| url         = https://www.chicagotribune.com/entertainment/ct-nora-oconnor-hideout-chicago-20140206-story.html\n| accessdate  = Mar 25, <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Sean_McConnell","to":"Sean McConnell"}],"pages":{"51880506":{"pageid":51880506,"ns":0,"title":"Sean McConnell","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer-songwriter}}\n\n{{Use mdy dates|date=January 2019}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = Sean McConnell\n| image           =\n| alt             =\n| caption         =\n| image_size      =\n| landscape       =\n| birth_name      =\n| alias           =\n| birth_date      =\n| birth_place     =\n| origin          = [[Athol, Massachusetts]]\n| genre           = {{hlist|[[Country music|Country]]|[[folk music|folk]]|[[American folk music|roots music]]}}\n| occupation      = Singer-songwriter\n| instrument      = {{hlist|Vocals|guitar}}\n| years_active    = 2000\u2013present\n| label           = [[Rounder Records|Rounder]]\n| associated_acts = [[Wade Bowen]]\n| website         = \n}}\n\n'''Sean McConnell''' is an American [[folk music|folk]] and [[country music|country]] singer-songwriter.\n\n==Biography==\nMcConnell was born in [[Athol, Massachusetts]] to two folk singers who played in local venues in the [[Boston]] area. His family moved to [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] when he was eleven years old, and while there he began playing guitar and writing his own songs.
