Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"June_Carter_Cash","to":"June Carter Cash"}],"pages":{"227681":{"pageid":227681,"ns":0,"title":"June Carter Cash","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer (1929\u20132003)}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=February 2024}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = June Carter Cash\n| image           = JuneCarterAtGrandOleOpry1999.jpg\n| caption         = Carter in July 1999\n| birth_name      = Valerie June Carter\n| birth_date      = {{birth date|1929|06|23}}\n| birth_place     = [[Maces Spring, Virginia]], U.S.\n| death_date      = {{death date and age|2003|05|15|1929|06|23}}\n| death_place     = [[Nashville, Tennessee]], U.S.\n| occupation      = {{flatlist|\n* Singer\n* songwriter\n* actress\n}}\n| instrument      = {{flatlist|\n* Vocals\n* guitar\n* banjo\n* harmonica\n* autoharp\n* piano\n}}\n| genre           = {{flatlist|\n* [[Country music|Country]]\n* [[Folk music|folk]]\n* [[Americana (music)|Americana]]\n* [[Gospel music|gospel]]\n* [[Appalachian music|Appalachian]]\n* [[country folk]]\n* [[rockabilly]]\n}}\n| years_active    = 1939\u20132003\n| label           = {{flatlist|\n* [[American Recordings (record label)|American]]\n* [[House of Cash]]\n* [[Decca Records|Decca]]\n* [[Legacy Recordings|Legacy]]\n}}\n}}\n\n'''Valerie June Carter Cash''' (June 23, 1929&nbsp;\u2013 May 15, 2003<ref>{{Citation | date = March 2007 | url = http://rootdig.com/2007/03/1930-census-june-carter-cash.html | title = Root dig | contribution = June Carter Cash in the 1930 US Census | access-date = August 24, 2008 | archive-date = September 21, 2013 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20130921053709/http://rootdig.com/2007/03/1930-census-june-carter-cash.html | url-status = dead }}</ref>) was an American [[Country music|country]] singer and songwriter. A five-time [[Grammy]] award-winner, she was a member of the [[Carter Family]] and the second wife of singer [[Johnny Cash]]. Prior to her marriage to Cash, she was known as '''June Carter''' and continued to be credited as such even after her marriage (as well as on songwriting credits predating it). She played guitar, [[banjo]], harmonica, and [[autoharp]], and acted in several films and television shows. Carter Cash was inducted into the Christian Music Hall of Fame in 2009.<ref>{{cite web| year = 2009 | title = Awards|url= http://hallmuseum.com/9awards.htm | publisher= Christian Music Hall of Fame and Museum | access-date = April 15, 2013 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120515174455/http://hallmuseum.com/9awards.htm|archive-date = May 15, 2012}}</ref>\n\n==Early life==\nJune Carter Cash was born Valerie June Carter in [[Maces Spring, Virginia]], to [[Maybelle Carter|Maybelle]] (n\u00e9e Addington) and [[Ezra Carter]]. Her mother was a country music performer with June's aunt Sara and uncle [[A. P. Carter]] and she performed with the Carter Family from the age of 10, in 1939. In March 1943, when the Carter Family trio stopped recording together at the end of the [[WBT (AM)|WBT]] contract, Maybelle Carter, with encouragement from her husband Ezra, formed \"The Carter Sisters and Mother Maybelle\" with her daughters, Helen on accordion, Anita Carter on bass fiddle and June on autoharp and as front person and comedian. The new group first aired on radio station [[WRNL]] in [[Richmond, Virginia]], on June 1. Doc (Addington) and Carl (McConnell)\u2014Maybelle's brother and cousin, respectively, known as \"The Virginia Boys\", joined them in late 1945. June, then 16, was a co-announcer with Ken Allyn and did the commercials on the radio shows for Red Star Flour, Martha White, and [[Thalhimers|Thalhimers Department Store]], just to name a few.<ref name=\"JUNE CARTER CASH BIOGRAPHY\">{{Citation | url = http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/cash_june_carter/bio.jhtml | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20040106040953/http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/cash_june_carter/bio.jhtml | url-status = dead | archive-date = January 6, 2004 | title = Artists | contribution = June Carter Cash | type = biography | publisher = CMT}}</ref> For the next year {1946}, the Carters and Doc and Carl did show dates within driving range of Richmond, through [[Virginia]], [[Maryland]], [[Delaware]], and [[Pennsylvania]]. She attended [[John Marshall High School (Richmond, Virginia)|John Marshall High School]] during this period.<ref>{{cite web | title = Walk the line, drive the road | url = http://www.virginia.org/WalktheLineDrivetheRoad/ | publisher = Virginia | access-date = May 28, 2012 | archive-date = September 12, 2015 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150912115216/http://www.virginia.org/walkthelinedrivetheroad/ | url-status = dead }}</ref> June later said she had to work harder at her music than her sisters, but she had her own special talent \u2014comedy.<ref>{{Citation | last = Bufwack | first = Mary | year = 1998 | contribution = Carter Sisters | title = The Encyclopedia of Country Music | editor-first = Paul | editor-last = Kingsbury | place = New York | publisher = Oxford University Press | page = 85}}</ref> A highlight of the road shows was her \"Aunt Polly\" comedy routine. With her thin and lanky frame, June Carter often played a comedic foil during the group's performances alongside other Opry stars [[Faron Young]] and [[Webb Pierce]]. Carl McConnell wrote in his memoirs that June was \"a natural-born clown, if there ever was one\". Decades later, Carter revived Aunt Polly for the 1976 TV series ''Johnny Cash & Friends''.\n\nAfter Doc and Carl dropped out of the music business in late 1946, Maybelle and her daughters moved to [[Sunshine Sue|Sunshine Sue Workman's]] \"Old Dominion Barn Dance\" on the [[WRVA (AM)|WRVA]] Richmond station. After a while there, they moved to [[WNOX]] in [[Knoxville, Tennessee]], where they met [[Chet Atkins]] with Homer and Jethro.\n\nIn 1949, the Carter Sisters and Mother Maybelle, with their lead guitarist, Atkins, were living in [[Springfield, Missouri]], and performing regularly at [[KWTO (AM)|KWTO]]. Ezra \"Eck\" Carter, Maybelle's husband and manager of the group, declined numerous offers from the [[Grand Ole Opry]] to move the act to [[Nashville, Tennessee]], because the Opry would not permit Atkins to accompany the group onstage. Atkins' reputation as a guitar player had begun to spread, and studio musicians were fearful that he would displace them as a 'first-call' player if he came to Nashville. Finally, in 1950, Opry management relented and the group, along with Atkins, became part of the Opry company. Here the family befriended [[Hank Williams]] and [[Elvis Presley]] (to whom they were distantly related), and June met Johnny Cash.\n\nCarter and her sisters, with their mother Maybelle and aunt Sara joining in from time to time, reclaimed the name \"The Carter Family\" for their act during the 1960s and 1970s.\n\n==Career highlights==\n[[File:President Richard Nixon, Pat Nixon, June Carter Cash, and Johnny Cash.jpg|thumb|Cash with husband [[Johnny Cash|Johnny]], President [[Richard Nixon]] and First Lady [[Pat Nixon]] on April 17, 1970.]]\nWhile Carter may be best known for singing and songwriting, she was also an author, dancer, actress, comedian, philanthropist, and humanitarian.<ref>{{Citation|url=http://johnnycash.com/june/june2.html |contribution=June |title=Johnny Cash.com |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080813152000/http://www.johnnycash.com/june/june2.html |archive-date=August 13, 2008 }}</ref> Director [[Elia Kazan]] saw her perform at the Grand Ole Opry in 1955 and encouraged her to study acting. She studied with [[Lee Strasberg]] and [[Sanford Meisner]] at the [[Neighborhood Playhouse School of the Theatre]] in New York. Her acting roles included Mrs. \"Momma\" Dewey in [[Robert Duvall]]'s 1998 movie ''[[The Apostle]]'', Sister Ruth, wife to Johnny Cash's character Kid Cole, on ''[[Dr. Quinn, Medicine Woman]]'' (1993\u201397), and Clarise on ''[[Gunsmoke]]'' in 1957. She was notable as [[Mayhayley Lancaster]] playing alongside husband Cash in the [[1983 in film|1983]] [[television movie]] ''[[Murder in Coweta County]]''. June was also Momma James in ''[[The Last Days of Frank and Jesse James]]''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://lapostexaminer.com/jesse-james-part-2-dad-especially-mom/2014/08/05 |title=Jesse James: Dad and especially mom (Part 2) |first=Stephen |last=Goode |date=August 5, 2014 |access-date=February 7, 2019 |work=Los Angeles Post-Examiner}}</ref> She also acted in occasional comedy skits for various Johnny Cash TV programs.\n\nAs a singer, she had both a solo career and a career singing with first her family and later her husband. As a solo artist, she became somewhat successful with upbeat country tunes of the 1950s, such as \"Jukebox Blues\" and the comedic hit \"No Swallerin' Place\" by Frank Loesser. Carter also recorded \"The Heel\" in the 1960s along with many other songs.\n\nIn the early 1960s, Carter wrote the song \"[[Ring of Fire (song)|Ring of Fire]]\", which later went on to be a hit for her future husband, Johnny Cash. She co-wrote the song with fellow songwriter [[Merle Kilgore]]. Carter wrote the lyrics about her relationship with Cash and she offered the song to her sister, [[Anita Carter]], who was the first singer to record the song. In 1963, Cash recorded the song with the Carter Family singing backup and added mariachi horns. The song became a number-one hit and went on to become one of the most recognizable songs in the world of country music.\nIn her autobiography, ''I Walked the Line'', Cash's first wife [[Vivian Cash]] disputes the myth that Carter co-wrote the song \"[[Ring of Fire (song)|Ring of Fire]]\". Vivian relates the story that Cash told her in 1963: he wrote the song with Kilgore and Curly Lewis while fishing and he was going to give Carter half credit because \"She needs the money. And I feel sorry for her.\"<ref>{{cite book |last1=Cash, with Ann Sharpsteen |first1=Vivian |title=I Walked the Line: My Life with Johnny |date=2007 |publisher=Scribner |page=338}}</ref>\n\nCarter's first notable studio performance with Johnny Cash occurred in 1964 when she duetted with Cash on \"[[It Ain't Me Babe]]\", a [[Bob Dylan]] composition, that was released as a single and on Cash's album ''[[Orange Blossom Special (album)|Orange Blossom Special]]''. In 1967, the two found more substantial success with their recording of \"[[Jackson (Johnny Cash and June Carter song)|Jackson]]\", which was followed by a collaboration album, ''[[Carryin' On with Johnny Cash and June Carter]]''. All these releases predated her marriage to Cash, after which she changed her professional name to June Carter Cash. She continued to work with Cash on recordings and on stage for the rest of her life, recording a number of duets with Cash for his various albums and being a regular on ''[[The Johnny Cash Show]]'' from 1969 to 1971 and on Cash's annual Christmas specials. After ''Carryin' On'', Carter recorded one more direct collaboration album, ''[[Johnny Cash and His Woman]]'', released in 1973, and, along with her daughters, was a featured vocalist on Cash's 1974 album ''[[The Junkie and the Juicehead Minus Me]]''. She also shared sleeve credit with her husband on a 2000 small-label gospel release, ''[[Return to the Promised Land]].''\n\nAlthough she provided vocals on many recordings and shared the billing with Cash on several album releases, June Carter Cash only recorded three solo albums during her lifetime: the first, ''[[Appalachian Pride]]'', released in 1975, ''[[Press On (June Carter Cash album)|Press On]]'' (1999), and ''[[Wildwood Flower (album)|Wildwood Flower]]'', released posthumously in 2003 and produced by her son, [[John Carter Cash]]. ''Appalachian Pride'' is the only one of the three on which Johnny Cash does not perform, while ''Press On'' is notable for featuring Carter singing her original arrangement of \"Ring of Fire\".\n\nOne of her final appearances was a non-speaking/non-singing appearance in the music video for her husband's 2003 single, \"[[Hurt (Nine Inch Nails song)|Hurt]]\", filmed a few months before her death. One of her last known public appearances was on April 7, 2003, just over a month before her death, when she appeared on the [[CMT (U.S. TV channel)|CMT Flameworthy]] awards program to accept an achievement award on behalf of her husband, who was too ill to attend.\n\nShe won a Grammy award in 1999 for, ''Press On''. Her last album, ''Wildwood Flower'', won two additional Grammys. It contains bonus video enhancements showing extracts from the film of the recording sessions, which took place at the Carter Family estate in [[Hiltons, Virginia]], on September 18\u201320, 2002. The songs on the album include \"Big Yellow Peaches\", \"Sinking in the Lonesome Sea\", \"Temptation\", and the trademark staple \"[[Wildwood Flower]]\". Due to her involvement in providing backing vocals on many of her husband's recordings, a further posthumous release occurred in 2014, when ''[[Out Among the Stars]]'' was released under Johnny Cash's name. The album consists of previously unreleased recordings from the early 1980s, including two on which June Carter Cash provides duet vocals.\n\nHer autobiography was published in 1979, and she wrote a memoir, ''From the Heart'', almost 10 years later.<ref name = \"mtv\" />\n\n==Personal life==\n[[File:JohnnyCashJuneCarterCash1969.jpg|thumb|Johnny Cash and June Carter Cash in 1969]]\nCarter was married three times and had one child with each husband. All three of her children went on to have successful careers in country music. She was married first to [[Country music|country]] singer [[Carl Smith (country musician)|Carl Smith]] from July 9, 1952, until their divorce in 1956. Together, they wrote \"Time's A-Wastin\". They had a daughter, Rebecca Carlene Smith, known professionally as [[Carlene Carter]], a country musician.<ref name = \"Johnny Cash and June Carter Cash Marriage Profile\">{{Citation | url = http://marriage.about.com/od/entertainmen1/p/johncash.htm | contribution = Johnny Cash and June Carter Cash | title = Marriage | type = profile | publisher = About | access-date = May 28, 2012 | archive-date = April 12, 2008 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20080412081323/http://marriage.about.com/od/entertainmen1/p/johncash.htm | url-status = dead }}</ref> Carter's second marriage was to Edwin \"Rip\" Nix, a former football player and police officer, on November 11, 1957. They had a daughter, [[Rosie Nix Adams]], on July 13, 1958, who became a country/rock singer. The couple divorced in 1966. Their daughter died in 2003, at the age of 45, from accidental [[carbon monoxide poisoning]] in a [[school bus]] that had been [[Conversion van|converted into a campervan]].<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20150203044749/http://www.cmt.com/news/1479995/june-carter-cash-daughters-death-ruled-accidental/ \"June Carter Cash Daughter's Death Ruled Accidental\"] (October 28, 2003). ''[[CMT (U.S. TV channel)|CMT]].com''. Retrieved September 1, 2019.</ref>\n\nCarter and the entire Carter Family had performed with Johnny Cash for a number of years. In 1968, Cash proposed to Carter during a live performance at the [[London Ice House]] in [[London, Ontario]]. They married on March 1 in [[Franklin, Kentucky]].<ref name=\"mtv\"/> They had one son, [[John Carter Cash]], who is a musician, songwriter, and producer. The couple remained married until her death in May 2003, four months before Cash died.\n\nShe also gained four stepdaughters from her third husband's previous marriage to [[Vivian Cash|Vivian Liberto]], including [[Cindy Cash|Cindy]] and [[Rosanne Cash|Rosanne]].\n\nCarter's distant cousin, the 39th U.S. president [[Jimmy Carter]], became closely acquainted with Cash and Carter and maintained their friendship throughout their lifetimes. In a June 1977 speech, Jimmy Carter acknowledged that June Carter was his distant cousin.{{Sfn | Carter | 1978 | p = 1115 (Conference on HIRE, June 14)}}\n\nCarter was a longtime supporter of [[SOS Children's Villages]]. In 1974, the Cashes donated money to help build a village near their home in Barrett Town, Jamaica, which they visited frequently, playing the guitar and singing songs to the children in the village.<ref name=\"sos\">{{cite web|url=http://sos-childrensvillages.org/get-involved/celebrities-as-partners/pages/johnny-cash.aspx |publisher=SOS Children's Villages |work=Spotlight on |title=Johnny Cash |year=2006 |access-date=August 6, 2008 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080518093650/http://www.sos-childrensvillages.org/Get-involved/Celebrities-as-partners/Pages/Johnny-Cash.aspx |archive-date=May 18, 2008 }}</ref>\n\nCarter also had close relationships with a number of entertainers, including [[Audrey Williams]], [[James Dean]], [[Patsy Cline]],<ref name=\"Writer\">{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/local/obituaries/la-me-june-carter-cash-20030516-20160515-snap-story.html|title=From the Archives: June Carter Cash, 73; Lifelong Star of Country Music|first=Geoff|last=Boucher|website=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=May 16, 2003|access-date=January 26, 2018}}</ref> [[Loretta Lynn]],<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=11159719|title=Son Pays Loving Tribute to June Carter Cash|work=NPR.org|access-date=January 26, 2018|language=en}}</ref> [[Jessi Colter]], [[Kris Kristofferson]], [[Willie Nelson]], [[Elvis Presley]],<ref name=\"Writer\"/> [[Robert Duvall]], and [[Roy Orbison]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://royorbison.com/photo-of-roy-orbison-johnny-cash-june-carter-cash/|title=Photo of Roy Orbison, Johnny Cash, & June Carter Cash|website=royorbison.com|language=en-US|access-date=January 26, 2018}}</ref>\n\nAt the end of her life, she and her husband attended the First [[Baptist Church]] in [[Hendersonville, Tennessee]].<ref> Timothy Cockes, [https://www.baptistpress.com/resource-library/news/johnny-cash-documentary-tells-faith-journey-of-man-in-black/ Johnny Cash documentary tells faith journey of Man in Black], baptistpress.com, USA, December 1, 2022 </ref>\n\n===Death===\nIn April 2003, Carter was diagnosed with a [[Valvular heart disease|leaky heart valve]], and doctors told her that valve replacement surgery was the only solution for her issue.<ref>{{Citation |title=Tragic Details About Johnny Cash | date=August 3, 2019 |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wtTIV73J0tM |access-date=August 15, 2023 |language=en}}</ref> She had the surgery on May 7; however, complications arose, and her health deteriorated rapidly over the next few days. She died on May 15, 2003, at the age of 73. She was surrounded by her family, including her husband of 35 years, Johnny Cash.<ref name=\"mtv\">Downey, Ryan J. [http://mtv.com/news/articles/1471909/20030515/cash_june_carter.jhtml ''Country Star June Smith First Wife Carl Smith 73.'' MTV.com. 2003-05-15.] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101209023740/http://mtv.com/news/articles/1471909/20030515/cash_june_carter.jhtml |date=December 9, 2010 }}</ref> Public funeral services were held at the First Baptist Church in [[Hendersonville, Tennessee]].<ref> Billboard, [https://www.billboard.com/music/music-news/stars-mourn-june-carter-cash-71010/ Stars Mourn June Carter Cash], billboard.com, USA, May 19, 2003 </ref> At Carter's funeral, her stepdaughter [[Rosanne Cash]] stated, \"If being a wife were a corporation, June would have been a CEO. It was her most treasured role.\"<ref>{{cite web |url=http://capitalnews.com.au/editorial.asp?editorial_id=313&issue=44 |title=COUNTRY MUSIC - Capital News |access-date=August 24, 2008 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080724001216/http://www.capitalnews.com.au/editorial.asp?editorial_id=313&issue=44 |archive-date=July 24, 2008  }}</ref> Johnny Cash died of complications from diabetes on September 12. Carter's daughter [[Rosie Nix Adams]] died on October 24. All three are buried at the [[Hendersonville Memory Gardens]] near their home in [[Hendersonville, Tennessee]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/2003/09/15/cash-buried-near-nashville.html|title=Cash Buried Near Nashville|date=September 15, 2003|work=Fox News|access-date=January 24, 2018|language=en-US}}</ref>\n\n==Awards==\nCarter and her then-future husband, Johnny Cash, reached number&nbsp;2 on the [[Hot Country Songs|U.S. Country]] charts with their 1967 duet of \"[[Jackson (song)|Jackson]]\". Their performance won the [[10th Grammy Awards#Country|1968 Grammy Award]] for Best Country & Western Performance Duet, Trio or Group. The two won the [[13th Grammy Awards#Country|1971 Grammy Award]], for [[Grammy Award for Best Country Performance by a Duo or Group with Vocal#1970s|Best Country Vocal Performance by a Duo or Group]], for their 1970 duet \"[[If I Were a Carpenter (song)|If I Were a Carpenter]]\".\n\nCarter Cash won the [[42nd Grammy Awards#Folk|2000 Grammy Award]], for [[Grammy Award for Best Traditional Folk Album#2000s|Best Traditional Folk Album]], for her 1999 album ''Press On''. The album was a top-15 success on the Americana chart. Carter Cash's last album, ''Wildwood Flower'', was released posthumously in 2003. Carter Cash won the [[46th Grammy Awards#Folk|2004 Grammy Award]] for [[Grammy Award for Best Traditional Folk Album#2000s|Best Traditional Folk Album]], and she also won the [[46th Grammy Awards#Country|2004 Grammy Award]] for [[Grammy Award for Best Female Country Vocal Performance|Best Female Country Vocal Performance]] for the single \"[[Keep on the Sunny Side]]\".<ref name=\"JUNE CARTER CASH BIOGRAPHY\" />\n\n== Philanthropy ==\nCarter Cash, along with her husband, [[Johnny Cash]], worked with and gave money to the group, [[SOS Children's Villages]], throughout their lives. They began this involvement in 1973 when they donated $12,000 ($75,351 in 2022 terms) to build an orphanage in a Jamaican village close to their home in that country.<ref>{{Cite magazine|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/69076/cash-family-support-boosts-childrens-charity|title=Cash Family Support Boosts Children's Charity|magazine=Billboard|access-date=June 22, 2017}}</ref> They would visit the nearby village during their time spent in Jamaica and play with the children and sing songs to them. When Cash died in 2003, their family asked that donations be made to the SOS Children's Villages due to the couple's involvement.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sos-childrensvillages.org/publications/news/the-family-of-johnny-cash-ask-for-donations-for-so|title=The family of Johnny Cash ask for donations for SOS Children's Villages - SOS Children's Villages International|website=www.sos-childrensvillages.org|access-date=June 22, 2017}}</ref> In a quote from a representative of the Prime Minister of Jamaica at the time, [[P. J. Patterson|P.J. Patterson]], talks about their charitable works in the country, \"A philanthropist extraordinaire, Mrs. Cash made Jamaica her second home and loved and cared deeply for the people of her adopted country. A gifted and talented singer, she and her husband, Johnny Cash, used the very talents for the benefit of many charities in and around Montego Bay.\"\n\n==Legacy==\nIn 2003, Carter was included by [[Country Music Television]] on their list of the \"40 Greatest Women of Country Music\".<ref>{{Cite web|last=Staff August 28, 2002|first=CMT com|title=40 Greatest Women Announced|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/1457238/40-greatest-women-announced/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305012222/http://www.cmt.com/news/1457238/40-greatest-women-announced/|url-status=dead|archive-date=March 5, 2016|access-date=October 4, 2020|website=CMT News}}</ref>\n\nCarter was played by [[Reese Witherspoon]] in ''[[Walk the Line]]'', a 2005 biographical film of Johnny Cash (played by [[Joaquin Phoenix]]). The film largely focused on the development of their relationship over the course of 13 years, from their first meeting to her final acceptance of his proposal of marriage. Witherspoon performed all vocals for the role, singing many of Carter's famous songs, including \"[[Juke Box Blues]]\" and \"Jackson\" with Phoenix.<ref>{{Citation | url = http://oregonherald.com/reviews/mark-sells/reviews/walktheline.html | title = The Reel Deal | newspaper = Oregon Herald | date = December 2005 | access-date = March 23, 2007 | url-status = dead | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20061025231811/http://www.oregonherald.com/reviews/mark-sells/reviews/walktheline.html | archive-date = October 25, 2006 | df = mdy-all }}</ref> Witherspoon won an [[Academy Award for Best Actress|Academy Award]], [[Golden Globe Award for Best Actress \u2013 Motion Picture Comedy or Musical|Golden Globe]], [[BAFTA Award for Best Actress in a Leading Role|BAFTA]] and [[Screen Actors Guild Award for Outstanding Performance by a Female Actor in a Leading Role|Screen Actors Guild Award]] for Best Actress in the role.<ref>{{cite web |title=Awards for Walk the Line|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0358273/awards|publisher= IMDb}}</ref>\n\nMusician and actress [[Jewel (singer)|Jewel]] portrayed Carter in the [[Lifetime (TV network)|Lifetime]] television movie ''[[Ring of Fire (2013 film)|Ring of Fire]]'', which aired on May 27, 2013. The film is based on John Carter Cash's memoir ''Anchored in Love: An Intimate Portrait of June Carter Cash.''<ref>{{cite web|title = Jewel Will Play June Carter Cash in TV Movie|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20592960,00.html | publisher =People |date=May 6, 2012|access-date=May 28, 2012}}</ref>\n\nCarter was played by Erin Beute in the 2019 television movie ''[[Patsy & Loretta]]''.<ref>{{Cite web |title=TV Insider |url=https://www.tvinsider.com/819719/patsy-loretta-lifetime-megan-hilty-jessie-mueller/ |access-date=January 20, 2024 |website=TV Insider|date=October 14, 2019 }}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Year\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Album\n! colspan=\"2\"| Chart Positions\n|-\n! style=\"width:60px;\"| <small>[[Top Bluegrass Albums|US Bluegrass]]</small>\n! style=\"width:60px;\"| <small>[[Top Country Albums|US Country]]</small>\n|-\n| 1975\n| ''[[Appalachian Pride]]''\n| style=\"text-align:center;\"| \u2014\n| style=\"text-align:center;\"| \u2014\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 1999\n| ''[[Press On (June Carter Cash album)|Press On]]''\n| style=\"text-align:center;\"| \u2014\n| style=\"text-align:center;\"| \u2014\n|-\n| ''It's All in the Family''\n| style=\"text-align:center;\"| \u2014\n| style=\"text-align:center;\"| \u2014\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 2003\n| ''[[Wildwood Flower (album)|Wildwood Flower]]''\n| style=\"text-align:center;\"| 2\n| style=\"text-align:center;\"| 33\n|-\n|}\n\n===Albums with Johnny Cash===\n: ''Note: this list only lists albums on which June Carter Cash received co-billing. Most 1970s and 1980s album releases by Cash featured at least one duet with her, and/or she provided backing vocals.''\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Year\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Album\n! colspan=\"2\"| Chart Positions\n|-\n! style=\"width:60px;\"| <small>[[Top Country Albums|US Country]]</small>\n! style=\"width:60px;\"| <small>[[Billboard 200|US]]</small>\n|-\n| 1967\n| ''[[Carryin' On with Johnny Cash and June Carter]]''\n| style=\"text-align:center;\"| 5\n| style=\"text-align:center;\"| \u2014\n|-\n| 1973\n| ''[[Johnny Cash and His Woman]]''\n| style=\"text-align:center;\"| 32\n| style=\"text-align:center;\"| \u2014\n|-\n| 1978\n| ''[[Johnny & June]]''\n| style=\"text-align:center;\"| \u2014\n| style=\"text-align:center;\"| \u2014\n|-\n| 2000\n| ''[[Return to the Promised Land]]''\n| style=\"text-align:center;\"| \u2014\n| style=\"text-align:center;\"| \u2014\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 2006\n| ''[[16 Biggest Hits (Johnny Cash and June Carter Cash album)|16 Biggest Hits: Johnny Cash & June Carter Cash]]''\n| style=\"text-align:center;\"| 26\n| style=\"text-align:center;\"| 126\n|-\n| ''[[June Carter and Johnny Cash: Duets]]''\n| style=\"text-align:center;\"| \u2014\n| style=\"text-align:center;\"| \u2014\n|}\n\n===Singles===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"No Swallerin' Place\"\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"You Flopped When You Got Me Home\"\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n|-\n| 1954\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Tennessee Mambo, Left Over Mambo\"\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n|-\n| 1955\n! Year\n! style=\"width:12em;\"| Video\n|-\n| 2003\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Keep on the Sunny Side\"\n|}\n\n==References==\n{{reflist |30em}}\n\n===Bibliography===\n* {{Citation | last = Carter | first = James 'Jimmy' | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=biqLkX0CCzQC | title = Public papers of the presidents of the United States: Jimmy Carter, 1977 | publisher = Government Printing Office | year = 1978}}.\n\n==Further reading==\n* {{Citation | last = Cash | first = June Carter | title = Among My Klediments | place = Grand Rapids, MI | publisher = Zondervan | year = 1979 | isbn = 0-310-38170-3}}.\n* {{Citation | last = Dawidoff | first = Nicholas | title = In the Country of Country: A Journey to the Roots of American Music | publisher = Vintage Books | year = 1998 | isbn = 0-375-70082-X}}.\n* {{Citation | last = McConnell | first = Carl P | title = A Brief History of My Family and an Autobiographical Sketch of My Musical Life | date = January 24, 1976}}. Online at {{cite web|url=http://www.southernmusic.net/ |title=Southern music}}\n* {{Citation | last1 = Zwonitzer | first1 = Mark | first2 = Charles | last2 = Hirschberg | title = Will you miss me when I'm gone? The Carter Family and their legacy in American music | place = New York | publisher = Simon & Schuster | year = 2002}}.\n\n==External links==\n{{wikiquote}}\n{{Commons category}}\n*[http://www.junecartercash.com/ June Carter Cash Official Site]\n* {{Citation|url=http://music.yahoo.com/ar-291783---June-Carter-Cash |publisher=Yahoo! |title=Music |contribution=June Carter Cash |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060424172539/http://music.yahoo.com/ar-291783---June-Carter-Cash |archive-date=April 24, 2006 }}.\n* {{IMDb name|id=0141745|name=June Carter Cash}}\n* {{Citation | url = http://virginia.org/site/description.asp?AttrID=10670&CharID=287406 | title = A.P. Carter Museum | publisher = Virginia | url-status = dead | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20080528203853/http://www.virginia.org/site/description.asp?AttrID=10670&CharID=287406 | archive-date = May 28, 2008 | df = mdy-all }}.\n*[http://www.carterfamilyfold.org/ Official Carter Family Fold Website]\n{{Carter Family}}\n{{Johnny Cash|family}}\n{{Grand Ole Opry members}}\n{{CMA Group of the Year}}\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Cash, June Carter}}\n[[Category:1929 births]]\n[[Category:2003 deaths]]\n[[Category:20th-century American singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:21st-century American singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Musicians from Nashville, Tennessee]]\n[[Category:People from Scott County, Virginia]]\n[[Category:American women country singers]]\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Dancers from Virginia]]\n[[Category:American banjoists]]\n[[Category:Country musicians from Virginia]]\n[[Category:Country musicians from Tennessee]]\n[[Category:Burials in Tennessee]]\n[[Category:Grammy Award winners]]\n[[Category:American autoharp players]]\n[[Category:Grand Ole Opry members]]\n[[Category:Liberty Records artists]]\n[[Category:Johnny Cash]]\n[[Category:Cash\u2013Carter family]]\n[[Category:American folk singers]]\n[[Category:Guitarists from Virginia]]\n[[Category:The Carter Family members]]\n[[Category:20th-century American women singers]]\n[[Category:20th-century American singers]]\n[[Category:20th-century American guitarists]]\n[[Category:21st-century American women singers]]\n[[Category:20th-century American women guitarists]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from Tennessee]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from Virginia]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"A.P._Carter","to":"A.P. Carter"}],"pages":{"750953":{"pageid":750953,"ns":0,"title":"A.P. Carter","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"#REDIRECT [[A. P. Carter]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Diana_Jones_(singer-songwriter)","to":"Diana Jones (singer-songwriter)"}],"pages":{"9063131":{"pageid":9063131,"ns":0,"title":"Diana Jones (singer-songwriter)","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer-songwriter}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=July 2020}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| image           =\n| name            = Diana Jones\n| caption         =\n| birth_name      = \n| alias           = \n| birth_date      = circa 1965\n| death_date      =\n| origin          =\n| instrument      = [[Lead singer|vocals]], guitar,<br>[[fiddle]], [[mandolin]]\n| genre           = [[Country music|country]], [[Folk music|folk]]<br>singer-songwriter\n| occupation      =\n| years_active    = 1997\u2013present\n| label           = [[NewSong Recordings|NewSong]], [[Proper Records|Proper]]\n| associated_acts = [[Jonathan Byrd (musician)|Jonathan Byrd]]<br>[[Ferron]]\n| website         = [http://www.dianajonesmusic.com/ dianajonesmusic.com]\n| current_members =\n| past_members    = \n}}\n\n'''Diana Jones''' is an American singer-songwriter based in [[Nashville, Tennessee]].  Jones's career gained wider critical acclaim in 2006 with the release of her album, ''[[My Remembrance of You]]''.  The album made a number of critics end-of-the-year \"best of\" lists.  The ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'' rated the album as the \"best country recording of 2006\" and described Jones as \"an Americana gem\", whose sound rides \"an old-timey vibe that never sounds fussy, ... in a voice subtly shaded by the high lonesome sound.\"<ref name = \"Tribune\">Chrissie Dickinson, \"The Best of 2006: Music Recordings: Country: No substitute for experience\", ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'', December 10, 2006 ([http://www.chicagotribune.com/entertainment/music/chi-0612090228dec10,1,7127316.story?coll=chi-ent_music-hed article]{{Dead link|date=November 2019 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }})</ref>\n\nJones has also won a number of songwriting competitions including the venerable \"New Folk\" competition at the 2006 [[Kerrville Folk Festival]].  Her song \"Pony\" was nominated as \"Song of the Year\" by the [[North American Folk Alliance]], and Jones herself was nominated as \"Emerging Artist of the Year\" for 2006.<ref name = \"about.com\">Kim Ruehl, \"Nominees for the Second Annual North American Folk Alliance Awards\", folkmusic.[[about.com]] ([http://folkmusic.about.com/od/awardsetc1/qt/FolkAlliance06.htm article] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070208191714/http://folkmusic.about.com/od/awardsetc1/qt/FolkAlliance06.htm |date=February 8, 2007 }}, ceremony to be held February 21, 2007)</ref>\n\n== Biography ==\nDiana Jones was adopted as an infant and raised in New York City. She was first drawn to [[country music]] in the early 1980s while attending high school on [[Long Island]].  While her peers were listening to [[Michael Jackson]], [[Kenny Loggins]] and [[Prince (musician)|Prince]] she began to seek out recordings by [[Johnny Cash]] and [[Patsy Cline]].<ref name = \"Dispatch\">{{cite news| author=Eidhenberger, Bill | title=Preview of Diana Jones: Love of folk a tradition for writer, her family| publisher='[[Columbus Dispatch]]| date=January 17, 2007| url=http://www.dispatch.com/features-story.php?story=dispatch/2007/01/17/20070117-B1-03.html| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110523054714/http://www.dispatch.com/live/contentbe/dispatch/2007/01/17/20070117-B1-03.html| archive-date=2011-05-23}}</ref>\nShe was also drawn to contemporary acts like [[Dolly Parton]] and [[Emmylou Harris]].<ref name = \"bio\">[http://dianajonesmusic.com/pages/story.htm Official Biography] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070209134750/http://www.dianajonesmusic.com/pages/story.htm |date=February 9, 2007 }} from dianajonesmusic.com, accessed January 22, 2007</ref>\n\nAfter graduating from college Jones was reunited with her birth family in eastern [[Tennessee]].<ref name = \"Dispatch\"/> It was there that she also gained a sense of her musical heritage when she discovered her grandfather, Robert Lee Maranville, was a talented singer and had been in a [[Knoxville, Tennessee|Knoxville]] band with [[Chet Atkins]].  \"I found my first [[Smithsonian Folkways]] recording of Southern ballads up at [[Cades Cove]] in the [[Great Smoky Mountains|Smokies]] on a drive with him\", Jones explained to the ''[[Columbus Dispatch]]''. \"I put it in the CD player, and he started singing along and tapping his finger on his leg. He knew all those songs...I felt like I had discovered the source of what I had been trying to find musically.\"<ref name = \"Dispatch\"/>\n\nIn the 1990s Jones continued to develop as a writer and performer in the [[Music of Austin|music scene]] around [[Austin, Texas]] She released two albums, signed a deal with Hamstein Publishing,<ref name = \"Hamstein\">[http://www.hamstein.com/ Hamstein] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070228172325/http://www.hamstein.com/ |date=February 28, 2007}}, publisher, official site</ref> and began to develop a grass roots following.\n\nIt was the death of Maranville in 2000 that caused her to move back to the northeastern United States and enter a period of personal reflection: \"I wrote this last project [''My Remembrance of You''] in a cabin in the woods, trying to recover my balance after the loss of my grandfather. I was writing songs because I had to, for myself.\"<ref name = \"Dispatch\"/>\n\n== Career ==\nAlthough widely recognized as an \"emerging artist\" in 2006, Jones's recording and songwriting career began a decade earlier.  Her 1997 debut, ''Imagine Me'', has been described as a combination of \"the traditional American folk genre with a cutting edge on modern female folk music.\"<ref name = \"FAME97\">Julie Block, \"Review: ''Imagine Me''\", edited by Shawn Linderman, [http://www.acousticmusic.com/pfms/ Peterborough Folk Music Society] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070206091420/http://www.acousticmusic.com/pfms/ |date=February 6, 2007 }}/[http://www.acousticmusic.com/frames/fame.htm Folk and Acoustic Music Exchange], 1997</ref>\nTwo years later, Jones followed-up with ''The One That Got Away''.\n\nJones really caught the attention of folk music fans when she re-emerged with ''My Remembrance of You''.  The album was released March 12, 2006.  It was dedicated to her late grandfather while also paying tribute to producer and archivist [[Alan Lomax]].<ref name = \"Dispatch\"/>\n\nThe recording almost immediately received high praise from critics.<ref name = \"Tribune\"/><ref name = \"FAME06\">Sonny Thomas, \"Review: ''My Remembrance of You''\", edited by David N. Pyles, [http://www.acousticmusic.com/pfms/ Peterborough Folk Music Society] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070206091420/http://www.acousticmusic.com/pfms/ |date=February 6, 2007 }}/[http://www.acousticmusic.com/frames/fame.htm Folk and Acoustic Music Exchange], 2006</ref><ref name = \"SO!\">Matt Watroba, \"Off the Beaten Track: Diana Jones \u2013 ''My Remembrance of You''\", [[Sing Out!]], 50:2, Summer 2006, p. 119-120</ref> The collection of eleven original songs have been described as \"understated and beautifully crafted\"<ref name = \"SO!\"/> and sounding as though they could have been written in 1935 rather than 2005.<ref name = \"Dispatch\"/> In addition to vocals, Jones is featured on guitar, mandolin and fiddle.  Other musicians include [[Duke Levine]] on strings, [[Bob Dick]] on bass, [[Lorne Entress]] on percussion, and [[Jay Ungar]] on fiddle.\n\nPerhaps the most noted track in the collection is \"Pony\", a song told from the viewpoint of a young Native American girl in the 1920s who is forced to assimilate to a life and culture that is not her own.\n\n\"Pony\" features [[Ferron]] on backing vocals. In addition to being nominated for a \"Song of the Year\" award by the [[North American Folk Alliance]], the song finished the year at number 15 in the 2006 year-end Folk Radio Airplay Chart.<ref name = \"FDJ-L\">[http://folkradio.org/06topsongs.html Top Folk Songs of 2006] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070923124909/http://www.folkradio.org/06topsongs.html |date=September 23, 2007}} by FolkDJ-L DJs, compiled by Richard Gillmann</ref>\n\nIn 2007 Jones produced an album of songs written and performed with [[North Carolina]]-based songwriter [[Jonathan Byrd (musician)|Jonathan Byrd]].  ''[[Radio Soul]]''  is a stripped down recording featuring the voices and guitars of the two songwriters with little added instrumentation.\n\nIn September 2008, [[Joan Baez]] released a recording of Jones's \"Henry Russell's Last Words\" on her album ''[[Day After Tomorrow (Joan Baez album)|Day After Tomorrow]]''. Baez' album has since been nominated for a [[Grammy Award|Grammy]].\n\nIn 2009, Jones released \"Better Times Will Come\" on Proper Records which included \"Henry Russell's Last Words,\" \"Cracked and Broken,\" and \"The Day I Die.\" Nanci Griffith sang back up on the title track.\n\nHigh Atmosphere (Proper) was released in 2011.\n\nMuseum of Appalachia Recordings was recorded at Peters Homestead Cabin, Museum of Appalachia, in Clinton, Tennessee in December 2012, and released in November 2013. Recorded live with two session musicians, the record was inspired by the love of old-time Appalachian music Jones's grandfather passed on to her.\n\nJones is frequently compared to other distinct voices in [[Americana music]] such as [[Gillian Welch]], [[Iris DeMent]], and [[Alison Krauss]].<ref name = \"Tribune\"/> Jones states that she is flattered by the comparisons and if asked to add a name to the list suggests \"[[Ginny Hawker]] would be the name I would add. She has one of the truest voices I have heard. I love everything about the way she sings a song.\"<ref name = \"Dispatch\"/>\n\nJones has shared the stage with many artists, including Janis Ian, Steve Earle, Martina McBride, Nanci Griffith, Richard Thompson, John Gorka, Mary Gauthier, Old Crow Medicine Show, Guy Clark, and many others.\n\n== Discography ==\n* ''Imagine Me'' (1997, New Shoes Records)\n* ''[[The One That Got Away (Diana Jones album)|The One That Got Away]]'' (1998, New Shoes Records)\n* ''[[My Remembrance of You]]'' (2006, NewSong Recordings)\n* ''[[Radio Soul]]'', with [[Jonathan Byrd (musician)|Jonathan Byrd]] (May 2007)\n* ''Better Times Will Come'' (February 2009, [[Proper Records]] [UK]/ April 2009 [US])\n* ''High Atmosphere'' (April 5, 2011, USA)\n* ''Museum Of Appalachia Recordings'' (July 8, 2013 Proper Records [UK]/ November 5, 2013 Goldmine Records USA)\n* ''Song to a Refugee'' (September 25, 2020, [[Proper Records]])\n\n== External links ==\n* [http://www.dianajonesmusic.com/ Diana Jones], official web site\n* [http://www.myspace.com/dianajonesmusic  Diana Jones] at [[MySpace]]\n\n== Notes and references ==\n{{reflist}}\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Jones, Diana}}\n[[Category:American women country singers]]\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:American women singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:American folk singers]]\n[[Category:Sarah Lawrence College alumni]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]]\n[[Category:Proper Records artists]]\n[[Category:Country musicians from Tennessee]]\n[[Category:21st-century American women singers]]\n[[Category:21st-century American singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from Tennessee]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Ian_Tyson","to":"Ian Tyson"}],"pages":{"1048172":{"pageid":1048172,"ns":0,"title":"Ian Tyson","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|Canadian singer-songwriter (1933\u20132022)}}\n{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2020}}\n{{Use Canadian English|date=October 2011}}\n{{Infobox person\n| name             = Ian Tyson\n| honorific_suffix = {{post-nominals|country=CAN|CM|AOE|size=100%}}\n| image            = Ian Tyson (4396806840).jpg\n| caption          = Tyson in 2010\n| birth_name       = Ian Dawson Tyson\n| birth_date       = {{birth date|df=yes|1933|09|25}}\n| birth_place      = [[Victoria, British Columbia]], Canada\n| death_date       = {{death date and age|df=yes|2022|12|29|1933|09|25}}\n| death_place      = [[Longview, Alberta|Longview]], [[Alberta]], Canada\n| alma_mater       = [[Emily Carr University of Art and Design|Vancouver School of Art]]\n| spouse           = {{plainlist|\n* {{marriage|[[Sylvia Tyson|Sylvia Fricker]]|1964|1975}}\n* {{marriage|Twylla Dvorkin|1986|2008}}\n}}\n| children         = 2\n| module           =\n{{Infobox musical artist | embed=yes\n| origin           = [[Toronto]]. [[Ontario]], Canada\n| genre            = {{hlist|[[Country music|Country]]|[[Folk music|folk]]|[[Western music (North America)|Western]]|[[Americana (music)|Americana]]}}\n| occupations      = {{hlist|Singer|songwriter|producer|author}}\n| instruments      = {{hlist|Vocals|guitar}}\n| years_active     = 1959\u20132022\n| label            = [[Stony Plain Records|Stony Plain]], [[A&M Records|A&M]]\n| past_member_of   = [[Ian & Sylvia]], [[Great Speckled Bird (band)|Great Speckled Bird]]\n| website          = {{Official URL}}\n}}\n}}\n\n'''Ian Dawson Tyson''' {{post-nominals|country=CAN|CM|AOE}} (25 September 1933 \u2013 29 December 2022) was a Canadian singer-songwriter who wrote several folk songs, including \"[[Four Strong Winds]]\" and \"[[Someday Soon (Ian Tyson song)|Someday Soon]]\", and performed with partner [[Sylvia Tyson]] as the duo [[Ian & Sylvia]].<ref name=\"Klaszus\"/>\n\n==Early life and education==\nIan Dawson Tyson was born on 25 September 1933, in [[Victoria, British Columbia]] to George and Margaret Tyson.<ref name=\":0\">{{Cite news |last=Applebome |first=Peter |date=2022-12-30 |title=Ian Tyson, Revered Canadian Folk Singer, Dies at 89 |language=en-US |work=The New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2022/12/29/arts/music/ian-tyson-dead.html |access-date=2022-12-30 |issn=0362-4331}}</ref> His father George was an insurance salesman and [[polo]] enthusiast who emigrated from England in 1906.<ref name=\":0\" /> Growing up in [[Duncan, British Columbia]],<ref name=\":1\">{{cite web |last=Witko |first=Kolya |date=Fall\u2013Winter 2009 |title=Ian Tyson: The many faces of a Canadian icon |url=http://alternativetrends.com/fall-winter-2010/features/ian-tyson |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110707120514/http://alternativetrends.com/fall-winter-2010/features/ian-tyson |archive-date=7 July 2011 |access-date=5 March 2011 |publisher=Alternativetrends.com}}</ref> he learned to ride horses on his father's farm, and eventually became a [[rodeo]] rider in his late teens and early twenties. He took up the guitar while in hospital recovering from a broken ankle sustained in a rodeo accident.<ref name=\":1\" /> Fellow Canadian country artist [[Wilf Carter (musician)|Wilf Carter]] was a musical influence.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=eQkEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PT77 \"Ian's 1st Solo Album Marks Return To Country Roots\"], Billboard, 23 November 1974, p.66</ref> He graduated from the [[Emily Carr University of Art and Design|Vancouver School of Art]] in 1958.<ref name=\":1\" />\n\n==Career==\nAfter graduation, Tyson moved to [[Toronto]] where he began a job as a commercial artist. There he performed in local clubs and in 1959 began to sing on occasion with [[Sylvia Tyson|Sylvia Fricker]].<ref name=\":1\" /> By early 1959 Tyson and Fricker were performing part-time at the Village Corner as [[Ian & Sylvia]]. The pair became a full-time musical act in 1961 and married three years later. In 1969, they formed and fronted the group [[Great Speckled Bird (band)|The Great Speckled Bird]]. Residing in southern [[Alberta]], the Tysons toured all over the world. During their years together, the pair released 13 albums of folk and country music.<ref name=\"Inc.2000\">{{cite magazine|first=Larry|last=LeBlanc|title=Tyson album, stage show, draw on her life and long career in music|magazine=Billboard|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=aREEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA60|date=9 September 2000|publisher=Nielsen Business Media, Inc.|pages=60\u2013|issn=0006-2510}}</ref>\n\nFrom 1970 to 1975, Tyson hosted a national television program, ''The Ian Tyson Show'', on [[CTV Television Network|CTV]], known as ''Nashville North'' in its first season. Sylvia Tyson and the Great Speckled Bird appeared often in the series.<ref name=tvarchive>{{cite web | url=http://www.tvarchive.ca/database/17889/ian_tyson_show,_the/details/ | title=Ian Tyson Show, The (Series) (1970\u20131975) |date=February 2003 | access-date=18 July 2019 | publisher=TV Archive|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190213021618/http://www.tvarchive.ca/database/17889/ian_tyson_show,_the/details/|archive-date=13 February 2019}}</ref>\n\nIn 1980, Tyson became associated with Calgary music manager and producer [[Neil MacGonigill]]. Tyson decided to concentrate on [[country music|country]] and [[cowboy music]], resulting in the well-received 1983 album ''Old Corrals and Sagebrush'',<ref>[[Heath McCoy]], [http://www.canada.com/story_print.html?id=243398d1-ce40-4624-a9ea-e9bfdb598778&sponsor= Field of dreamers] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150622043655/http://www.canada.com/story_print.html?id=243398d1-ce40-4624-a9ea-e9bfdb598778&sponsor= |date=22 June 2015 }}.  ''[[Calgary Herald]]'' via [[Canada.com]], 19 June 2007.  Retrieved 3 April 2015.</ref> released on [[Columbia Records]].\n\nIn 1989, Tyson was inducted into the [[Canadian Country Music Hall of Fame]]. His next albums were cowboy music: ''I Outgrew the Wagon'' (1989), ''And Stood There Amazed'' (1991), and ''Eighteen Inches of Rain'' (1994).<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://archive.macleans.ca/article/1999/2/15/home-on-the-range |title=Home on the range &#124; Maclean's |date=15 February 1999 |first=Brian |last=Bergman |website=Maclean's magazine archive |access-date=13 April 2021 |archive-date=30 December 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221230021050/https://archive.macleans.ca/article/1999/2/15/home-on-the-range |url-status=dead }}</ref> Tyson credited [[Adrian Chornowol]] with creating a unique sound for his platinum album \"Cowboyography\", a unique style that he maintained for the rest of his recording career.<ref name=\"zagria\">{{cite web | url=https://zagria.blogspot.com/2010/12/toby-dancer-1953-2004-musician.html | title=A Gender Variance Who's Who: Toby Dancer (1953 \u2013 2004) musician | date=13 December 2010 }}</ref>\n\nIn 2005, [[CBC Radio One]] listeners chose his song \"[[Four Strong Winds]]\" as the greatest Canadian song of all time on the series ''[[50 Tracks: The Canadian Version]]''. There was strong momentum for him to be nominated the Greatest Canadian, but he fell short. He has been a strong influence on many Canadian artists, including [[Neil Young]], who recorded \"Four Strong Winds\" for ''[[Comes a Time]]'' (1978).  [[Johnny Cash]] would also record the same song for ''[[American V: A Hundred Highways]]'' (2006). [[Judy Collins]] recorded a version of his song \"[[Someday Soon (Ian Tyson song)|Someday Soon]]\" in 1968.<ref name=\"zagria\"/>\n\n[[Bob Dylan]] and [[the Band]] recorded his song \"One Single River\" in Woodstock, New York, in 1967. The recording can be found on the unreleased [[List of Basement Tapes songs|Genuine Basement Tapes]], vol. I.<ref>{{cite book|title=Bob Dylan: The Recording Sessions 1960\u20131994 |last=Heylin |first=Clinton |isbn=978-0312150679 |year=1995 |publisher=St. Martin's Griffin |page=55 |url=http://www.clinton-heylin.com/Bob%20Dylan%20Recording.htm |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120121032101/http://www.clinton-heylin.com/Bob%20Dylan%20Recording.htm |archive-date=21 January 2012 }}</ref>\n\nIn 2006, Tyson sustained irreversible scarring to his vocal cords as a result of a concert at the [[Havelock Country Jamboree]] followed a year later by a virus contracted during a flight to [[Denver]].<ref>{{cite magazine |url= https://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/ian-tysons-brave-new-cd |title= Ian Tyson's Brave New CD|magazine= Maclean's|access-date= 5 March 2011|date= 1 December 2008}}</ref> This resulted in a notable loss of the vocal quality and range he was known for; he has self-described his new sound as \"gravelly\".<ref>{{cite encyclopedia |url=http://thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/ian-tyson-emc/ |title= Ian Tyson|encyclopedia=Canadian Encyclopedia |access-date=5 March 2011 }}</ref> Notwithstanding, he released the album ''From Yellowhead to Yellowstone and Other Love Stories'' in 2008 to high critical praise. He was nominated for a 2009 Canadian Folk Music Award for Solo Artist of the Year.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Results 2009 :: Canadian Folk Music Awards |url=https://folkawards.ca/past-years/results-2009/ |access-date=2023-08-06 |language=en-US}}</ref> The album includes a song about Canadian hockey broadcasting icon Don Cherry and the passing of his wife, Rose, a rare Tyson cover written by Toronto songwriter [[Jay Aymar]].\n\n[[File:Bookbits - 2010-11-02 Ian Tyson-The Long Trail.vorb.oga|thumb|right|Ian Tyson talks about ''The Long Trail'' on Bookbits radio]]\n\nSylvia joined Ian to sing their signature song, \"Four Strong Winds\", at the 50th anniversary of the [[Mariposa Folk Festival]] on 11 July 2010, in Orillia, Ontario.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/arts/books-and-media/four-strong-winds-ian-sylvia-by-john-einarson-with-ian-tyson-and-sylvia-tyson/article4256234/|title=Four Strong Winds: Ian & Sylvia by John Einarson with Ian Tyson and Sylvia Tyson|access-date=13 April 2021|newspaper=[[The Globe and Mail]]}}</ref>\n\nTyson has also written a book of [[young adult fiction]] about his song \"La Primera\", called ''La Primera: The Story of Wild Mustangs''.<ref>{{cite book |title= La primera : the story of wild mustangs|last= Tyson|first= Ian|others= Paintings by Adeline Halvorson|year= 2009|publisher= [[Tundra Books]]|location= Toronto|isbn= 978-0-88776-863-7|oclc= 226999077}}</ref>\n\n==Personal life==\nTyson's first marriage, to his musical partner [[Sylvia Tyson|Sylvia Fricker]], ended in an amicable<ref>Ian: \"Silvia and I had parted, amicably, and I came out to Alberta...\" in documentary {{cite web | url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=F44XXgLcdus  |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211222/F44XXgLcdus |archive-date=22 December 2021 |url-status=live| title=Songs from the Gravel Road | year=2010 | access-date=11 February 2012 | publisher=Bravo network }}{{cbignore}}</ref> divorce in 1975. Their son Clay (Clayton Dawson Tyson,<ref name=LovinSound-notes-Clayton>\"They're partners in life as well as in music, which must have its difficult moments like the prospect of having to sing with someone you were maybe not speaking to. But they certainly have made that work, what with that thing rolling around on the rug, young Clayton Dawson, herein and hereafter referred to as 'Mr. Spoons.'\" From the jacket notes (by John Court) to [[Ian and Sylvia]]'s LP \"Lovin' Sound\", MGM 4388, 1967. Quoted in [http://www.mudcat.org/thread.cfm?threadid=10363#71474 Mudcat Forum] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120320172248/http://www.mudcat.org/thread.cfm?threadid=10363#71474 |date=20 March 2012 }} by Dale Rose, 16 April 1999; accessed 8 May 2011.</ref> born 1966<ref name=LivLegClay>{{cite web | url=http://www.livinglegendsmusic.com/library.php?personID=4942 | title=Clay Tyson | publisher=Living Legends Music | date=2006\u20132008 | access-date=19 April 2011 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111005012132/http://www.livinglegendsmusic.com/library.php?personID=4942 | archive-date=5 October 2011 | url-status=dead | df=dmy-all }}</ref>) was also a musical performer and has since moved to a career modifying racing bikes.<ref name=GM2009>{{cite news | url=https://beta.theglobeandmail.com/arts/tyson-comes-clean/article1351833/ | title=Tyson comes clean | first=Marsha | last=Lederman | date=30 March 2008 | newspaper=[[The Globe and Mail]] | access-date=10 November 2017 }}</ref><ref name=NME>{{cite magazine | url=http://www.nme.com/artists/ian-and-sylvia | title=Biography (Ian Tyson) | magazine=[[NME]] | access-date=1 July 2009}}</ref>\n\nAfter the divorce, Tyson returned to southern Alberta to farm and train horses but also continued his musical career on a limited basis. In 1978, Neil Young recorded \"Four Strong Winds\", and Tyson used the royalties for a down payment on a cattle and horse ranch. He started playing regularly at Calgary's Ranchman's Club around this time.<ref name=\"Klaszus\">{{cite web |last1=Klaszus |first1=Jeremy |title=The Gift: What Ian Tyson Left Us |url=https://www.sprawlcalgary.com/remembering-ian-tyson |website=The Sprawl |access-date=21 January 2023 |date=31 December 2022}}</ref>\n\nTyson's autobiography, ''The Long Trail: My Life in the West'', was published in 2010.<ref name=\"ccma-ian\">{{cite web |url=https://members.ccma.org/cgi/page.cgi/hall_of_fame_inductees.html?log=view&log_id=15 |title=Ian Tyson |author=<!--Not stated--> |date= |website=Canadian Country Music Hall of Fame |publisher= |access-date= |quote=}}</ref><ref name=\"canadianmusichalloffame.ca\">{{Cite web|url=https://canadianmusichalloffame.ca/inductee/ian-sylvia/|title=Ian & Sylvia |publisher=Canadian Music Hall Of Fame|access-date=13 April 2021}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last= Tyson |first= Ian |author2=Klaszus, Jeremy |title= The Long Trail: My Life in the West |publisher= [[Random House]] |date=October 2010 |isbn= 978-0-307-35935-3}}</ref> Co-written with Calgary journalist Jeremy Klaszus,<ref name=\"Klaszus\"/> the book \"alternates between autobiography and a broader study of [Tyson's] relationship to the 'West' \u2013 both as a fading reality and a cultural ideal.\"<ref name=\"Herald2010\">{{cite news |last=Volmers |first=Eric |date=23 October 2010 |title=Truly Tyson |pages=D1, D6 |newspaper=[[Calgary Herald]] |url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/488172607/ |access-date=2023-08-06 |via=[[Newspapers.com]]}}</ref> CBC's [[Michael Enright (broadcaster)|Michael Enright]] said the book is like Tyson himself \u2013 \"straightforward, unglazed and honest.\"<ref>{{cite interview |last= Tyson |first= Ian |subject-link= Ian Tyson |interviewer= [[Michael Enright (broadcaster)|Michael Enright]]|title=Interview with Ian Tyson |url=http://www.cbc.ca/thesundayedition/2010/10/october-24-2010-1.html |work= [[The Sunday Edition (CBC Radio)|The Sunday Edition]] |publisher= [[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation|CBC]] |location= [[Toronto]] |date= 24 October 2010 |access-date= 1 November 2010}}</ref>\n\nIan Tyson married Twylla Dvorkin in 1986.  Their daughter Adelita Rose was born {{circa|1987}}.<ref name=GM2009 /><ref name=CBC2000>{{cite web | url=http://archives.cbc.ca/society/celebrations/clips/12016/ | title=A true son of the west | publisher=[[CBC Television]] | date=16 November 2000 | access-date=1 July 2009 | work=Canada Now | first=David | last=Ingram }}</ref> Tyson's second marriage ended in divorce in early 2008, several years after he and Dvorkin had separated.<ref name=Maclean's2008>{{cite news | url=http://www.macleans.ca/tag/ian-tyson/ | title=The end of love and a famous voice | first=Brian D. | last=Johnson | date=24 November 2008 | access-date=1 July 2009 }}</ref><ref name=TS2006>{{cite news | url=http://www.iantyson.com/pages/reviews.asp | title=Recent Reviews | first=Philip | last=Marchand | newspaper=[[Toronto Star]] | date=6 February 2006 | access-date=1 July 2009 | archive-date=30 December 2022 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221230122714/http://www.iantyson.com/pages/reviews.asp | url-status=dead }}</ref>\n\nA book by John Einarson, ''Four Strong Winds: Ian & Sylvia'', was published in 2012. A few years later, Ian said that Evinia Pulos (Bruce) was his \"soulmate\"; since she lived in [[Kelowna]], a city in south central British Columbia, he said that he was unable to see her often. \"We\u2019ve been lovers for 55 years. ... How many people can say that?\" Tyson said. In 2018, Tyson made concert appearances in British Columbia and Alberta.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://50plusworld.com/cowboy-ian-tysons-four-strong-winds/|title=Cowboy Ian Tyson's Four Strong Winds ( written about Evinia)|first=Anita|last=Hamilton|website=50plusworld.com|date=25 September 2018 |access-date=13 April 2021}}</ref> His website indicated that in 2019, he was to make two concert appearances, one in Calgary and the other in Bragg Creek, Alberta.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.iantyson.com/pages/concertlistings.asp|title=The Legendary Ian Tyson Official Website|website=Iantyson.com|access-date=13 April 2021|archive-date=31 December 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221231193110/http://www.iantyson.com/pages/concertlistings.asp|url-status=dead}}</ref>\n\n===Death===\nTyson died at his ranch near [[Longview, Alberta|Longview]], [[Alberta, Canada|Alberta]], on 29 December 2022, at the age of 89.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Clark |first1=Darin |title=Canadian music legend, Ian Tyson passes away at age 89 |url=https://lacombeonline.com/articles/canadian-music-legend-ian-tyson-passes-away-at-age-89 |access-date=29 December 2022 |work=Lacombe Online |date=29 December 2022}}</ref><ref name=\"Friend\">{{Cite news |last=Friend |first=David |date=29 December 2022 |title=Folk legend Ian Tyson, known for 'Four Strong Winds' as part of Ian & Sylvia, dies |language=en |work=Toronto Star |url=https://www.thestar.com/entertainment/music/2022/12/29/cp-newsalert-folk-legend-ian-tyson-known-for-hit-four-strong-winds-dies-at-89.html |access-date=29 December 2022}}</ref> According to his manager Paul Mascioli, this followed several health issues, including a [[heart attack]] and open heart surgery in 2015.<ref name=\"Friend\" />\n\n==Awards and recognition==\n[[File:Ian Tyson with the 2011 Charles M. Russell Heritage Award.jpg|thumb|upright|Tyson with the 2011 [[Charles Marion Russell|Charles M. Russell]] Heritage Award]]\nTyson became a Member of the [[Order of Canada]] in October 1994 and was inducted into the [[Alberta Order of Excellence]] in 2006.<ref name=\"ooc\">{{cite web | url=https://www.gg.ca/en/honours/recipients/146-4413 | title=Mr. Ian Tyson | access-date=19 May 2021 | publisher=The [[Governor General of Canada]] }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.lieutenantgovernor.ab.ca/aoe/2006_tyson.cfm | title=Ian Tyson OC, D Litt (hon), LLD (hon) | publisher=Government of Alberta | access-date=1 July 2009 }}</ref> In 2003, Tyson received a [[Governor General's Performing Arts Award]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://ggpaa.ca/award-recipients/2003/tyson-ian.aspx | title=Ian Tyson biography | access-date=25 November 2013 | publisher=Governor General's Performing Arts Awards Foundation}}</ref>\n\nTyson's 1987 album ''Cowboyography'' contained two songs that were later chosen by the [[Western Writers of America]] as among the Top 100 Western Songs of all time: \"Navajo Rug\" and \"Summer Wages\".<ref name=\"Top100\">{{Cite web|title=The Top 100 Western Songs |author=Western Writers of America |year=2010 |author-link=Western Writers of America |publisher=American Cowboy |url=http://www.americancowboy.com/culture/top-100-western-songs |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101019002745/http://americancowboy.com/culture/top-100-western-songs |archive-date=19 October 2010 |url-status=dead  }}</ref>\n\nHe was inducted into the [[Canadian Music Hall of Fame]], with Sylvia, in 1992.<ref name=\"canadianmusichalloffame.ca\"/>\n\nIan Tyson was inducted into the Mariposa Hall of Fame, with Sylvia, in 2006 <ref name=\"canadianmusichalloffame.ca\"/>\n\nHe was inducted into the Canadian Country Music Hall of Fame in 1989.<ref name=\"ccma-ian\"/> (Sylvia Tyson was inducted in 2003.)<ref name=\"ccma-sylvia\">{{cite web |url=https://members.ccma.org/cgi/page.cgi/hall_of_fame_inductees.html?log=view&log_id=34 |title=Sylvia Tyson |author=<!--Not stated--> |date= |website=Canadian Country Music Hall of Fame |publisher= |access-date= |quote=}}</ref>\n\nThe song \"Four Strong Winds\", written by Ian Tyson, was named as the greatest Canadian song of all time by the CBC-Radio program ''50 Tracks: The Canadian Version'' in 2005.<ref name=\"canadianmusichalloffame.ca\"/><ref name=\"Klaszus\"/>\n\nAn announcement in July 2019 stated that Ian Tyson and Sylvia Tyson would be inducted into the [[Songwriters Hall of Fame]], individually, not as a duo. The [[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]] article stated that \"the duo's 1964's hit, 'Four Strong Winds', has been deemed one of the most influential songs in Canadian history\". The report also referenced the song \"You Were on My Mind\", written by Sylvia Tyson, as well as her four albums (1975\u20131980).<ref name=\"cbc-cshof\">{{cite web |url=https://www.cbc.ca/news/entertainment/ian-tyson-sylvia-tyson-canadian-songwriters-hall-of-fame-1.5215382 |title=Ian Tyson and Sylvia Tyson to be inducted separately into Canadian Songwriters Hall of Fame |last=Friend |first=David |date=17 July 2019 |website=CBC |publisher= |access-date= |quote=}}</ref>\n\n===Tribute recordings===\nA tribute CD to Ian Tyson, ''The Gift'', was released in 2007 on [[Stony Plain Records]] featuring \"Someday Soon\" done by Doug Andrew with [[Buddy Cage]] on pedal steel guitar (Buddy played in Great Speckled Bird), \"Four Strong Winds\" recorded by Blue Rodeo, plus another 13 of Tyson's best known songs done by major folk and country artists. The album is titled after a song of Tyson's, which itself is a tribute to [[Charles Marion Russell]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.discogs.com/release/9344591-Various-The-Gift-A-Tribute-To-Ian-Tyson| title=The Gift @ discogs| website=[[Discogs]]| date=6 August 2023}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n! scope=\"col\" rowspan=\"2\" | Year\n! scope=\"col\" rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:24em;\" | Title\n! scope=\"col\" colspan=\"2\" | Peak positions\n! scope=\"col\" rowspan=\"2\"| [[List of music recording certifications|Certifications]]\n|-\n! scope=\"col\" style=\"width:4em; font-size:90%;\" | [[RPM (magazine)|CAN Country]]<br/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bac-lac.gc.ca/eng/discover/films-videos-sound-recordings/rpm/Pages/list.aspx?OCRText=Ian+Tyson&ChartEn=Country+Albums%2fCDs&|title=Ian Tyson - Country Albums/CDs|work=[[RPM (magazine)|RPM]]|date=17 July 2013 |access-date=31 December 2022}}</ref>\n! scope=\"col\" style=\"width:4em; font-size:90%;\" | [[RPM (magazine)|CAN]]<br/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bac-lac.gc.ca/eng/discover/films-videos-sound-recordings/rpm/Pages/list.aspx?OCRText=Ian+Tyson&ChartEn=Top+Albums%2fCDs&|title=Ian Tyson - Top Albums/CDs|work=RPM|date=17 July 2013 |access-date=31 December 2022}}</ref>\n|-\n| 1973\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Ol' Eon''\n| \u2014\n| 81\n|\n|-\n| 1978\n! scope=\"row\"| ''One Jump Ahead of the Devil''\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n|\n|-\n| 1983\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Old Corrals and Sagebrush''\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n|\n|-\n| 1984\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Ian Tyson''\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n|\n|-\n| 1987\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Cowboyography''\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n| align=\"left\"| \n*[[Music Canada|CAN]]: Platinum{{Certification Cite Ref|region=Canada|type=albums|title=Cowboyography|artist=Ian Tyson}}\n|-\n| 1989\n! scope=\"row\"| ''I Outgrew the Wagon''\n| 12\n| 74\n| align=\"left\"| \n*CAN: Gold{{Certification Cite Ref|region=Canada|type=albums|title=I Outgrew the Wagon|artist=Ian Tyson}}\n|-\n| 1991\n! scope=\"row\"| ''And Stood There Amazed''\n| 16\n| \u2014\n|\n|-\n| 1994\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Lost Herd''\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n|\n|-\n| 2002\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Live at Longview''\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n|\n|-\n| 2005\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Songs from the Gravel Road''\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n|\n|-\n| 2008\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Yellowhead to Yellowstone and Other Love Stories''\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n|\n|-\n| 2011\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Songs from the Stone House''\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n|\n|-\n| 2012\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Raven Singer''\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n|\n|-\n| 2013\n! scope=\"row\"| ''All the Good 'Uns Vol. 2''\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n|\n|-\n| 2015\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Carnero Vaquero''\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n|\n|-\n| colspan=\"6\" style=\"font-size:8pt\"| \"\u2014\" denotes releases that did not chart\n|}\n\n===Singles===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n! scope=\"col\" rowspan=\"2\" | Year\n! scope=\"col\" rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:20em;\" | Title\n! scope=\"col\" colspan=\"3\" | Peak positions\n! scope=\"col\" rowspan=\"2\"| Album\n|-\n! scope=\"col\" style=\"width:4em; font-size:90%;\" | [[RPM (magazine)|CAN Country]]<br/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bac-lac.gc.ca/eng/discover/films-videos-sound-recordings/rpm/Pages/list.aspx?OCRText=Ian+Tyson&ChartEn=Country+Singles&|title=Ian Tyson - Country Singles|work=[[RPM (magazine)|RPM]]|date=17 July 2013 |access-date=31 December 2022}}</ref>\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Black Nights\"\n| 35\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n|-\n| rowspan=\"3\"| 1992\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Lights of Laramie\"\n| 9\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Magpie\"\n| 43\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Eighteen Inches of Rain\"\n| 27\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Heartaches Are Stealin'\"\n| 39\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n|-\n| 1995\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Horsethief Moon\"\n| 68\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n|-\n| 1996\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Barrel Racing Angel\"\n| 35\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n| rowspan=\"2\"| ''All the Good 'uns''\n|-\n| 1997\n! scope=\"row\"| \"The Wonder of It All\"\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n|-\n| 1999\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Brahmas and Mustangs\"\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n| ''Lost Herd''\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 2005\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Land of Shining Mountains\"\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n| rowspan=\"3\"| ''Songs from the Gravel Road''\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"This Is My Sky\"\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n|-\n| 2006\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Always Saying Goodbye\"\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n|-\n| colspan=\"6\" style=\"font-size:8pt\"| \"\u2014\" denotes releases that did not chart\n|}\n\n==Videography==\n{{More citations needed|sect|date=January 2022}}\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n! Year\n! Title\n! Notes\n! Ref\n|-\n|1971\u20131974\n|''Ian Tyson Show''\n|CTV network\n|<ref name=tvarchive/>\n|-\n|2010\n|''Songs from the Gravel Road''\n|[[Bravo (Canada)|Bravo! Network]] documentary\n|\n|-\n|2010\n|''Mano a Mano''\n|DVD with [[Tom Russell]]\n|\n|-\n|2010\n|''This Is My Sky''\n|DVD set\n|\n|}\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n==Further reading==\n{{Refbegin}}\n*{{Cite encyclopedia|title= Tyson, Ian|url= http://thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/ian-tyson-emc/ |encyclopedia= Encyclopedia of Canadian Musicians|publisher= Historica Foundation of Canada|access-date= 15 July 2009}}\n{{Refend}}\n\n==External links==\n*{{Official website|http://www.iantyson.com/pages/home.asp}}\n*{{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p1852|label=Ian Tyson}}\n* {{discogs artist|Ian Tyson}}\n* {{IMDb name|0879163}}\n* [https://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/ian-tyson-emc Article at the canadianencyclopedia.ca]\n\n{{Great Speckled Bird}}\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Tyson, Ian}}\n[[Category:1933 births]]\n[[Category:2022 deaths]]\n[[Category:Canadian folk singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Canadian male singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Members of the Alberta Order of Excellence]]\n[[Category:Members of the Order of Canada]]\n[[Category:Singers from Toronto]]\n[[Category:Musicians from Victoria, British Columbia]]\n[[Category:Singers from British Columbia]]\n[[Category:Canadian country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Canadian people of English descent]]\n[[Category:Juno Award winners]]\n[[Category:Canadian Country Music Association Male Artist of the Year winners]]\n[[Category:Great Speckled Bird (band) members]]\n[[Category:Stony Plain Records artists]]\n[[Category:A&M Records artists]]\n[[Category:Singers from Alberta]]\n[[Category:Governor General's Award winners]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Mary_Gauthier","to":"Mary Gauthier"}],"pages":{"3180998":{"pageid":3180998,"ns":0,"title":"Mary Gauthier","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer-songwriter}}\n\n{{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject_Musicians -->\n| name             = Mary Gauthier\n| image            = Mary Gauthier 2006.jpg\n| caption          = Gauthier in 2006\n| image_size       = \n| landscape        = \n| background       = solo_singer <!-- includes singer-songwriters -->\n| birth_name       = \n| alias            =\n| birth_date       = {{birth date and age|1962|3|11}}\n| birth_place      = [[New Orleans]], Louisiana, United States\n| instrument       = Vocals, guitar\n| genre            = {{Flatlist|\n*[[Folk music|Folk]]\n*[[Country music|country]]\n*[[Americana (music)|Americana]]}}\n| occupation       = Songwriter, musician, writing teacher, restaurateur\n| years_active     = 1990\u2013present\n| label            = [[Lost Highway Records|Lost Highway]], In the Black, [[Signature Sounds Recordings|Signature Sounds]], [[Proper Records|Proper]]\n| website          = {{URL|www.marygauthier.com/}}\n}}\n\n'''Mary Veronica Gauthier''' ({{IPAc-en|\u02c8|\u0261|o\u028a|\u0283|e\u026a}} {{respell|GOH|shay}}; born March 11, 1962) is a [[Grammy Awards|Grammy]]-nominated American [[folk music|folk]] singer-songwriter and author, whose songs have been covered by performers including [[Tim McGraw]], [[Blake Shelton]], [[Kathy Mattea]], [[Boy George]], [[Jimmy Buffett]], [[Bettye Lavette]], [[Candi Staton]], and [[Amy Helm]].\n\nMary's songs often deal with marginalization, informed by her experience of adoption, addiction and recovery, and growing up gay in the deep south. Her work demonstrates an \"ability to transform her own trauma into a purposeful and communal narrative\", such as the lyric \"we could all use, a little mercy, now\", from her song \"[[Mercy Now]]\".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/2018/01/27/580429847/reworking-trauma-mary-gauthier-tells-veteran-stories-on-rifles-rosary-beads|title = Reworking Trauma: Mary Gauthier Tells Veteran Stories on 'Rifles & Rosary Beads'| website=NPR.org }}</ref>\n\nHer Grammy nominated 2018 album ''Rifles & Rosary Beads'', co-written with military veterans and their families, has been hailed as a landmark achievement.<ref name=\"countrystandardtime.com\">{{Cite web|url=https://www.countrystandardtime.com/d/cdreview.asp?xid=6603|title = Mary Gauthier - Rifles and Rosary Beads}}</ref>\n\nShe has won awards from the  Americana Music Association, International Folk Music Awards, the Independent Music Awards, the GLAMA Awards, and the UK Americana Association.\n\n==Early life, addiction and sobriety==\nGauthier was born in 1962 in [[New Orleans]], Louisiana, to a mother who gave her to St Vincent's Women and Infants Asylum, where she spent the first year of her life.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://explore.baltimoreheritage.org/items/show/467|title = St. Vincent's Infant Asylum}}</ref> In adulthood, Mary spoke to her biological mother once by phone, but there was no further contact between them.<ref name=\"independent.co.uk\">{{Cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/features/mary-gauthier-hottest-star-country-music-6103582.html|title=Mary Gauthier: The hottest star in country music|website=[[Independent.co.uk]] |date=April 2009}}</ref> She was adopted by an [[Italian American|Italian]] [[Roman Catholic Church|Catholic]] couple from [[Thibodaux, Louisiana|Thibodaux]], Louisiana. Her father was an alcoholic.<ref>{{Citation\n  | last = Gold\n  | first = Scott\n  | title = Change of tune\n  | newspaper = [[Los Angeles Times]]\n  | date = June 12, 2008\n| url = http://www.timesunion.com/AspStories/story.asp?storyID=695464&category=ARTS&newsdate=6/12/2008\n  | access-date =January 27, 2010\n}}\n</ref> Struggling with a variety of issues, Gauthier left home young and abused drugs and alcohol, as did her brother, who was three years younger and also adopted.<ref name=Reighley>{{Citation\n  | last = Reighley\n  | first = Kurt B.\n  | title = Singing her stories\n  | newspaper = [[The Advocate (LGBT magazine)|The Advocate]]\n  | page = 65\n  | date = March 29, 2005\n| url = https://books.google.com/books?id=-GMEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA65\n  | access-date =January 27, 2010\n}}\n</ref> He was later jailed for armed robbery. Mary says she had drunk herself unconscious on sloe gin by the time she was twelve.<ref name=\"independent.co.uk\"/>\n\nWhen she was fifteen she ran away from home, recalling that \"I was a gay kid, and back then, that just didn\u2019t fly. Back then, gay kids were beat up, abused, some ended up taking their own lives.
