Album\n|-\n| 1992\n| \"The Road to Home\"\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n| ''Love on the Range''\n|-\n| 1993\n| \"A Song for Brent\"\n| align=\"center\"| 19\n| Non-album song\n|-\n| rowspan=\"3\"| 1994\n| \"Rockabilly Heart\"\n| align=\"center\"| 19\n| rowspan=\"4\"| ''Love on the Range''\n|-\n| \"Love on the Range\"\n| align=\"center\"| 43\n|-\n| \"This October Day\"\n| align=\"center\"| 32\n|-\n| rowspan=\"3\"| 1995\n| \"My Wishing Room\"\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n|-\n| \"Still a Fool\"\n| align=\"center\"| 40\n| rowspan=\"4\"| ''Just a Little Rain''\n|-\n| \"Trying to Rope the Wind\"\n| align=\"center\"| 50\n|-\n| rowspan=\"3\"| 1996\n| \"Never Got Over You\"\n| align=\"center\"| 60\n|-\n| \"Sleeping Alone\"\n| align=\"center\"| 68\n|-\n| \"Sweet Dreams of You\"\n| align=\"center\"| 72\n| rowspan=\"5\"| ''Cindy Church''\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 1997\n| \"My Baby\"\n| align=\"center\"| 54\n|-\n| \"[[Lover Please]]\"\n| align=\"center\"| 44\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 1998\n| \"Wichita\"\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n|-\n| \"Whispering Pines\"\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n|-\n| align=\"center\" colspan=\"10\" style=\"font-size:8pt\"| \"\u2014\" denotes the single failed to chart or not released\n|-\n|}\n\n==References==\n{{reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n*[http://www.cindychurch.com Official Site]\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Church, Cindy}}\n[[Category:1958 births]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:Canadian women singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Canadian women country singers]]\n[[Category:Quartette (band) members]]\n[[Category:Canadian country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Canadian folk singer-songwriters]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Jenny_Whiteley","to":"Jenny Whiteley"}],"pages":{"9826118":{"pageid":9826118,"ns":0,"title":"Jenny Whiteley","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|Canadian singer-songwriter}}\n{{Use Canadian English|date=July 2022}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=July 2022}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| image           =\n| name            = Jenny Whiteley\n| image_size      = <!-- Only for images smaller than 220 pixels -->\n| birth_place     =\n| birth_date      = {{Birth date and age|1971|1|14}}\n| origin          = [[Toronto]], Ontario, Canada\n| instrument      = Vocals, guitar\n| genre           = [[Country music|Country]], [[Folk music|folk]]\n| occupation      = Singer, songwriter\n| years_active    = 1976\u2013present\n| label           = [[MapleMusic Recordings|MapleMusic]], [[Black Hen Music|Black Hen]]\n| associated_acts = [[Sarah Harmer]]<br />[[Amy Millan]]\n| website         = [http://www.jennywhiteley.com/ www.jennywhiteley.com]\n| current_members =\n| past_members    = \n}}\n\n'''Jenny Whiteley''' is a Canadian [[country music|country]] and [[folk music|folk]] singer-songwriter.  She was a member of the band Heartbreak Hill, and released several solo albums of folk music.  She has won two Juno Awards for her music.\n\n==Early life and family==\nWhiteley grew up in Toronto. She is the daughter of blues musician Chris Whiteley and his wife Caitlin Hanford.<ref>[http://nodepression.com/article/jenny-whiteley-following-family-footsteps \"Jennny Whiteley \u2013 Following family footsteps\"]. ''No Depression'', December 31, 2006</ref> Her brother is Dan Whiteley, who is also a folk musician and singer, and her uncle is folk musician Ken Whiteley.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://nodepression.com/article/jenny-whiteley-following-family-footsteps | title=Jenny Whiteley \u2013 Following family footsteps | work=The Journal of Roots Music | accessdate=October 2, 2016 | date=December 31, 2006}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://exclaim.ca/music/article/jenny_whiteley-the_original_jenny_whiteley | title=The Original Jenny Whiteley | work=Exclaim! | accessdate=October 2, 2016 | date=September 16, 2016}}</ref>\n\n==Career==\nShe began her musical career as a child, recording with Canadian children's musician [[Raffi (musician)|Raffi]] along with her brother Dan.\n\nIn the 1990s she performed with the bluegrass band Heartbreak Hill.<ref>{{usurped|1=[https://web.archive.org/web/20000204135613/http://chartattack.com/road/reviews/1999/19990721-stardust.html \"Live Reviews: The Stardust Picnic\"]}}. ''Chart Attack'', July 11, 1999, Howard Druckman</ref> Just prior to that band's breakup, she released her self-titled debut album in 2001,<ref>[https://www.theglobeandmail.com/arts/in-harmony-with-your-family-roots/article18428427/ \"In harmony with your family roots\"]. ''The Globe and Mail'', Carl Wilson, TORONTO, December 14, 2000</ref> and followed up with ''Hopetown'' in 2004. Both albums won the [[Juno Award]] for [[Juno Award for Roots & Traditional Album of the Year - Solo|Best Roots & Traditional Album of the Year]].<ref>[https://ottawacitizen.com/entertainment/local-arts/junofest-preview-doesnt-everybodys-mom-have-two-junos-jenny-whiteleys-daughters-say \"JunoFest preview: 'Doesn't everybody's mom have two Junos?' Jenny Whiteley's daughters say\"]. Lynn Saxberg, ''Ottawa Citizen'', March 23, 2017</ref> She has released three more albums since: ''Dear'', ''Forgive or Forget'' and ''The Original Jenny Whiteley'', all getting good reviews. Her last four records have been released through [[Black Hen Music]].<ref>[https://www.allmusic.com/album/forgive-or-forget-mw0001959854 \"Jenny Whiteley Forgive or Forget\"]. AllMusic, Review by Paula Carino</ref> [[Steve Dawson]] produced ''Hopetown'',<ref>[https://www.allmusic.com/album/hopetown-mw0001331040 \"Jenny Whiteley Hopetown\"]. AllMusic Review by Erik Hage</ref> ''Dear'' and ''Forgive or Forget''.<ref>[http://nodepression.com/article/alphabet-project-roars-back-vacationtheres-fog-upon-la-sitting-here-blue-j-way \"The alphabet project roars back from vacation...there's a fog upon LA, sitting here in blue J way\"]. ''No Depression'', July 2, 2010</ref>\n\nShe has also collaborated with [[Sarah Harmer]], [[Amy Millan]], [[Carolyn Mark]] and [[Riley Baugus]].\n\n==Personal life==\nWhiteley moved from Toronto to a country home near Elphin, Ontario in eastern Ontario with her musician husband, Joey Wright (b. October 9, 1973), in January 2002. She and Joey have two daughters, Lila (born April 16, 2003) and Audrey (born September 18, 2007).\n\n==Discography==\n\n===With Heartbreak Hill===\n* ''Heartbreak Hill'' (1998)<ref name=\"Billboard 1998\">\"Bluegrass Thrives in Northern Nich\"{{cite book|author=Nielsen Business Media, Inc.|title=Billboard|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rg4EAAAAMBAJ&pg=RA1-PA72|date=April 11, 1998|publisher=Nielsen Business Media, Inc.|pages=1\u2013|issn=0006-2510}}</ref>\n\n===Solo===\n* ''Jenny Whiteley'' (2001)\n* ''Hopetown'' (2004)\n* ''Dear'' (2006)\n* ''Forgive or Forget'' (2010)\n* ''The Original Jenny Whiteley'' (2016)\n\n==Awards and recognition==\n;[[Juno Awards]]\n* 1999 nominee, Best Roots/Traditional Album: Group: ''Heartbreak Hill''\n* 2001 Best Roots/Traditional Album: ''Jenny Whiteley''\n* 2005 Roots/Traditional Album of the Year: ''Hopetown''\n;[[Canadian Folk Music Awards]]\n* 2007 nominee, Best Contemporary Album: ''Dear''\n\n==References==\n{{reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n* [http://www.jennywhiteley.com/ Official Jenny Whiteley website]\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Whiteley, Jenny}}\n[[Category:1971 births]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:Canadian folk singers]]\n[[Category:Canadian women country singers]]\n[[Category:Canadian country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Canadian women folk singers]]\n[[Category:Juno Award for Roots & Traditional Album of the Year \u2013 Solo winners]]\n[[Category:Singers from Toronto]]\n[[Category:21st-century Canadian women singers]]\n[[Category:Black Hen Music artists]]\n[[Category:MapleMusic Recordings artists]]\n[[Category:21st-century Canadian singer-songwriters]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Chris_Hillman","to":"Chris Hillman"}],"pages":{"956561":{"pageid":956561,"ns":0,"title":"Chris Hillman","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American musician (b. 1944)}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=July 2014}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name              = Chris Hillman\n| image             = Hillman1972.JPG\n| caption           = Hillman in 1972\n| birth_name        = Christopher Hillman\n| birth_date        = {{birth date and age|1944|12|4}}\n| birth_place       = Los Angeles, California, U.S.\n| instrument        = {{hlist|Bass|guitar|mandolin|vocals}}\n| genre             = {{hlist|[[Folk music|Folk]]|[[bluegrass music|bluegrass]]|[[folk rock]]|[[rock music|rock]]|[[country rock]]|[[country music|country]]}}\n| occupation        = Musician\n| years_active      = 1960\u2013present\n| label             = {{hlist|[[Columbia Records|Columbia]]|[[Sugar Hill Records (bluegrass)|Sugar Hill]]|[[Asylum Records|Asylum]]|[[A&M Records|A&M]]|[[Rounder Records|Rounder]]}}\n| past_member_of    = {{hlist|[[Scottsville Squirrel Barkers]]|[[The Hillmen]]|[[The Byrds]]|[[The Flying Burrito Brothers]]|[[Manassas (band)|Manassas]]|[[Souther Hillman Furay Band]]| [[McGuinn, Clark & Hillman]]|[[The Desert Rose Band]]}}\n| website           = {{URL|http://www.chrishillman.com/}}\n}}\n\n'''Christopher Hillman''' (born December 4, 1944)<ref name=\"LarkinCountry\">{{cite book|title=[[Encyclopedia of Popular Music|The Guinness Who's Who of Country Music]]|editor=[[Colin Larkin (writer)|Colin Larkin]]|publisher=[[Guinness Publishing]]|date=1993|edition=First|isbn=0-85112-726-6|page=190}}</ref> is an American musician. He was the original bassist of [[the Byrds]]. With frequent collaborator [[Gram Parsons]], Hillman was a key figure in the development of [[country rock]], defining the genre through his work with the Byrds, [[the Flying Burrito Brothers]], [[Manassas (band)|Manassas]] and the country-rock group [[the Desert Rose Band]]. He was inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in 1991 as a member of the Byrds.\n\n==Early life==\nHillman was born in Los Angeles, California, the third of four children.<ref>{{cite web|title=Guitarist Chris Hillman|publisher=[[Library of Congress]]|url=https://www.loc.gov/today/cyberlc/feature_wdesc.php?rec=4766|access-date=2015-12-10}}</ref> He spent his early years at his family's ranch home in rural northern [[San Diego County, California|San Diego County]], approximately {{convert|110|mi}} from Los Angeles. He has credited his older sister with exciting his interest in [[Country music|country]] and [[folk music]], when she returned from college during the late 1950s with folk music records by [[The New Lost City Ramblers]] and others. Hillman soon began watching many of the country-music shows on local television in southern California at the time such as ''Town Hall Party'', ''The [[Spade Cooley]] Show'' and ''Cal's Corral''. Hillman's mother encouraged his musical interests and bought him his first guitar; shortly thereafter he developed an interest in [[Bluegrass music|bluegrass]], particularly the [[mandolin]]. At the age of 15, Hillman went to Los Angeles to see the [[Kentucky Colonels (band)|Kentucky Colonels]] bluegrass band at the [[Ash Grove (music club)|Ash Grove]], and later convinced his family to allow him to travel by train to [[Berkeley, California|Berkeley]] for lessons from mandolinist Scott Hambly. When Chris was 16, his father committed suicide.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbn.com/700club/guests/interviews/CW98_chris_hillman.aspx |title=Chris Hillman: 'Turn, Turn, Turn' |website=Cbn.com |access-date=2015-12-10}}</ref>\n\nHillman became known in San Diego's folk music community as a solid player; this won him an invitation to join his first band, the [[Scottsville Squirrel Barkers]].<ref name=\"LarkinCountry\"/> The band lasted barely two years, recording only one album (''Blue Grass Favorites'', which was distributed in supermarkets); however, it has a posthumous reputation as the spawning ground for a number of musicians who went on to play in [[the Eagles]], the Flying Burrito Brothers, the Byrds, [[Hearts & Flowers]], and the [[Country Gazette (band)|Country Gazette]]. When the band broke up in late 1963 Hillman received an invitation to join the Golden State Boys, regarded as the top bluegrass band in [[southern California]] and featuring future country star [[Vern Gosdin]], his brother Rex and banjoist [[Don Parmley]] (later of the [[Bluegrass Cardinals]]). Shortly thereafter the band changed its name to [[The Hillmen]];<ref name=\"LarkinCountry\"/> soon Hillman was appearing regularly on television and using a fictitious ID, \"Chris Hardin\", to allow the underage musician into the country bars where many of his gigs were played. When the Hillmen folded, he briefly joined a spinoff of Randy Sparks' [[The New Christy Minstrels|New Christy Minstrels]] known as the Green Grass Revival.\n\n== Career ==\n\n=== The Byrds (1964\u20131968) ===\n{{main|The Byrds}}\n[[File:The Byrds 1965.png|thumb|Hillman (far left) as a member of the Byrds in 1965]]\nAt this point a frustrated Hillman considered quitting music and enrolling at [[UCLA]] when he received an offer from The Hillmen's former manager and producer, Jim Dickson, to join Jim (later Roger) McGuinn, David Crosby, Gene Clark and Michael Clarke in a new band, The Byrds.<ref name=\"LarkinCountry\"/> Hillman was recruited to play bass guitar, although he had never picked up the instrument. Thanks to his bluegrass background, he quickly developed his own melodic style on the instrument. The Byrds' first single, a jangly cover of [[Bob Dylan]]'s \"[[Mr. Tambourine Man]]\", was an international hit and marked the birth of [[folk rock]]. During the mid-1960s the Byrds ranked as one of the most successful and influential American pop groups; they recorded a string of hits, including \"[[Turn! Turn! Turn!]]\", \"[[Eight Miles High]]\" and \"[[So You Want to Be a Rock 'n' Roll Star]]\".\n\nHillman kept a low profile on the band's first two albums, on which McGuinn and Clark shared lead vocals with Crosby adding high harmony and singing the bridge on \"[[All I Really Want to Do]]\". However, Clark's departure in 1966 and Crosby's growing restlessness allowed Hillman the opportunity to develop as a singer and songwriter in the group. He came into his own on the Byrds' 1967 album ''[[Younger Than Yesterday]]'', co-writing and sharing lead vocals with McGuinn on the hit \"[[So You Want to Be a Rock 'n' Roll Star]]\".<ref name=\"LarkinCountry\"/> Hillman also wrote (and sang) the minor hit \"[[Have You Seen Her Face]]\", \"Thoughts and Words\", \"Time Between\" and \"The Girl with No Name\", the latter two demonstrating his bluegrass and country roots. Hillman's prominence continued with the Byrds' next album, ''[[The Notorious Byrd Brothers]]'', on which he shared songwriting credit on seven of the album's eleven songs.\n\n=== Pioneering country rock ===\nInternal strife dogged the Byrds, and by the beginning of 1968 the band was down to two original members (Hillman and McGuinn), with Hillman's cousin [[Kevin Kelley (musician)|Kevin Kelley]] on drums. They then hired [[Gram Parsons]] to replace Crosby. Hillman, who had brought country music into the Byrds' earliest recording of \"Satisfied Mind\", found another lover of country music in Parsons.  ''[[Sweetheart of the Rodeo]]'' was recorded in Nashville and Los Angeles and continues to inspire musicians in the Americana format.<ref name=\"LarkinCountry\"/> Parsons left the band shortly thereafter; Hillman brought in former Kentucky Colonels guitarist [[Clarence White]] as a replacement and White suggested that the group replace Kelley with [[Gene Parsons]] (no relation to Gram) on drums, but this line-up was short-lived and Hillman himself left the Byrds due to financial misappropriation by their management.\n\n=== The Flying Burrito Brothers (1969\u20131972) ===\n{{Main article|The Flying Burrito Brothers}}\n[[File:FlyingBurritos1970.jpg|upright=1.35|thumb|[[The Flying Burrito Brothers]] (Amsterdam, 1970). From left to right: [[Pete Kleinow|'Sneaky' Pete Kleinow]], [[Rick Roberts (musician)|Rick Roberts]], Chris Hillman, [[Michael Clarke (musician)|Michael Clarke]] & [[Bernie Leadon]] ]]\n\nHillman teamed with Gram Parsons again (this time as vocalist, guitarist and songwriter) to form the [[Flying Burrito Brothers]].<ref name=\"LarkinCountry\"/> Further honing their pioneering country-rock hybrid sound by combining the energy, instrumentation and attitude of [[rock and roll]] with the issues and themes of [[country music]], the Burritos recorded the landmark ''[[The Gilded Palace of Sin]]'' (1969) followed by 1970's ''[[Burrito Deluxe]]''. Parsons was fired from the line-up by June 1970 (replaced by guitarist [[Rick Roberts (musician)|Rick Roberts]]) when the band toured Canada as part of the [[Festival Express]] tour, with Hillman reverting to bass guitar. Hillman stayed with the band for two more records, ''[[The Flying Burrito Bros (album)|The Flying Burrito Brothers]]'' and ''[[Last of the Red Hot Burritos]]''.\n\n=== Various bands and solo career (1970s) ===\n{{Main article|Manassas (band)|Souther-Hillman-Furay Band|McGuinn, Clark & Hillman}}\nBefore the Flying Burrito Brothers disbanded, Hillman joined [[Stephen Stills]]' band [[Manassas (band)|Manassas]].<ref name=\"LarkinCountry\" /> They released two albums, a 1972 [[Manassas (album)|self-titled double album]], and a 1973 album ''[[Down the Road (Manassas album)|Down the Road]]''. Led by Stills, Manassas was an exploration into a mixture of rock, country, blues, bluegrass and Latin music. In 1972, Stills gave Hillman a 1924 [[Lloyd Loar]] [[Gibson F-5]] mandolin.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Lewis |first=Randy |date=2017-09-18 |title=Byrds co-founder Chris Hillman taps David Crosby, Roger McGuinn, Tom Petty for new solo album |url=https://www.latimes.com/entertainment/music/la-et-ms-chris-hillman-bidin-my-time-tom-petty-20170810-story.html |access-date=2024-05-29 |website=Los Angeles Times |language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2017-09-18 |title=Chris Hillman |url=https://www.latimes.com/94338813-132.html |access-date=2024-05-29 |website=Los Angeles Times |language=en-US}}</ref> Hillman remained with Manassas until 1973, when he briefly re-joined the original line-up of the Byrds for a reunion album on [[Asylum Records]].\n\nIn 1974, Hillman teamed with singer-songwriter [[Richie Furay]] (who co-founded [[Buffalo Springfield]] and [[Poco (band)|Poco]]) and songwriter [[JD Souther]] (who co-wrote much of the [[Eagles (band)|Eagles]]' early repertoire) in the [[Souther-Hillman-Furay Band]].<ref name=\"LarkinCountry\" /> The trio never quite gelled, and broke up in 1975 after two albums and internal squabbles.\n\nHillman released two solo albums, ''Slippin' Away'' and ''Clear Sailin''',<ref name=\"LarkinCountry\"/> which included several songs co-written with ''[[Crawdaddy!|Crawdaddy]]'' magazine editor [[Peter Knobler]]. One of their songs, \"Step on Out,\" was recorded by [[The Oak Ridge Boys]] on their 1985 album and became the title cut. He was also an in-demand studio musician, playing and singing on sessions for [[Gene Clark]], [[Dillard & Clark]], [[Poco (band)|Poco]], [[Dan Fogelberg]] and others. After an early 1977 UK tour reunited him with [[Roger McGuinn]] and [[Gene Clark]], the trio stayed together as [[McGuinn, Clark & Hillman]] for two albums<ref name=\"LarkinCountry\"/> (on which Hillman continued his songwriting collaboration with Knobler) and one under the McGuinn-Hillman name, with a hit single in 1979's \"Don't You Write Her Off\".\n\n=== The Desert Rose Band (1985\u20131994, 2008) ===\n{{Main article|The Desert Rose Band}}\nBy the early 1980s Hillman had returned to his bluegrass and country roots, recording two acclaimed (mainly acoustic) albums for [[Sugar Hill Records (bluegrass)|Sugar Hill Records]] with singer/guitarist/banjo player [[Herb Pedersen]] (a former member of [[The Dillards]]). Soon after, Hillman and Pedersen formed the [[Desert Rose Band]];<ref name=\"LarkinCountry\"/> this proved to be Hillman's most commercially successful post-Byrds project. Their self-titled debut album in 1987 generated two [[Record chart|Top Ten]] country hits in \"Love Reunited\" (written with Steve Hill), \"One Step Forward\" and the number-one single \"He's Back and I'm Blue.\" From 1987 until late 1993 the band recorded five albums and one Greatest Hits package and had a string of 16 country-music [[Billboard magazine|hits]] (the majority of which were in the country Top Ten) and a number of [[Academy of Country Music]] awards before disbanding in 1994. As Hillman said, \"We definitely quit while we were ahead.\"\n\nChris Hillman, Herb Pedersen, JayDee Maness, John Jorgenson, Bill Bryson, and Steve Duncan performed their first reunion concert on August 27, 2008  in Solana Beach, CA. Before this date Chris Hillman and Herb Pedersen were as a duo joined by John Jorgenson on May 2, 2008 for a small DRB set at the [[Station Inn]] in Nashville. This six-man lineup is the best known, and includes all of the original members present on the hit albums from the 1980s. At this show, Hillman said it was the first time they had played together in 19 years. They went through a string of DRB hits but were unable to play \"He's Back and I'm Blue\" because Hillman said he had forgotten the words. This sold-out show prompted Hillman and the band to play a handful of other reunion shows at  music festivals throughout the U.S. Several of these were recorded for inclusion on a live album, which Hillman hopes to release in the U.S. and Europe. If released, this will be the Desert Rose Band's only live album.\n\n=== 1990s and beyond ===\n[[File:ChrisHillman.jpg|thumb|Hillman in 2004]]\nAt the peak of the Desert Rose Band's success, Hillman began appearing infrequently with McGuinn. A duet recorded by the pair for the [[Nitty Gritty Dirt Band]]'s ''[[Will The Circle Be Unbroken Vol. II]]'' album, \"You Ain't Going Nowhere\", reached the Country Top 10 in 1989. Soon the pair joined Crosby in a reformed Byrds, playing a handful of club dates. In 1990 they appeared at a tribute to [[Roy Orbison]], performing \"Mr. Tambourine Man\" with the song's composer [[Bob Dylan]]. That same year the Byrds cut four new songs for inclusion in a career-spanning box set, and in 1991 they were inducted into the [[Rock and Roll Hall of Fame]]. In 1996 Hillman reunited with Desert Rose Band alumnus Herb Pederson for the CD ''Bakersfield Bound''. ''Like a Hurricane'' (1998) and three bluegrass-flavored releases on [[Rounder Records]] with Pedersen, [[Larry Rice (musician)|Larry Rice]], and [[Tony Rice]] followed. He appeared on the 1999 album ''[[Return of the Grievous Angel: A Tribute to Gram Parsons]]'' in a duet with [[Steve Earle]] on \"High Fashion Queen\" (which Hillman wrote with Parsons).\n\nAfter a brief hiatus Hillman and Pedersen returned with ''Way Out West'' (2002), a 17-track collection of country, [[roots rock]] and [[Americana (music)|Americana]]; this was followed by ''The Other Side'' (2005). In 2010 he recorded \"Live at Edwards Barn\" with Herb Pedersen for Rounder Records.\n\nHillman has continued to write, perform and tour, with dates in 2017 with Herb Pedersen and John Jorgenson.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chrishillman.com/calendar.html |title=Tour Dates |publisher=Chris Hillman |access-date=2017-10-07}}</ref>  He released his latest album, ''Bidin' My Time'' (2017), co-produced with [[Tom Petty]], featuring guests including Roger McGuinn, David Crosby and members of The Heartbreakers. This has been described as \"a kind of summing up of Hillman's long and varied career, incorporating the folk, bluegrass, country and rock styles he's touched on over the years.\"<ref>{{cite magazine|last1=Graff|first1=Gary|title=Byrds Legend Chris Hillman Premieres Tom Petty-Produced 'Bidin' My Time' Album: Exclusive|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/rock/7968856/chris-hillman-bidin-my-time-album|magazine=Billboard|access-date=October 7, 2017|date=September 19, 2017}}</ref>\n\nAlong with Roger McGuinn, Marty Stuart and his Fabulous Superlatives, Hillman toured in the U.S. with the 50th Anniversary of the Sweetheart of the Rodeo, to sold out venues and outstanding reviews.\n\nHis memoir, ''Time Between: My Life as a Byrd, Burrito Brother and Beyond,''  was published by BMG Books in November 2020, with positive reviews in Rolling Stone, The Wall Street Journal, Associated Press, and now in the second printing.\n\n==Personal life==\nChris Hillman identifies as a Christian although his father was Jewish.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://thebluegrasssituation.com/read/counsel-of-elders-chris-hillman-on-looking-across-time/|title=Counsel of Elders: Chris Hillman on Looking Across Time|date=2017-11-10|website=The Bluegrass Situation|language=en-US|access-date=2020-01-28}}</ref> He married  former record executive Connie Pappas in 1979, who influenced him to affiliate with the [[Greek Orthodox Archdiocese of America|Greek Orthodox Church]]. He later stated, \"I\u2019m still learning. You know what I do on Sundays? I sing in a choir. I sing in a Greek Orthodox choir, and I\u2019m the only hillbilly tenor in the Orthodox Church.\"<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.patheos.com/blogs/joeljmiller/2013/11/i-like-the-christian-life-chris-hillman-talks-about-his-faith/ | title=I like the Christian life: The Byrds' Hillman talks about his faith | date=November 5, 2013 }}</ref> Hillman and Pappas have two children, Catherine and Nicholas.<ref name=\"bbc\">{{Cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/entertainment-arts-43547436 |title=5 pop songs you didn't know were about God |last=Savage |first=Mark |publisher=[[BBC]] |date=27 March 2018}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n{{Main| Chris Hillman discography}}\n\n=== Other Singles ===\n{| Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Robin_and_Linda_Williams","to":"Robin and Linda Williams"}],"pages":{"5148425":{"pageid":5148425,"ns":0,"title":"Robin and Linda Williams","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American folk music duo}}\n{{BLP sources|date=October 2018}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=November 2020}}\n\n{{Infobox musical artist\n|name                = Robin and Linda Williams \n|image                 = \n|caption            = \n|background          = group_or_band \n|genre               = {{flatlist|\n*[[Country music|Country]]\n*[[Folk music|folk]]}}\n|years_active        = 1971\u2013present\n| label               = {{flatlist|\n* Flashlight\n*[[Red House Records|Red House]]\n*[[Sugar Hill Records (bluegrass)|Sugar Hill]]}}\n| associated_acts     = [[The Hopeful Gospel Quartet]]\n| website                 = {{URL|www.robinandlinda.com/}}\n}}\n'''Robin and Linda Williams''' are a husband-and-wife singer-songwriter [[folk music]] duo from [[Virginia]]. They met in [[South Carolina]] in 1971,<ref name=\"TSD\">{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/115934889|title=Country singers Robin, Linda Williams live at the Mainstay|work=[[The Star Democrat]]|date=December 11, 2009|accessdate=October 21, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/70484420|title=Robin & Linda Williams: They're in the company of strangers|work=Index-Journal|date=March 19, 2000|accessdate=October 21, 2018}}</ref> and began performing in 1973.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/296140489|title=Singer electrifying: Review|first=Lori|last=Farmer|work=[[Mansfield News Journal]]|date=July 23, 1993|accessdate=October 21, 2018}}</ref>\n\nThe Williamses appeared on [[Garrison Keillor]]'s ''[[A Prairie Home Companion]]'' radio show from 1975.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/279146457/|title=Robin and Linda Williams are ingrained like family|work=[[The Morning Call]]|date=December 16, 2007|accessdate=October 21, 2018}}</ref> The duo were members of the Hopeful Gospel Quartet with Keillor and Kate MacKenzie.<ref name=\"TSD\"/><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/274534576|title=Williamsburg Theater to 'Companion' regulars|first=Tony|last=Gabriele|date=January 4, 2002|work=[[Daily Press (Virginia)|Daily Press]]|accessdate=October 21, 2018}}</ref> After touring with [[Mary Chapin Carpenter]] in 1993,<ref>{{cite news|url=https://eu.pressconnects.com/story/entertainment/2017/05/30/robin-linda-williams-play-saturday-oxford/102329188/|title=Robin and Linda Williams play Saturday in Oxford|work=[[Press & Sun-Bulletin]]|date=May 30, 2017|accessdate=October 21, 2018}}</ref> the pair later sang on her [[Grammy Award]]-winning album ''[[Stones in the Road]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://prairiehome.publicradio.org/programs/20010505/guests.shtml|title=A Prairie Home Companion bio of Robin & Linda Williams|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171124123054/http://prairiehome.publicradio.org/programs/20010505/guests.shtml|archive-date=November 24, 2017|publisher=[[American Public Media]]|date=May 5, 2001|accessdate=July 5, 2008}}</ref> ''Sugar for Sugar'' spent 11 weeks in the top 20 of the [[Americana (music)|Americana]] Chart in the ''[[Gavin Report]]'' in 1996.{{citation needed|date=October 2018}} In 2004, they switched labels, recording ''Deeper Waters'' as their first release on [[Red House Records]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/391655377|title=Robin and Linda Williams, \"Deeper Waters\" (Red House)|first=Rich|last=Harris|work=[[Globe Gazette]]|date=February 29, 2004|accessdate=October 21, 2018}}</ref>\n\nThe Williamses appeared in the film ''[[A Prairie Home Companion (film)|A Prairie Home Companion]]''.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/279146462|title='Prairie Home' guitarist Pat Donohue a wearer of many shoes|first=Geoff|last=Gehman|work=The Morning Call|date=December 16, 2007|accessdate=October 21, 2018}}</ref> They appeared on the ''[[WoodSongs Old-Time Radio Hour]]'', hosted by [[Michael Johnathon]].\n\n==Discography==\n*''Robin & Linda Williams'' (1975)\n*''Shenandoah Moon'' (1977)\n*''Welcome Table'' (1978)\n*''Dixie Highway Sign'' (1979)\n*''Harmony'' (1981)\n*''Close As We Can Get'' (1984)\n*''Nine 'Til Midnight'' (1985)\n*''All Broken Hearts Are the Same'' (1988)\n*''Rhythm of Love'' (1990)\n*''Turn Toward Tomorrow''\n*''Robin & Linda Williams & Their Fine Group Live'' (1994)\n*''Good News'' (1995)\n*''Sugar for Sugar'' (2013)\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n== External links ==\n*[http://www.robinandlinda.com/ Official Site]\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Williams, Robin and Linda}}\n[[Category:American bluegrass music groups]]\n[[Category:American country music groups]]\n[[Category:American country music duos]]\n[[Category:American folk musical duos]]\n[[Category:Fast Folk <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Tim_Hus","to":"Tim Hus"}],"pages":{"12236890":{"pageid":12236890,"ns":0,"title":"Tim Hus","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{BLP sources|date=October 2021}}\n{{Use Canadian English|date=October 2011}}\n{{Infobox musical artist| <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject Musicians -->\n| name            = Tim Hus\n| image             =Image:Tim Hus 7.JPG \n| image_size        = 200px\n| caption        = '''Tim Hus''' performing on Stephen Avenue Mall in [[Calgary]], [[Alberta]]\n| background      = solo_singer\n| birth_name      = \n| birth_date      = \n| birth_place     = \n| origin          = \n| instruments     = Vocals, guitar\n| genre           = [[Country music|Country]], [[Folk music|folk]]\n| occupation      = Singer-songwriter, musician\n| years_active    = \n| label           = [[Stony Plain Records]]\n| associated_acts =\n| website         = {{URL|https://www.timhus.ca|Tim Hus}}\n}}\n\n'''Tim Hus''' (born in [[Nelson, British Columbia]])<ref name=\"Myles\" /> is a [[Canadians|Canadian]] [[country music|country]]/[[folk music|folk]] singer, based out of [[Calgary]], [[Alberta]], Canada.\n\nTim Hus and his Travelin' Band, which includes bull [[fiddle]]r Riley Tubbs, Billy MacInnis on lead guitar and fiddle, and occasionally Pat Phillips on drums, have toured from coast to coast performing their true Canadian music. His music is coined as \"Canadiana Cowboy Music\" and tells tales of the Historic West and those who formed it. Tim has shared the stage with many other great talents such as Canadian legend [[Stompin' Tom Connors]], [[Ian Tyson]], [[Tim Harwill]] and [[Gary Fjellgaard]] and worked with [[Corb Lund]] on the song \"Hurtin' Albertan\".\n\nHe has worked as a carpenter's helper, framer, warehouse hand, [[forklift]] driver, van driver, treeplanter, brewery worker, beer truck driver, fruit picker, fisherman, pine cone picker, sawhand, cabinet maker, well driller, painter, courier, assembly line worker, salmon farmer, furniture mover, labourer, and a maintenance man.\n\nIn September 2016, Hus fell while helping a friend repair a roof, shattering his heel. During the resulting time in hospital, somebody used Hus's identity to open several credit card accounts.<ref name=\"Myles\">{{cite news |last1=Myles |first1=Ruth |title=Housebound on the Range: Smashed heel won't stop Stompin' Tom disciple Tim Hus |url=https://calgaryherald.com/life/swerve/housebound-on-the-range-smashed-heel-wont-stop-stompin-tom-disciple-tim-hus |access-date=10 October 2021 |work=Calgary Herald |date=3 February 2017 |language=en-CA}}</ref>\n\nHe is married to anthropologist Janelle Baker. They have two sons.<ref name=\"Myles\" />\n\n== Discography ==\n*''Songs of West Canada'' (2002)\n*''Alberta Crude'' (2004)\n*''Huskies and Husqvarnas'' (2006)\n*''Bush Pilot Buckaroo'' (2008)\n*''Hockeytown'' (2010)\n*''Western Star'' (2013)\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n== External links ==\n{{Commons category|Tim Hus}}\n* [https://www.timhus.ca/ Official Tim Hus website]\n* {{cite news | url=http://jam.canoe.ca/Music/Artists/H/Hus_Tim/2007/08/04/4393477.html | archive-url=https://archive.today/20130115061757/http://jam.canoe.ca/Music/Artists/H/Hus_Tim/2007/08/04/4393477.html | url-status=usurped | archive-date=January 15, 2013 | publisher=[[Jam!]] | title=Tim Hus a Canadiana cowboy | first=Jenny | last=Feniak | accessdate=2008-08-05 | date=4 August 2007 }}\n* {{cite news | url=http://www.canada.com/cityguides/edmonton/story.html?id=be8d52b3-465f-4f3d-8c54-76f623cc030d | title=Cowboy troubadour Tim Hus riding high | first=Peter | last=North | accessdate=2008-08-05 | date=5 June 2008 | newspaper=[[Edmonton Journal]] }}\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Hus, Tim}}\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:Canadian country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Musicians from British Columbia]]\n[[Category:People from Nelson, British Columbia]]\n[[Category:Stony Plain Records artists]]\n[[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]]\n\n\n{{Canada-singer-songwriter-stub}}"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"pages":{"1762370":{"pageid":1762370,"ns":0,"title":"Valdy","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|Canadian musician (b. 1945)}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name                    = Valdy\n| image                   = Valdy performing in 1976.jpg\n| caption                 = Valdy in 1976\n| image_size              =\n| background              = solo_singer\n| birth_name              = Paul Valdemar Horsdal\n| birth_date              = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1945|9|1}}\n| birth_place             = [[Ottawa]], Ontario, Canada\n| origin                  =\n| instrument              = [[lead vocals|Vocals]], guitar\n| genre                   = [[folk music|Folk]], [[country music|country]]\n| occupation              = Singer-songwriter, musician\n| spouse = {{marriage|Kathleen Fraser|1986}}\n| years_active            = 1960s\u2013present\n| label                   =\n| associated_acts         =\n| website                     =\n}}{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2015}}\n\n'''Paul Valdemar Horsdal''', {{post-nominals|country=CAN|CM}} (born 1 September 1945<ref name=birth>{{cite news | newspaper=[[Ottawa Journal]] | date=3 September 1945 | page=12 | title=Want Ads: Births }}<br />{{cite news | newspaper=[[Ottawa Citizen]] | title=Want Ads: Births | page=12 | date=3 September 1945 }}</ref>), commonly known as '''Valdy''', is a Canadian folk and country musician whose solo career began in the early 1970s. He is known for \"Rock and Roll Song\", his first mainstream single.<ref name=Jam>{{cite encyclopedia | url=http://jam.canoe.ca/Music/Pop_Encyclopedia/V/Valdy.html | archive-url=https://archive.today/20130115071025/http://jam.canoe.ca/Music/Pop_Encyclopedia/V/Valdy.html | url-status=usurped | archive-date=15 January 2013 | access-date=2009-05-06 | title=Valdy (biography) | encyclopedia=The Canadian Pop Encyclopedia|publisher=[[Jam!]]/Canoe }}</ref><ref name=\"Inc.1972\">{{cite magazine|author=Michael Bennett|title=Western Canada:Activity abounds on all fronts|magazine=Billboard|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YUUEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA48|date=30 September 1972|publisher=[[Nielsen Business Media, Inc.]]|pages=48\u2013|issn=0006-2510}}</ref> Valdy is the winner of two [[Juno Award]]s for Folk Singer of the Year and Folk Entertainer of the Year and has received seven additional Juno nominations. His fourteen albums, including four which are certified gold, have achieved sales of nearly half a million copies.\n\n==Early life and education==\nValdy was born and grew up in [[Ottawa, Ontario]],<ref>[https://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/valdy-emc \"Valdy\"]. ''The Canadian Encyclopedia'', by Holly Quan, 7 February 2006</ref> the third child of Danish [[portrait photographer]] Paul Horsdal and Lillian Horsdal (n\u00e9e West), an English nurse and writer.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.cheknews.ca/country-story-canadian-folk-singer-valdy-289165/ | title=Your Country, Your Story: Canadian Folk Singer Legend, Valdy | publisher=CHEK News | first=Veronica | last=Cooperon | date=15 March 2017}}</ref> He studied guitar and piano,<ref>[https://www.allmusic.com/artist/valdy-mn0000837237/biography \" Valdy\"]. ''AllMusic'', biography by John Bush</ref> and attended [[Lisgar Collegiate Institute]].\n\n==Career==\n===Early career===\nValdy was a member of The London Towne Criers during the 1960s and subsequently joined [[Montreal]] band The Prodigal Sons.  He then moved to [[Victoria, British Columbia|Victoria]], where he worked with various rock and country musicians, including [[Blake Emmons]].<ref name=Jam />\n\nWhen he was 25 Valdy bought several acres of land in [[Sooke]], BC, and began farming.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.sookenewsmirror.com/entertainment/legendary-folk-singer-valdy-returns-to-sidney-for-fourth-show-in-four-years/ | title=Legendary folk singer \"Valdy returns to Sidney for fourth show in four years\" | newspaper=Sooke News Mirror | first=Hugo | last=Wong | date=29 December 2017}}</ref> He began performing as a solo artist, and in 1972 recorded his \"Rock and Roll Song\" on Haida/[[A&M Records|A&M]]; it became a hit.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.keremeosreview.com/entertainment/valdy-performs-to-sell-out-crowd-at-the-grist-mill/ | title=Valdy performs to sell out crowd at the Grist Mill | work=Keremeos Review | date=2 September 2014}}</ref><ref name=\"Makin2015\">{{cite book|author=David Makin|title=Reantasy, Montreal: The Book to Read, the Place to Be|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NpCzCgAAQBAJ&pg=PT46|date=5 October 2015|publisher=AuthorHouse|isbn=978-1-5049-5071-8|page=46}}</ref> His music was featured in the 1972 Steve McQueen film ''[[The Getaway (1972 film)|The Getaway]]''. In 1973 he won a Juno Award for Outstanding Folk Performance.<ref name=\"Inc.1973a\">{{cite magazine|title=This Year's Winners|magazine=Billboard|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3CcEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA56|date=7 April 1973|publisher=Nielsen Business Media, Inc.|pages=56\u2013|issn=0006-2510}}</ref>\n\nValdy recorded a live album, ''Family Gathering'', through [[A&M Records|A&M]]; it was recorded at [[Massey Hall]] in Toronto and released in 1974.\n\nValdy appeared on the CBC TV show ''[[The Beachcombers]]'' as the environmental activist \"Halibut\" Stu.  He also secured a part in the reunion production of ''[[The New Beachcombers]]'' performing a song he wrote, \"It's The Water,\" as part of a jug band.\n\n===1980s===\nIn 1986, Valdy made a guest appearance as himself in the popular 1980's Canadian children's television show, ''[[Today's Special]]'' (episode entitled: \"trash\"). He also guest appeared as himself on ''[[Sharon, Lois & Bram's Elephant Show]]'' in the third-season episode titled \"Growing Up\".\n\n===2000s===\nIn 2000, Valdy released the album ''Contenders'' with country musician Gary Fjellgaard.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://exclaim.ca/music/article/valdy_gary_fjellgaard-contenders | title=Valdy & Gary Fjellgaard Contenders | magazine=Exclaim! | first=Eric | last=Thom | date=1 April 2000}}</ref> He continued to tour with Fjellgaard for many years.<ref>[https://www.kamloopsthisweek.com/entertainment/contenders-still-valdy-on-why-he-s-still-on-the-road-1.23477503 \"Contenders, still: Valdy on why he's still on the road\"]. Sean Brady ''Kamloops This Week'', 26 October 2018</ref>\n\nValdy recorded 2003's ''Viva Valdy: Live at Last'' during the Rack-On-Tour. On 21 November 2005, Valdy was awarded the National Achievement Award by [[SOCAN]] at the 2005 SOCAN Awards in Toronto.<ref>[http://www.socan.ca/about/awards/2005-socan-awards \"2005 SOCAN Awards\"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180105181912/http://www.socan.ca/about/awards/2005-socan-awards |date=5 January 2018 }}. SOCAN website</ref>\n\n===2010s===\nValdy was appointed a member of the [[Order of Canada]] in June 2011.<ref>{{cite news |date=30 June 2011 |title=Appointments to the Order of Canada |publisher=[[Governor General of Canada]] |url=http://www.gg.ca/document.aspx?id=14175 |access-date=1 July 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110704224012/http://www.gg.ca/document.aspx?id=14175 |archive-date=2011-07-04}}</ref><ref name=devlin />\nIn 2012, he released his 18th album, ''Read Between the Lines'', and toured across Canada in support.<ref>[https://www.vernonmorningstar.com/life/street-sounds-folk-troubadour-remains-relevant/ \"Street Sounds: Folk troubadour remains relevant\"]. ''Vernon Morning Star'', Dean Gordon-Smith, 9 Nov. 2012</ref><ref>[https://www.cbc.ca/nb/mt/east-coast-music/2012/10/valdy-in-province-for-tour-new-album.html \"Valdy in Province For Tour, New Album\"]. ''CBC East Coast Music'', Bob Mersereau, 4 Oct 2012.</ref>\n\nIn 2013, Valdy toured in Canada with New Zealand guitarist Graham Wardrop.<ref name=devlin>[https://www.timescolonist.com/folk-stalwart-valdy-at-home-on-the-coast-1.653230 \"Folk stalwart Valdy at home on the coast\"]. Mike Devlin, ''Times Colonist'', 8 October 2013</ref> In 2014, he continued to perform at folk festivals, including Kingsville Folk with jazz pianist Karel Roessingh and Nadina Mackie-Jackson on bassoon.<ref>[http://folkrootsradio.com/festival-review-kingsville-folk/ \"Review: Kingsville Folk 2014\"]. ''Folk Roots Radio'', JAN HALL</ref>\n\nAs of 2018, Valdy continues to regularly tour across Canada, including a performance on the main stage at the Mariposa Folk Festival.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.barrietoday.com/local-news/mariposa-folk-festival-a-record-breaker-13-photos-978105 | title=Mariposa Folk Festival a record breaker | work=Barrie Today | date=7 July 2018 | first=Nathan | last=Taylor}}</ref>\n\n==Personal life==\n\nIn 1986, Valdy married Kathleen Fraser Horsdal. Kathleen is a teacher, hospice worker and song co-writer. His daughter with his then partner Lindsay Whalen is actress [[Chelah Horsdal]] (b. 1973).<ref>{{cite web |title=Dear Daddy: The father-child bond is many things, but it's almost always complicated |url=https://theprovince.com/life/dear-daddy-the-father-child-bond-is-many-things-but-its-almost-always-complicated |website=theprovince.com}}</ref><ref name=tvg>{{cite web|url=http://www.tvguide.com/celebrities/chelah-horsdal/bio/227049|title=Chelah Horsdal|publisher=TVGuide.com|accessdate=January 11, 2016|archivedate=October 4, 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151004061033/http://www.tvguide.com/celebrities/chelah-horsdal/bio/227049}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n! [https://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/valdy-emc The Canadian Encyclopedia: Valdy]\n* {{Discogs artist|Valdy}}\n*{{IMDb name|id=1284660}}\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n[[Category:1945 <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Tommy_Cash","to":"Tommy Cash"}],"pages":{"2365819":{"pageid":2365819,"ns":0,"title":"Tommy Cash","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American country musician (1940\u20132024)}}\n{{About|the American country singer|the Estonian rapper|Tommy Cash (rapper)}}\n{{More citations needed|date=September 2024}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=October 2015}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name         = Tommy Cash\n| image        = Tommy Cash.jpg\n| caption      = Cash in 1969\n| birth_name   = \n| alias        = \n| birth_date   = {{birth date|1940|04|05}}\n| birth_place  = [[Dyess, Arkansas]], U.S.\n| death_date   = {{death date and age|2024|09|13|1940|04|05}}\n| death_place  = \n| instrument   = {{hlist|Vocals|guitar}}\n| genre        = {{hlist|[[Country music|Country]]|[[Contemporary folk music|folk]]}}\n| occupation   = {{hlist|Musician|singer|songwriter}}\n| years_active = 1965\u20132016\n| label        = {{hlist|[[Epic Records]]|[[House of Cash]]}}\n| website      = {{URL|tommycash.com}}\n}}\n\n'''Tommy Cash''' (April 5, 1940 \u2013 September 13, 2024) was an American [[Country music|country]] musician. His elder brother was [[Johnny Cash]].\n\n==Background and career==\nCash was born in [[Dyess, Arkansas]], on April 5, 1940,<ref name=\"LarkinCountry\">{{cite book |title=[[The Encyclopedia of Popular Music|The Guinness Who's Who of Country Music]] |editor=[[Colin Larkin]] |publisher=[[Guinness World Records|Guinness Publishing]] |date=1993 |edition=First |isbn=0-85112-726-6 |page=78}}</ref> the youngest of four sons and three daughters of Ray and Carrie (Rivers) Cash (one of whom was [[Johnny Cash]], born eight years earlier). He formed his first band in high school. After high-school graduation, he enlisted in the [[United States Army]], and worked as a [[disc jockey]] for the [[American Forces Network|Armed Forces Radio]] network.<ref name=\"LarkinCountry\" />\n\nAfter the Army, Cash played with [[Hank Williams Jr.]], and eventually gained a record deal from [[Musicor Records]] in 1965. A year later, he joined [[United Artists Records]] and just missed the [[country music|Country]] Top 40 in 1968 with \"The Sounds of Goodbye.\"\n\nIn late 1969, while on [[Epic Records]], he delivered his biggest hit, a tune dedicated to [[John F. Kennedy]], [[Robert F. Kennedy]], and [[Martin Luther King Jr.]], titled \"Six White Horses\".<ref name=\"LarkinCountry\" /> In 1970, he had a pair of top-10 singles, \"One Song Away\" and \"Rise and Shine\", written by [[Carl Perkins]].<ref name=\"LarkinCountry\" /> Cash's final top-20 hit, \"[[I Recall a Gypsy Woman]]\", was released in 1973.<ref name=\"LarkinCountry\" />\n\nCash also acted in the 2016 film ''[[The River Thief]]''. He continued to tour until at least late 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url = https://www.tommycash.com/tour/|title = Tour|website = Tommy Cash|accessdate = September 14, 2024}}</ref>\n\n==Other interests==\nCash was a licensed realtor in Tennessee, and an agent with Crye-Leike Real Estate Services in Nashville. He was listing agent for the sale of Johnny Cash and [[June Carter Cash]]'s home in [[Hendersonville, Tennessee]], after they both died in 2003.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tommycash.crye-leike.com/ |title=Tommy Cash \u2212 Crye-Leike|website=Tommycah.crye-leike.com |access-date=January 16, 2011}}</ref>\n\n==Death==\nCash died on September 13, 2024, at the age of 84.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.kait8.com/2024/09/14/tommy-cash-brother-johnny-cash-dies/|title=Tommy Cash, brother of Johnny Cash, dies|date=September 14, 2024 |website=Kait8.com |access-date=September 15, 2024}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n! Year\n! Album\n! <small>[[Top Country Albums|US Country]]</small>\n! Records \n|-\n| | ''[[Fade to Black: Memories of Johnny]]'' || |\n|}\n\n===Singles===\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Year\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Single\n! colspan=\"2\"| Chart Positions\n! single only\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 1969\n| \"Your Lovin' Takes the Leavin' Out of Me\"\n| align=\"center\"| 43\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n| ''Your Lovin' Takes the Leavin' Out of Me''\n|-\n| \"[[Six rowspan=\"3\"| ''Rise and Shine''\n|-\n| \"One Song Away\"\n| align=\"center\"| 9\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n|-\n| \"The Tears on Lincoln's Face\"\n| align=\"center\"| 36\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n|-\n| rowspan=\"3\"| 1971\n| \"So This Is Love\"\n| align=\"center\"| 20\n| align=\"center\"| 28\n| rowspan=\"2\"| ''Cash Country''\n|-\n| \"I'm Gonna Write a Song\"\n| align=\"center\"| 28\n| the Circle Be Unbroken\"\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n|-\n| \"Roller Coaster Ride\"\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 1975\n| \"The One I Sing My Love Songs To\"\n| align=\"center\"| 58\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n| rowspan=\"2\"| ''Only a Stone''\n|-\n| \"Only a Stone\"\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n| single only\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 1978\n| \"Take My Love to Rita\"\n| align=\"center\"| 98\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n| rowspan=\"2\"| ''The New Spirit''\n|-\n| \"In Crowd\"\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 1979\n| \"I'd Be Better Off Alone\"\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n| rowspan=\"4\"| singles only\n|-\n| \"When the Lovin' Starts\"\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n|-\n| 1982\n| \"(I Used to Want to Be a) Cowboy\"\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n| rowspan=\"2\"| ''25th Anniversary Album''\n|-\n| \"Guess Things Happen That Way\" <small>(w/ [[Johnny Cash]])</small>\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n|-\n| 1996\n| \"Man of Experience\"\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n| single only\n|-\n| 2009\n| \"Ramblin' Kind\"\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n| ''Fade to Black''\n|}\n*<sup>A</sup>\"Six White Horses\" peaked at No.&nbsp;79 on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Billboard Hot 100|Hot 100]] and No.&nbsp;72 on the ''[[RPM (magazine)|RPM]]'' Top Singles chart in Canada.\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n{{Commons category}}\n* [http://www.tommycash.com/ Official website]\n* {{AllMusic}}\n* {{Discogs artist|Tommy Cash}}\n* {{IMDb name|1652223}}\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Cash, Tommy}}\n[[Category:1940 births]]\n[[Category:2024 deaths]]\n[[Category:American male singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:American people of English descent]]\n[[Category:American people of Scottish descent]]\n[[Category:Country musicians from Arkansas]]\n[[Category:Cash\u2013Carter family]]\n[[Category:People from Mississippi County, Arkansas]]\n[[Category:United Artists Records artists]]\n[[Category:Monument Records artists]]\n[[Category:Elektra Records artists]]\n[[Category:Epic Records artists]]\n[[Category:United States Army soldiers]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from Arkansas]]\n[[Category:American male film actors]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"pages":{"47319667":{"pageid":47319667,"ns":0,"title":"EmiSunshine","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer-songwriter}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name             = EmiSunshine\n| image            = File:EmiSunshine_WoodSongs_2023.jpg\n| image_size       = \n| landscape        = <!-- yes, if wide image, otherwise leave blank -->\n| alt              = \n| caption          = EmiSunshine in 2023\n| birth_name       = Emilie Sunshine Hamilton<ref name=\"ISWC\">{{cite web|url=http://iswcnet.cisac.org/MWI/result/list.do?pageNumber=1&localEngineCode=999|title=Your query : Creator's Name begins with HAMILTON EMILIE on any territories (Domestic works)|website=[[International Standard Musical Work Code|ISWC]]|access-date=February 17, 2020}}</ref>\n| birth_date       = {{birth date and age|2004|06|08}}\n| birth_place      = [[Madisonville, Tennessee]], United States\n| origin           = \n| genre            = [[Country music|Country]], folk, indie, blues, rock\n| occupation       = Singer-songwriter\n| instrument       = Vocals, guitar, ukulele\n| years_active     = 2013\u2013present\n| label            = \n| website          = {{URL|theemisunshine.com}}\n}}\n\n'''Emilie Sunshine Hamilton''' (born June 8, 2004),<ref name=\"bostonglobe.com\">{{cite web|url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/arts/music/2015/07/09/rootsy-prodigy-emisunshine-shows-her-pluck-somerville/1HhJsdePxT2AKRCtwCAZ4K/story.html|title=Rootsy prodigy EmiSunshine shows her pluck in Somerville|work=BostonGlobe.com}}</ref> known professionally as '''EmiSunshine''', is an American singer-songwriter from [[Madisonville, Tennessee]], and a [[Internet celebrity|social media personality]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nashvillescene.com/nashville/the-10-year-old-ukulele-playing-wunderkind-is-the-real-deal-says-marty-stuart/Content?oid=4952796|title=Ten-year-old ukulele-playing wunderkind EmiSunshine is the 'real deal,' says Marty Stuart|work=Nashville Scene|access-date=2015-09-08|archive-date=2016-03-25|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160325231400/http://www.nashvillescene.com/nashville/the-10-year-old-ukulele-playing-wunderkind-is-the-real-deal-says-marty-stuart/Content?oid=4952796|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref name=\"today.com\">{{cite web|url=http://www.today.com/video/today/54806485|title=Emily Sunshine Hamilton, 9, sings blues on TODAY|work=TODAY.com}}</ref> Her performance of [[Jimmie Rodgers (country singer)|Jimmie Rodgers]]' \"[[Blue yodel|Blue Yodel No.&nbsp;6]]\" was posted on [[YouTube]] in 2014 and received over 1&nbsp;million views and attention from the ''[[Today (U.S. TV program)|Today]]'' show ([[NBC Studios (New York City)|NBC]]) and [[Music Row]].<ref name=\"today.com\"/><ref name=\"Tennessean.com\">{{cite web|url=http://www.tennessean.com/story/entertainment/music/2014/12/11/emi-sunshine-sings-like-old-soul-sparkles-stage-age/20281257/|title=Emi Sunshine sings like old soul, sparkles at age 10|date=December 11, 2014|work=The Tennessean}}</ref> Her YouTube series, ''Americana Corner'', featured [[Holly Williams (musician)|Holly Williams]] for its debut episode and earned a feature story in ''[[Rolling Stone]]''{{'s}} country section.<ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/videos/see-holly-williams-perform-hank-classic-with-11-year-old-prodigy-20150625|title=See Holly Williams Perform Hank Classic With 11-Year-Old Prodigy|magazine=Rolling Stone|date=25 June 2015 }}</ref>\n\nEmiSunshine's music is generally described as [[Country music|country]], but also exhibits [[Americana (music)|Americana]], [[Bluegrass music|bluegrass]], [[blues]] and [[Gospel music|gospel]] influences. She has described her style as \"old-time music turned upside-down.\"<ref name=\"guitargirlmag.com\">{{cite web|url=https://guitargirlmag.com/interviews/emisunshine-cma-fest-old-school-music-turned-upside-down/|title=EmiSunshine at CMA Fest: old school music turned upside down|work=GuitarGirlMag.com|date=8 July 2018 }}</ref> She is known for writing and performing songs about mature subjects not ordinarily associated with artists her age, including [[murder]], [[Poverty in the United States|poverty]], [[Politics of the United States|politics]], [[autism]] and [[family dysfunction]]. In 2017, ''Rolling Stone'' named her among \"10 new country artists you need to know.\"<ref name=\"RollingStone.com\">{{cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country-lists/10-new-country-artists-you-need-to-know-september-2017-199288/emisunshine-111280/|title=10 new country artists you need to know|date=September 12, 2017|magazine=Rolling Stone}}</ref>\n\n==Early life==\nEmiSunshine was born on June 8, 2004, in [[Madisonville, Tennessee]], to Randall Hamilton, a musician and recording engineer, and Alisha Karol Hamilton, a songwriter and nurse. Randall and Alisha have said that, even as a baby, EmiSunshine exhibited a remarkable musical ability, humming along to songs with perfect pitch. \"I noticed it at nine months,\" Randall told the ''[[Chicago Tribune]]''. \"There was a pure tone in the key of C coming out of her. I thought, 'This baby is something. She may be able to sing when she is older.'\" By the age of three, she was singing with her grandmothers. Her first performance in front of an audience occurred at age four, when she performed \"[[You Are My Sunshine]]\" at the wedding of her aunt and uncle.<ref name=\"ChicagoTribune.com\">{{cite web|url=https://www.chicagotribune.com/entertainment/music/ct-emi-sunshine-gran-old-opry-20150813-story.html|title=EmiSunshine is all country, all the time, at age 11|date=August 13, 2015|work=Chicago Tribune}}</ref>\n\nEmiSunshine began singing in churches and festivals throughout East Tennessee. At the age of seven she simultaneously recorded her first two albums, ''Strong as the Tall Pine'' and ''Wide River to Cross'' in her father's studio with help from her father and her grandfather, \"PaPaw Bill\".<ref name=\"tennessean.com\">{{cite web|url=https://www.tennessean.com/story/entertainment/music/2014/12/11/emi-sunshine-sings-like-old-soul-sparkles-stage-age/20281257/|title=EmiSunshine sings like old soul, sparkles at age 10|date=December 11, 2014|work=The Tennessean}}</ref>\n\n==Career==\n===2013\u20132015: Breakthrough===\nWhen EmiSunshine was nine years old, a fan in her hometown posted a video on YouTube of her singing the [[Jimmie Rodgers (pop singer)|Jimmie Rodgers]] and [[Louis Armstrong]] song \"Blue Yodel No. 6\" at a flea market. The video went viral, attracting millions of views. As a result, she was invited to perform on NBC's [[Today (U.S. TV program)|''Today'']] show. Video of her televised performance attracted even more attention on the Internet and among country music professionals in Nashville.<ref name=\"NewJerseyStage.com\">{{cite web|url=https://www.newjerseystage.com/articles/2018/03/22/an-interview-with-emisunshine/|title=An Interview with EmiSunshine|date=March 22, 2018|work=New Jersey Stage}}</ref>\n\nSoon, she was writing songs and appearing on stage with established artists. In 2014, she made her debut performance at the [[Grand Ole Opry]]. She released her first single, \"Oh Mary, Where Is Your Baby?\" in 2014 and a year later released her next single, \"I Am Able.\" She released the full-length album ''Black Sunday '35'' when she was nine years old. \nAlso during this time, she opened for Willie Nelson in Southern California and Las Vegas, Tanya Tucker and Loretta Lynn in Branson.\n\n===2016\u2013present: Continued success===\nIn 2016, at age 12, EmiSunshine appeared in ''[[The King (2017 American film)|The King]]'', a documentary film about [[Elvis Presley]], which featured celebrities such as [[Emmylou Harris]], [[Rosanne Cash]], [[Alec Baldwin]], [[Ashton Kutcher]] and others.<ref name=\"Columbus Ledger-Enquirer\">{{cite web|url=https://www.ledger-enquirer.com/entertainment/local-events/article228956464.html|title=Tennessee girl in viral YouTube video is now grown-up star you can see in concert|date=April 8, 2019|work=Columbus Ledger-Enquirer}}</ref> In the movie, she sang two songs she had previously written, \u201cDanny Ray\" and \"Johnny June and Jesus,\" which she performed while riding in the backseat of Elvis Presley's 1963 Rolls-Royce Silver Cloud. She later performed at the film's international premiere at the 2017 [[Cannes Film Festival]]. The soundtrack was nominated for a [[Grammy]] award.<ref name=\"Variety.com\">{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2018/music/news/grammy-nominations-2019-complete-list-1203082934/|title=Grammy Awards Nominations: The Complete List|date=December 7, 2018|work=Variety}}</ref>\n\nShe released her fourth studio album, ''Ragged Dreams'', in 2017, which included her two songs from ''The King''. She also attracted attention for another song on that album, \"90 Miles\", which was about [[autism]]. \"I have a really good friend who has autism, and he was treated really differently because of it and it really bothered me,\" she told the ''[[South Bend Tribune]]''. \"I met him and I didn't know that he had autism. The kids would tell me not to talk to him, even adults\u2026 I want this song to be something that just kind of shows people that, hey, they\u2019re just like us.\"<ref name=\"southbendtribune.com\">{{cite web|url=https://www.southbendtribune.com/entertainment/inthebend/music/emisunshine-brings-fresh-face-to-country-music/article_b692f027-309e-54e3-a099-e9caee446b47.html|title=EmiSunshine brings fresh face to country music|date=April 22, 2018|work=South Bend Tribune}}</ref>\n\nShe began working with four-time Grammy-winning producer [[Tony Brown (record producer)|Tony Brown]] in 2017, after she was introduced to him by her manager, Steve Pritchard.<ref name=\"lula1892.com\">{{cite web|url=http://lula1892.com/elvis-strait-to-jesus/|title=Elvis, Strait To Jesus: Tony Brown On His Life In The Music Industry And His Brand New Book|date=June 6, 2018|work=Lula 1892}}</ref>  Emi and Brown co-produced her sixth studio album, ''Family Wars'', which was released in 2019. The album includes a duet with singer-songwriter [[Jim Lauderdale]], back up singing on one song by The McCrary Sisters and creative collaborations with other prominent musical artists in Nashville including songwriters [[Vicky McGehee]], [[Kyle Jacobs (songwriter)|Kyle Jacobs]], [[Chelle Rose]], Autumn McEntire and Fish Fisher. In a review, the music magazine ''[[No Depression (magazine)|No Depression]]'' wrote that the album \"establishes EmiSunshine as a strong creative force\u2026 She's just plain good, with talents outliving the novelty that went along with her earliest exposure at age 9 and establishing her as someone bold and talented enough to tackle today\u2019s issues while honoring yesterday\u2019s folk traditions.\"<ref name=\"nodepression.com\">{{cite web|url=https://www.nodepression.com/album-reviews/15-year-old-emisunshine-balances-darkness-and-light-on-family-wars/|title=15-Year-Old EmiSunshine Balances Darkness and Light on 'Family Wars'|date=October 17, 2019|work=No Depression}}</ref>\n\nOn December 11, 2019, she received The [[ASCAP Foundation]] [[Desmond Child]] Anthem Award in New York City.<ref name=\"musicrow.com\">{{cite web|url=https://musicrow.com/2019/11/emisunshine-to-receive-ascap-foundation-desmond-child-anthem-award-in-new-york/|title=EmiSunshine to receive ASCAP Foundation Desmond Child Anthem Award in New York|date=November 6, 2019|work=Music Row}}</ref> The award was established by [[ASCAP]] Board member, composer and producer Desmond Child to recognize promising young artists. Child called EmiSunshine \"one of the most talented up-and-coming artists and songwriters I've ever heard in AMERICAN music.\"<ref name=\"AllAccess.com\">{{cite web|url=https://www.nodepression.com/album-reviews/15-year-old-emisunshine-balances-darkness-and-light-on-family-wars/|title=ASCAP Foundation Honors EmiSunshine with Desmond Child Anthem Award|date=October 17, 2019|work=No Depression}}</ref>\n\nIn March 2020, acclaimed funk musician [[Bootsy Collins]] invited EmiSunshine to collaborate with him on the song \"Stars\" to benefit the [[Recording Academy]]'s MusiCares COVID-19 Relief Fund. Released on June 12, the single and an accompanying music video featured guest appearances by Dr. [[Cornel West]], [[B\u00e9la Fleck]], [[Steve Jordan (drummer)]], [[Victor Wooten]], [[Olvido Ruiz]], [[Manou Gallo]], [[Uch\u00e9]] and others.<ref name=\"soundslikenashville.com\">{{cite web|url=https://www.soundslikenashville.com/news/bootsy-collins-emisunshine-stars-collaboration/|title=Rock and Roll Hall of Famer Bootsy Collins and Country Upstart EmiSunshine Join Forces on 'Stars'|date=June 12, 2020|work=Sounds Like Nashville}}</ref> A remixed version of \"Stars\" later appeared as \"Stargate\" on Collins' album ''The Power of the One'', which was released on October 23, 2020.<ref name=\"bassmagazine.com\">{{cite web|url=https://bassmagazine.com/artists/bootsy-collins-to-release-new-album-the-power-of-the-one-on-october-23rd|title=Bootsy Collins to Release New Album 'The Power of the One' on October 23rd|date=September 16, 2020|work=Bass Magazine}}</ref>\n\nOn March 21 and 22, 2021, EmiSunshine appeared on ''[[American Idol]]'', performing the [[Johnny Cash]] song \"I Walk the Line\" as a duet with fellow contestant Alex Miller, a 17-year-old singer from Kentucky. Country star [[Luke Bryan]], a judge on the program, gave the pair \"kudos\" and said that Emi \"really carried a lot of that performance.\"<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.yahoo.com/now/american-idol-singers-frightening-face-plant-leaves-judges-contestants-crew-in-shock-021848543.html|title=American Idol singer's frightening face-plant leaves judges, contestants, crew in shock|date=March 23, 2021|work=Yahoo! Entertainment}}</ref> Both artists advanced to the \"Showstopper\" round one week later, but did not continue beyond that.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wideopencountry.com/emisunshine-american-idol/\n|title=EmiSunshine Covers Fellow Folk and Bluegrass Singer at Heart Janis Joplin on 'American Idol'|date=March 31, 2021|work=Wide Open Country}}</ref>\n\nIn February 2022, EmiSunshine released her first solo album, ''Diamonds'', receiving mostly positive reviews, with ''No Depression'' describing it as \u201c(filtering) the traditional sounds of roots music through pop.\u201d<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nodepression.com/album-reviews/emisunshine-takes-a-new-musical-direction-on-solo-outing-diamonds/\n|title=EmiSunshine takes a new direction on solo outing Diamonds|date=February 1, 2022|work=No Depression}}</ref> ''American Songwriter'' wrote that \u201c''Diamonds'' can be considered an ambitious offering from an artist whose talent and ambition reside well beyond her years.\u201d<ref>{{cite web|url=https://americansongwriter.com/review-emisunshine-shares-the-brightness-of-her-being/|title=EmiSunshine shares the brightness of her being|date=April 5, 2022|work=American Songwriter}}</ref>\n\nEmiSunshine's 10th studio album, ''Sideshow'' was released in October 2023.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://tasteofcountry.com/new-country-music-released-this-week-oct-6/\n|title=18 new country songs and albums released this week|date=October 6, 2023|work=Taste of Country}}</ref> In a review, ''Wide Open Country'' described the album as \"another solid example of how to acknowledge the past while pushing folksier music into the future.\"<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wideopencountry.com/country-music-playlist/\n|title=6 New Country Songs You Need to Hear This Week|date=October 6, 2023|work=Wide Open Country}}</ref>\n\nEmiSunshine performs about 150 shows a year across the country. She has performed twice on [[Marty Stuart]]\u2019s Late Night Jam at the [[Ryman Auditorium]] during CMA Music Fest<ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/marty-stuarts-hillbilly-answer-to-cma-fest-20140606|title=Marty Stuart's 'Hillbilly' Answer to CMA Fest|magazine=Rolling Stone|date=6 June 2014 }}</ref> and has had 16 performances at the [[Grand Ole Opry]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.opry.com/artist/emisunshine|title=EMISUNSHINE|work=Grand Ole Opry|access-date=2015-09-08|archive-date=2017-03-31|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170331205218/http://www.opry.com/artist/emisunshine|url-status=dead}}</ref> She has also appeared on several national television shows, including ''[[Little Big Shots]]'', ''[[Song of the Mountains]]'', ''[[WoodSongs Old-Time Radio Hour]]'' and ''[[Pickler & Ben]]''.\n\n==Discography==\n{{BLP unsourced section|date=February 2020}}\n\n===Studio albums===\n\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! style=\"width:16em;\"| Title\n! style=\"width:18em;\"| Album details\n|-\n| scope=\"row\" |''Strong as the Tall Pine''\n|\n* Release date: 2011\n* Label: [[Independent record label|independent]]\n* Formats: CD\n|-\n| scope=\"row\" |''Wide River to Cross''\n|\n* Release date: 2011\n* Label: [[Independent record label|independent]]\n* Formats: CD\n|-\n| scope=\"row\" |''Black Sunday '35''\n|\n* Release date: January 25, 2014\n* Label: [[Independent record label|independent]]\n* Formats: CD, digital\n|-\n|''American Dream''\n|\n* Release date: October 22, 2016\n* Label: [[Independent record label|independent]]\n* Formats: CD, digital\n|-\n|''Ragged Dreams''\n|\n* Release date: August 25, 2017\n* Label: [[Independent record label|independent]]\n* Formats: CD, digital\n|-\n|''Family Wars''\n|\n* Release date: October 18, 2019\n* Label: [[Little Blackbird Records]]\n* Formats: CD, vinyl, digital\n|-\n|''Universe''\n|\n* Release date: January 28, 2022\n* Label: [[Little Blackbird Records]]\n* Formats: CD, digital\n|-\n|''Diamonds''\n|\n* Release date: February 18, 2022\n* Label: [[Little Blackbird Records]]\n* Formats: CD, vinyl, digital\n|-\n|''Sideshow''\n|\n* Release date: October 6, 2023\n* Label: [[Little Blackbird Records]]\n* Formats: CD, vinyl, digital\n|}\n\n===Singles===\n\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! style=\"width:16em;\"| Title\n! style=\"width:18em;\"| Album details\n|-\n| scope=\"row\" |''Stars'' (with Bootsy Collins)\n|\n* Release date: June 12, 2020\n* Label: [[Bootzilla Records]]\n* Formats: Digital\n|-\n| scope=\"row\" |''Stargate'' (with Bootsy Collins)\non the album ''The Power of the One''\n|\n* Release date: October 23, 2020\n* Label: [[Bootzilla Records label|Bootzilla Records]]\n* Formats: CD, digital\n|}\n\n==Touring members==\n{{BLP unsourced section|date=February 2020}}\n*EmiSunshine \u2013 lead vocals, guitar, ukulele\n*Randall Hamilton \u2013 upright bass, harmony\n*John Hamilton \u2013 mandolin\n*\"Uncle\" Bobby Hill \u2013 drums\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n* {{official|http://theemisunshine.com}}\n* {{youTube|user=TheEmiSunshine}}\n* {{facebook|emisunshinemusic}}\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n[[Category:2004 births]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:American Idol participants]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Sharon_Anderson_(singer)","to":"Sharon Anderson (singer)"}],"pages":{"22138501":{"pageid":22138501,"ns":0,"title":"Sharon Anderson (singer)","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|Canadian country music singer|bot=PearBOT 5}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=April 2023}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n|name = Sharon Anderson\n|image = Sharon Anderson.jpg\n|background = solo_singer\n| alias               = \n| birth_date          = \n| birth_place         = \n| origin              = [[Edmonton]], Alberta, Canada\n| death_date          =\n| death_place         = \n|instrument = Vocals, guitar\n|genre =  [[country music|Country]], [[folk music|folk]]\n|occupation = singer/songwriter\n|years_active         = 1988{{dash}}present\n|label = [[Curb Records|Curb]], [[Capitol Records|Capitol]], [[Liberty Records|Liberty]], [[Royalty Records|Royalty]]\n|associated_acts = Trinity Lane<br />[[Lisa Brokop]]\n| website             = {{URL|sharonlenoreanderson.com}}\n}}\n\n'''Sharon Lenore Anderson'''<ref name=\"cmrra.ca\"/> is a Canadian [[country music]] singer.  During the late 1980s Anderson was a member of country group Trinity Lane, who charted three singles on ''Billboard'' [[Hot Country Songs|Hot Country Singles]] chart in 1988.<ref>{{harvtxt|Whitburn|2008|p=427}}</ref> In 1991, she signed to [[Capitol Records|Capitol Nashville]] and released her solo debut album, ''The Bottom Line'', the same year. The album produced two singles that charted on the ''[[RPM (magazine)|RPM]]'' Country Tracks chart in Canada. Another album, ''Bringing It Home'', was released on [[Royalty Records]] in 1995.\n\nAs a songwriter Anderson co-wrote fellow Canadian country singer [[Lisa Brokop]]'s 1994 Top 20 single \"[[Give Me a Ring Sometime (song)|Give Me a Ring Sometime]]\".<ref name=\"cmrra.ca\"/><ref name=\"allmusic.com\"/> Anderson recorded her own version, as \"Gimme a Ring Sometime\", on her 1995 album.\n\n==Discography==\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! style=\"width:16em;\"| Title\n! style=\"width:18em;\"| Details\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| [[Royalty Records]]\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Life and Times''\n| \n* Release date: April 2011\n* Label: RDR Music\n\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Enchanted Trails''\n| \n* Release date: 2016\n* Available to listen or purchase: CDbaby and YouTube\n\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Trinity Lane''\n| \n* Release date: 2016\n* Available to listen or purchase: Cdbaby and YouTube\n|}\n\n===Singles===\n{| magazine|url=http://americanradiohistory.com/Archive-Billboard/90s/1991/BB-1991-07-20.pdf|title=Single Reviews|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|date=July 20, 1991}}</ref>\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Pony\"\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n|-\n| 1992\n! scope=\"row\"| \"The Wheel of Love\"\n| 84\n| \u2014\n|-\n| 1995\n! scope=\"row\"| \"I Take It Back\"\n| 47\n| \u2014\n| align=\"left\" rowspan=2| ''Bringing It Home''\n|-\n| 1996\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Too Cool\"\n| 57\n| \u2014\n|-\n| rowspan=3|2011\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Springtime Johnny\"\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n| align=\"left\" rowspan=3| ''Life and Times''\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Long Gone Free\"\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"I Got Love\"\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n|-\n| colspan=\"5\" style=\"font-size:8pt\"| \"\u2014\" denotes releases that did not chart\n|}\n\n==See also==\n{{Portal|Music|Canada}}\n*[[Music of Canada]]\n*[[List of Canadian musicians]]\n\n==References== <!-- use
