Fire''\n|-\n| 2011\n| \"If We Had a Fire\"\n| align=\"center\"| *\n| align=\"center\"| *\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n|}\n\n===Music videos===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\"\n|-\n! Year\n! style=\"width:12em;\"| Video\n|-\n| 1992\n! scope=\"row\"| Man of Steel\n|-\n| 1994\n! scope=\"row\"| Which Way Does The River Run\n|-\n| 1997\n! scope=\"row\"| Lifeline\n|-\n| 1998\n! scope=\"row\"| Meet Me At The Oasis\n|-\n| 2006\n! scope=\"row\"| Pieces of You\n|-\n|2018\n!Christmas Day on Planet Earth\n|}\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n* {{Official website|http://www.lenniegallant.com}}\n* {{cite web|title=Lennie Gallant|publisher=Songwriters Association of Canada|url=http://www.songwriters.ca/member/LennieGallant}}\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Gallant, Lennie}}\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:Canadian country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Canadian folk singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Canadian male singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Members of the Order of Canada]]\n[[Category:Singers from Prince Edward Island]]\n[[Category:Canadian Folk Music Award winners]]\n[[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Andrew_Jenkins_(songwriter)","to":"Andrew Jenkins (songwriter)"}],"pages":{"22947142":{"pageid":22947142,"ns":0,"title":"Andrew Jenkins (songwriter)","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer-songwriter}}\n\n{{Use mdy dates|date=August 2014}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = Andrew Jenkins\n| image           =\n| caption         =\n| image_size      =\n| birth_name      =\n| alias           = Blind Andy, Gooby Jenkins, The Blind Newsboy Evangelist\n| birth_date      = {{birth date|1885|11|26}}\n| death_date      = {{death date and age|1957|4|25|1885|11|26}}\n| origin          = [[Atlanta]], Georgia, United States\n| instrument      = Acoustic guitar, [[mandolin]], [[banjo]], harmonica\n| genre           = [[Country music|Country]], [[Folk music|folk]], [[gospel music|gospel]]\n| occupation      = Musician, singer, songwriter, preacher\n| years_active    = circa. 1916\u20131934\n| label           = [[Okeh Records]]\n| past_member_of = Jenkins Family, Jenkins Sacred Singers, Irene Spain Family, [[Carson Robison]]\n}}\n'''The Rev. Andrew W. Jenkins''' (November 26, 1885 \u2013 April 25, 1957<ref>Green p. 37</ref>) was a leading composer of American [[Country music|country]], [[Folk music|folk]] and [[gospel music|gospel songs]]. He is credited with more than 800 compositions, about a third of which were [[Secular music|nonsacred]].<ref name = \"Georgia\">{{cite web | url = http://www.georgiaencyclopedia.org/nge/Article.jsp?id=h-887 | title = Andrew Jenkins | publisher = The New Georgia Encyclopedia | accessdate = 2009-05-24 | archive-date = October 12, 2012 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20121012190644/http://www.georgiaencyclopedia.org/nge/Article.jsp?id=h-887 | url-status = dead }}</ref> He and his stepchildren performed as the Jenkins Family, a group considered to be the first family act to record country music, while Jenkins himself was among the most important country composers of the 1920s.<ref name=\"Carlin p. 204\">Carlin p. 204</ref><ref name=\"McNeil p. 204\">McNeil p. 204</ref>\n\n==Early life==\nJenkins was born in 1885 in [[Jenkinsburg, Georgia]], on the edge of [[Atlanta]]. He was left partially [[blindness|blind]] by a misprescribed medication while still an infant.<ref name=\"Miller p. 160\">Miller p. 160</ref> Early on, he exhibited remarkable musical talents and was able to play almost any instrument he picked up, learning completely [[Learning music by ear|by ear]]. Jenkins, who also showed a proficiency for writing songs at a young age, saw his musical abilities as \"a God gift.\"<ref name = \"Georgia\" /><ref>Peterson p. 242-243</ref>\n\nBecause he had some vision, Jenkins could not attend the state's school for the blind and had to pursue an education on his own. Besides his musical talents, he was skilled in other ways. After becoming a Methodist at the age of nine, he began \"preaching\" to playmates from porches and tree stumps.<ref name=\"McNeil p. 204\" /> Not surprisingly, he became a licensed preacher around the age of 21 and moved into the city, supplementing whatever he could earn from preaching and street performing and also by running a newspaper stand.<ref name=\"Peterson p. 24\">Peterson p. 24</ref> After his first wife's death, Jenkins married Francis Jane Walden Eskew in 1919.<ref name=\"McNeil p. 205\">McNeil p. 205</ref> A young widow, his new wife had three musically talented children, Irene, Mary Lee and a son, T.P.<ref name = \"Georgia\" /> Thus was born the Jenkins Family, one of the most popular family acts of its day.<ref name=\"McNeil p. 205\" />\n\n==The Jenkins Family==\nLittle is known about the Jenkins' musical development over their first three years together, but in 1922, they performed their first program on Atlanta radio station [[WSB (AM)|WSB]] with Andrew Jenkins billed as \"the blind newsboy evangelist.\"<ref name = \"Georgia\" /><ref name=\"Kenney p. 149\">Kenney p. 149</ref> The station, which had begun broadcasting just five months before and had a signal that reached coast-to-coast, became known as The Voice of the South.<ref name=\"Miller p. 160\" /> Performing folk, country and light classical material, the Jenkins Family was an immediate success and remained with the station for nearly a decade.<ref name=\"McNeil p. 205\">McNeil p. 205</ref> Their popularity, which reached to Canada and Mexico,<ref name=\"McNeil p. 205\" /> also attracted the attention of a major record label, [[Okeh Records]], for whom they made their debut recordings in 1924<ref name=\"Miller p. 160\">Miller p. 160</ref> (three years before the [[Carter Family]] began recording).<ref name=\"McNeil p. 205\">McNeil p. 205</ref>\n\nThe Jenkins Family's initial releases were not originals,<ref>Laird p. 119</ref> but were successful enough to earn the group another session, where they recorded four of Rev. Jenkins's songs, including two gospel numbers.<ref name=\"McNeil p. 205\" /> Jenkins was soon asked to write songs for the label's other artists, and his first effort, \"The Death of Floyd Collins\", took just 45 minutes to complete.<ref name=\"Miller p. 160\" /> While the song sold poorly for Okeh,<ref name=\"Peterson p. 24\" /> it was picked up by [[Columbia Records]], which hired [[Vernon Dalhart]], one of the era's leading singers, to record it. The Dalhart version eventually sold more than 300,000 copies,<ref name=\"Wolfe p. 191\">Wolfe p. 191</ref> Besides being one of the all-time best-selling country music [[Gramaphone record|78s]],<ref>{{cite web | url = {{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p437369|pure_url=yes}} | last = Kurutz | first = Steve | title = Reverend Andrew Jenkins | publisher = [[Allmusic]] | accessdate = 2009-06-02}}</ref> the song set a sales record for Columbia that stood for many years.\n\n\"The Death of Floyd Collins\" was based on one of the first great media events of the century, the story of a [[Caving|spelunker]] who became trapped in caverns near [[Mammoth Cave]] in Kentucky.<ref name=\"Carlin p. 204\" /><ref name=\"Kenney p. 149\" /> The song was one of a series of \"event\" songs recorded in the mid-20s. The songs told of train wrecks, natural disasters and outlaws, stories often lifted directly from the daily newspapers. The form was not new, and in fact, the music and lyrics owed much to the folk songs of the previous century. The trend did not develop as a natural revival, either. It was devised by the recording companies in response to the drop in sales they were experiencing as the public turned its attention from what had been the latest technological development, records, to an even more alluring medium, radio.<ref>Wolfe p. 188-198</ref>\n\n==Prolific songwriter==\nJenkins proved a master at crafting topical songs from traditional musical and lyrical forms. For example, \"Floyd Collins\" opened with two lines that came directly from an old British ballad:\n\n''Oh, come all you young people''<br />\n''and listen while I tell''<br />\n''The fate of Floyd Collins,<br />\n''a lad we all know well''<ref name=\"Wolfe p. 191\" />\n\nJenkins was adept at more than just ballads, turning out one song after another, as his stepdaughter Irene described it, like a mill grinding wheat.<ref name=\"Kenney p. 149\" /> Many of his topical compositions were recorded by other artists over the ensuing years, including \"[[Billy the Kid]]\", drawn from a popular 1926 biography of the cowboy killer; \"The Wreck of the Royal Palm\", about a two-train collision in Georgia in 1926; \"The Tragedy on Daytona Beach\", based on the 1929 death of race car driver [[Lee Bible]] in Florida; \"The Fate of Frank Dupre\", the story of an Atlanta robbery/murder; and \"Ben Dewberry's Final Run\", which recounted the death of an Atlantan who was the engineer in a 1908 train wreck.<ref name = \"Georgia\" /><ref name=\"McNeil p. 205\">McNeil p. 205</ref><ref name=\"Miller p. 161\">Miller p. 161</ref> In all, he wrote more than 300 non-sacred songs, many of them \"news ballads\".<ref name=\"McNeil p. 205\" />\n\nAlthough the genre's popularity lasted just one brief year, country artists returned to the form again and again<ref>Peterson p. 31</ref> \u2013 in the late 1920s, pioneers such as [[Jimmie Rodgers (country singer)|Jimmie Rodgers]] and the Carter Family and in the 1930s, early folk artists such as [[Woody Guthrie]] and [[Lead Belly]].<ref>Wolfe p. 197-198</ref> The genre was revisited during the folk revival of the 1950s and 1960s, in particular, by [[Bob Dylan]], who wrote one of his first songs based on the same \"formula\" used by Jenkins, and [[Phil Ochs]], many of whose songs came directly from newspaper headlines.\n\nMeanwhile, Jenkins earned very little from the songs he wrote.<ref name=\"McNeil p. 205\">McNeil p. 205</ref> The hit \"The Death of Floyd Collins\", for example, brought him just $25, and under his agreement with the producer he was working with at Okeh, he also gave up all rights to the song.<ref>Peterson p. 24-25</ref> After experiencing copyright problems, Jenkins began keeping meticulous records of his songs. The practice eventually paid off. Years later, after [[Mahalia Jackson]] recorded one of his gospel songs, \"God Put a Rainbow in the Sky\", his stepdaughter Irene was able to prove the song was not in the public domain but was Jenkins's composition.<ref name=\"Miller p. 161\" />\n\n==Last recordings and later years==\nRev. Jenkins and the Jenkins Family continued to record with Okeh into the mid-1930s under a variety of names, including the Jenkins Sacred Singers, Irene Spain Family, Gooby Jenkins, Andrew Jenkins & [[Carson Robison]] and Jenkins & (Byron) Whitworth.<ref name=\"McNeil p. 205\" /> Jenkins cut his last record as an accompanied soloist billed as Blind Andy, a name he often recorded under, on April 23, 1930, while the Jenkins Family's last recording session for Okeh was July 30, 1934.<ref>Russell p. 455-7</ref>\n\nThe Jenkins Family's popularity opened Rev. Jenkins's ministry to a wide audience, as they performed at concerts and organized [[revival meeting]]s throughout Georgia. Over time, Jenkins also served as pastor of several churches. In 1939, he lost his eyesight completely, yet continued to preach until the time of his death and also broadcast as an evangelist on [[border blaster|Mexico's powerful, uncontrolled radio stations]].<ref name=\"Miller p. 161\" />\n\nJenkins was killed in an automobile accident in [[Thomaston, Georgia]], in 1957.\n\n==Notes==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n==References==\n*{{cite book | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=UWmyUQVUqhQC | last = Carlin | first = Richard | title = Country Music: A Biographical Dictionary | publisher = Taylor & Francis | pages = 497 | year = 2003 | isbn= first = Richard A. | title = Creating Country Music: Fabricating Authenticity | publisher = University of Chicago Press | year = 1997 | pages = 306 | isbn = 0-226-66284-5}}\n*{{cite book | url = last3 = Country Music Hall of Fame & Museum | title = Country Music Records: A Discography, 1921\u20131942 | publisher = Oxford University Press US | year = 2004 | pages = [https://archive.org/details/countrymusicreco00tony/page/1183 1183] | isbn = 0-19-513989-5}}\n*{{cite book | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=0tz5YpijuksC&q=andrew-jenkins+gospel+jenkins-family&pg=PA208 | last1 = Shepherd | first1 = John | last2 = Laing | first2 = Dave | title = Continuum Encyclopedia of Popular Music of the World | publisher = Continuum International Publishing Group | year = 2003 | pages = 832 | isbn = 0-8264-6321-5}}\n*{{cite book | url = Reading Country Music: Steel Guitars, Opry Stars, and Honky-Tonk Bars | publisher = Duke University Press | year = 1998 | pages = [https://archive.org/details/isbn_9780822321682/page/408 408] | isbn = 0-8223-2168-8}}\n*{{cite book | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=U57IX-6r3msC | last1 = Zwonitzer | first1 = Mark | last2 = Hirshberg | first2 = Charles | title = Will You Miss Me When I'm Gone?: The Carter Family and Their Legacy in American Music | publisher = Simon and Schuster | year = 2004 | pages = 304 | isbn = 0-7432-4382-X}}\n\n==External links==\n* [[University of California, Santa Barbara]]\n* Blind Andy, \"[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jXEc6deMvCs Hello World Song (Don't You Go 'Way)]\", recorded March 5, 1930\n{{Authority <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Cole_Vosbury","to":"Cole Vosbury"}],"pages":{"41411566":{"pageid":41411566,"ns":0,"title":"Cole Vosbury","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer}}\n\n{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2014}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = Cole Vosbury\n| image           =\n| caption         =\n| image_size      =\n| birth_date      = {{birth date and age|1991|04|29}}\n| alias           = 1/2 of The Lovers\n| origin          = [[Shreveport]], [[Louisiana]], U.S.\n| instrument      = Vocals, guitar, piano, drums\n| genre           = {{hlist|[[Folk music|Folk]]|[[blues]]|[[R&B]]|[[Americana music|Americana]]|[[Electronic music|electronic]]}}\n| occupation      = Recording artist, musician, singer, music producer\n| years_active    = 2010\u2013present\n| label           =\n| associated_acts = The Lovers\n| website         = {{URL|www.theloversmusic.com}}\n}}\n\n'''Cole Vosbury''' is an American singer, songwriter, producer and musician who has appeared on [[The Voice (U.S. season 5)|Season 5]] of the [[NBC]] singing competition ''[[The Voice (U.S. TV series)|The Voice]]'' as a member of [[CeeLo Green]]'s team and later [[Blake Shelton]]'s team.<ref>{{cite news|last=Kroll|first=Katy|title='The Voice' Recap: Cee Lo Green Disses Blake Shelton's Team|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-news/the-voice-recap-cee-lo-green-disses-blake-sheltons-team-68234/|access-date=December 29, 2013|newspaper=[[Rolling Stone]]|date=October 29, 2013}}</ref> During his time on ''The Voice'', six of Vosbury's singles charted on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' charts. He released his self-produced debut album, \"Entity: One\" on September 1, 2020.\n\nVosbury also has a duo with his partner Amanda June called The Lovers. The duo released a 7 song Self-titled EP on February 26, 2020.\n\nIn the time since appearing on television Vosbury, a multi-instrumentalist, has produced and released a multitude of albums ranging in styles from folk, rock, lo-fi and electronic. \n\n\"Most of the time I consider myself to be an abstract artist and I think of my music as paintings. When I make a song I'm painting a picture with sound.\" - Cole Vosbury\n\n==''The Voice''==\nOn the second episode of the Blind Auditions broadcast on September 24, 2013, he performed [[The Jeffersons]] theme song, \"[[The Jeffersons#Theme song|Movin' On Up]].\" Only [[Cee Lo Green]] turned his chair, thus he defaulted to Team CeeLo.<ref>[http://www.nbc.com/the-voice/video/the-blind-auditions-premiere-part-2/n41090/ The Blind Auditions Part 2]</ref>\n\n\nIn Knockout Round, Vosbury lost his battle, he was stolen by Blake.\n\n{| class=\"wikitable\" style=\"text-align:center; font-size:90%; line-height:16px;\"\n|-\n! Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Ron_Hynes","to":"Ron Hynes"}],"pages":{"5095607":{"pageid":5095607,"ns":0,"title":"Ron Hynes","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|Musical artist (1950\u20132015)}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=November 2020}}\n{{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject Musicians -->\n| name            = Ron Hynes\n| image             = Ron Hynes.jpg\n| caption        = Hynes performing in Gros Morne\n| image_size        =\n|\n| background      = solo_singer\n| birth_name      =\n| alias           =\n| birth_date            = {{birth date|1950|12|07}}\n| death_date            = {{death date and age|2015|11|19|1950|12|07}}\n\n| birth_place          = [[St. John's, Newfoundland and Labrador]], Canada \n|death_place= [[St. John's, Newfoundland and Labrador]], Canada\n| instrument      =\n| genre           = [[Folk music|Folk]], [[Country music|Country]]\n| occupation      = Singer-songwriter\n| years_active    = 1972\u20132015\n| past_member_of  = [[Wonderful Grand Band]]\n| label           = {{ubl|World Records <small>(1972)</small>|Grand East Records <small>(1978)</small>|Lost Island <small>(1990)</small>|[[EMI]] <small>(1993)</small>|[[Borealis Records]] <small>(2003)</small>}}\n| website             = [http://www.hynesite.ca/ Hynesite.ca]\n| current_members =\n| past_members    = \n}}\n\n'''Ron Hynes''' (December 7, 1950 \u2013 November 19, 2015) was a [[Folk music|folk]] singer-songwriter from [[Newfoundland and Labrador]]. He was especially known for his composition \"[[Sonny's Dream]]\",<ref name=\"Moore2017\">{{cite book|author=Christopher Moore|title=The Big Book of Canada (Updated Edition): Exploring the Provinces and Territories|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zmS0DgAAQBAJ&pg=PA23|date=April 4, 2017|publisher=Tundra Books|isbn=978-1-101-91894-4|pages=23\u2013}}</ref> which has been recorded worldwide by many artists and was named the 41st greatest Canadian song of all time on the 2005 [[CBC Radio One]] series ''[[50 Tracks: The Canadian Version]]''.<ref>{{cite news|title=\"50 Tracks\" list of essential Canadian music|url=http://www.cbc.ca/50tracks/essentialcanadianmusic.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050412002329/http://www.cbc.ca/50tracks/essentialcanadianmusic.html|archivedate=April 12, 2005|accessdate=April 23, 2013|newspaper=Canadian Broadcasting Corporation|date=2005}}</ref>\n\n==Biography==\nRon Hynes was born in [[St. John's, Newfoundland and Labrador]] in December 1950, and raised in [[Ferryland]]. He was a founding member of [[The Wonderful Grand Band]], one of Newfoundland's most popular performing groups, and has released seven solo albums. His debut album, ''Discovery'', released in 1972, was the first album composed of totally original content by a Newfoundland artist. Hynes is a seven-time [[East Coast Music Awards]] winner, and past [[Juno Award|Juno]] and [[Canadian Country Music Awards]] nominee.<ref>{{cite news|title=Ron Hynes to undergo surgery|url=https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/newfoundland-labrador/ron-hynes-to-undergo-surgery-1.1209399|access-date=April 23, 2013|newspaper=Canadian Broadcasting Corporation|date=July 18, 2012}}</ref> He was named Artist of the Year ('92) and was presented with the prestigious Arts Achievement Award (2004) by the Newfoundland/Labrador Arts Council. In 2002, Hynes received an honorary Doctor of Letters from [[Memorial University]] in St. John's in recognition of his original songwriting and his contribution to the cultural heritage of Newfoundland. In 2006, Hynes was honored as the recipient of the St. John's Folk Arts Council's Lifetime Achievement Award.\n\nWidely regarded as one of Canada's premier singer-songwriters with a career spanning over 30 years, Hynes' songs have become part of the fabric of Newfoundland culture. His work is also known outside the province; Hynes' songs have been covered worldwide by over 100 artists, including [[Emmylou Harris]], [[Valdy]] and [[Christy Moore]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Ron Hynes on CBC Music|url=http://music.cbc.ca/#/artists/Ron-Hynes|accessdate=April 23, 2013|newspaper=[[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]]}}</ref>\n\nMost recently, Hynes was the winner of Male Solo Recording of the Year at the 2007 [[East Coast Music Awards]], and picked up three awards at the 2006 [[MusicNL]] awards show in November 2006. The awards included Entertainer of the Year, Songwriter of the Year and Folk/Roots Artist of the Year.\n\nHynes narrated two audiobooks for Rattling Books, ''Hard Light: 32 Little Stories'' by [[Michael Crummey]]<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.overdrive.com/media/133106/hard-light | title=Hard Light: 32 Little Stories by Michael Crummey | publisher=Rattling Books / [[Rakuten OverDrive]] | accessdate=August 3, 2019}}</ref> and ''Death on the Ice'' by [[Cassie Brown]].<ref>{{cite book | url=https://sellfy.com/p/qR6q/ | title=Death on the Ice (Cassie Brown, Harold Horwood) The Great Newfoundland Sealing Disaster of 1914 | publisher=Rattling Books audiobooks, Alca Productions | author=Cassie Brown, [[Harold Horwood]] | year=2011 | isbn=978-0-9782065-7-4 | orig-year=1972}}</ref>\n\nHe also had occasional acting roles, including in the films ''[[The Adventure of Faustus Bidgood]]'', ''[[Secret Nation]]'', ''Anchor Zone'', ''[[Violet (2000 film)|Violet]]'' and ''The Bingo Robbers'', and the television series ''[[Dooley Gardens]]'' and ''[[Emily of New Moon (TV series)|Emily of New Moon]]''.\n\n==Illness and death==\nIn July 2012, it was announced that Ron Hynes was diagnosed with throat cancer.<ref>{{cite news|title=Musician Ron Hynes diagnosed with cancer|url=https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/newfoundland-labrador/musician-ron-hynes-diagnosed-with-cancer-1.1209396|access-date=April 23, 2013|newspaper=Canadian Broadcasting Corporation|date=July 28, 2012}}</ref> On August 11, 2012, Hynes performed to a sold-out crowd of more than 3,000 at the Mile One Centre in St. John's. This was his last performance before undergoing cancer treatment.  The concert included a reunion of Hynes' old band, [[The Wonderful Grand Band]].<ref>{{cite news|title='Magical' Ron Hynes performs before cancer treatment|url=https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/newfoundland-labrador/magical-ron-hynes-performs-before-cancer-treatment-1.1238692|access-date=April 23, 2013|newspaper=[[CBC News]]|date=August 12, 2012}}</ref> In the fall of 2013, he was in remission and back on tour, including participation in a [[Vinyl Cafe]] tour broadcast on [[CBC Radio]]. Hynes died at a hospital in St. John's on November 19, 2015, at the age of 64.<ref>{{cite news|author=Michael MacDonald |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/arts/music/newfoundland-and-labrador-folk-legend-ron-hynes-dead-at-64/article27381444/ |title=Newfoundland and Labrador folk legend Ron Hynes dead at 64 |newspaper=[[The Globe and Mail]] |date= November 19, 2015|accessdate=November 20, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.thetelegram.com/News/Local/2015-11-19/article-4349461/Reports-songwriter-Ron-Hynes-dead/1 |title=Songwriter Ron Hynes dead: reports \u2013 Local |publisher=The Telegram |date= |accessdate=November 20, 2015}}</ref>\n\nAfter Hynes' death, actor and writer [[Joel Thomas Hynes]],<ref>[http://www.durhamregion.com/whatson-story/5155826-singer-ron-hynes-brings-his-folk-classic-to-greenbank-hall/ \"Singer Ron Hynes brings his folk classic to Greenbank hall\"]</ref> his nephew, announced on Facebook<ref>{{cite web|author=The Canadian Press |url=http://www.ctvnews.ca/entertainment/family-friends-hope-ron-hynes-death-shines-light-on-drug-addiction-1.2674108 |title=Family, friends hope Ron Hynes' death shines light on drug addiction |publisher=[[CTV News]] |date= November 25, 2015|accessdate=November 25, 2015}}</ref> that Hynes suffered from drug addictions that led to his demise. \"He remained a hardcore addict right to his final days. And it killed him.\", said Joel Thomas Hynes.\n\n==Stage and screen career==\nHynes had starred on screen and stage as an actor/writer in numerous roles dating back to the 1970s, including ''The Bard of Prescott Street'', \"Wonderful Grand Band\", ''[[CODCO|The Best of CODCO]]'', ''[[Hank Williams: The Show He Never Gave]]'', ''The Island Opry Show'', ''The Lost Island Opry'', ''[[Secret Nation]]'', ''Anchor Zone'' and ''[[Dooley Gardens]]''.\n\n==Tributes==\nAn independent tribute album, entitled ''11:11 \u2013 Newfoundland Women Sing Songs by Ron and Connie Hynes'', was released in 1997, with various female artists performing songs written by Ron Hynes and his ex-wife Connie.\n\nA documentary on Hynes, entitled ''Man of a Thousand Songs'' and directed by [[William D. MacGillivray]], debuted at the [[2010 Toronto International Film Festival]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Jankovic|first=Jovana|title=Review: Man of a Thousand Songs \u2013 RWMFF 2010|url=http://thetfs.ca/2010/11/09/review-man-of-a-thousand-songs-tiff-2010/|accessdate=April 23, 2013|newspaper=Toronto Film Scene|date=November 9, 2010}}</ref>\n\nThe 2023 tribute album ''Sonny Don't Go Away'' featured versions of Hynes's songs performed by artists such as [[Tim Baker (musician)|Tim Baker]], [[Alan Doyle]], [[The Once]], [[Fortunate Ones]], [[Amelia Curran (musician)|Amelia Curran]], [[The Ennis Sisters]], [[Rum Ragged]], [[Matthew Byrne (musician)|Matthew Byrne]], [[The Dardanelles (band)|The Dardanelles]] and [[Kellie Loder]].<ref>Calum Slingerland, [https://www.google.com/search?client=firefox-b-d&q=tim+baker+leaving+on+the+evening+tide \"Tim Baker, Alan Doyle, the Once Cover Ron Hynes for New Tribute Album\"]. ''[[Exclaim!]]'', August 29, 2023.</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n\n===Albums===\n{|class=\"wikitable\"\n|-\n!Year\n!Album\n!Label\n|-\n| 1972\n| ''Discovery''\n| World Records/Audat\n|-\n| 1978\n| ''[[Wonderful Grand Band (album)|The Wonderful Grand Band]]'' <small>(with [[Wonderful Grand Band|The Wonderful Grand Band]])</small>\n| rowspan=\"2\"| Grand East Records\n|-\n| 1981\n| ''[[Living in a Fog]]'' <small>(with The Wonderful Grand Band)</small>\n|-\n| 1987\n| ''Small Fry: The Ron Hynes Album for Children''\n| Independent\n|-\n| 1993\n| ''[[Cryer's Paradise]]''\n| rowspan=\"2\"| EMI\n|-\n| 1997\n| ''[[Face to the Gale]]''\n|-\n| 1998\n| ''[[Standing in Line in the Rain]]''\n| rowspan=\"2\"| Independent\n|-\n| 2001\n| ''The Sandcastle Sessions''\n|-\n| 2003\n| ''Get Back Change''\n| rowspan=\"3\"| [[Borealis Records|Borealis]]\n|-\n| 2006\n| ''Ron Hynes''\n|-\n| 2010 \n| ''Stealing Genius''\n|-\n|2016\n|''Later That Same Life''\n|\n|}\n\n===Singles===\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n|-\n! \u2014\n|}\n\n==Videography==\n* Cryer's Paradise, 1993;\n* Godspeed, 1997;\n* Ron Hynes \u2013 The Irish Tour, 2000 (full-length documentary);\n* A Good Dog Is Lost, 2002;\n* Record Man, 2003.\n* THE MAN OF A THOUSAND SONGS, 2010, (feature documentary).\n\n==Awards and nominations==\n*2007 [[East Coast Music Awards|ECMA]]\n** won ''Male Artist of the Year''\n** nominated ''Album of the Year'' for the album ''Ron Hynes''\n** nominated ''Entertainer of the Year''\n** nominated ''Songwriter of the Year'' for the song ''Dry''\n*2004 [[East Coast Music Awards|ECMA]]\n** won ''Album of the Year'' for the album ''Get Back Change''\n** won ''Country Recording of the Year'' for the album ''Get Back Change''\n*1999 [[East Coast Music Awards|ECMA]]\n** nominated ''Male Artist of the Year''\n*1998 [[East Coast Music Awards|ECMA]]\n** nominated ''Country Recording of the Year''\n** nominated ''Male Artist of the Year\t''\n** nominated ''Songwriter of the Year'' for the song ''Godspeed''\n** nominated ''Video of the Year'' for ''Godspeed''\n*1994 [[East Coast Music Awards|ECMA]]\n** nominated ''Album of the Year'' for album ''Cryer's Paradise ''\n** won ''Country Recording of the Year''\n** won ''Male Artist of the Year''\n** won ''Song of the Year'' for the song ''Man of a Thousand Songs ''\n** nominated ''Video of the Year'' for ''Cryer's Paradise''\n*1992 [[East Coast Music Awards|ECMA]]\n** nominated ''Song of the Year'' for the song ''Never Met a Liar ''\n*1991 [[East Coast Music Awards|ECMA]]\n** nominated ''Male Artist of the Year''\n*2009 [[SOCAN]] Awards\n** won ''National Achievement Award''\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n* [http://www.hynesite.org Ron's website with photos, biography and more]\n* {{Discogs artist|Ron Hynes}}\n* Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Quartette_(band)","to":"Quartette (band)"}],"pages":{"4671776":{"pageid":4671776,"ns":0,"title":"Quartette (band)","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|Canadian country-folk group}}\n{{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject Musicians -->\n| name            = Quartette \n| image           = \n| caption         = \n| background      = group_or_band\n| origin          = [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]], Canada\n| genre           = [[Country music|Country]]/[[Folk music|Folk]] \n| years_active    = 1993&ndash;present\n| label           = [[Denon Records|Denon]]\n| associated_acts = \n| website         = {{URL|quartette.com}}\n| current_members = [[Cindy Church]]<br />[[Caitlin Hanford]]<br />[[Gwen Swick]]<br />[[Sylvia Tyson]]\n| past_members    = [[Colleen Peterson]]\n}}\n\n'''Quartette''' is a [[Canadian]] country-folk group consisting of [[Cindy Church]], [[Caitlin Hanford]], [[Gwen Swick]] and [[Sylvia Tyson]].<ref name=\"Inc.1995\">{{cite magazine|author=Larry LeBlanc|title=Canada: Who's Who|magazine=Billboard|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=sAsEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA80|date=4 February 1995|publisher=Nielsen Business Media, Inc.|pages=80\u2013|issn=0006-2510}}</ref> Each of the four members also record as solo artists in addition to their work as a group.<ref name=\"Inc.1995a\">{{cite magazine|author=Larry LeBlanc|title=Stony Plain's Church revives folk with 'Just a Little Rain'work=Billboard| magazine=Billboard |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xgsEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA24|date=19 August 1995|publisher=Nielsen Business Media, Inc.|pages=24\u2013|issn=0006-2510}}</ref>\n\n==History==\nThe group was originally formed in 1993 and included Tyson, Hanford, Church and [[Colleen Peterson]].<ref name=\"Einarson2001\">{{cite book|author=John Einarson|title=Desperados: The Roots of Country Rock|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pydnobIDzJEC&pg=PA233|date=January 2001|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield|isbn=978-0-8154-1065-2|pages=233\u2013}}</ref><ref name=\"Schneider2010\">{{cite book|author=Jason Schneider|title=Whispering Pines: The Northern Roots of American Music... from Hank Snow to the Band|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=c--zNXu1v74C&pg=RA1-PT149|date=15 December 2010|publisher=ECW Press|isbn=978-1-55490-552-2|pages=1\u2013}}</ref> \n\nIn 1994 Quartette released a self-titled album,<ref name=boro>[http://www.stalbertgazette.com/article/Quartette-brings-Christmas-to-Morinville-20151125 \"Quartette brings Christmas to Morinville\"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170108190338/http://www.stalbertgazette.com/article/Quartette-brings-Christmas-to-Morinville-20151125 |date=2017-01-08 }}. ''St. Albert Gazette'', Nov 25, 2015 Anna Borowiecki</ref> and later that year won a [[Canadian Country Music Association]] award for best vocal collaboration. \n\nIn 1995 and 1996 they were nominated for [[Juno Awards]] in the category of best country group.<ref Name=boro />\n\nPeterson had toured and recorded with Quartette until early 1996, when she was diagnosed with cancer and was unable to perform with the band during her cancer treatment. She chose her friend and collaborator Gwen Swick to fill in for her,<ref>Ted Shaw, \"Quartette copes with loss\". ''[[Windsor Star]]'', December 14, 1996.</ref> and later died in Toronto on October 9 that year. She is interred in Little Lake Cemetery in Peterborough, Ontario.\n\nAll four current members of the group are also solo performers who have toured throughout Canada,<ref name=\"Inc.2000\">{{cite magazine|author=Larry LeBlanc|title=Tyson album, stage show, draw on her life and long career in music|magazine=Billboard|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=aREEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA60|date=9 September 2000|publisher=Nielsen Business Media, Inc.|pages=60\u2013|issn=0006-2510}}</ref> having performed on ''[[Adrienne Clarkson Presents]]'' and at the [[Vancouver Folk Music Festival]]. \n\nQuartette's recordings and live performances have been reviewed favorably by ''[[The Globe and Mail]]'', ''[[Chatelaine (magazine)|Chatelaine]]'' and ''[[Billboard magazine|Billboard]]''.\n\nAt the end of 2016, Quartette continued to perform live, completing a month-long tour in December.<ref>[https://ottawacitizen.com/entertainment/local-arts/a-quartette-christmas-with-sylvia-tyson-and-friends \"A Quartette Christmas with Sylvia Tyson and friends\"]. ''Ottawa Citizen'', Lynn Saxberg, December 16, 2016</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n! Year\n! Title\n! <small>CAN Country</small>\n|-\n| 1993\n| ''Quartette''<ref name=\"Inc.1995\" />\n| \n|-\n| 1995\n| ''Work of the Heart''<ref>[http://www.countrystandardtime.com/d/cdreview.asp?xid=2243 \"Quartette Work Of The Heart \u2013 1995 (Denon (Canada))\"]. ''Country Standard Time'', Reviewed by Joel Bernstein</ref>\n| align=\"center\"| 19\n|-\n| 1996\n| ''It's Christmas''\n| \n|-\n| 1998\n| ''In the Beauty of the Day''\n| \n|-\n| 2002\n| ''I See a Star''\n| \n|-\n| 2007\n| ''Down at the Fair''\n|\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 2013\n| ''Rocks and Roses''\n| \n|-\n| ''20 Years of Quartette''\n| \n|}\n\n=== Singles ===\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n! Year\n! Title\n! <small>CAN Country</small>\n! Album\n|- \n| 1994\n| \"Red Hot Blues\"\n| align=\"center\"| 9\n| ''Quartette''\n|-\n| 1995\n| \"No Place Like Home\"\n| align=\"center\"| 81\n| ''Work of the Heart''\n|-\n| 1999\n| \"I Don't Want to Cry\"\n| align=\"center\"| 53\n| ''In the Beauty of the Day''\n|}\n\n==References==\n{{reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n* [http://www.quartette.com/ Quartette] official website\n{{Great Speckled Bird}}\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Quartette}}\n[[Category:Musical groups established in 1993]]\n[[Category:Musical groups from Toronto]]\n[[Category:Canadian country music groups]]\n[[Category:Vocal quartets]]\n[[Category:Country music supergroups]]\n[[Category:1993 establishments in Ontario]]\n[[Category:Canadian all-female bands]]\n[[Category:All-female folk bands]]\n[[Category:All-female country bands]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Mindy_Smith","to":"Mindy Smith"}],"pages":{"4003805":{"pageid":4003805,"ns":0,"title":"Mindy Smith","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer-songwriter (born 1972)}}\n\n{{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject Musicians -->\n| name                = Mindy Smith\n| image               = Mindysmith1.jpg\n| caption             = Mindy Smith performing in 2005\n| background       = solo_singer\n| birth_name       = \n| birth_date         ={{Birth date and age|1972|6|1|mf=y}}\n| birth_place        = [[Long Island, New York]], U.S.\n| genre               = [[Folk music|Folk]], [[pop music|pop]], [[country music|country]]\n| occupation        = Singer, songwriter\n| instrument        = Guitar, vocals\n| years_active     = 2003\u2013present\n| label                = [[Vanguard Records|Vanguard]]\n| associated_acts =\n| website            = {{URL|www.mindysmithmusic.com}}\n}}\n\n'''Melinda Leigh Smith''' (born June 1, 1972, [[Long Island, New York]]) is an American singer-songwriter. Her first record deal came after she sang a cover version of the song \"[[Jolene (song)|Jolene]]\" by [[Dolly Parton]].\n\n==Music career==\nSmith was adopted at birth by a non-denominational Protestant minister and his wife, who was choir director at the church. She grew up on [[Long Island]], New York. After her mother died of cancer in 1991, Smith attended Cincinnati Bible College for two years.<ref name=\"ND\">{{cite web|title=Mindy Smith - On the inside|url=http://nodepression.com/article/mindy-smith-inside|website=No Depression|accessdate=26 January 2017|date=31 October 2006}}</ref>\n\nSmith and her father moved to [[Knoxville, Tennessee]], where she began listening to [[folk music|folk]] and [[bluegrass music]], [[Alison Krauss]], and [[the Cox Family]]. In 1998, she moved to [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]] to pursue a career in music. Two years later, she reached the finals of a contest at the [[Kerrville Folk Festival]]. This led to a contract with [http://www.bigyellowdogmusic.com/ Big Yellow Dog Music].<ref name=\"AM bio\">{{cite web|last1=Deming|first1=Mark|title=Mindy Smith {{!}} Biography|url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/mindy-smith-mn0000493015/biography|website=AllMusic|accessdate=22 January 2017}}</ref>\n\nSmith attracted attention in 2003 when she sang a cover version of \"[[Jolene (song)|Jolene]]\" by [[Dolly Parton]] for the tribute album\n''[[Just Because I'm a Woman: Songs of Dolly Parton|Just Because I'm a Woman]]''. Soon after, she signed a contract with [[Vanguard Records]], who released her debut album, ''[[One Moment More]]'' in 2004.<ref name=\"AM bio\" /> In addition to Dolly Parton, she has expressed admiration for [[John Prine]], [[Alison Krauss]], [[Patty Griffin]], [[Shania Twain]], [[Kris Kristofferson]], [[Buddy Miller]], and [[Bill Gaither (gospel singer)|Bill Gaither]].<ref name=\"ND\" />\n\n\"Come to Jesus\" was her biggest hit, receiving airplay on [[country music|country]], [[Christian music|Christian]], [[adult album alternative]] (AAA), and [[adult contemporary music|adult contemporary]] radio. The song charted at No. 32 on the [[Adult Top 40]] chart of ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' magazine.{{citation needed|date=January 2017}} In 2004 Smith appeared at the [[Cambridge Folk Festival]] in the U.K., which was broadcast nationally on [[BBC Radio]].\n\nIn October 2006, Smith released \"Out Loud\", the first single from her second album ''[[Long Island Shores]]''. The song was well received by AAA rock radio and Country Music Television ([[CMT (U.S. TV channel)|CMT]]). On January 10, 2007, she performed \"Please Stay\" on ''[[The Tonight Show with Jay Leno]]''.\n\nIn October 2007, Smith released a Christmas album, ''[[My Holiday]]''. She wrote six original songs, including \"I Know the Reason\" with [[Thad Cockrell]].<ref name=\"pop_matters_mindysmith\">{{cite web|url=http://www.popmatters.com/pm/review/mindy-smith-my-holiday/|title=Mindy Smith: My Holiday|last=Gilstrap|first=Andrew|work=[[Popmatters]]|accessdate=2009-10-24}}</ref>\n\nIn August 2009, Smith released her fourth studio album, ''[[Stupid Love (album)|Stupid Love]]''. She appeared on ''[[The Early Show]]'' on August 15, 2009, to perform the first single, \"Highs and Lows\". On September 29, 2009, while promoting the album on the syndicated radio show ''[[World Cafe (radio program)|World Cafe]]'', she disclosed that she had [[obsessive\u2013compulsive disorder]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=113306795|title=Mindy Smith: A Chanteuse's Emotional Return|work=NPR|date=September 29, 2009|accessdate=April 2, 2017}}</ref>\n\nIn June 2012, Smith released an [[Mindy Smith (album)|eponymous independent studio album]] on her own Giant Leap label, in conjunction with TVX. In October of the same year, Vanguard Records released a compilation album of her songs, \"The Essential Mindy Smith\".\n\nOn October 29, 2013, Smith released a holiday EP entitled ''Snowed In'' on Giant Leap/TVX. The release contained both original [[Christmas songs]] and cover material.\n\nBetween 2015 and 2018, Smith contributed (as sole writer or co-writer) several songs to the musical television drama series ''[[Nashville (2012 TV series)|Nashville]]''. She is credited on four of the songs performed by cast members and appearing [[Nashville discography|on the soundtrack]] in the series' final three seasons.\n\n==Charity==\nIn March 2013, Smith worked with [[Anthropologie]] during an in-store performance to raise money and awareness for the [[Captain Planet Foundation]], a non-profit organization. Anthropologie donated fifteen percent of sales made in the first hour after Smith's performance to CPF.<ref name=\"Charity Work\">{{cite web|title=Mindy Smith joins forces with lifestyle brand Anthropologie and Captain Planet|url=http://www.mindysmithmusic.com/news/mindy-smith-joins-forces-lifestyle-brand-anthropologie-and-captain-planet-176|website=Mindy Smith|accessdate=14 October 2015|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924121433/http://www.mindysmithmusic.com/news/mindy-smith-joins-forces-lifestyle-brand-anthropologie-and-captain-planet-176|archivedate=24 September 2015}}</ref>\n\n==Awards and honors==\n* Best New/Emerging Artist of the Year,  [[Americana Music Association]], 2004\n\n==Discography==\n\n===Studio albums===\n\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! Track: \"The Cruel War\"\n\n==References==\n{{reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n* {{Official website|MindySmithMusic.com}}\n* [https://web.archive.org/web/20031221122527/http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/smith_mindy/artist.jhtml CMT Profile]\n{{s-start}}\n{{s-ach|aw}}\n{{s-new|First|reason=None recognized before}}\n{{s-ttl|title=[[Americana Music Association|AMA New/Emerging Artist Of The Year]]|years=2004}}\n{{s-aft|after=[[Mary Gauthier]]}}\n{{s-end}}\n{{Mindy Smith}}\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Smith, Mindy}}\n[[Category:1972 births]]\n[[Category:American bluegrass musicians]]\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:American women country singers]]\n[[Category:American folk singers]]\n[[Category:American performers of Christian music]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:People with obsessive\u2013compulsive disorder]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from New York (state)]]\n[[Category:21st-century American singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:21st-century American women singers]]\n[[Category:Country musicians from New York (state)]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Jonathan_Byrd_(musician)","to":"Jonathan Byrd (musician)"}],"pages":{"4757005":{"pageid":4757005,"ns":0,"title":"Jonathan Byrd (musician)","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer-songwriter}}\n{{for|the [[PGA Tour]] [[golf]]er|Jonathan Byrd (golfer)}}\n\n{{Use mdy dates|date=November 2020}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n|image = Jonathan Byrd.jpg\n|image_size = \n|name = Jonathan Byrd\n||caption = \n|background = solo_singer\n|birth_name = Jonathan Byrd\n|alias = \n|birth_date = {{birth year and age|1970}}\n|birth_place = [[Fayetteville, North Carolina]], U.S. \n|origin = [[Carrboro, North Carolina]]\n|instrument = [[Lead singer|vocals]], guitar\n|genre = [[Country music|country]], [[Folk music|folk]]<br />singer-songwriter<br />[[World music|world]], [[folk-rock]]\n|occupation = \n|years_active = 2000\u2013present\n|label = [[Waterbug Records]]\n|associated_acts = [[Dromedary (band)|Dromedary]]<br />[[Diana Jones (singer-songwriter)|Diana Jones]]<br />[[Greg Klyma]]<br />Karen Mal<br />[[Ana\u00efs Mitchell]]<br />[[The Sentimentals (band)|The Sentimentals]]\n|website = {{URL|www.jonathanbyrd.com}}\n}}\n\n'''Jonathan Byrd''' (born 1970 in [[Fayetteville, North Carolina]]) is an American singer-songwriter based in [[Carrboro]], [[North Carolina]].  He is best known for his narrative tales of love, life, and death in America.  In 2003, he was among the winners of the New Folk competition at the [[Kerrville Folk Festival]].  He set a record for CD sales at the festival that year, making more sales than the main stage acts.  His song, \"The Ballad of Larry\" has been listed a \"Top Rated Song\" by Americana-UK.  He primarily performs solo and accompanies himself in a variety of traditional acoustic guitar styles.  His recordings have featured a variety of instrumental ensembles and typically include one or more [[instrumental]] tracks that feature Byrd's skillful [[flatpicking]] technique.  Occasionally he also appears with the [[Athens, Georgia]] based [[world music]] duo, [[Dromedary (band)|Dromedary]].\n\nJonathan Byrd teamed up with Chris Kokesh after meeting her at the Americana Song Academy and the duo released a self-titled album under the name The Barn Birds in 2013.<ref>from an interview on [http://americanamusicshow.com/episode164 episode 164 of the Americana Music Show], released November 4, 2013</ref>\n\nIn 2014, Byrd released You Can't Outrun The Radio, a collection of songs inspired by an impromptu song circle in 2009 at the Green Room in Montreal.<ref>from an interview published on [http://americanamusicshow.com/episode223 episode 223 of the Americana Music Show], released December 8, 2014</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n\n===Albums===\n*''[[Wildflowers <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Bruce_Robison","to":"Bruce Robison"}],"pages":{"10471206":{"pageid":10471206,"ns":0,"title":"Bruce Robison","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer-songwriter}}\n\n{{Use mdy dates|date=August 2020}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = Bruce Robison\n| image           = Bruce Robison (1).jpg\n| caption         = Robison in 2009\n| birth_name      = Bruce Ben Robison\n| birth_date      = {{Birth date and age|1966|6|11}}\n| origin          = [[Bandera, Texas]]\n| instrument      = Vocals, guitar, harmonica\n| genre           = [[Folk music|Folk]], [[Country music|country]]\n| label           = Vireo, Lucky Dog, Premium\n| spouse = {{Marriage|[[Kelly Willis]]|1996|2022|end=div}}\n| website         = {{url|brucerobison.com}}\n}}\n\n'''Bruce Ben Robison''' (born June 11, 1966) is an American, [[Austin, Texas|Austin]]-based [[Texas country music]] singer-songwriter.  Bruce and his brother, fellow singer-songwriter [[Charlie Robison]], grew up in [[Bandera, Texas]], near [[San Antonio]].  His self-titled debut album was released in 1995.<ref>{{cite web|author=William Ruhlmann |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/bruce-robison-mw0000083869 |title=Bruce Robison \u2013 Bruce Robison &#124; Songs, Reviews, Credits, Awards |publisher=AllMusic |access-date=July 14, 2014}}</ref>\n\nRobison has written several songs which have become hits when covered by well-known singers, including: \"[[Travelin' Soldier]],\" (recorded in 2003 by the [[Dixie Chicks]], reached No. 1 on the Country charts); \"[[Angry All the Time]],\" (recorded by [[Tim McGraw]] and [[Faith Hill]] in 2001, also reached No. 1 on the country charts); and \"[[Wrapped (George Strait song)|Wrapped]]\" (recorded in 2006 by [[George Strait]], reached No. 2 in 2007). Bruce runs The Next Waltz, a record label by artists for artists.\n\n==Personal life==\nSister, Robyn Ludwick, and late brother [[Charlie Robison]] are accomplished singer-songwriters in their own right.\n\nIn 1992, he met singer-songwriter [[Kelly Willis]] and they married in 1996. Together they had a son, Deral Otis, in January 2001. Willis became pregnant again and gave birth to twins Abigail Esme and Benjamin James<ref>[http://www.commotionpr.com/images/BruceKelly_twins.jpg]  {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930095738/http://www.commotionpr.com/images/BruceKelly_twins.jpg |date=September 30, 2007 }}</ref> on March 24, 2003.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rykodisc.com/Catalog/dump/rykoalbums_1266.asp |access-date=April 28, 2008 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070617180822/http://www.rykodisc.com/Catalog/dump/rykoalbums_1266.asp |archive-date=June 17, 2007 |title=Rykodisc Catalog - Easy - Kelly Willis }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://dir.salon.com/story/mwt/feature/2003/08/01/rockermoms/index.html |title=Mothers who rock - Salon.com |publisher=Dir.salon.com |date=August 1, 2003 |access-date=July 14, 2014 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110606191622/http://dir.salon.com/story/mwt/feature/2003/08/01/rockermoms/index.html |archive-date=June 6, 2011 }}</ref><ref>[http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1481015/12092003/willis_kelly.jhtml ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080907041646/http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1481015/12092003/willis_kelly.jhtml |date=September 7, 2008 }}</ref> On January 10, 2006, Kelly welcomed fourth child Joseph Willis Robison.<ref>[http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1520547/01112006/robison_bruce.jhtml ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930031459/http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1520547/01112006/robison_bruce.jhtml |date=September 30, 2007 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=US Willis &#124; Gratis muziek, tourneedata, foto's, video's |publisher=Blogs.myspace.com |access-date=March 29, 2012 }}</ref>\n\nOn January 21, 2022 Kelly and Bruce announced their upcoming divorce via their Facebook pages.<ref>{{Facebook|id= 100050585345408/posts/461424962220345/?d=n |name=Bruce Robinson }}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Tish_Hinojosa","to":"Tish Hinojosa"}],"pages":{"485231":{"pageid":485231,"ns":0,"title":"Tish Hinojosa","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American singer-songwriter (born 1955)}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2020}}\n{{BLP sources|date=September 2010}}\n{{Infobox musical artist | <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject Musicians -->\n|name               = Tish Hinojosa\n|image              = Tish Hinojosa Hamburg Germany 2010.jpg\n|image_size         = <!-- default size is 250px -->\n|background         = solo_singer\n|birth_name         = Leticia Hinojosa<ref name=\"whitburn\">{{cite book|last=Whitburn|first=Joel|title=Hot Country Songs 1944 to 2008|publisher=Record Research, Inc|year=2008|page=190|isbn=978-0-89820-177-2}}</ref>\n|alias              = \n|birth_date         = {{birth date and age|1955|12|06}}<ref name=TARO_THinojosa>{{cite web| publisher=[[University of Texas]] Libraries| date=2009| title=Tish Hinojosa Papers: Bio| url=https://txarchives.org/utlac/finding_aids/00311.xml| accessdate=2021-12-18}}</ref>\n|birth_place        = [[San Antonio]], Texas, US<ref name=SelfBio_THinojosa>{{cite web| publisher=Tish Hinajosa| title=Tish Hinajosa| author=Hinajosa, Tish| date=2021| url=https://www.mundotish.com/about| accessdate=2021-12-18}}</ref>\n|instrument         = Vocals, guitar\n|genre              = [[Country music|Country]], [[Folk music|Folk]]\n|occupation         = Singer-songwriter\n|years_active       = 1969-present<ref name=SelfBio_THinojosa/>\n|label              = [[Warner Bros. Records]], [[MCA Records|MCA]]/[[Curb Records|Curb]], [[A&M Records|A&M]], [[Rounder Records|Rounder]], [[Valley Entertainment]], [[Watermelon Records]], Texas Music Group, Tish Records (self released)\n|associated_acts    = [[Patricia Vonne]], [[Stephanie Urbina Jones]], [[Kris Kristofferson]]<ref name=SelfBio_THinojosa/>\n|website            = [http://www.MundoTish.com/ MundoTish]\n}}\n\n'''Leticia''' (\"'''Tish'''\") '''Hinojosa''' (born December 6, 1955, [[San Antonio]], Texas) is a [[folk music|folksinger]] recording in both Spanish and English. Hinojosa was the youngest of 13 children. Hinojosa's parents were Mexican immigrants.<ref name=SelfBio_THinojosa/>  Known for singing both traditional Mexican folksongs and her own original songs, both in Spanish and English, Hinojosa accompanies herself on guitar, which she plays right-handed although she is naturally [[Handedness|lefthanded]]. Influenced by traditional [[Music of Mexico|Mexican]], [[Folk music|folk]], [[Tejano music|Tejano]], [[conjunto]], and [[Country music|country]] musics, Hinojosa considers her music to be music of the US/Mexico border.{{citation needed|date=December 2021}}\n\nHinojosa has recorded numerous albums and has charted twice on the ''Billboard'' country charts.<ref name=\"whitburn\"/>  Her 1992 album ''Culture Swing'' won the National Association of Independent Record Distributors ([[NAIRD]]) Indie Folk Album of the Year.<ref name=TaosNews2021_THinojosa>{{cite news| publisher=[[Taos News]]| title=Tish Hinojosa remains a Taos favorite| author=Romancito, M. Elwell| date=October 6, 2016| url=https://www.taosnews.com/tish-hinojosa-remains-a-taos-favorite/article_dbd3c884-c3c2-5915-a53d-ba9ff9eb8441.html| accessdate=2021-12-18}}</ref>\n\nUsing music to bring awareness to cultural issues, Hinojosa hopes to bring into focus the plight of migrant workers and children of the poor. Additionally, she often performs children's music of her culture to help children develop an understanding of the Southwest's Hispanic traditions.<ref name=TARO_THinojosa/>\n\nAs of 2021, Hinajosa lives in both [[Austin, Texas]] and [[Tubac, Arizona]].  In the 1970s and 1980s she also lived in [[Taos, New Mexico]] and [[Nashville, Tennessee]].  In 2005, Hinojosa moved to Germany, and in 2013 returned to Austin.<ref name=TaosNews2021_THinojosa/><ref name=TARO_THinojosa/><ref>{{cite news| title=Behind the scenes on the Tish Hinojosa story| last=Flores|first=Nancy| date=September 14, 2014| work=[[The Austin American-Statesman]]| url=https://www.austin360.com/story/entertainment/music/2017/02/03/behind-the-scenes-on-the-tish-hinojosa-story/10193755007/| accessdate=2021-12-18}}</ref>\n\n==Career highlights==\n<!--lists are better as lists {{list | date = February 2018}} -->\n\n===Awards and honors===\n* White House performance for [[Bill Clinton|President Bill]] and [[Hillary Clinton]]<ref name=SelfBio_THinojosa/>\n* NAIRD Indie Folk Album of the Year ''Culture Swing''\n* Las Primera (The Firsts) award from MANA, the largest organization of Latino women\n* Performances at presidential and gubernatorial inauguration events.\n\n===Television===\n* VH 1\n* ABC-TV special: Alma Awards\n* MTV\n* The Nashville Network\n* Austin City Limits (three separate appearances)\n* Fox Television Bravo Awards\n* Good Morning America\n* Onyx TV Germany\n* WDR TV Germany\n* SWR TV Switzerland\n* VPRO TV Netherlands\n\n===Humanitarian activities===\n* Spokesperson, National Latino Children's Agenda\n* Spokesperson, National Assoc. Of Bilingual Education\n* United Farm Workers of America\n\n==Discography==\n<ref>{{cite web| publisher=Tish Hinajosa| title=Tish Hinajosa: Discography| author=Hinajosa, Tish| date=2013| url=https://www.MundoTish.com/discography| accessdate=2021-12-18}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| publisher=Tish Hinajosa| title=Tish Hinajosa: ''My Homeland'' - out now| author=Hinajosa, Tish| date=2019| url=https://www.MundoTish.com/shop| accessdate=2021-12-18}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| publisher=[[AllMusic]]| title=Discography: Tish Hinajosa| url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/tish-hinojosa-mn0000601654/discography| accessdate=2021-12-18}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| publisher=[[Discogs]]| title=Tish Hinajosa| url=https://www.discogs.com/artist/356657-Tish-Hinojosa| accessdate=2021-12-18}}</ref>\n===Albums===\n====Self====\n*1987 ''Taos to Tennessee'', Self-release; re-released 1992; \n*1989 ''Homeland'', Fonatana [[A&M Records]], re-released 2006? w/ bonus track \n*1990, 1991 ''Memorabilia Navide\u00f1a'', EP: self released cassette; [[Watermelon Records]] re-released CD 1992\n*1991 ''Aquella Noche'', [[Watermelon Records]]\n*1992 ''Culture Swing'', [[Rounder Records]]\n*1994 ''[[Destiny's Gate]]'', [[Warner Bros. [[Lone Star Records]]/[[Texas Music Group]]<ref>{{cite work |author=Hinojsa, Tish| title=From Texas for a Christmas Night: History and Acknowledgement [recording liner notes]| publisher=Texas Music Group| place=Austin, Texas| date=2003}}</ref>\n*2005 ''A Heart Wide Open'', [[Valley Entertainment]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.valley-entertainment.com/a-heart-wide-open-1.html |title=A Heart Wide Open |work=Valley Entertainment |accessdate=June 28, 2010}}</ref>\n*2006 ''Retrospective'', [[Var\u00e8se Sarabande]]\n*2008 ''Our Little Planet'', CRS ([[Var\u00e8se Sarabande]])\n*2013 ''After the Fair'', [[Var\u00e8se Sarabande]]\n*2018 ''West'', Tish Records\n*2019 ''My Homeland'', Tish Records<ref name=TaosNews2021_THinojosa/>\n\n====The Texicana Mamas ([[Patricia Vonne]], Tish Hinojosa, [[Stephanie Urbina Jones]])====\n*2020 ''The Texicana Mamas'', self-released, internet only<ref>{{cite web| publisher=The Texicana Mamas| title=The Texicana Mamas| date=2020| url=https://www.thetexicanamamas.com/bio| accessdate=2021-12-18}}</ref>\n\n===Singles===\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n|- \n!Year\n!Single\n!width=45|<small>[[Hot Country Songs|US Country]]</small><ref name=\"whitburn\"/>\n!Album\n|- \n|1986\n|\"I'll Pull You Through\" <small>(with [[Craig Dillingham]])</small>\n|align=\"center\"|80\n|single only\n|-\n|1989\n|\"Til U Love Me Again\"\n|align=\"center\"|75\n|''Homeland''\n|-\n|1992\n|\"In the Real West\"\n|align=\"center\"|\u2014\n|rowspan=3|''Culture Swing''\n|-\n|rowspan=2|1993\n|\"Closer Still\"\n|align=\"center\"|\u2014\n|-\n|\"Drifter's Wind\"\n|align=\"center\"|\u2014\n|-\n|1994\n|\"I'm Not Through Loving You Yet\"\n|align=\"center\"|\u2014\n|''Destiny's Gate''\n|}\n\n===Music videos===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\"\n|-\n! Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Jimmy_Rankin","to":"Jimmy Rankin"}],"pages":{"11608176":{"pageid":11608176,"ns":0,"title":"Jimmy Rankin","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Use mdy dates|date=August 2020}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| image             = July 23 Area 506 Jimmy Rankin 3-2.jpg\n| caption           = Jimmy Rankin, July 2021.\n| name              = Jimmy Rankin\n| birth_name        = James Kevin Rankin\n| alias             = \n| birth_date        = {{birth date and age|1964|05|28}}\n| death_date        = {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}}\n| origin            = [[Mabou, Nova Scotia]], Canada<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.stratfordbeaconherald.com/ArticleDisplay.aspx?e=3112530 |title=Rankin set list has family favourites and new tunes |access-date=July 26, 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111006152002/http://www.stratfordbeaconherald.com/ArticleDisplay.aspx?e=3112530 |archive-date=October 6, 2011 |url-status=dead }}</ref>\n| instrument        = Vocals, guitar\n| genre             = [[Country music|Country]], [[Folk music|folk]]\n| occupation        = Singer-songwriter\n| years_active      = 1989\u2014present\n| label             = Song Dog Music\n| associated_acts   = [[Rankin Family|The Rankin Family]], [[Heather Rankin (singer)|Heather Rankin]], [[Alvvays]]\n| website           = [http://www.jimmyrankin.com/ www.jimmyrankin.com]\n}}\n\n'''James Kevin Rankin''' (born May 28, 1964) is a Canadian [[country music|country]] and [[folk music|folk]] artist. A member of [[The Rankin Family]], Rankin has also released seven solo albums: ''[[Song Dog]]'' (2001), ''[[Handmade (Jimmy Rankin album)|Handmade]]'' (2003), ''[[Edge of Day]]'' (2007), ''[[Forget About the World (album)|Forget About the World]]'' (2011), ''Tinsel Town'' (2012), ''[[Back Road Paradise]]'' (2014) and ''Moving East'' (2018). Rankin's solo and Rankin Family awards include 5 Junos, 27 East Coast Music Awards, 9 SOCAN top radio play Awards, 7 Canadian Country Music Awards, 2 Music NS Awards, and 2 Canadian Radio Music Awards.\n\n==Early years==\nRankin was born in 1964 in [[Mabou, Nova Scotia]]. He grew up as part of a musical family that would entertain the neighbors every third weekend as part of the local [[c\u00e9ilidh]]. This group became known as [[The Rankin Family]] and went on to achieve international success in the 1990s as they brought their well-loved mix of Cape Breton traditional music, roots and pop to the rest of the world.\n\n==Musical career==\n===2001\u20132002: ''Song Dog''===\nAfter embarking on a solo career, Rankin released his debut album, ''[[Song Dog]]'' in August 2001.<ref>{{usurped|1=[https://web.archive.org/web/20010719224341/http://www.chartattack.com/damn/2001/07/1701.cfm \"CD Reviews: The Beta Band, Default, Toploader and many more\"]}}. ''Chart Attack'', July 17, 2001</ref> Three singles were released from the album, \"Followed Her Around\", \"Midnight Angel\", and \"Wasted\". \"Followed Her Around\" was named the \"Single of the Year\" award at the [[SOCAN]] Awards in 2002. The song also was named \"Single of the Year\" and \"Video of the Year\" from the [[East Coast Music Association]]. ''Song Dog'' was named \"Album of the Year\" at the Canadian Country Music Awards and at the East Coast Music Awards. In 2003, \"Midnight Angel\" was named \"Single of the Year\" and Rankin was named [[SOCAN]] Songwriter of the Year at the East Coast Music Awards.\n\n===2003\u20132004: ''Handmade''===\n''[[Handmade (Jimmy Rankin album)|Handmade]]'' was released in September 2003 and produced three singles, \"Morning Bound Train\", \"Butterfly\", and \"California Dreamer\". It was named \"Album of the Year\" and \"Roots/Traditional Solo Recording of the Year\" at the East Coast Music Awards in 2003. \"Morning Bound Train\" was named \"Single of the Year\" and Rankin was named SOCAN Songwriter of the Year at the ECMA's. \"Butterfly\" was named \"Single of the Year\" and \"Video of the Year\" at the ECMA's in 2005. Rankin also received SOCAN Songwriter of the Year for the song.\n\n===2006\u20132007: ''Edge of Day''===\nAfter a brief hiatus, ''[[Edge of Day]]'' was released in May 2007 and produced three singles, \"Slipping Away\", \"Got to Leave Louisiana\", and \"Still Lovers Now\". In 2008, Rankin was named Songwriter of the Year at the Canadian Country Music Awards for the song, \"First Time in a Long Time\" with [[Deric Ruttan]]. At the East Coast Music Awards, ''Edge of Day'' was named Country Recording of the Year, FACTOR Recording of the Year and Konica Minolta Male Solo Recording of the Year. He was also awarded SOCAN Songwriter of the Year for the song, \"Slipping Away\".\n\n===2011\u20132012: ''Forget About the World''===\n''[[Forget About the World (album)|Forget About the World]]'' was released in April 2011 and has released three singles, \"Here in My Heart\", \"I'm Just Saying\" and \"The Hurtin' Part\". ''Forget About the World'' was nominated fore Juno for Country Recording of the Year and a record breaking 8 ECMAs including: Recording of the Year, Entertainer of the Year, Song of the Year, Video of the Year, Country Album of the Year, Video of the Year and Songwriter of the Year. In September 2011, Rankin won a CCMA for \"Roots Artist of the Year\" and in November 2011 he won the Music Nova Scotia \"SOCAN Songwriter of the Year\" Award as well as a SOCAN top radio play award for his song \"Up All Night\". The accolades continued in December with Rankin's fans naming him one of CBC Radio's Top 50 Artists of 2011. Rankin's song \"Here in My Heart\" was named the number one Canadian Country song of 2011 by Top Country. Rankin won \"Roots Artist of the Year\" for the second year in a row in September 2012.\n\n===2012\u20132013: ''Tinsel Town''===\nThe Christmas themed album ''Tinsel Town'' was released on November 6, 2012. Rankin embarked on Cross-Canada tours in support of the effort in November and December 2012 and 2013. The album, produced by Bill Bell (Jason Mraz, Tom Cochrane), contains four original songs: \"Tinseltown\", \"December\", \"Boogie Woogie Christmas\" and \"Don't Wanna Say Goodbye to Christmas\". The CD package has a unique feature that allows it to be sent in the mail as a Christmas card.\n\n===2014\u2013present: ''Back Road Paradise'' and ''Moving East''===\nRankin  released his sixth full-length album, ''[[Back Road Paradise]]'', produced by Bill Bell, on April 1, 2014. ''Back Road Paradise'' features 12 brand-new Rankin compositions, including lead-off single \"Cool Car\" and duets with Grammy winner and bluegrass icon [[Alison Krauss]], as well as [[Blue Rodeo]]\u2019s [[Jim Cuddy]]. After living and working in [[Nashville]] for seven years, Rankin returned to his home province of Nova Scotia. His latest album, ''Moving East'', was produced by [[Joel Plaskett]] and was issued in September 2018. It is his first album for [[True North Records]].\n\n==Discography==\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! style=\"width:12em;\"| Title\n! style=\"width:20em;\"| Details\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''[[Song Dog]]''\n| \n* Release date: August 14, 2001\n* Label: Song Dog Music/[[Fontana North]]\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''[[Handmade (Jimmy Rankin album)|Handmade]]''\n| \n* Release date: September 2, 2003\n* Label: Song Dog Music/Fontana North\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''[[Edge of Day]]''\n| \n* Release date: May 8, 2007\n* Label: Song Dog Music/Fontana North\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''[[Forget About the World (album)|Forget About the World]]''\n| \n* Release date: April 12, 2011\n* Label: Song Dog Music/Fontana North\n|- \n! scope=\"row\"| ''Tinsel Town''\n| \n* Release date: November 6, 2012\n* Label: Song Dog Music/Fontana North\n|- \n! scope=\"row\"| ''[[Back Road Paradise]]''\n| \n* Release date: April 1, 2014\n* Label: Song Dog Music/Fontana North\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Moving East''\n|\n* Release date: September 28, 2018\n* Label: True North\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Harvest Highway''\n|\n* Release date: October 13, 2023\n* Label: True North\n|}\n\n===Singles===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Year\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:20em;\"| Single\n!
