Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Cheryl_Wheeler","to":"Cheryl Wheeler"}],"pages":{"793681":{"pageid":793681,"ns":0,"title":"Cheryl Wheeler","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American folk singer and songwriter}}\n{{for|the American stuntwoman|Cheryl Wheeler-Dixon}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2020}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = Cheryl Wheeler\n| image           = Cheryl Wheeler1.jpg\n| caption         = Cheryl Wheeler performing live at the Falcon Ridge Folk Festival in July 2006.\n| image_size      =\n| birth_name      =\n| alias           =\n| birth_date      = {{birth date and age|mf=yes|1951|7|10}}\n| origin          = [[Timonium, Maryland]], United States\n| instrument      = {{hlist|Vocals|guitar}}\n| genre           = {{hlist|[[Folk music|Folk]]|[[Country music|country]]}}\n| occupation      = Singer-songwriter\n| years_active    = 1976\u2013present\n| label           = {{hlist|[[Capitol Records|Capitol]]|Philo/[[Rounder Records|Rounder]]|Dias}}\n| associated_acts = [[Shawn Colvin]]<br />[[Mary Chapin Carpenter]]<br />[[Suzy Bogguss]]\n| website         = \n}}\n\n'''Cheryl Wheeler''' (born July 10, 1951) is a [[Massachusetts]]-based singer-songwriter of contemporary [[folk music]]. She has recorded thirteen folk albums to date<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cherylwheeler.com/home/discog.html|title=Discography|website=Cherylwheeler.com|access-date=July 2, 2014|archive-date=February 28, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140228181622/http://cherylwheeler.com/home/discog.html|url-status=dead}}</ref> and has toured extensively throughout the United States since the mid-1970s.<ref name=Daley2018>{{Cite news|last=Daley|first=Lauren|title=Cheryl Wheeler follows her bemused muse wherever it takes her|url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/arts/music/2018/01/02/cheryl-wheeler-follows-her-bemused-muse-wherever-takes-her/ZFVy1sWqb149tlXHKG7H9M/story.html|work=[[Boston Globe]]|date=January 2, 2018|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=November 28, 2020}}</ref>\n\nHeralded as a \u201cfolk luminary,\u201d an \u201cunassuming folk star,\u201d and a \u201cfolk diva,\u201d Wheeler is known for her well-crafted songs, stellar vocals, and witty on-stage patter.<ref name=Daley2018 /><ref name=DirtyLinen2009>{{Cite web|title=Cheryl Wheeler Launches Record Company, New Record|url=https://dirtylinen.wordpress.com/2009/06/09/cheryl-wheeler-launches-record-company-new-record/|website=Dirty Linen|date=June 9, 2009|access-date=November 28, 2020}}</ref><ref name=Hill2007>{{Cite news|last=Hill|first=Whit|title=Cheryl Wheeler - Hero, worshipped|url=https://annarborobserver.com/articles/cheryl_wheeler_full_article.html|work=[[Ann Arbor Observer]]|date=April 2007|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201207210408/https://annarborobserver.com/articles/cheryl_wheeler_full_article.html|archive-date=December 7, 2020|access-date=November 28, 2020|url-status=dead}}</ref> ''The Boston Globe'' wrote: \u201cOver decades, she\u2019s built a cult following through Boston radio and the New England folk circuit for her uncanny ability, not unlike Tom Rush, to have her audience laughing during one song and silently tearing up with the next.\u201d<ref name=Daley2018 /> \u201cIf Wheeler never picked up an instrument, she could have easily become a comedian,\u201d said another reviewer. \u201cFortunately for us, she does both. Because, after the jokes, stories and self-deprecating comments have people rolling in the aisles, she starts singing and her voice is spellbinding.\u201d<ref name=Nostrand2016>{{Cite news|last=Nostrand|first=George V.|title=Cheryl Wheeler: Comic, storyteller, poet, singer-songwriter|url=https://www.rutlandherald.com/cheryl-wheeler-comic-storyteller-poet-singer-songwriter/article_dd926171-cb69-5f3e-a389-69d733b2c2a1.html|work=[[Rutland Herald]]|date=March 24, 2016|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=November 28, 2020}}</ref>\n\n== Early life ==\nBorn and raised in [[Timonium, Maryland]], Wheeler began playing ukulele and guitar in middle school and writing songs in high school, making up melodies to go with the poems in \u201cThe Golden Book of Poetry,\u201d a children's book.<ref name=Daley2018 /><ref name=McNally2017>{{Cite web|last=McNally|first=Owen|title=Folk Singer Cheryl Wheeler Brings Her Saucy Stage Persona To Iron Horse|url=https://www.courant.com/ctnow/music/hc-cheryl-wheeler-at-iron-horse-20170109-story.html|work=[[Hartford Courant]]|date=January 9, 2017|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201208231538/https://www.courant.com/ctnow/music/hc-cheryl-wheeler-at-iron-horse-20170109-story.html |archive-date=December 8, 2020 |access-date=November 28, 2020}}</ref><ref name=Lenker>{{Cite news|last=Lenker|first=George|title=Cheryl Wheeler talks songwriting, humor, before Northampton shows|url=https://www.masslive.com/entertainment/2019/01/cheryl_wheeler_talks_songwriti.html|work=[[The Republican (Springfield, Massachusetts)|MassLive]]|date=January 1, 2019|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=November 28, 2020}}</ref> Wheeler completed two years of community college and then transferred to [[Coker College]] in South Carolina. She quit in early 1972. \u201cI didn\u2019t quit thinking: Do I embark on a folk music career?\u201d she said. \u201cI quit because I was in 15th grade, and enough was enough already.\u201d<ref name=Daley2018 />\n\nNot long after leaving college, Wheeler was hired at a steakhouse as a waitress. \u201cWithin a week, the owners and me, we realized we made a terrible mistake,\u201d she said. \u201cI could never be a waitress. But they needed [a musician], and I thought maybe I could do that, and they were relieved to get me out of waitressing.\"<ref name=Daley2018 /> Around the same time, Wheeler began performing at clubs in the [[Washington, D.C.]], and [[Baltimore]] area.<ref name=Bellaire2015>{{Cite web|last1=Bellaire|first1=Rick|title=Cheryl Wheeler|url=http://www.ripopmusic.org/musical-artists/musicians/cheryl-wheeler/|website=Rhode Island Music Hall of Fame Historical Archive|date=April 2015|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131025083307/http://www.ripopmusic.org:80/musical-artists/musicians/cheryl-wheeler/ |archive-date=October 25, 2013 |access-date=November 28, 2020}}</ref>\n\n== Career ==\nIn 1976, Wheeler moved to [[Providence, Rhode Island]], and began playing at folk clubs throughout New England, opening for artists such as [[Jonathan Edwards (musician)|Jonathan Edwards]], [[Tom Rush]], [[Jesse Winchester]], and [[Gordon Lightfoot]].<ref name=Lenker /><ref name=Bellaire2015 /><ref name=Whitlock1996>{{Cite news|last=Whitlock|first=Jennifer|title=Several Singers Have Scored with Cheryl Wheeler Songs|url=https://www.mcall.com/news/mc-xpm-1996-01-19-3082110-story.html|work=[[The Morning Call]]|date=January 19, 1996|url-status=|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=November 28, 2020}}{{deadlink|date=September 2023}}</ref> Her big break came when Edwards asked her to audition for a spot in his band as a bass player. Wheeler didn't play bass, but she bought one and auditioned nonetheless. \u201cTo my complete astonishment, I got the gig,\" Wheeler recalled. \"But I knew I didn't get it for my bass playing. So I thought I must've got it for my singing. So that was a real shot in the arm because I hadn't thought about it before, but I thought I might actually be a good singer if Jonathan Edwards is hiring me.\"<ref name=Lenker />\n\nIn 1983, Wheeler released her first album, a four-song EP called ''Newport Songs'', which is now out of print. Her next two releases \u2013 a self-titled album in 1986 and ''Half a Book'' in 1987 \u2013 were produced by North Star Records in Providence. The song \u201cAddicted,\u201d from the self-titled album, was recorded by country singer [[Dan Seals]] and became a No. 1 hit for him in 1988 on Billboard's Top 40 Country chart.<ref name=Bellaire2015 />\n\nFollowing the success of her first two full-length albums, Wheeler was signed to [[Capitol Records]] and released ''Circles and Arrows'' in 1990. [[Suzy Bogguss]] recorded Wheeler's song \u201cAces\u201d from this album, and it reached #9 on the country charts in 1992. Wheeler's next four albums \u2013 ''Driving Home'' (1993), ''Mrs. Pinocci's Guitar'' (1995), ''Sylvia Hotel'' (1999), and ''Defying Gravity'' (2005) \u2013 were produced by the folk-oriented Philo-Rounder Records in Cambridge, Massachusetts.<ref name=Bellaire2015 />\n\nIn 2003, Wheeler approved the production of a double disc album, ''No Previous Record'',<ref>{{Cite web|title=No Previous Record|url=http://cherylwheeler.com/discog/npr.html|website=Cherylwheeler.com|access-date=October 3, 2006|archive-date=October 12, 2006|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061012134701/http://www.cherylwheeler.com/discog/npr.html|url-status=dead}}</ref> which contains songs that never made it onto a commercial recording. Distribution of the album is free, but restricted to members of her e-mail list.{{citation needed|date=November 2020}}\n\nWheeler's two most-recent albums \u2013 ''Pointing at the Sun'' (2009) and ''Cheryl Wheeler Live'' (2012) \u2013 were released by her own record label, Dias Records.<ref name=DirtyLinen2009 /><ref name=Bellaire2015 />\n\nWheeler's songs have been covered by a number of other artists in addition to [[Dan Seals]] and [[Suzy Bogguss]]. They include [[Kathy Mattea]], [[Sylvia Kirby|Sylvia]], [[Garth Brooks]], [[Peter, Paul, and Mary]], [[Bette Midler]], [[Kenny Loggins]], [[Melanie Safka|Melanie]], [[Holly Near]], and D.C. Anderson.<ref name=Bellaire2015 /><ref name=DirtyLinen2009 /> Wheeler has said she doesn't purposefully write for other people, but she appreciates when others cover her songs. \u201c[It\u2019s] great. I make money if they do well,\u201d she said. \u201cBut more than that, it's wonderful to have a singer you respect singing your song.\"<ref name=Whitlock1996 />\n\nHer song \"If It Were Up to Me\" (which was written shortly after the [[1998 Westside Middle School shooting]]), with the closing line \"If it were up to me, I'd take away the guns\" got nationwide attention shortly after the [[Columbine High School massacre]].<ref>{{Cite web|title=If It Were Up to Me|url=http://cherylwheeler.com/songs/iiwutm.html|website=Cherylwheeler.com|access-date=April 15, 2020|archive-date=October 20, 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101020161720/http://cherylwheeler.com/songs/iiwutm.html|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref name=DirtyLinen2009 /> Wheeler released the recording into the public domain to exempt radio stations from paying royalties (it was being played every hour near the high school), and Rounder Records ran a promotional campaign to donate money to the [[Brady Campaign]] each time the song was played on [[Adult Album Alternative]] radio stations.{{citation needed|date=November 2020}}\n\nIn 2014, Wheeler was inducted into the Rhode Island Music Hall of Fame.<ref name=Bellaire2015 />\n\n==Performances==\nWheeler has toured extensively throughout her career, and her live concerts include both comedic and serious commentary in addition to the songs themselves. As one reviewer wrote, she \u201cmasterfully blends blisteringly on-target observational humor, simple storytelling, gorgeous guitar work, and beautiful, rich songs.\u201d<ref name=Hill2007 /> Another commented on her \u201cfree-wheeling live concerts\u201d and called Wheeler a \u201cthoughtful, amusing musician and storyteller (and irrepressible social critic)\u2026. [H]er patter is a delicious, folk-flavored blend of Phyllis Diller and Mort Sahl, sometimes puckish, sometimes barbed.\u201d<ref name=McNally2017 />\n\nAbout half of the songs Wheeler performs in concert are not available on any of her albums.<ref name=Nostrand2016 /> Many never get recorded and eventually fade from her set list. Although she mostly tours alone, she has also toured with [[Kenny White]] (who produced a number of her albums). White generally opens for her and then plays and sings harmony during Wheeler's set.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://cherylwheeler.com/home/promoconfig.html|title=Performance Configurations|website=Cherylwheeler.com|access-date=July 3, 2009|archive-date=June 19, 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090619105334/http://www.cherylwheeler.com/home/promoconfig.html|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref name=McNally2017 /> Wheeler has also toured with the [[Christine Lavin]]-inspired tour \"On a Winter's Night\" and occasionally as part of Lavin's consortium [[Four Bitchin' Babes]].<ref name=Nostrand2016 />\n\nWheeler participated in a concert with fellow folk singer-songwriters [[Shawn Colvin]] and [[Mary Chapin Carpenter]] in 1988, the year before Colvin released her debut album.<ref name=Nostrand2016 /> The three performed on two consecutive nights, to critical acclaim, at [[The Birchmere]] in [[Alexandria, Virginia]]. The two performances were recorded at the soundboard and although never released officially, have been favorites among fans of the three artists.{{citation needed|date=November 2020}}\n\n== Personal life ==\nWheeler is openly [[lesbian]].<ref name=Advocate1999>{{cite magazine|title=Wheeler's angry anthem |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iWMEAAAAMBAJ&dq=Wheeler&pg=PA79 |magazine=[[The Advocate (LGBT magazine)|The Advocate]] |date=June 8, 1999 |page=22 |access-date=25 January 2022}}</ref> She and her wife, Cathleen, live in Swansea, Massachusetts.<ref name=Daley2018 /> They were married in 2004, ten days after Massachusetts made [[same-sex marriage]] legal.<ref name=TGV2013>{{Cite news|title=Think, laugh and cry: An interview with Cheryl Wheeler|url=https://thegavoice.com/culture/music/think-laugh-and-cry-an-interview-with-cheryl-wheeler/|work=[[The Georgia Voice]]|date=October 25, 2013|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=November 28, 2020}}</ref><ref name=Daley2018 />\n\nIn October 2022, her management announced that her forthcoming concerts were cancelled due to hospitalization for mental health challenges.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://meandthee.org/concerts/cheryl-wheeler-oct2022/|title=Cheryl Wheeler [canceled] at the me&thee coffeehouse 7 October 2022 {{!}} Kenny White Special Guest|date=October 7, 2022|website=Me & Thee Music}}</ref>\n\nShe returned to performing in 2023.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pfmsconcerts.org/concert/debs/cheryl-wheeler-kenny-white-101523|title=Cheryl Wheeler with Kenny White - 10/15/23|website=Peterborough Folk Music Society}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/2024/04/23/arts/cheryl-wheeler/|title=Singer-songwriter Cheryl Wheeler talks about returning to performing after being in rehab|first=Noah|last=Schaffer|date=April 23, 2024|newspaper=[[The Boston Globe]]}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\nMost of the following albums are still in print:\n\n===Studio albums===\n* ''Cheryl Wheeler'' (1985)\n* ''Half a Book'' (1987)\n* ''Circles and Arrows'' (1990)\n* ''Driving Home'' (1993)\n* ''Mrs. Pinocci's Guitar'' (1995)\n* ''Sylvia Hotel'' (1999)\n* ''Defying Gravity'' (2005)\n* ''Pointing at the Sun'' (2009)\n* ''Greetings: Cheryl Wheeler Live (feat. Kenny White) (2012)\n\n===EPs===\n* ''Newport Songs'' (1983)\n* ''Live and Otherwise'' (1987)\n\n===Compilation albums===\n* ''Different Stripe'' (2000)\n* ''No Previous Record'' (2003)\n\n===Other contributions===\n*''[[Live at the World Caf\u00e9 - Volume 9]]'' (1999) \u2013 \"If It Were Up to Me\"\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n*[http://www.CherylWheeler.com Official website]\n*[http://www.mmreview.com/ronsfolkchords Cheryl Wheeler guitar chords]\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Wheeler, Cheryl}}\n[[Category:1951 births]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:20th-century American guitarists]]\n[[Category:20th-century American singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:20th-century American women guitarists]]\n[[Category:20th-century American women singers]]\n[[Category:20th-century American LGBTQ people]]\n[[Category:21st-century American guitarists]]\n[[Category:21st-century American singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:21st-century American women guitarists]]\n[[Category:21st-century American women singers]]\n[[Category:21st-century American LGBTQ people]]\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:American folk musicians]]\n[[Category:American lesbian musicians]]\n[[Category:American women country singers]]\n[[Category:Fast Folk artists]]\n[[Category:LGBTQ people from Maryland]]\n[[Category:People from Timonium, Maryland]]\n[[Category:People from Swansea, Massachusetts]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from Maryland]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Michael_Johnson_(singer)","to":"Michael Johnson (singer)"}],"pages":{"569909":{"pageid":569909,"ns":0,"title":"Michael Johnson (singer)","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American musician and singer (1944\u20132017)}}\n{{Other people|Michael Johnson|Michael Johnson (disambiguation){{!}}Michael Johnson}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=July 2014}} \n{{Infobox musical artist\n| image             = MichaelJohnson2001.jpg\n| image_size        = \n| name              = Michael Johnson\n| caption           = Johnson in 2002\n| background        = solo_singer\n| birth_name        = Michael Jay Johnson\n| birth_date        = {{Birth date|1944|8|8}}\n| birth_place       = [[Alamosa, Colorado]], U.S.\n| death_date        = {{death date and age|2017|7|25|1944|8|8}}\n| death_place       = [[Minneapolis|Minneapolis, Minnesota]], U.S.\n| instrument        = Vocals, classical guitar, acoustic guitar, piano\n| genre             = [[Folk music|Folk]],<ref name=\"auto\">{{Cite web|url=https://ricochet.com/444725/archives/michael-johnson-1944-2017-a-requiem/|title=Michael Johnson (1944-2017): A Requiem|website=Ricochet|date=July 28, 2017 }}</ref> [[folk rock]], [[country music|country]],<ref name=\"auto\"/> [[soft rock]]<ref name=\"auto\"/>\n| occupation        = Singer-songwriter, instrumentalist, [[recording industry|record producer]], actor, writer\n| years_active      = 1957\u20132017\n| label             = [[Atco Records|Atco]], Sanskrit Records, [[EMI]], [[RCA]], [[Vanguard Records|Vanguard]], [[Atlantic Records|Atlantic]], Intersound, American Originals, [[Red House Records|Red House]]\n| website           = {{URL|http://www.mjblue.com}}\n}}\n\n'''Michael Jay Johnson''' (August 8, 1944 \u2013 July 25, 2017) was an American pop, [[country music|country]], and [[folk music|folk]] singer-songwriter and guitarist. He is best remembered for his 1978 hit song \"[[Bluer Than Blue]]\". He charted four hits on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] chart and nine more on [[Hot Country Songs]], including two number one country hits in 1986's \"[[Give Me Wings]]\" and \"[[The Moon Is Still Over Her Shoulder]]\". He also co-wrote \"Cain's Blood\", the debut single of 1990s country group [[4 Runner]].\n\n==Career==\n{{more citations needed|section|date=July 2017}}\nJohnson was born in the small town of [[Alamosa, Colorado]] and grew up in [[Denver]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.mjblue.com/|title=Michael Johnson: Singer & Guitarist|website=Mjblue.com|access-date=August 7, 2021}}</ref> He started playing the guitar at 13. In 1963, he began attending Colorado State College (now the [[University of Northern Colorado]]) in Greeley to study music but his college career was truncated when he won an international talent contest two years later. First prize included a deal with [[Epic Records]].<ref>{{cite magazine |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/country/news/bluer-than-blue-singer-michael-johnson-dead-at-72-w492020|title='Bluer Than Blue' Singer Michael Johnson Dead at 72|first=Stephen L.|last=Betts|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]|date=July 27, 2017|issn=0035-791X}}</ref>\n\nWishing to hone his instrumental skills, in 1966 he set off for [[Barcelona, Spain]], to the [[Liceu Conservatory]], studying with the eminent classical guitarists, Graciano Tarrag\u00f3 and [[Renata Tarrag\u00f3]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mjblue.com/bcountry.html|author=Barry McCloud|title=''Definitive Country: The Ultimate Encyclopedia of Country Music and Its Performers'' (Perige, 1995).}}</ref> Upon his return to the States, he joined [[Randy Sparks]] in a group called the New Society and did a tour of the Orient.\n\nWhen the band dissolved in 1967, he signed on with the [[Chad Mitchell Trio]] for a year, spending some of that time co-writing with another member, [[John Denver]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://chadmitchelltrio.com/|title=Chad Mitchell Trio - Official Website|website=Chadmitchelltrio.com|access-date=August 7, 2021}}</ref> The group was renamed Denver, Boise & Johnson. When the trio came to an end, Johnson made a radical departure from everything he had done previously by taking on a major supporting role in the off-Broadway production of ''[[Jacques Brel Is Alive and Well and Living in Paris]].''<ref>{{cite magazine |url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/obituary/7881194/bluer-than-blue-michael-johnson-obit |title='Bluer Than Blue' Singer Michael Johnson Dies at 72 |first=Chuck |last=Dauphin |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |date=July 27, 2017 |issn=0006-2510}}</ref>\n\nIn 1971, Johnson signed with [[Atco Records]] to record his first album, ''There Is A Breeze'', which was released in 1973 and produced by Johnson, Chris Dedrick, [[Peter Yarrow]] and [[Phil Ramone]] in New York and Toronto, Canada.<ref name=\"LarkinCountry\">{{cite book|title=[[Encyclopedia of Popular Music|The Guinness Who's Who of Country Music]]|editor=[[Colin Larkin (writer)|Colin Larkin]]|publisher=[[Guinness Publishing]]|date=1993|edition=First|isbn=0-85112-726-6|pages=206/8}}</ref> Feeling this first effort was not a true reflection of his music (despite being a best seller in the Minneapolis-St. Paul area), Johnson self-produced his next LP in 1975, ''For All You Mad Musicians'', relying more on his voice and guitar for a folk feel. He followed this up with ''Ain't Dis Da Life'', where he added a rhythm section. With each new recording and his continued touring, his popularity was increasing.\n\nTeaming up with [[Brent Maher]] and Steve Gibson in [[Nashville, Tennessee]], Johnson created a two-song demo consisting of \"[[Bluer Than Blue]]\" and \"[[Almost Like Being in Love]]\" (the latter song from the Broadway musical ''[[Brigadoon (musical)|Brigadoon]]''). [[EMI America]] took one listen and wasted no time in signing him, quickly getting ''The Michael Johnson Album'' out in 1978. \"Bluer Than Blue\" was written by Randy Goodrum. The first single, \"Bluer Than Blue\", became Johnson's first [[Top 40]] hit, peaking at No.&nbsp;12 on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] chart in the summer of 1978;<ref name=\"LarkinCountry\"/> the song became a chart-topping single on the [[Hot Adult Contemporary Tracks|Adult Contemporary]] chart. \"Almost Like Being in Love\" went to No.&nbsp;91 on the [[Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs|R&B]] chart while hitting the Top 5 on the AC chart and the Top 40 on the pop chart. \n\nJohnson recorded five albums in all for EMI and in 1985 moved over to [[RCA Records]],<ref name=\"LarkinCountry\"/> where he adopted a contemporary country style that stayed compatible with his soft, mellow leanings. He scored five Top Ten country hits from 1986 to 1989, including the chart-toppers \"Give Me Wings\" and \"The Moon Is Still Over Her Shoulder.\"<ref name=\"LarkinCountry\"/> After two country albums on RCA (plus two greatest hits collections), Johnson moved over to [[Atlantic Records]] in 1991.\n\nIn 1995, the country music group [[4 Runner]] scored a minor hit with the single \"[[Cain's Blood]]\", for which Johnson co-wrote an updated version with Jack Sundrud of [[Poco (band)|Poco]].\n\n==Death==\nJohnson died at his home in [[Minneapolis|Minneapolis, Minnesota]] on July 25, 2017, two weeks before what would have been his 73rd birthday.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.startribune.com/bluer-than-blue-singer-michael-johnson-dies-at-72/436868903|title='Bluer Than Blue' Singer Michael Johnson dies at 72|first=Jon|last=Bream|newspaper=[[Star Tribune]]|date=July 27, 2017}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n! rowspan=\"2\"|Year\n! magazine|url={{BillboardURLbyName|artist=michael johnson|chart=Country Albums C}}|title=Michael Johnson Album & Song Chart History \u2013 Country Albums|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|access-date=September 24, 2010}}</ref>\n! width=\"40\"|<small>[[Billboard 200|US]]</small><br><ref>{{cite web|url={{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p1667/charts-awards|pure_url=yes}}|title=allmusic ((( Michael Johnson > Charts & Awards > Billboard Albums )))|website=[[Allmusic]]|access-date=September 24, magazine|url=http://www.collectionscanada.gc.ca/rpm/028020-110.01-e.php?PHPSESSID=cg010r1lheoktbud48dql41hb0&q1=Michael+Johnson&q2=Top+Albums%2FCDs&interval=20|title=Results \u2013 RPM \u2013 Library and Archives Canada \u2013 Top Albums/CDs|magazine=[[RPM (magazine)|RPM]]|access-date=September 24, 19, 2012|url-status=dead}}</ref>\n|-\n| 1973\n| ''[[There Is a Breeze]]''\n|\n| align=\"center\"| 213\n|\n| Atco\n|-\n| 1975\n| ''For All You Mad Musicians''\n|\n|\n|\n| rowspan=\"2\"| Sanskrit\n|-\n| chart\n|-\n|}\n\n===Featured singles===\n{| class=\"wikitable\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Year\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Single\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Artist\n! colspan=\"2\"| Peak
