<https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Darden_Smith","to":"Darden Smith"}],"pages":{"38859823":{"pageid":38859823,"ns":0,"title":"Darden Smith","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer-songwriter}}\n\n{{autobiography|date=October 2019}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name         = Darden Smith\n| image        = Darden Smith, Matt Sturtevant.jpeg\n| image_size   =\n| caption      = Smith in 2013\n| birth_name   = Darden Craig Smith\n| birth_date   = {{birth date and age|mf=yes|1962|03|11}}\n| origin       = [[Austin, TX|Austin]], [[Texas]] [[United States|US]]\n| instrument   = [[Guitar]]\n| genre        = [[Folk music|Folk]], [[Americana (music)|Americana]], [[Rock music|Rock]], [[Country music|Country]]\n| occupation   = Singer-songwriter, educator\n| years_active = 1986\u2013present\n| label        = [[Compass Records]], [[Dualtone Music Group]], DardenMusic, [[Columbia Music]], [[Ensign Records]]\n| website      = {{URL|http://www.dardensmith.com}}\n}}\n'''Darden Smith''' (born March 11, 1962, in [[Brenham, Texas]]) is an [[Austin, Texas|Austin]]-based singer-songwriter known for his lyrics and for weaving [[Folk music|folk]] and [[Americana (music)|Americana]] influences with [[Rock music|rock]], [[Pop music|pop]], and the musical roots of his home state.<ref name=\"Quick Change Artist\">Keith Kachtick, \"Quick Change Artist ''Texas Monthly'' p. 70 (October 3, 1996).</ref> His debut album, \"Native Soil,\" was released in 1986. His sixteenth album, ''Western Skies,'' was released March 25, 2022.<ref name=\"Darden Smith Hears Love Calling\">{{Cite web | title=Darden Smith Hears Love Calling on August 27th Album | url=http://www.directcurrentmusic.com/dc-music-news-feed/2013/4/11/darden-smith-hears-love-calling-on-august-27-album-stream-an.html | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130416213737/http://www.directcurrentmusic.com/dc-music-news-feed/2013/4/11/darden-smith-hears-love-calling-on-august-27-album-stream-an.html | archive-date=2013-04-16 }} ''Direct Current Music'' (April 11, 2013). Accessed May 1, 2013.</ref> Smith has published two books, ''The Habit of Noticing: Using Creativity to Make a Life (and a Living) (''2018) and ''Western Skies (2022),'' a companion book for the album of the same name. Over the past two decades, Smith has developed two non-profit programs, The Be An Artist Program (2003)<ref name=\":0\">{{Cite web |title=Darden Smith Songwriting Workshop |url=https://www.marfalivearts.org/darden-smith-songwriting-workshop |access-date=2022-10-12 |website=marfalivearts |language=en}}</ref> and SongwritingWith: Soldiers (2011).<ref name=\":1\">{{Cite web |title=Songwriting With Soldiers |url=https://www.songwritingwithsoldiers.org/ |access-date=2022-10-12 |language=en-US}}</ref> Both use collaborative songwriting to work with groups ranging from children in the classroom to military members returning home from combat.<ref name=\"Music Row\">{{Cite web | author=Jessica Nicholson | title=Nashville Songwriters Partner With SongwritingWith:Soldiers | url=http://www.musicrow.com/2013/04/nashville-songwriters-partner-with-songwritingwithsoldiers/ | publisher=Music Row | date=2013-04-09}}</ref> Smith established SongwritingWith:Soldiers as a separate non-profit organization in 2012.<ref name=\"Writing Songs Provides Peace for Some Soldiers\">{{Cite news |last=Shevory |first=Kristina |date=2012-11-17 |title=Writing Songs Provides Peace for Some Soldiers |language=en-US |work=The New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/11/18/us/songwritingwithsoldiers-eases-way-for-soldiers.html |access-date=2023-02-17 |issn=0362-4331}}</ref>\n\n== Biography ==\nSmith's early interest in music was sparked by singing in the local church choir, the \"seat-rattling sound\" of the church's [[pipe organ]], and accompanying his parents to [[country-western dance]]s. By the third grade, he had a [[guitar]] and a teacher who taught him how to play every song on [[Neil Young]]'s ''[[Harvest (Neil Young album)|Harvest]]'' and ''[[After the Gold Rush]]''. Smith began writing his own songs at age ten. In 1976, after his family moved to [[Humble, Texas]], in the [[Houston]] suburbs, Smith spent his teen years listening to [[Guy Clark]], [[Townes Van Zandt]], [[John Prine]], and [[Bob Dylan]].<ref name=\"Quick Change Artist\"/> His musical influences expanded when he moved to Austin to attend [[The University of Texas]] and was exposed to [[blues]] and [[reggae]], as well as musicians coming out of the [[United Kingdom]] such as [[Nick Lowe]], [[Elvis Costello]], and [[The Pretenders]].<ref>{{Cite web | title=Darden Smith: Biography | url=http://www.last.fm/music/Darden+Smith/+wiki | website=Last FM }}</ref> Smith quickly got involved with Austin's burgeoning music scene, playing in small Austin venues like the Alamo Lounge, Taco Flats, and Waterloo Ice House. By the time Smith graduated with a [[Bachelor of Arts]] in American Studies (1985),<ref>{{Cite web |title=College of Liberal Arts {{!}} The University of Texas at Austin |url=https://liberalarts.utexas.edu/ |access-date=2022-10-12 |website=liberalarts.utexas.edu |language=en}}</ref> he was a regular on the local and Texas music scenes.<ref name=\"Quick Change Artist\"/> He has one son and one daughter.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.thebluegrasssituation.com/read/conversations-darden-smith |title=Conversations With... Darden Smith &#124; the Bluegrass Situation |access-date=2015-06-18 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150618214412/http://www.thebluegrasssituation.com/read/conversations-darden-smith |archive-date=2015-06-18 |url-status=dead }}</ref>\n\n== Career ==\n\n[[File:Darden Smith Performing.jpeg|thumb|350px|left|Photograph by Stacy L. Pearsall]]\nAfter releasing ''Native Soil'' in 1986,<ref>{{Citation |title=Darden Smith - Native Soil |date=1986 |url=https://www.discogs.com/release/6632826-Darden-Smith-Native-Soil |language=en |access-date=2022-10-12}}</ref> Darden Smith was signed by [[Dick James Music]] to a publishing deal. In 1987, [[Epic Records]] signed Smith at the inaugural [[South by Southwest Festival]] and released ''Darden Smith'' (1988), which produced two country chart hit singles, \u201cLittle Maggie\u201d and \u201cDay After Tomorrow.\u201d<ref>{{Cite web | author=Johnny Loftus | title=Darden Smith Biography | url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/darden-smith-mn0000572385  | publisher=AllMusic}}</ref> Later that year, [[Nigel Grainge]], the head of [[Ensign Records]], introduced Smith to the British songwriter [[Boo Hewerdine]]. Four days later, they had eight songs and a record deal with Ensign/Chrysalis that resulted in ''Evidence'' (1989). After Smith's label deal with Epic was transferred to the pop division of [[Columbia Records]], he released ''[[Trouble No More (Darden Smith album)|Trouble No More]]'' (1990), best known for \u201cMidnight Train\u201d and \u201cFrankie & Sue,\" and ''[[Little Victories (Darden Smith album)|Little Victories]]'' (1993) which included the Top 10 pop hit single, \"Loving Arms\".<ref name=\"Quick Change Artist\"/>\n\nSmith left Columbia in 1995 and spent several years without an agent or label. He returned to recording through independent labels, which led to ''Deep Fantastic Blue'',<ref>{{Cite web |first=Keith |last=Kachtick |date=1996-10-01 |title=Quick-Change Artist |url=https://www.texasmonthly.com/arts-entertainment/quick-change-artist/ |access-date=2022-10-12 |website=Texas Monthly |language=en}}</ref> on Plump Records,<ref>{{Cite web |title=Plump Records |url=https://www.discogs.com/label/24030-Plump-Records |access-date=2022-10-12 |website=Discogs |language=en}}</ref> and a trio of albums for [[Dualtone Records]]\u00a0(''Sunflower'', 2002; ''Circo'', 2004; ''Field of Crows'', 2005).<ref name=\"Marathon\">{{Cite web | author=Jim Caligiuri | title=Darden Smith - For the Sake of the Song | url=http://www.austinchronicle.com/music/2010-11-26/darden-smith-marathon/ }}</ref> He self- released a collection of his favorites from his previous albums, ''After All This Time'',<ref>{{Cite web |last=Armstrong |first=Gene |title=Darden Smith: After All This Time: The Best of Darden Smith (Darden Music) |url=https://www.tucsonweekly.com/tucson/darden-smith-after-all-this-time-the-best-of-darden-smith-darden-music/Content?oid=1816547 |access-date=2022-10-12 |website=Tucson Weekly |language=en}}</ref> in 2007, to ''Marathon''<ref>{{Cite web |last=Caligiuri |first=Jim |date=November 26, 2010 |title=Darden Smith: Marathon Album Review |url=https://www.austinchronicle.com/music/2010-11-26/darden-smith-marathon/ |access-date=2022-10-12 |website=www.austinchronicle.com |language=en-US}}</ref> (2010), a 15-track cycle of songs named for a remote town in West Texas, described by one reviewer as \"a peak in [Smith's] 25-year songwriting career.<ref>{{Cite web | author=Patrick Beach | title=Lesson in Passion | url=http://www.statesman.com/news/entertainment/music/lesson-in-passion-austin-singer-songwriter-darde-2/nRbdp/ | archive-url=https://archive.today/20130630093304/http://www.statesman.com/news/entertainment/music/lesson-in-passion-austin-singer-songwriter-darde-2/nRbdp/ |archive-date=2013-06-30 }}</ref> His 2017 album ''Everything''<ref>{{Cite web |last=Hernandez |first=Raoul |date=April 14, 2017 |title=Darden Smith: Everything Album Review |url=https://www.austinchronicle.com/music/2017-04-14/darden-smith-everything/ |access-date=2022-10-12 |website=www.austinchronicle.com |language=en-US}}</ref> was co-produced by Smith and [[Stewart Lerman]] and released on [[Compass Records]]. ''The Habit of Noticing:Using Creativity to Make a Life (and a Living)'' (2018) was published by Irie Books.<ref>{{Cite web |title=The Habit of Noticing |url=https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/41718670-the-habit-of-noticing |access-date=2022-10-12 |website=www.goodreads.com}}</ref> ''Western Skies'' (2022) is multi-media work comprising a new studio record, a book of photography, lyrics, and essays. A spoken word album, ''Western Skies - The Essays'' (2022) was released in 2022.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Shannon |first=Hannah Means |date=2022-03-28 |title=Interview: Darden Smith Takes The Time To Discover 'Western Skies' \u2022 Americana Highways |url=https://americanahighways.org/2022/03/28/interview-darden-smith-takes-the-time-to-discover-western-skies/ |access-date=2022-10-12 |website=Americana Highways |language=en-US}}</ref> Smith continues to write songs for his own albums as well as collaborating with other writers on outside projects. He tours regularly, performing at venues across America and the UK.\n\n== Visual Art ==\nSmith began drawing in his late twenties as a way to remain creative while traveling for music. What began a private exercise now makes up a major part of his work. His first gallery show was at Austin\u2019s Bale Creek Allen Gallery (2018).<ref>{{Cite web |title=Bale Creek Allen Gallery |url=http://balecreekallengallery.com/ |access-date=2022-10-12 |website=Bale Creek Allen Gallery |language=en-US}}</ref> His work is in corporate and private collections in the US, UK and Europe. ''The Western Skies \u2013 Lithographs'' series premiered at Houston\u2019s Redbud Gallery in March 2022.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Darden Smith {{!}} Redbud Gallery {{!}} Houston |url=https://www.redbudgallery.com/darden-smith |access-date=2022-10-12 |website=redbud-gallery |language=en}}</ref> ''Lucky Strikes'', an etching from 2018, was purchased by the Library of Congress for the Prints and Photography Collection.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Library of Congress Acquisitions |url=https://www.flatbedpress.com/library-of-congress-acquisitions |access-date=2022-10-12 |website=Flatbed Press |language=en-US}}</ref>\n\n== Collaborative Songwriting ==\nSmith began writing songs with non-songwriters in 2003 with Smith founded The Be An Artist Program in 2003.<ref name=\":0\" /> The program bringing arts and creativity into educational settings, including songwriting with students. Smith has brought this work to such diverse groups as homeless young adults at [[Covenant House]] in [[New Jersey]]; residents of [[South Africa]] and [[Sefhare]], [[Botswana]] suffering from [[HIV/AIDS]], and Israeli and Palestinian groups. He co-founded SongwritingWith:Soldiers in 2012 with Mary Judd to bring professional songwriters together with military members and their families to process the effects of combat and the return home.<ref name=\":1\" /> In 2021 he co-founded Frontline Songs to bring this therapeutic process to frontline healthcare workers during the pandemic. Through his Collaborative Songwriting, he works with corporate clients and individuals to use songwriting in corporate settings to help tell stories through song, and to foster greater understanding.\n\n== Other contributions ==\n\n* Songwriter-in-Residence at [[University of Texas at Austin]]'s College of Fine Arts<ref>{{cite web | url=https://news.utexas.edu/2023/09/07/ut-names-darden-smith-its-inaugural-texas-songwriter-in-residence/ | title=UT Names Darden Smith its Inaugural Texas Songwriter in Residence | date=7 September 2023 }}</ref>\n* Artist-in-Residence at [[Oklahoma State University]]\u2019s Institute for Creativity and Innovation<ref>{{cite web|title=Institute for Creativity and Innovation| url= http://creativity.okstate.edu/speakerseries/past-speakerseries/ |date=October 7, 2011}}{{dead link|date=June 2024}}</ref>\n* Arts Entrepreneur-in-Residence at Oklahoma's School of Entrepreneurship.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://entrepreneurship.okstate.edu/ses/cie/ |title=Creativity, Innovation, and Entrepreneurship Scholars Program |access-date=2013-04-06 |archive-date=2013-07-16 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130716055202/http://entrepreneurship.okstate.edu/ses/cie/ |url-status=dead }}</ref>\n* Published \"Using Your Gift: Creativity in the Classroom\" with [[The Huffington Post]].<ref>{{Cite web | title=Darden Smith: Using Your Gift: Creativity in the College Classroom | url=http://lifestyle.topnewstoday.org/lifestyle/article/5323392/ | archive-url=https://archive.today/20130705172217/http://lifestyle.topnewstoday.org/lifestyle/article/5323392/ | archive-date=2013-07-05 | publisher=Top News Today}}</ref>\n* Developed scripts and workshop performances of \u201cMarathon\u201d (2009\u201310).<ref name=\"Marathon\"/>\n* Researched and produced \u201cSongs From the Big Sky,\u201d a radio documentary on Texas songwriters for [[BBC Radio 2]] (2006).<ref>{{Cite web |title=BBC - Music - South By South West |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/music/southbysouthwest/radio2/schedule.shtml |access-date=2023-02-17 |website=www.bbc.co.uk}}</ref>\n* Composed \u201cGrand Motion,\u201d a symphony commissioned by [[Peter Bay]] for the [[Austin Symphony Orchestra]], accompanied by dance performance inspired by composition (1999).<ref name=\"Singer takes symphony in new direction\">Jerry Young, \"Singer takes symphony in new direction,\" ''Austin American-Statesman,'' (November 4, 1999).</ref>\n* Composed music for dance/theatre productions, including \u201c9 Chains to the Moon\u201d and \u201cWalking on Water\u201d for the Johnson/Long Dance Company in Austin, TX (1988\u201394).<ref name=\"Singer takes symphony in new direction\"/>\n\n==Discography==\n\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n|-\n! re-released Compass Records, 1996\n|-\n| Darden Smith || \n* Released: 1988\n* Label: CBS/Epic Records\n|-\n| Native Soil || \n* Released: 1986\n* Label: Redi-Mix Records; re-released on [[Watermelon Records]], 1992\n|}\n\n== References ==\n\n{{Reflist}}\n\n== External links ==\n* [http://www.dardensmith.com Darden Smith's Official Website]\n* [http://www.songwritingwithsoldiers.org SongwritingWith:Soldiers Website]\n* [https://web.archive.org/web/20131104213708/http://www.thebeanartistprogram.com/ The Be An Artist Program Website]\n\n{{Commons category|Darden Smith}}\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Smith, Darden Craig}}\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:1962 births]]\n[[Category:People from Brenham, Texas]]\n[[Category:Singers from Austin, Texas]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from Texas]]\n[[Category:Country musicians from Texas]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Jeff_Hanna","to":"Jeff Hanna"}],"pages":{"50157170":{"pageid":50157170,"ns":0,"title":"Jeff Hanna","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer-songwriter (born 1947)}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name             = \n| image            = Hanna 2024.jpg\n| image_upright    = \n| image_size       = \n| landscape        = \n| alt              = Jeff Hanna singing and playing an acoustic guitar\n| caption          = Hanna performing with Nitty Gritty Dirt Band, 2024\n| birth_name       = Jeffrey R. Hanna\n| alias            = \n| birth_date       = {{birth date and age|1947|07|11}}\n| birth_place      = [[Detroit, Michigan]], U.S.\n| origin           = [[Long Beach, California]], U.S.\n| genre            = [[Country music|Country]], [[folk music|folk]], [[rock music|rock]]\n| occupation       = Singer, songwriter\n| instrument       = Vocals, guitar, drums\n| years_active     = 1966 \u2013 present\n| current_member_of = [[Nitty Gritty Dirt Band]]\n| spouse = {{Marriage|[[Matraca Berg]]|1993}}\n}}\n'''Jeffrey R. Hanna''' (born July 11, 1947) is an American singer-songwriter and performance musician, best known for his association with the [[Nitty Gritty Dirt Band]]. His professional music career has spanned seven decades.\n\n==Early life==\nHanna was born in Detroit, Michigan.<ref name=\"discogs\">{{cite web |url=https://www.discogs.com/artist/330658-Jeff-Hanna |title=Jeff Hanna Discography |work=discogs.com |publisher=[[Discogs]] |accessdate=2016-04-12 }}</ref> In 1962, he moved with his family to Long Beach, California. As a high school student there, he and some friends started a [[jug band]] that ultimately evolved into the Nitty Gritty Dirt Band.<ref name=\"encyclopedia\">{{cite encyclopedia |editor-last=Stambler |editor-first=Irwin |editor2-last=Landon |editor2-first=Grelun |encyclopedia=Country Music: The Encyclopedia |pages=135\u2013137 |title=Dirt Band, Nitty Gritty Dirt Band |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=d18K8QWcEo8C&q=jeff+hanna+biography&pg=PA135 |date=2000-07-14 |publisher=Macmillan |isbn=9780312264871 |accessdate=2016-04-12 }}</ref>\n\n==Musical career==\nHe was one of the founders and is the longest-serving member of the Nitty Gritty Dirt Band, where he has been a singer, songwriter, lead guitarist, drummer and [[Washboard (musical instrument)|washboard player]]. Through the years, he has been a major force in keeping the band together and maintaining its blend of folk, country and rock music.<ref name=\"discogs\"/><ref name=\"encyclopedia\"/>\n\nHanna has over 380 recording credits, primarily as a composer, but also as a vocalist, guitarist ([[acoustic guitar|acoustic]], [[electric guitar|electric]], [[steel guitar|steel]], [[slide guitar|slide]], [[Twelve-string guitar|twelve-string]], and [[baritone guitar|baritone]]), arranger, and producer.<ref name=\"credits\">{{cite web |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/jeff-hanna-mn0000189629/credits |title=Jeff Hanna - Credits |work=allmusic.com |publisher=[[AllMusic]] |accessdate=2016-04-12 }}</ref>\n\nIn addition to the Nitty Gritty Dirt Band, his credits include work with artists such as [[Linda Ronstadt]], [[Suzy Bogguss]], [[The Texas Tenors]], [[Patty Loveless]], [[Rascal Flatts]], [[Matraca Berg]], [[Hannah Montana]], [[Emmylou Harris]], [[The Chieftains]], [[Johnny Cash]], [[June Carter Cash]], [[Earl Scruggs]], [[Michael Martin Murphey]], [[Dickey Betts]], and [[Steve Martin]].<ref name=\"credits\"/>\n\nIn 2006, his composition \"[[Bless the Broken Road]]\", co-written with [[Marcus Hummon]] and Bobby Boyd in 1994, won a [[Grammy Award for Best Country Song]].<ref name=\"awards\">{{cite web |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/jeff-hanna-mn0000189629/awards |title=Jeff Hanna - Awards |work=allmusic.com |publisher=[[AllMusic]] |accessdate=2016-04-12 }}</ref> It has been recorded by the Nitty Gritty Dirt Band, Marcus Hummon, and, in the Grammy year, [[Rascal Flatts]].<ref name=\"theboot\">{{cite web |url=http://theboot.com/jeff-hanna-matraca-berg-country-love-stories/ |title=Jeff Hanna + Matraca Berg \u2014 Country's Greatest Love Stories |work=theboot.com |accessdate=2016-04-12 }}</ref>\n\n==Personal life==\nHanna's children are visual artist Christopher Hanna, and Jaime Hanna. Jamie was formerly a touring member of [[the Mavericks]] before founding the duo [[Hanna-McEuen]]. He joined Nitty Gritty Dirt Band in 2018.<ref name=\"ArtistDirect\">{{cite web |url=http://www.artistdirect.com/artist/bio/hanna-mceuen/3273816 |title=Hanna-McEuen Biography |authorlink=[[Artistdirect]] |work=artistdirect.com |publisher=ARTISTdirect |accessdate=2016-04-12 }}</ref>\n\nHe has been married to [[Matraca Berg]] since December 5, 1993. The couple met while touring with [[Clint Black]] in the late 1980s. They live in Nashville, Tennessee.<ref name=\"theboot\"/>\n\n==References==\n{{reflist}}\n{{Nitty Gritty Dirt Band}}\n{{authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Hanna, Jeff}}\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:1947 births]]\n[[Category:Nitty Gritty Dirt Band members]]\n[[Category:American folk singers]]\n[[Category:American male singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:American country guitarists]]\n[[Category:American rock guitarists]]\n[[Category:American folk guitarists]]\n[[Category:American slide guitarists]]\n[[Category:Steel guitarists]]\n[[Category:American lead guitarists]]\n[[Category:American acoustic guitarists]]\n[[Category:American country rock singers]]\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Grammy Award winners]]\n[[Category:American male guitarists]]\n[[Category:20th-century American guitarists]]\n[[Category:20th-century American male musicians]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from Michigan]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Rhiannon_Giddens","to":"Rhiannon Giddens"}],"pages":{"36521333":{"pageid":36521333,"ns":0,"title":"Rhiannon Giddens","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American musician (born 1977)}}\n{{Use American English|date=June 2022}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=June 2022|cs1-dates=y}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name             = Rhiannon Giddens\n| image            = Rhiannon-Giddens.jpg\n| image_size       = \n| landscape        = yes\n| alt              = Rhiannon Giddens with a stringed instrument\n| caption          = Giddens performing at [[Aarhus Festuge|Aarhus Festival]] in 2015\n| birth_date       = {{Birth date and age|1977|2|21}}\n| birth_place      = [[Greensboro, North Carolina|Greensboro]], North Carolina, U.S.\n| alias            = \n| origin           = \n| genre            = {{hlist|[[Folk music|Folk]]|[[old-time music]]|[[Bluegrass music|bluegrass]]|[[Country music|country]]|[[Gospel music|gospel]]|[[blues]]|[[jazz]]|[[Soul music|soul]]|R&B|[[Celtic music|Celtic]]|[[Americana (music)|Americana]]}}\n| instruments      = {{hlist|Vocals|[[fiddle]]|[[banjo]]|viola}}\n| years_active     = 2005\u2013present\n| label            = {{hlist|[[Music Maker (label)|Music Maker]]|[[Nonesuch Records|Nonesuch]]}}\n| past_member_of   = {{hlist|[[Carolina Chocolate Drops]]|[[The New Basement Tapes]]}}\n| website          = {{Official website}}\n}}\n\n'''Rhiannon Giddens''' (born February 21, 1977) is an American musician known for her eclectic [[American folk music|folk music]]. She is a founding member of the [[Country music|country]], [[blues]], and [[old-time music]] band the [[Carolina Chocolate Drops]], where she was the lead singer, fiddle player, and [[banjo]] player.\n\nGiddens is a native of [[Greensboro, North Carolina]]. In addition to her work with the [[Grammy Award|Grammy]]-winning<ref>{{Cite web |title=Past Winners Search |url=http://www.grammy.com/nominees/search?artist=&field_nominee_work_value=&year=2010&genre=59 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029202620/http://www.grammy.com/nominees/search?artist=&field_nominee_work_value=&year=2010&genre=59 |archive-date=2013-10-29 |access-date=2013-10-28}}</ref> Chocolate Drops, Giddens has released five solo albums: ''[[Tomorrow Is My Turn (album)|Tomorrow Is My Turn]]'' (2015) and ''[[Freedom Highway (Rhiannon Giddens album)|Freedom Highway]]'' (2017), 2019 and 2021's ''[[There Is No Other]]'' and  ''[[They're Calling Me Home]]'' (both collaborations with Italian multi-instrumentalist [[Francesco Turrisi]]), and ''You're the One'' (2023). She appears in the [[Smithsonian Folkways]] collection documenting [[Mike Seeger]]'s final trip through Appalachia in 2009, ''Just Around The Bend: Survival and Revival in Southern Banjo Styles \u2013 Mike Seeger's Last Documentary'' (2019).<ref name=\"SmithsonianSeeger\">{{Cite web |date=September 2019 |title=''Just Around the Bend: Survival and Revival in Southern Banjo Sounds \u2013 Mike Seeger's Last Documentary'' |url=https://folkways.si.edu/mike-seeger/just-around-the-bend-survival-and-revival-in-southern-banjo-styles |access-date=2019-09-11 |website=folkways.si.edu |publisher=[[Smithsonian Folkways]]}}</ref>  In 2014, she participated in the [[T Bone Burnett]]-produced project titled [[The New Basement Tapes]] along with several other musicians, which set a series of recently discovered [[Bob Dylan]] lyrics to newly composed music.  The resulting album, ''[[Lost on the River: The New Basement Tapes]]'', was a top-40 Billboard album.\n\nIn 2023, the opera ''[[Omar (opera)|Omar]]'', co-written by Giddens and [[Michael Abels]], won the [[Pulitzer Prize for Music]].<ref>{{cite web |title=2023 Pulitzer Prizes |url=https://www.pulitzer.org/prize-winners-by-year/2023 |website=Pulitzer.org |access-date=9 May 2023}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Rhiannon Giddens Announces Forthcoming Album on Heels of Pulitzer Prize News|url=https://variety.com/2023/music/news/rhiannon-giddens-album-youre-one-pulitzer-prize-1235607326/|website= variety.com|date=May 9, 2023 |access-date=9 May 2023}}</ref>\n\n==Early life==\nGiddens is of [[multiracial]] ancestry. Her father, David Giddens, is [[European-American]]. Her mother, Deborah Jamieson, is a descendant of African Americans and [[Native_Americans_in_the_United_States|Native American tribes]] including the [[Lumbee]], [[Occaneechi]], and [[Seminole]]. Giddens does not claim any specific tribal affiliation.<ref>{{Cite magazine |date=2019-05-09 |title=Rhiannon Giddens and What Folk Music Means |url=https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2019/05/20/rhiannon-giddens-and-what-folk-music-means |access-date=2023-01-20 |magazine=The New Yorker |language=en-US}}</ref> David and Deborah met as college students in the city of [[Greensboro, North Carolina]]. Giddens' parents separated soon after her birth, when Deborah came out as a lesbian.<ref>{{Cite magazine |last=Sullivan |first=John Jeremiah |date=2019-05-13 |title=Rhiannon Giddens and What Folk Music Means |url=https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2019/05/20/rhiannon-giddens-and-what-folk-music-means |magazine=The New Yorker |language=en-US |issn=0028-792X}}</ref>\n\nRhiannon and her sister Lalenja grew up in Greensboro and nearby rural [[Gibsonville, North Carolina|Gibsonville]].<ref>{{Cite news |last=Gil de Rubio |first=Dave |date=2015-04-15 |title=Rhiannon Giddens Doesn't Need No Stinking Labels |work=Long Island Weekly |url=http://longislandweekly.com/rhiannon-giddens-doesnt-need-no-stinking-labels/ |access-date=2016-05-12}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=Rhiannon Giddens: Pure Folk-Music Fire From 'A Good-Ol' Mixed Race North Carolinian' |url=https://indiancountrymedianetwork.com/culture/arts-entertainment/rhiannon-giddens-pure-folk-music-fire-from-a-good-ol-mixed-race-north-carolinian/ |access-date=2018-05-12 |publisher=Indian Country Today}}</ref><ref>{{Cite magazine |last=[[John Jeremiah Sullivan|Sullivan, John Jeremiah]] |date=2019-05-13 |title=Rhiannon Giddens and What Folk Music Means: The roots musician is inspired by the evolving legacy of the black string band |url=https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2019/05/20/rhiannon-giddens-and-what-folk-music-means |access-date=2020-10-14 |magazine=[[The New Yorker]]}}</ref> Lalenja Harrington is a director for Beyond Academics, a four-year certificate program supporting students with intellectual and developmental disabilities, at the [[University of North Carolina at Greensboro]]. A singer and songwriter herself, Harrington occasionally collaborates with her sister on musical projects.{{refn|{{Cite magazine |last=McDowell |first=Ian |date=2018-04-24 |title=Not just a Giddens sister: Lalenja Harrington sings out, educates and inspires |url=https://yesweekly.com/not-just-a-giddens-sister-lalenja-harrington-sings-out-educates-and-inspires/ |magazine=[[Yes! Weekly]]}}}}\n\n==Musical career==\n[[File:Rhiannon Giddens TFF 03.JPG|thumb|right|Giddens at [[Rudolstadt]] in 2015]]\n\nGiddens is a 1995 alumna of the [[North Carolina School of Science and Mathematics]],<ref>{{Cite web |last=Tomlinson |first=Tommy |date=2015-09-02 |title=Rhiannon Giddens & The Making of NC's Most Beautiful Voice |url=https://www.ourstate.com/rhiannon-giddens/ |access-date=2017-08-14 |website=Our State Celebrating North Carolina}}</ref> and a 2000 graduate of [[Oberlin Conservatory]] at [[Oberlin College]], where she studied opera.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Menconi |first=David |date=Spring 2011 |title=Creating Old-Time Music for the 21st Century |url=http://oberlin.edu/alummag/spring2011/features/oldtime.html |access-date=2013-01-21 |website=Oberlin Alumni Magazine |archive-date=2012-10-13  |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121013005053/http://oberlin.edu/alummag/spring2011/features/oldtime.html }}</ref>\n\nIn 2005, Giddens, who at that time was spending time participating in [[Scottish traditional music]] competitions (specializing in the [[Scottish Gaelic|Gaelic]] [[lilting]] tradition, also known as mouth music),<ref>{{Cite web |last=Wosahla |first=Steve |date=2008-04-30 |title=Carolina Chocolate Drops \u2013 Digging back, driving forward |url=http://nodepression.com/article/carolina-chocolate-drops-digging-back-driving-forward |access-date=2017-04-02 |publisher=No Depression}}</ref><ref>{{Cite magazine |last=Sullivan |first=John Jeremiah |date=2019-05-13 |title=Rhiannon Giddens and What Folk Music Means |url=https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2019/05/20/rhiannon-giddens-and-what-folk-music-means |magazine=New Yorker |access-date=2019-05-14}}</ref> attended the Black Banjo Then and Now Gathering, in [[Boone, North Carolina]]. There she met [[Dom Flemons]] and S\u00fale Greg Wilson. The three started playing together professionally as  a \"postmodern string band\", Sankofa Strings.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Epstein |first=Jon |title=Sankofa Strings: &#124; Features &#124; Creative Loafing Charlotte |url=http://clclt.com/charlotte/sankofa-strings/Content?oid=2141147 |access-date=2017-04-02 |website=Clclt.com}}</ref> During that same time period, Giddens was also a regular caller at local [[contra dance]]s and featured in a Celtic music band called Gaelwynd. Later in 2005, after both Gaelwynd and Sankofa Strings had released CD albums, Giddens and Flemons teamed up with other musicians and expanded the Sankofa Strings sound into what was to become the Grammy winning [[Carolina Chocolate Drops]].\n\nIn 2007, Giddens contributed fiddle, banjo, \"flat-footin'\" dancing and additional vocals to [[Talitha MacKenzie]]'s album ''Indian Summer''.\n\nPerforming as a soprano, Giddens and mezzo-soprano Cheryse McLeod Lewis formed a duo called Eleganza to release a CD in 2009. ''Because I Knew You...'' consists of classical, religious, theater, and movie music. Giddens and Lewis were middle school classmates who reconnected after college while working in the same office. The friends started singing together in 2003, but did not begin recording until 2008.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Pandolfi |first=Elizabeth |title=Classical duo Eleganza mixes it up musically |work=Charleston City Paper |url=http://www.charlestoncitypaper.com/charleston/classical-duo-eleganza-mixes-it-up-musically/Content?oid=3612268 |access-date=2017-04-10}}</ref>\n\nAs of November 12, 2013, Giddens became the only original member of the Carolina Chocolate Drops.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Carolina Chocolate Drops' Fan Bridge Newsletter |url=http://carolinachocolatedrops.fanbridge.com/campaigns/show.php?id=1042389 |access-date=2013-11-12 |website=Fanbridge.com| date=April 16, 2013 }}</ref>\n\nIn 2013, Giddens began pushing further into her solo career. Giddens participated in \"Another Day, Another Time\", a concert inspired by the [[Coen brothers]] film ''[[Inside Llewyn Davis]]''.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Another Day, Another Time |url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt3358552/ |access-date=2014-04-23 |website=IMDb.com}}</ref> Many critics have stated that Giddens had the best performance at what was called \"the concert of the year\".<ref name=\"Pareles\">{{Cite news |last=Pareles |first=Jon |date=2013-09-30 |title=Traditional Folk Frolic, With Old-Time Fervor and Youthful Yelps |work=[[The New York Times]] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/10/01/arts/music/another-day-another-time-a-concert-at-town-hall.html?_r=0 |access-date=2015-02-07}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Rosen |first=Christopher |date=2013-09-30 |title=5 Memorable Moments From The 'Inside Llewyn Davis' Concert, 'Another Day, Another Time' |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/09/30/another-day-another-time-inside-llewyn-davis_n_4018148.html |access-date=2017-04-02 |website=[[The Huffington Post]]}}</ref> Late in 2013, Giddens contributed the standout [[a cappella]] track \"We Rise\" to the LP ''We Are Not For Sale: Songs of Protest'' by the NC Music Love Army \u2013 a collective of activist musicians from North Carolina founded by [[Jon Lindsay (musician)|Jon Lindsay]] and [[Caitlin Cary]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=nc music love army |url=http://ncmusiclovearmy.org/ |access-date=2017-04-02 |publisher=nc music love army}}</ref> Giddens' protest song joins contributions from many other Carolina musical luminaries on the Lindsay-produced compilation (11/26/13 via [[Redeye Distribution]]), which was created to support the NC NAACP and the [[Moral Monday]] movement.<ref>{{Cite web |title='Songs of Protest' in North Carolina Mirror Activists' Anti-GOP Stance |url=https://news.yahoo.com/songs-protest-north-carolina-mirror-activists-anti-gop-185600220.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131210022014/http://news.yahoo.com/songs-protest-north-carolina-mirror-activists-anti-gop-185600220.html |archive-date=2013-12-10 |access-date=2017-01-15}}</ref>\n\nIn early 2014, Giddens recorded for ''[[Lost on the River: The New Basement Tapes]]'' alongside [[Elvis Costello]], [[Marcus Mumford]], [[Taylor Goldsmith]] and [[Jim James]]. The album was produced by [[T Bone Burnett]] and is a compilation of partial, unreleased lyrics written by [[Bob Dylan]].<ref>{{Cite magazine |last=Grow |first=Kory |date=2014-03-25 |title=Elvis Costello, Marcus Mumford, Jim James Record 'Lost' Dylan Lyrics The project, 'Lost on the River: The New Basement Tapes,' will come out in the fall |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/elvis-costello-marcus-mumford-jim-james-record-lost-dylan-lyrics-20140325 |magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] |access-date=2014-04-23}}</ref>\n\n[[File:Rhiannon Giddens (20072121276).jpg|thumb|Giddens performing in [[Edmonton]] in 2015]]\nIn February 2015, Giddens released her debut solo album, ''[[Tomorrow Is My Turn (album)|Tomorrow Is My Turn]]'', on [[Nonesuch Records]]. Also produced by Burnett, the album includes songs made famous by [[Patsy Cline]], [[Odetta]], [[Dolly Parton]], and [[Nina Simone]], among others.<ref name=Pareles/><ref>{{Cite web |date=2014-11-19 |title=Rhiannon Giddens, of Carolina Chocolate Drops, to Release Solo Debut Album \"Tomorrow Is My Turn,\" Produced by T Bone Burnett, February 10 |url=http://www.nonesuch.com/journal/rhiannon-giddens-carolina-chocolate-drops-solo-debut-album-t-bone-burnett-2014-11-19 |first=Danny|last= McElhinney|access-date=2015-06-11 |website=Nonesuch.com}}</ref> The ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'' said the album \"confirms the arrival of a significant talent whose voice and distinctive approach communicate the simmering emotion at the core of the songs.\"<ref>{{Cite news |date=2015-02-10 |title=Music review: Rhiannon Giddens in Resolute Voice |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/music-review-rhiannon-giddens-in-resolute-voice-1423610343 |first=Jim |last=Fusilli|access-date=2017-04-02 |newspaper=The Wall Street Journal}}</ref> Additionally, the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' called the album \"a collection that should solidify her status as one of the bright new lights in pop music.\"<ref>{{Cite news |title=Rhiannon Giddens discovers true calling with help from friends |work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|first=Randy|last= Lewis |url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/music/la-et-ms-ca-rhiannon-giddens-20141228-story.html |date=December 27, 2014|access-date=2017-04-02}}</ref>\n\nIn July 2015, she had a big stage at world music folk and dance festival at [[TFF Rudolstadt]] in Germany.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Rhiannon Giddens at Heinepark Stage 3 July 2015 |url=http://tff-rudolstadt.de/de/programm/artistdetail/artist/rhiannon-giddens/bp/p100/ba/a36.html |access-date=2015-07-03 |publisher=TFF Rudolstadt}}</ref> Her performance was also broadcast live by the German national public radio [[Deutschlandfunk]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=Rudolstadt-Festival \u2013 das gr\u00f6\u00dfte Folk-Roots-Weltmusik-Festival Deutschlands \u2013 Rudolstadt-Festival 6. \u2013 9. Juli 2017 |url=http://tff-rudolstadt.de/de/tff-media/radio-tv.html |access-date=2017-04-02 |website=Tff-rudolstadt.de}}</ref> Rhiannon appears on [[Jon Lindsay (musician)|Jon Lindsay]]'s single \"Ballad of Lennon Lacy\" ([[Redeye Distribution]], August 21). The song tackles the mysterious hanging death of [[Death of Lennon Lacy|Lennon Lacy]], a black teen from rural [[Bladenboro, North Carolina]].<ref>{{Cite web |last=Devores |first=Courtney |date=2015-08-07 |title=Charlotte songwriter 'obsessed' with teen death case |url=http://www.charlotteobserver.com/entertainment/music-news-reviews/article30409689.html |access-date=2017-04-02 |website=Charlotte Observer}}</ref>\n\nOn November 27, 2015, to coincide with the Black Friday [[Record Store Day]] event, Giddens released ''Factory Girl'' (EP) on Nonesuch Records, which contained music culled from the same T Bone Burnett\u2013produced sessions that yielded ''Tomorrow Is My Turn''.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Nonesuch to Release Rhiannon Giddens's EP \"Factory Girl\" for Black Friday Record Store Day, November 27 &#124; Nonesuch Records |url=http://www.nonesuch.com/journal/nonesuch-rhiannon-giddens-ep-factory-girl-black-friday-record-store-day-november-27-2015-10-20 |access-date=2017-04-02 |website=Nonesuch.com|date=October 20, 2015 }}</ref> A digital version of Factory Girl was made available December 11, 2015. The sessions for the album and EP took place in Los Angeles and [[Nashville]], with a multi-generational group of players assembled by Burnett. Musicians on Factory Girl include Burnett; fiddle player [[Gabe Witcher]] and double bassist [[Paul Kowert]] of [[Punch Brothers]]; percussionist [[Jack Ashford]] of Motown's renowned [[Funk Brothers]]; drummer [[Jay Bellerose]]; guitarist [[Colin Linden]]; veteran Nashville session bassist Dennis Crouch; and Giddens's Carolina Chocolate Drops touring band-mates, multi-instrumentalist [[Hubby Jenkins]] and beat-boxer [[Adam Matta]].\n\nRhiannon appeared on ''[[Jools' Annual Hootenanny|Jools Holland's Hootenanny]]'' on December 31, 2015, shown on [[BBC Two]]. She performed songs from her 2015 album ''[[Tomorrow Is My Turn (album)|Tomorrow Is My Turn]]'', including \"Waterboy\" and a cover of \"[[St. James Infirmary Blues]]\" with [[Tom Jones (singer)|Tom Jones]].\n\nIn January 2016, she was selected to take part in [[Transatlantic Sessions]].  This collaboration between American and Celtic musicians is a coveted honor. The ensemble performed as part of [[Celtic Connections]] in Glasgow, and a short UK/Irish tour.  Her performances on the tour included the stirring tribute to [[David Bowie]] \"It Ain't Easy\".  On October 8, 2016, Rhiannon was featured on [[Austin City Limits]].  \n\nLater in 2016, Giddens became the first American to be honored as Folk Singer of the Year at the [[BBC Radio 2 Folk Awards]], and it was announced that she would be receiving the prestigious [[Steve Martin Prize for Excellence in Banjo and Bluegrass]]. Winning this award makes Giddens both the only woman and the only person of color to receive the prize in its six-year history.<ref>{{Cite news |date=2016-09-12 |title=Rhiannon Giddens Brings Diversity to Banjo Award |work=[[The New York Times]]|first=Dave |last=Itzkoff |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/09/12/arts/music/rhiannon-giddens-steve-martin-bluegrass-prize.html |access-date=2017-04-02}}</ref> Also in 2016, it was announced that Giddens and the Carolina Chocolate Drops would be inducted into the [[North Carolina Music Hall of Fame]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=2016 INDUCTION CEREMONY: List of Inductees |url=https://northcarolinamusichalloffame.org/event/2016-induction-ceremony/ |access-date=2017-04-02 |website=Northcarolinamusichalloffame.org}}</ref>\n\nIn 2017, Giddens became only the fourth musician to perform at both the Newport Folk and Jazz Festivals.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Gibbs |first=Ryan |title=5 must-see acts at the 2017 Newport Jazz Festival |url=http://www.newportri.com/newportmercury/arts/rhiannon-giddens/article_14586294-73d6-5006-8f10-c4d79fb7c2ad.html |access-date=2017-08-14 |publisher=Newport Mercury |archive-date=2017-08-07  |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170807075909/http://www.newportri.com/newportmercury/arts/rhiannon-giddens/article_14586294-73d6-5006-8f10-c4d79fb7c2ad.html }}</ref> Later that year, she delivered the keynote address at the World of Bluegrass Business Conference 2017.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Video: Rhiannon Giddens' Keynote Address \u2013 IBMA Business Conference 2017 |url=https://ibma.org/rhiannon-giddens-keynote-address-2017/ |access-date=2023-05-18 |website=ibma.org |date=11 February 2018 |first=Robert |last=Povelones}}</ref> According to Bluegrass Today, \"Giddens shattered long-held stereotypes...By the time she was done, she had systematically dismantled the myth of a homogenous Appalachia.\"<ref>{{Cite web |date=2017-09-27 |title=Rhiannon Giddens: Bluegrass in Black and White |url=https://bluegrasstoday.com/rhiannon-giddens-bluegrass-in-black-and-white/ |access-date=2017-09-27 |website=bluegrasstoday.com}}</ref> In June 2017, Giddens appeared in the multi award-winning documentary ''[[The American Epic Sessions]]'', directed by [[Bernard MacMahon (filmmaker)|Bernard MacMahon]], where she recorded \"One Hour Mama\" and English [[Folk music|folk ballad]] \"[[Pretty Saro]]\", on the restored first [[History of sound recording#The electrical era (1925 to 1945) (including sound on film)|electrical sound recording]] system from the 1920s.<ref>{{Cite news |date=2017-06-06 |title=The Performers in 'The American Epic Sessions' |language=en-US |work=WTTW Chicago Public Media \u2013 Television and Interactive |url=http://interactive.wttw.com/playlist/2017/06/05/performers-american-epic-sessions |access-date=2018-02-27}}</ref> Both performances were released on ''[[Music from The American Epic Sessions: Original Motion Picture Soundtrack]]''.<ref name=\"HeraldScotland-2017\">{{Cite web |title=Album review: Various Artists, American Epic: The Sessions (Columbia/Lo-Max) |url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/arts_ents/15337638.Album_review__Various_Artists__American_Epic__The_Sessions__Columbia_Lo_Max_/ |access-date=2018-02-27 |website=HeraldScotland |date=June 9, 2017 |language=en}}</ref> Upon hearing the playback of these direct-to-disc recordings, she exclaimed \"you feel like your soul is coming out of the speaker.\"<ref name=\"HeraldScotland-2017\" />\n\nIn October 2017, Giddens was named one of the 2017 class of [[MacArthur Fellows Program|MacArthur \"Genius\" Fellows]]. The organization noted, \"Giddens's drive to understand and convey the nuances, complexities, and interrelationships between musical traditions is enhancing our musical present with a wealth of sounds and textures from the past.\"<ref>{{Cite web |title=Rhiannon Giddens \u2013 MacArthur Foundation |url=https://www.macfound.org/fellows/987/ |access-date=2019-01-24 |publisher=Macfound.org}}</ref> Rhiannon further demonstrated the broad range of her musical interests with several subsequent projects. In early November, she performed as a soprano with the [[Louisville Orchestra]] in [[Teddy Abrams]]' multimedia tribute to [[Muhammad Ali]], ''The Greatest''.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Keel |first=Eli |title=Teddy Abrams' 'The Greatest' musically explores Ali in his own words and through the eyes of history |url=https://insiderlouisville.com/lifestyle_culture/arts-and-entertainment/teddy-abrams-the-greatest-musically-explores-ali-in-his-own-words-and-through-the-eyes-of-history/ |access-date=2018-04-27 |publisher=insiderlouisville.com |archive-date=2018-04-27  |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180427184744/https://insiderlouisville.com/lifestyle_culture/arts-and-entertainment/teddy-abrams-the-greatest-musically-explores-ali-in-his-own-words-and-through-the-eyes-of-history/ }}</ref> A week later, she sang with the [[Cincinnati Pops Orchestra]] for their live recording of ''American Originals: 1918'', which explored the early development of jazz during the post WWI era.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Baker |first=Brian |title=Review: 'American Originals' a Great Success |url=https://www.citybeat.com/arts-culture/classical-music/article/20982475/american-originals-at-cincinnati-pops-a-great-success |date=Nov 11, 2017|access-date=2018-04-27 |publisher=citybeat.com}}</ref> In January 2018, Giddens co-produced (with [[Dirk Powell]]) ''[[Songs of Our Native Daughters]]'' for [[Smithsonian Folkways]]. Written and recorded with fellow artists Amythyst Kiah, [[Leyla McCalla]], and Allison Russell, \"The album confronts the ways we are culturally conditioned to avoid talking about America's history of slavery, racism, and misogyny.\"<ref>{{Cite web |title=Smithsonian Folkways Recordings 2018 Release Schedule |url=https://shorefire.com/releases/entry/smithsonian-folkways-recordings-2018-release-schedule |access-date=2018-05-11 |publisher=shorefire.com}}</ref> Also in early 2018, the Nashville Ballet announced that Rhiannon Giddens has been commissioned to write the music for ''Lucy Negro, Redux'', a new dance choreographed by artistic director, Paul Vasterling. Based on the book of the same name by [[Caroline Randall Williams]], its premise is that Shakespeare's Dark Lady was of African descent. The ballet premiered in February 2019.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Stumpfl |first=Amy |title=Nashville Ballet celebrates 'Big Ideas' and major milestones with 2018\u201319 season |url=https://www.tennessean.com/story/life/arts/2018/03/04/nashville-ballet-celebrates-big-ideas-and-major-milestones-2018-19-season/377530002/|date=2018-03-04 |access-date=2018-03-07 |website=www.tennessean.com}}</ref>  Then, in March 2018, Giddens fulfilled a previously announced engagement as guest curator for the [[Cambridge Folk Festival]] by inviting [[Peggy Seeger]], [[Kaia Kater]], [[Birds of Chicago]], Amythyst Kiah, and [[Yola Carter]] to perform at the event.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2018-03-04 |title=Rhiannon Giddens Selects Artists for Cambridge Folk Festival |url=http://www.nonesuch.com/journal/rhiannon-giddens-selects-artists-cambridge-folk-festival-2018-03-21 |access-date=2018-04-27 |publisher=nonesuch.com}}</ref>\n\nGiddens recorded vocals for ''Silo Songs'', an audio installation created by composer Brad Wells for [[Hancock Shaker Village]]. She contributed a song, \"Mountain Hymn\", to the popular video game ''[[Red Dead Redemption 2]]'' which was released in October 2018. The song was written with [[Daniel Lanois]]. In December 2018, she began hosting a podcast called ''[[Aria Code with Rhiannon Giddens]]'' produced by the [[Metropolitan Opera]] and [[WQXR-FM]]. The program examines why individual arias have a lasting impact on audiences and how singers prepare to perform them.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Welcome to Aria Code with Rhiannon Giddens |url=https://www.wnycstudios.org/story/aria-code-rhiannon-giddens-season-one-trailer |access-date=2018-11-15 |publisher=www.wnycstudios.org}}</ref> In 2019, Giddens released two studio albums: ''Songs of Our Native Daughters'' with [[Allison Russell]], [[Leyla McCalla]] and Amythyst Kiah, and ''There Is No Other'' with Italian musician Francesco Turrisi.<ref>{{Cite magazine |last=Bernstein |first=Jonathan |date=2019-02-21 |title=How Our Native Daughters Reimagine Folk Song Narratives |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/our-native-daughters-album-rhiannon-giddens-allison-russell-797295/ |magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] |access-date=2019-05-04}}</ref><ref>{{Cite magazine |last=Betts |first=Stephen L. |date=2019-03-20 |title=Rhiannon Giddens Details Collaborative New Album With Francesco Turrisi |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/rhiannon-giddens-francesco-turrisi-new-album-there-is-no-other-810643/ |magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] |access-date=2019-05-04}}</ref>\n\nFor the 2020 [[Spoleto Festival USA]], Rhiannon Giddens was commissioned to create an opera based on the Arabic language autobiography of [[Omar Ibn Said]], a highly literate and cultured [[Torodbe]] (Muslim cleric)  from the [[Fula people]] of modern [[Senegal]], who was enslaved in an intertribal war against the [[Imamate of Futa Toro]] and brought aboard a slave ship to [[Charleston, South Carolina]] in 1807.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2019-08-21 |title=Making an Opera: Meet the Composer, Rhiannon Giddens |url=https://spoletousa.org/blog/making-an-opera-meet-the-composer-rhiannon-giddens/ |access-date=2020-06-08 |publisher=spoletousa.org}}</ref> Giddens wrote the libretto and served as lead composer with help from co-composer [[Michael Abels]]. Owing to the [[COVID-19 pandemic]], the world premiere of ''[[Omar (opera)|Omar]]'' was postponed until 2022.<ref>{{Cite web |website=[[The New York Times]]|title=Rhiannon Giddens Is Writing an Opera|author=Cooper, Michael|date=2019-06-10|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2019/06/10/arts/music/rhiannon-giddens-opera.html|access-date=2021-11-25|url-access=subscription}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=Omar |url=https://spoletousa.org/events/omar/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220531031040/https://spoletousa.org/events/omar/ |archive-date=2022-05-31  |access-date=2022-06-01 |website=[[Spoleto Festival USA]] |language=en-US }}</ref> It received the 2023 Pulitzer Prize in Music.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Times |first=The New York |date=2023-05-08 |title=Pulitzer Prizes: 2023 Winners List |language=en-US |work=The New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2023/05/08/business/pulitzer-prize-winners.html |access-date=2023-05-09 |issn=0362-4331}}</ref> \n\nIn July 2020, Giddens was named Artistic Director of the cross-cultural music organization [[Silkroad (arts organization)]]. The position had been vacant since 2017 when Silkroad's founder, [[Yo-Yo Ma]], stepped down.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2020-07-28 |title=Rhiannon Giddens Named Artistic Director Of Silkroad |url=https://www.silkroad.org/rhiannon-giddens-announcement |access-date=2020-08-03 |publisher=silkroad.org}}</ref>\n\nOn {{date2|August|17, |2020}}, Giddens guest-hosted the [[BBC Radio 2]] Blues Show while its regular host [[Cerys Matthews]] was on her holidays.<ref>{{Cite web |title=BBC Radio 2 - The Blues Show with Cerys Matthews, Rhiannon Giddens sits in |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/m000lt68 |access-date=2024-06-23 |website=BBC |language=en-GB}}</ref>\n\nGiddens earned an Honorary [[Doctor of Letters]] from the [[University of North Carolina at Greensboro]] for her lasting impact on the UNCG community and work in music. She sang \"Calling me Home\" by [[Alice Gerrard]] at a virtual commencement after accepting the degree in December 2020.<ref>{{Cite web |last=john.newsom@greensboro.com |first=John Newsom |title=UNCG's next virtual commencement will have the traditional pomp and circumstance |url=https://greensboro.com/news/local/education/uncgs-next-virtual-commencement-will-have-the-traditional-pomp-and-circumstance/article_8536d06c-2829-11eb-91f5-b35120e6832e.html |access-date=2020-12-11 |website=Greensboro News and Record |date=November 25, 2020 |language=en}}</ref> In 2023, she was awarded an honorary Doctor of Music from Princeton University.<ref>{{Cite web |date=May 30, 2023 |title=Princeton awards five honorary degrees |url=https://www.princeton.edu/news/2023/05/30/princeton-awards-five-honorary-degrees |access-date=2024-06-04 |website=Princeton University |language=en}}</ref>\n\nIn 2023, Giddens joined the programming lineup at [[Wondrium]] leading the series \"The Banjo: Music, History and Heritage.\"<ref>{{Cite web |last=MacCary |first=Julia |date=2023-02-06 |title=Rhiannon Giddens, Curtis Stone, Ari Shapiro and Selema Masekela Join Wondrium Lineup (EXCLUSIVE) |url=https://variety.com/2023/tv/news/wondrium-rhiannon-giddens-curtis-stone-ari-shapiro-selema-masekela-1235510984/ |access-date=2023-03-24 |website=Variety |language=en-US}}</ref> In 2022, Giddens was named the [[List_of_music_directors_of_the_Ojai_Music_Festival|musical director]] of the 2023 [[Ojai Music Festival]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Rhiannon Giddens, 2023 Music Director |url=https://www.ojaifestival.org/rhiannon-giddens-2023-music-director/ |website=Ojai Music Festival |date=September 2, 2022 |access-date=15 May 2023}}</ref>\n\nOn 7th July 2024, Giddens and her band headlined the [https://www.gtsf.uk/ Gate to Southwell Festival.]\n\n==Acting==\nIn 2017 and 2018, Giddens appeared in the [[Nashville (season 5)|fifth]] and [[Nashville (season 6)|sixth]] seasons of the [[CMT (U.S. TV channel)|CMT]]'s ''[[Nashville (2012 TV series)|Nashville]]'' as Hannah Lee \"Hallie\" Jordan, a social worker and gospel singer who is a significant character in [[Juliette Barnes|Juliette's]] storyline.<ref>{{Cite magazine |last=Betts |first=Stephen L. |date=2016-09-02 |title=Rhiannon Giddens to Join the Cast of 'Nashville' |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/country/news/rhiannon-giddens-to-join-the-cast-of-nashville-w437790 |magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] |access-date=2017-04-02}}</ref> Giddens appeared in 11 episodes and performed several songs that have been made available following each episode.\n\n==Documentary==\nGiddens is featured in the 2024 documentary ''[[Cover Your Ears]]'' produced by ''[[Prairie Coast Films]]'' and directed by ''[[Sean Patrick Shaul]]'', discussing music censorship.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt18296562/?ref_=ext_shr_lnk | title=Cover Your Ears }}</ref>\n\nGiddens is featured in the 2022 documentary [[Black Fiddlers]] next to Justin Robinson. Produced by [[Heritage Film Project]] and directed by [[Eduardo Montes-Bradley]]. In the film Giddens shares her memories of [[Joe Thompson (musician)|Joe Thomson]] and Odell Thomson.\n\n==Author==\nRhiannon Giddens has announced that she will have four children's books published by [[Candlewick Press]]. The first two books, scheduled for release in Fall 2022, are based on the lyrics of her songs \"Build A House\" and \"We Could Fly\" with illustrations by Monica Mikai and Briana Mukodiri Uchendu respectively.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Rhiannon Giddens to Publish Children's Books with Candlewick Press |url=https://nonesuch.com/journal/rhiannon-giddens-publish-childrens-books-candlewick-press-2021-06-24 |access-date=2021-06-24 |website=nonesuch.com|date=June 24, 2021 }}</ref>\n\n==Personal life==\nGiddens married [[Irish traditional music]]ian Michael Laffan in 2007.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Honeymoon Couple|date=2008-11-05 |url=http://talithamackenzie.com/node/87 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160302154849/http://talithamackenzie.com/node/87 |archive-date=2016-03-02 |access-date=2016-01-01 |publisher=Talitha Mackenzie}}</ref> They have a daughter born in 2009 and a son born in 2013.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2015-09-02 |title=Rhiannon Giddens & The Making of NC's Most Beautiful Voice|first= Tommy|last= Tomlinson|url=https://www.ourstate.com/rhiannon-giddens/ |access-date=2016-01-01 |publisher=Our State}}</ref> They had separated as of 2018.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2018-10-21 |title=Blues star Rhiannon Giddens on her Irish ex and how Trump inspired action |url=https://extra.ie/2018/10/21/entertainment/blues-star-rhiannon-giddens-on-irish-ex-and-how-trump-inspired-action |access-date=2018-10-22 |first=Danny |last=McElhinney|publisher=Extra.ie}}</ref> \n\nGiddens currently lives in [[Limerick]], Ireland.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Rhiannon Giddens: 'It's great to be back playing for people' |url=https://www.independent.ie/entertainment/music/rhiannon-giddens-its-great-to-be-back-playing-for-people-40927068.html |access-date=2021-11-23 |website=independent |date=October 7, 2021 |language=en}}</ref> In 2019, Giddens began a relationship with her Italian musical partner [[Francesco Turrisi]].<ref>{{Cite web |last=Gage |first=Jeff |date=2019-05-20 |title=How Rhiannon Giddens Merged Her Musical Selves With the Help of an Italian Jazz Musician |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/rhiannon-giddens-jazz-folk-there-is-no-other-837691/ |access-date=2019-12-05 |website=rollingstone.com |publisher=[[Rolling Stone]]}}</ref> They released albums together in May 2019 and April 2021.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2020-08-01 |title=A moment of zen in the midst of a lot going on! |url=https://www.facebook.com/RhiannonGiddensMusic/posts/10158213398962860 |access-date=2020-11-20 |website=Facebook.com}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |date=2021-04-16 |title=Rhiannon Giddens and Francesco Turrisi: They're Calling Me Home review &#124; Jude Rogers's folk album of the month |url=http://www.theguardian.com/music/2021/apr/16/rhiannon-giddens-and-francesco-turrisi-theyre-calling-me-home-review |first=Jude |last=Rogers|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]}}</ref>\n\n== Discography (2013)\n* As [[Ben Harper]] and Rhiannon Giddens, ''Black Eyed Dog'' (single) (2020)\n* As [[Amanda Palmer]] and Rhiannon Giddens, ''It's a Fire'' (single) (2020)\n* As [[Ren\u00e9e Fleming]], [[Alison Krauss]], Rhiannon Giddens, and [[Yannick N\u00e9zet-S\u00e9guin]], ''Before the Deluge'' (single) (2021)\n\n===''Nashville''===\nSee [[Nashville discography]] Seasons Five and Six for songs performed by Hallie Jordan (played by Rhiannon Giddens)\n\n===Other significant appearances (lead, duet, trio, featured solo)===\n* \"Dreamland\" and \"Clothes of My Man\", ''Sonic New York'' ([[Sxip Shirey]]) (2010)\n* \"Brightest and Best\", \"Christ Child Lullaby\", \"A Babe is Born All of a Maid\", and \"Down in Yon Forest\", ''The Winter Moon'' (Immigrant's Daughter) (2010)\n* \"Lay Your Money Down\", ''Shamrock City'' ([[Solas (group)|Solas]]) (2012)\n* \"Outside Man Blues\", ''Yes We Can'' (An Apple A Day) (2013)\n* \"The Vanishing Race\", ''Look Again to the Wind: [[Johnny Cash]]'s [[Bitter Tears: Ballads of the American Indian|Bitter Tears]] Revisited'' (Various Artists) (2014)\n* \"Now to Conclude Our Christmas Mirth\", \"Christmas Day Is Come\", and \"The Enniscorthy Christmas Carol\", ''[[The Wexford Carols (Caitr\u00edona O'Leary album)|The Wexford Carols]]'' ([[Caitr\u00edona O'Leary]]) (2014)\n* \"[[Waterboy (song)|Waterboy]]\", \"'S iomadh rud tha dh\u00ecth orm / Ciamar a n\u00ec mi 'n dannsa d\u00ecreach\", and \"Didn't Leave Nobody But The Baby\", ''Another Day, Another Time: Celebrating the Music of [[Inside Llewyn Davis]]'' (Various artists) (concert recorded live September 29, 2013, album released January 2015)\n* \"Up In Arms\", ''Rhythm & Reason'' ([[Bhi Bhiman]]) (2015)\n* \"Julie\" and \"[[Cluck Old Hen]]\", ''Tunes from [[David Holt (musician)|David Holt's]] State of Music'' (Various Artists) (2015)\n* \"Ballad of Lennon Lacy\" (single) ([[Jon Lindsay (musician)|Jon Lindsay]] with Rhiannon Giddens and NC Music Love Army) (2015)\n* \"[[Kill a Word]]\", ''[[Mr. Misunderstood]]'' ([[Eric Church]]) (2015)\n* \"The Good Fight\", ''Real Midnight'' ([[Birds of Chicago]]) (2016)\n* \"[[St. James Infirmary Blues]]\", ''Sing Me Home'' ([[Yo-Yo Ma]] & The [[Silk Road Ensemble]]) (2016)\n* \"Manman\", ''A Day for the Hunter, A Day for the Prey'' ([[Leyla McCalla]]) (2016)\n* \"Come Sunday\" and \"Rocks in My Bed\", ''[[American Tunes]]'' ([[Allen Toussaint]]) (2016)\n* \"Woman of Constant Sorrow\", \"Just Drive By, Firefly\", and \"Bach, Stevie Wonder and Janelle Monae\", ''A Bottle of Whiskey and a Handful of Bees'' ([[Sxip Shirey]]) (2017)\n* \"West End Blues (Live)\" and \"Shake Sugaree\", ''Tunes from [[David Holt (musician)|David Holt's]] State of Music 2'' (Various Artists) (2017)\n* \"One Hour Mama\" and \"[[Pretty Saro]]\", ''[[Music from The American Epic Sessions: Original Motion Picture Soundtrack|Music from The American Epic Sessions]]'' (Various Artists) (2017)\n* \"Factory Girl\" and \"Lullaby\", ''[[Folk Songs (Kronos Quartet album)|Folk Songs]]'' ([[Kronos Quartet]]) (2017)\n* \"So Pretty\", ''For Lenny'' ([[Lara Downes]]) (2018)\n* \"My Baby Likes Bacon\" and \"Mansell's Waltz\", ''[[Hopes & Dreams: The Lullaby Project]]'' (Various Artists) (2018)\n* \"[[I'm Just Wild About Harry]]\", \"I Ain't Gonna Play No Second Fiddle\", \"Swing Along\", and \"[[I Ain't Got Nobody]]\", ''American Originals: 1918'' ([[Cincinnati Pops Orchestra]]) (2018)\n* \"Dream Variation\", ''Holes in the Sky'' ([[Lara Downes]]) (2019)\n* \"The May Morning Dew\", ''The Great Irish Songbook'' ([[Dervish (band)|Dervish]]) (2019)\n* \"Georgia Buck\" and \"Cripple Creek\", ''Just Around the Bend: Survival and Revival in Southern Banjo Sounds ([[Mike Seeger]]'s Last Documentary)'' (Various Artists) (2019)\n* \"Moonlight\", \"Mountain Hymn\", and \"Mountain Banjo\", ''The [[Music of Red Dead Redemption 2]]: Original Soundtrack'' (Various Artists) (2019)\n* \"All Babies Must Cry\" (single) ([[Sxip Shirey]]) (2019)\n* \"Wish in Vain\" (w/ [[Dirk Powell]]), ''Good Music to Avert the Collapse of American Democracy, Volume 2'' (Various Artists) (2020 1-day benefit release)\n* \"All You Fascists Bound To Lose\" (written by [[Woody Guthrie]]), ''This Joy'' (Resistance Revival Chorus) (2020, [[Righteous Babe Records]])\n* \"Woman of the House\", ''Canvas'' ([[Natalie MacMaster]] and Donnell [[Leahy]]) (2023)\n* \"[[Texas Hold 'Em (song)|Texas Hold 'Em]]\" (single) ([[Beyonc\u00e9]]) (2024)\n* \u201c[[Don't Come Around Here No More|Don\u2019t Come Around Here No More]]\u201d feat. [[Silkroad Ensemble (Musical Group & Social Impact Organization)|Silkroad Ensemble]] and [[Benmont Tench]], (2024, [https://store.tompetty.com/products/petty-country-a-country-music-celebration-of-tom-petty-cd Petty Country: A Country Music Celebration])\n\n==Awards and nominations==\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n|+Awards and nominations for Rhiannon Giddens\n! reading==\n* {{Cite news |last=Arthur |first=Dee Dee |date=June 8, 2011 |title=Rhiannon Giddens Laffan returns for a classical duet: Hitting the High Notes |work=Charleston City Paper |url=http://www.charlestoncitypaper.com/charleston/rhiannon-giddens-laffan-returns-for-a-classical-duet/Content?oid=3437805 |access-date=2015-06-11}}\n* {{Cite magazine |last=Fricke |first=David |date=2015-03-05 |title=Rhiannon Giddens' Old-Time Religion |magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/features/rhiannon-giddens-old-time-religion-20150305 |access-date=2015-06-11}}\n* {{Cite news |last=Hall |first=Erin |date=February 2014 |title=Country Girl: An Interview with the Carolina Chocolate Drops' Rhiannon Giddens |work=Antigravity |access-date=2015-06-11}}\n* {{Cite news |last=Mechanic |first=Michael |date=2010-10-04 |title=Rhiannon Giddens of the Carolina Chocolate Drops |work=Mother Jones Giddens: Musical Melting Pot Wows America |work=Forbes |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/craigsilver/2015/04/15/rhiannon-giddens-musical-melting-pot-wows-america/ |access-date=2015-06-11}}\n* {{Cite news |last=Wald |first=Gayle |date=2017-02-21 |title=Past Is Present |work=Oxford American |url=http://www.oxfordamerican.org/magazine/item/1102-past-is-present |access-date=2017-08-03}}\n* {{Cite news |last=Kaliss |first=Jeff |date=2017-07-09 |title=Rhiannon Giddens Shares Her Musical Journey |work=San Francisco Classical Voice |url=https://www.sfcv.org/events-calendar/artist-spotlight/rhiannon-giddens-shares-her-musical-journey |access-date=2017-07-09}}\n* {{Cite magazine |last=Sullivan |first=John Jeremiah |date=2019-05-20 artist|2612591-Rhiannon-Giddens}}\n* {{IMDb name|2871962}}\n* {{YouTube|user=rhiannongiddens}}\n\n{{Rhiannon Giddens|state=expanded}}\n{{authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Giddens,
