Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Jimmie_Rodgers_(pop_singer)","to":"Jimmie Rodgers (pop singer)"}],"pages":{"835175":{"pageid":835175,"ns":0,"title":"Jimmie Rodgers (pop singer)","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American singer (1933\u20132021)}}\n{{distinguish|Jimmie Rodgers (country singer)|Jimmy Rogers}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| image             = Jimmie Rodgers 1968.JPG\n| caption           = Rodgers in 1968\n| name              = Jimmie Rodgers\n| background        = solo_singer\n| birth_name        = James Frederick Rodgers\n| alias             = Jimmie F. Rodgers (credited as)\n| birth_date        = {{Birth date|1933|09|18|mf=y}}\n| birth_place       = [[Camas, Washington]], U.S.\n| death_date        = {{Death date and age|2021|01|18|1933|09|18|mf=y}}\n| death_place       = [[Palm Desert, California]], U.S.\n| instruments       = {{hlist|Vocals|guitar|piano}}\n| genre             = {{hlist|[[Folk music|Folk]]|[[traditional pop]]|[[rock and roll]]|[[rockabilly]]|[[Country music|country]]}}\n| occupation        = {{hlist|Singer|musician|songwriter}}\n| years_active      = 1957\u20132021\n| label             = {{hlist|[[Roulette Records|Roulette]]|[[Dot Records|Dot]]|[[A&M Records|A&M]]}}\n}}\n\n'''James Frederick Rodgers''' (September 18, 1933 \u2013 January 18, 2021) was an American pop singer. Rodgers had a run of hits and mainstream popularity in the 1950s and 1960s. His string of crossover singles ranked highly on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Pop Singles]], [[Hot Country Songs|Hot Country and Western Sides]], and [[Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs|Hot Rhythm and Blues Sides]] charts; in the 1960s, Rodgers had more modest successes with [[adult contemporary music]].\n\nHe was not related to country music pioneer [[Jimmie Rodgers|Jimmie C. Rodgers]] (1897\u20131933), who died the same year the younger Rodgers was born. Among country audiences, and in his official songwriting credits, the younger Rodgers, Jimmie Frederick, was often credited as '''Jimmie F. Rodgers''' to differentiate the two.\n\n==Career==\n===Early years===\nRodgers was born in [[Camas, Washington]].<ref name=\"auto4\">Wayne Harada. \"Spotlighted Singer.\" ''Honolulu Advertiser'', September 15, 1957, p. 36.</ref>  He was the second son of Archie and Mary Rodgers.<ref name=\"auto2\">John Vergara, \"Oh, Oh, He's Done It Again.\" ''New York Daily News'', April 27, 1958, p. M4.</ref>  Rodgers was taught music by his mother, a piano teacher,<ref name=\"auto1\">\"Jimmie Rodgers Returns to the Stage.\" ''Reno (NV) Gazette'', February 24, 1983, p. 16.</ref> and began performing as a child, first entertaining at a Christmas show when he was only five.<ref name=\"auto4\" /> He learned to play the piano and guitar, and performed locally.\n\nAfter attending [[Camas High School]], he briefly took courses at Clark College in Vancouver, Washington.<ref name=\"auto2\" /> He later went to work at the [[Crown Zellerbach]] paper mill in Camas.  Although he loved music, he was uncertain whether he could turn it into a career. He was subsequently drafted and served in the United States Air Force during the Korean War.<ref name=\"auto\">Dick Kleiner. \"Honeycomb Started Here.\" ''(Nashville) The Tennessean'', November 3, 1957, p. 7C.</ref>\n\n=== 1950s ===\nWhile in the Air Force, Rodgers joined a band named The Melodies started by violinist Phil Clark. During his service, he was transferred to Nashville, Tennessee, where he was stationed at Sewart Air Force Base from 1954 to 1956.<ref name=\"auto3\">Robert K. Oermann. \"Jimmie Rodgers: There's No Stopping Him Now.\" ''(Nashville) The Tennessean'', November 27, 1985, p. D1.</ref> It was during this time that he began expanding his musical repertoire. While he was in Nashville, he first heard \"[[Honeycomb (song)|Honeycomb]]\", the song that became his first hit.<ref name=\"auto\" />\n\nLike a number of other entertainers of the era, he was one of the contestants on [[Arthur Godfrey]]'s talent show on CBS television, winning $700.<ref name=\"auto5\">{{Cite web |title=Jimmie Rodgers on singing and surviving |url=https://www.thespectrum.com/story/entertainment/2016/05/26/jimmie-rodgers-singing-and-surviving/84813944/ |website=The Spectrum & Daily News}}</ref>  When [[Hugo Peretti]] and [[Luigi Creatore]] left [[RCA Records#Beginnings and history|RCA Victor]] for [[Morris Levy]]'s company, [[Roulette Records]], they became aware of Rodgers' talent and signed him to a recording contract.\n\nIn the summer of 1957, he recorded his version of \"[[Honeycomb (song)|Honeycomb]]\", written by [[Bob Merrill]] and recorded by [[Georgie Shaw]] three years earlier.<ref>Rod Ellis. \"WDXN's Disc Digest.\" ''(Clarksville TN) Leaf-Chronicle'', September 6, 1957, p. 3.</ref>  The tune was Rodgers' biggest [[Hit song|hit]], staying on the top of the charts for four weeks. It sold over 1 million copies,<ref>\"Honeycomb Passes Million.\" ''Cashbox'', October 5, 1957, p. 32.</ref> and was awarded a [[Music recording certification|gold disc]] by the [[Recording Industry Association of America|RIAA]].<ref name=\"The Book of Golden Discs\">{{Cite book |last=Murrells |first=Joseph |url=https://archive.org/details/bookofgoldendisc00murr/page/95 |title=The Book of Golden Discs |publisher=Barrie and Jenkins Ltd |year=1978 |isbn=0-214-20512-6 |edition=2nd |location=London |page=[https://archive.org/details/bookofgoldendisc00murr/page/95 95] |url-access=registration}}</ref> Over the following year, he had a number of other hits that reached the top 10 on the charts: \"[[Kisses Sweeter than Wine]]\"; \"[[Oh-Oh, I'm Falling in Love Again]]\"; \"[[Secretly]]\"; and \"[[Are You Really Mine?]]\". Other hits include \"[[Bo Diddley (Bo Diddley song)|Bo Diddley]]\", \"Bimbombey\", \"Ring-a-ling-a-lario\", \"Tucumcari\", \"Tender Love and Care (T.L.C)\", and a version of ''[[Waltzing Matilda]]'' as a film [[tie-in]] with the apocalyptic movie ''[[On the Beach (1959 film)|On the Beach]]'' in 1959.\n\nIn the United Kingdom, \"Honeycomb\" reached number 30 pn the UK Singles Chart in November 1957, and \"[[Kisses Sweeter than Wine]]\" climbed to number 7 the following month.<ref name=\"British Hit Singles & Albums\">{{Cite book |last=Roberts |first=David |title=British Hit Singles & Albums |publisher=Guinness World Records Limited |year=2006 |isbn=1-904994-10-5 |edition=19th |location=London |page=467}}</ref> Both \"Kisses Sweeter than Wine\" and \"Oh-Oh, I'm Falling in Love Again\" were million sellers.<ref name=\"The Book of Golden Discs\" />\n\nThe success of \"Honeycomb\" earned Rodgers guest appearances on numerous variety programs during 1957, including the \"Shower of Stars\" program, hosted by [[Jack Benny]], on October 31, 1957,<ref>Barbara Sammons. \"Your TV Favorites on New Time Schedule Starting Today.\" ''Greenville (SC) News'', October 27, 1957, p. 28.</ref> and the Big Record with [[Patti Page]], on December 4, 1957.<ref>\"Wednesday Television Programs.\" ''(New Brunswick NJ) Sunday Home News'', December 1, 1957, p. 13.</ref>  Rodgers also made several appearances on the ''[[Ed Sullivan Show]]'', including on September 8, 1957, when he was seen by 48,500,000, the largest television audience of his entire career,<ref>\"TV News.\" ''(Salem OR) Capital Journal'', September 7, 1957, Section 2, p. 6.</ref> and November 3, 1957.<ref>\"Famous Dancers From Bali Will Be on KOIN-TV.\" ''(Longview WA) Daily News'', November 2, 1957, p. 19.</ref>  In 1958, he appeared on NBC's ''[[The Gisele MacKenzie Show]]''. Also in 1958, he sang the opening theme song of the film ''[[The Long, Hot Summer]]'', starring [[Paul Newman]], [[Joanne Woodward]] and [[Orson Welles]].<ref>\"Folk Song Rodgers to Do Title Number.\" ''Los Angeles Times'', December 27, 1957, part 3, p. 10.</ref> He then had his own short-lived televised variety show on NBC in 1959.<ref>William Ewald. \"Television in Review.\" ''Naugatuck (CT) News'', May 27, 1959, p. 7.</ref>\n\n=== 1960s ===\nIn 1960, Rodgers' [[Sloop John B|\"Wreck of the John B\"]] was a number 1 hit in Canada, and reached No. 64 on the U.S.charts. His biggest hit of the decade in the UK was \"English Country Garden\", a version of the folk song \"[[Country Gardens]]\", which reached number 5 in the chart in June 1962.<ref name=\"British Hit Singles & Albums\" />  In 1962, he moved to the [[Dot Records|Dot]] label, and four years later to [[A&M Records]]. He also appeared in some films, including ''[[The Little Shepherd of Kingdom Come (1961 film)|The Little Shepherd of Kingdom Come]]'' and ''[[Back Door to Hell]]'', which he helped finance.\n\nIn 1966, a long dry spell ended for Rodgers when he re-entered the Top 40 with \"[[It's Over (Jimmie Rodgers song)|It's Over]]\" (later to be recorded by [[Eddy Arnold]], [[Elvis Presley]], [[Glen Campbell]], [[Mason Williams]], [[Scott Walker (singer)|Scott Walker]], and [[Sonny James]]). In 1967, he changed record labels, signing with [[A&M Records]].<ref>Bill Rumfelt. \"Easy Listening.\" ''Rocky Mount (NC) Telegram'', September 17, 1967, p. 2A.</ref> It was with that label that Rodgers had his final charting Top 100 single, \"Child of Clay\", written by [[Ernie Maresca]] (of \"[[Shout! Shout! (Knock Yourself Out)]]\" fame).<ref>David F. Wagner. \"Under the Album Covers.\" ''Appleton (WI) Post-Crescent'', September 24, 1967, p. S10.</ref> He performed the song on several television variety shows, including ''[[The Smothers Brothers Comedy Hour]]'',<ref>\"Channel Choices,\" ''Allentown (PA) Morning Call'', November 11, 1967, p. 10</ref> but it never became a big hit; it reached number 31 on the ''Billboard'' charts.\n\n===Later career===\nRecovery from injuries sustained mysteriously on a highway in 1967 caused an approximately year-long period in which Rodgers ceased to perform. Meanwhile, his voice was still being heard: Several of his earlier hits were used in jingles in the 1970s, one for [[SpaghettiOs]] and another for [[Honeycomb (cereal)|Honeycomb]] breakfast cereal.<ref name=\"auto3\" /> And Rodgers' songs continued to make the ''Billboard'' Country and Easy Listening charts until 1979. During the summer of 1969, he made a brief return to network television with a summer variety show <ref>Paul Henniger. \"TV People.\" ''San Francisco Examiner'', December 2, 1970, p. TV 19</ref> on ABC (which later bought the rights to Rodgers' [[Dot Records]] releases, now owned by [[Universal Music Group]]). It was not until the early 1980s when he began doing some limited live appearances again. Among the earliest was a series of shows in late February 1983: he performed at [[Harrah's Reno]] Casino Cabaret.<ref name=\"auto1\" /> He also performed a few shows in other cities, including at a nightclub named Mister Days in Fort Lauderdale, Florida in late 1983.<ref>Tim Smith. \"Jimmie Rodgers Rides Sweet Nostalgia Wave.\" ''Fort Lauderdale News/Sun-Sentinel'', May 27, 1983, p. 22.</ref>\n\nRodgers appeared in the 1999 video ''Rock & Roll Graffiti'' by American Public Television, along with about 20 other performers.<ref name=\"auto6\">{{Cite news |title=Street signs point to Jimmie Rodgers Avenue |work=The Columbian |url=https://www.columbian.com/news/2013/sep/13/street-signs-point-to-jimmie-rodgers-avenue/}}</ref> Nevertheless, he gave \"Honeycomb\" a try, and he mentioned that he had a show in Branson, Missouri.\n\nRodgers returned to his hometown of Camas, Washington in 2011 and 2012, performing to sell-out crowds.{{Citation needed|date=August 2018}} In 2013, his neighbors successfully got a street named after him, in the neighborhood where he grew up.<ref name=\"auto6\" />\n\n==Head injuries==\nOn December 1, 1967, Rodgers suffered traumatic head injuries after the car he was driving was stopped by an off-duty police officer near the San Diego Freeway in Los Angeles. He had a fractured skull and required several surgeries.<ref name=\"sreimp\">{{Cite news |date=December 11, 1967 |title=Singer reported improved after two brain operations |page=3A |work=Eugene Register-Guard |agency=Associated Press |location=(Oregon) |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=8OVVAAAAIBAJ&sjid=KeEDAAAAIBAJ&pg=4741%2C2607319}}</ref> Initial reports in the newspapers attributed his injuries to a severe beating with a blunt instrument by unknown assailants.<ref name=\"sgrhosp\">{{Cite news |date=December 4, 1967 |title=Singer hospitalized |page=8 |work=Spartanburg Herald |agency=Associated Press |location=(South Carolina) |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=aX0sAAAAIBAJ&sjid=vMwEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6810%2C713954}}</ref><!--<ref>[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=bWIwAAAAIBAJ&sjid=eeEFAAAAIBAJ&pg=3886,1691466&hl=en] {{dead link|date=October 2019}}</ref> --> Rodgers had no specific memory of how he had been injured, remembering only that he had seen blindingly bright lights from a car pulling up behind him.<ref>{{Cite web |title=The Milwaukee Journal - Google News Archive Search |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=BAAqAAAAIBAJ&sjid=-CcEAAAAIBAJ&pg=7361,530374&dq=jimmie+rodgers+bright+lights&hl=en |website=News.google.com |access-date=2016-09-20 |archive-date=2020-03-09 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200309185307/https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=BAAqAAAAIBAJ&sjid=-CcEAAAAIBAJ&pg=7361,530374&dq=jimmie+rodgers+bright+lights&hl=en |url-status=dead }}</ref>\n\nA few days later, the Los Angeles Police Department (LAPD) stated that off-duty LAPD officer Michael Duffy (at times identified in the press as Richard Duffy) had stopped him for erratic driving, and that Rodgers had stumbled, fallen and hit his head. According to the police version, Duffy then called for assistance from two other officers, and the three of them put the unconscious Rodgers into his car and left the scene.<ref name=\"ppapltf\">{{Cite news |date=December 20, 1967 |title=Jimmie Rodgers' injury linked to fall |page=11 |work=Pittsburgh Press |agency=UPI |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=CsQbAAAAIBAJ&sjid=pU8EAAAAIBAJ&pg=7177%2C1546271}}</ref> That account was supported by the treating physicians, who had first blamed the skull fracture on a beating but, by the latter part of December, they concluded that Rodgers had in fact fallen and that had caused his injuries.<ref>[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=dmIwAAAAIBAJ&sjid=eeEFAAAAIBAJ&pg=918,4276394&hl=en \"New Disclosure Hints Rodgers Hurt By Fall,\" ''The Modesto Bee'', December 20, 1967, p. C-9] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200413230300/https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=dmIwAAAAIBAJ&sjid=eeEFAAAAIBAJ&pg=918,4276394&hl=en |date=April 13, 2020 }}. AP wire service story.</ref>\n\n== Lawsuits ==\nThe following month, Rodgers filed an $11 million lawsuit against the City of Los Angeles, claiming that the three officers had beaten him.<ref>{{Cite book |last=Bronson |first=Fred |title=The Billboard Book of Number One Hits: Updated and Expanded 5th Edition |publisher=Billboard Books |year=2003 |isbn=978-0-823-07677-2 |location=New York |page=27}}</ref> The police and the L.A. County District Attorney rejected these claims, although the three officers (identified in the press as Michael T. Duffy, 27; Raymond V. Whisman, 29, and Ronald D. Wagner, 32)<ref>January 5, 1968,Independent, Long Beach, California \u00b7 Page 1</ref> were given two-week suspensions for improper procedures in handling the case, particularly their leaving the injured Rodgers alone in his car. (He was later found by a worried friend.)<ref name=\"spapjfv\">{{Cite news |date=January 5, 1968 |title=Officers suspended in injury to singer |page=2 |work=Spokesman-Review |agency=''Los Angeles Times'' News Service |location=(Spokane, Washington) |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=2b1YAAAAIBAJ&sjid=9ugDAAAAIBAJ&pg=7171%2C941919}}</ref><ref name=\"tusnw\">{{Cite news |date=March 28, 1968 |title=Officers cleared of assault on singer Jimmie Rodgers |page=28 |work=Tuscaloosa News |agency=(Los Angeles Times) |location=(Alabama) |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=k_4cAAAAIBAJ&sjid=OJsEAAAAIBAJ&pg=3199%2C5402861}}</ref> Duffy had had a previous four-day suspension for using unnecessary force; he had used a blackjack on a juvenile.<ref name=\"spapjfv\" /><ref name=\"tusnw\" />\n\nThe three officers and the LA Fire and Police Protective League filed a $13 million slander suit against Rodgers for his public statements accusing them of brutality.<ref name=\"njrbsu\">{{Cite news |last=Villasenor |first=Rudy |date=April 11, 1968 |title=Now Jimmie Rodgers being sued - for $13 million |page=5 |work=Tuscaloosa News |agency=(Los Angeles Times) |location=(Alabama) |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=agAdAAAAIBAJ&sjid=OZsEAAAAIBAJ&pg=7089%2C2021890}}</ref>\n\nNeither suit came to trial; the police slander suit was dropped, and in 1973 Rodgers elected to accept a $200,000 settlement from the Los Angeles City Council, which voted to give him the money rather than to incur the costs and risks of further court action.<ref name=\"fssetsu\">{{Cite news |date=August 23, 1973 |title=Folk singer settles suit for $200,000 |page=15-A |work=St. Petersburg Times |agency=UPI |location=(Florida) |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=gepRAAAAIBAJ&sjid=-HIDAAAAIBAJ&pg=7055%2C1376958}}</ref> Rodgers and his supporters still believe that one or more of the police officers beat him, although other observers find the evidence inconclusive.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Nashville Sound: Jimmie Rodgers |url=https://apnews.com/4c81ad015fac57cb988e8525ce047ad7 |website=Apnews.com}}</ref> In his 2010 biography ''Me, the Mob, and the Music'', singer [[Tommy James]] wrote that [[Morris Levy]], the Mafia-connected head of Roulette Records, had arranged the attack in response to Rodgers' repeated demands for unpaid royalties he was due by the label. All of Rodgers' most successful singles had been released by Roulette, who were notorious for not paying their artists for their record sales.<ref>James, Tommy, ''Me, the Mob, and the Music'', Scribner Publishing, 2010, p. 205</ref>\n\nIn 1993, Raymond Virgil Whisman, one of the three officers who were alleged to have assaulted Rodgers, was arrested for assaulting his wife and threatening to kill her.  The arrest occurred after sheriff's deputies stormed his house after being informed that he was holding his wife at gunpoint. Deputies found 11 rifles, four shotguns, and two handguns in the home.  Whisman was charged with two counts of assault and two counts of making terroristic threats.<ref>The Signal,Santa Clarita, California\n18 Jun 1993, Fri,Page 3</ref>\n\n== Publication ==\nIn 2010, Rodgers wrote and published his autobiography, ''Dancing on the Moon: The Jimmie Rodgers Story.''<ref name=\"auto5\" /> \n\n== Personal life ==\nRodgers and his first wife Colleen (''n\u00e9e'' McClatchey) divorced in 1970, and she died May 20, 1977.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Lodi News-Sentinel - Google News Archive Search |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2245&dat=19770520&id=QMMzAAAAIBAJ&sjid=wjIHAAAAIBAJ&pg=4723,2163053 |website=News.google.com}}</ref>  They had two children, Michael and Michele. He had remarried in 1970, and Jimmie and Trudy Rodgers had two sons, Casey and Logan. He and Trudy divorced in the late 1970s, and he remarried again. Jimmie and Mary Rodgers were still married when he died, and they have a daughter, Katrine, who was born in 1989.\n\nRodgers suffered from [[spasmodic dysphonia]] for a number of years and could hardly sing. After a 2012 concert, he returned home for open heart surgery, following a heart attack he had suffered three weeks earlier. \n\nRodgers died from kidney disease on January 18, 2021 at the age of 87.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Best Classic Bands Staff |date=19 January 2021 |title=Jimmie Rodgers, Early Rock 'n' Roll Star, Dies at 87 |work=Best Classic Bands |url=https://bestclassicbands.com/jimmie-rodgers-obituary-pop-singer-honeycomb-1-19-21 |access-date=2021-01-20}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n! rowspan=\"2\"| ''Troubled Times''\n| style=\"text-align:center;\"| \u2014\n| style=\"text-align:center;\"| \u2014\n|-\n| 1978\n| ''Yesterday/Today''\n| style=\"text-align:center;\"| \u2014\n| style=\"text-align:center;\"| \u2014\n| Scrimshaw\n|}\n\n===Singles===\n\n====1950s====\n\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Year\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Single (A-side, B-side)<br /><small>Both \u2014\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n| align=\"center\"| 32\n| ''15 Million Sellers''\n|-\n| \"Wistful Willie\"<br /><small>b/w \"It's Christmas Once Again\" (from ''It's Christmas Once Again'')</small>\n| align=\"center\"| 112\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n| rowspan=\"2\"|Non-album tracks\n|-\n| \"T.L.C. Tender Love and Care\" /\n| align=\"center\"| 24\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n| align=\"center\"| 13\n|-\n| \"[[Waltzing Matilda]]\"\n| align=\"center\"| 41\n| rowspan=\"2\"| Single (A-side, B-side)<br /><small>Both sides from same album except where indicated</small>\n! colspan=\"3\"| Chart positions\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Album\n|-\n! style=\"width:45px;\"| <small>[[Billboard Hot 100|US]]</small>\n! style=\"width:45px;\"| <small>[[Adult Contemporary (chart)|US AC]]</small>\n! style=\"width:45px;\"| <small>[[Canadian Singles Chart|CAN]]</small>\n|-\n| ''When the Spirit Moves You''\n|-\n| ''[[Sloop John B|The Wreck of the \"John B.\"]]''<br /><small>b/w \"Four Little Girls in Boston\"</small>\n| align=\"center\"| 64\n| align=\"center\"| -\n| <sup>A</sup>\"Tomorrow Is My Friend\" also peaked at #28 on RPM Adult Contemporary.\n\n====1970s====\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Year\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Single (A-side, B-side)<br Today'')</small>\n| align=\"center\"| 65\n| align=\"center\"| 46\n| rowspan=\"3\"|Non-album tracks\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 1979\n| \"Easy to Love\" /\n| align=\"center\"| 89\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n|-\n| \"Easy\" <small>(featuring Michele Rodgers)</small>\n| align=\"center\"| flip\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n|}\n\n==Films==\nRodgers parlayed his singing fame into a brief movie career with lead performances in:\n* ''[[The Little Shepherd of Kingdom Come (1961 film)|The Little Shepherd of Kingdom Come]]'' (1961)\n* ''[[Back Door to Hell]]'' (1964)\nJimmie sang the song titled \"Half Sung Song\" in the 1977 comedy film ''[[The Billion Dollar Hobo]]'', starring [[Tim Conway]].\n\n==Television==\nTV appearances included performances on ''[[American Bandstand]]'', ''[[Kraft Music Hall]]'', and ''[[Hootenanny]]'', as well as the following:\n* ''[[Hee Haw]]''&nbsp;\u2014 Himself (2 episodes, November 25, 1979 and November 3, 1980)\n* ''[[The George Burns Show]]''&nbsp;\u2014 Himself; Jimmie Rodgers Moves in with Ronnie (1 episode, March 3, 1959). When Jimmie Rodgers moves in with Ronnie, the apartment is suddenly overrun with pretty young groupies, so a jealous Judi turns to George for help.<ref>The George Burns Show; Wikipedia</ref>\n* ''[[The Mike Douglas Show]]''&nbsp;\u2014 Himself (2 episodes, May 15 and May 21, 1970)\n* ''[[The Merv Griffin Show]]''&nbsp;\u2014 Himself (1 episode, May 5, 1970)\n* ''[[The Andy Williams Show]]''&nbsp;\u2014 Himself (1 episode, January 24, 1970)\n* ''[[House Party (radio and TV show)|House Party]]'', a.k.a. ''Art Linkletter's House Party''&nbsp;\u2014 Himself (1 episode, August 24, 1964)\n* ''[[The Ford Show|The Ford Show, Starring Tennessee Ernie Ford]]''&nbsp;\u2014 Himself (Several appearances, 1959\u20131960)\n* ''Sunday Showcase'', aka ''[[NBC Sunday Showcase]]''&nbsp;\u2014 ''The Jimmy Durante Show'' (1959)&nbsp;\u2014 Himself (1 episode, 1959)\n* ''[[The Steve Allen Show]]'', a.k.a. The Steve Allen Plymouth Show (U.S.: new title)&nbsp;\u2014 Himself&nbsp;\u2014 Singer (2 episodes, Nos 4.31/4.4&nbsp;\u2014 1958-1959)\n* ''[[The Ed Sullivan Show|Toast of the Town]]'', a.k.a. ''The Ed Sullivan Show''&nbsp;\u2014 Himself (4 episodes, Nos. 0.50/11.6/11/18/11.36&nbsp;\u2014 1957-1958)\n* The 30th Annual [[Academy Awards]] (1958)&nbsp;\u2014 Himself&nbsp;\u2014 Performer\n* ''[[Shower of Stars]]''&nbsp;\u2014 Himself (1 episode, Comedy Time&nbsp;\u2014 1957)\n* ''The Jimmie Rodgers Show'' TV Series, a.k.a. ''[[Carol Burnett]] Presents the Jimmie Rodgers Show''\n\nIn the mid-1960s, he re-recorded (with altered tunes and words referring to the products) two of his best-known songs, for use in television advertisements:\n* \"Honeycomb\" was adapted for a [[Post Consumer Brands|Post Cereals]] product named \"[[Honeycomb (cereal)|Honeycomb]]\".\n* \"Oh-Oh, I'm Falling in Love Again\" was adapted for one of [[Franco-American (brand)|Franco-American]]'s pasta products: \"Uh-Oh, [[SpaghettiOs]]!\"<ref>{{Cite book |last=Wyman |first=Carolyn |url=https://archive.org/details/betterthanhomema0000wyma_m1j6 |title=Better Than Homemade |publisher=Quirk Books |year=2004 |isbn=9781931686426 |location=Philadelphia, PA |page=[https://archive.org/details/betterthanhomema0000wyma_m1j6/page/124 124] |url-access=registration}}</ref>\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n* {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180614043447/http://www.jimmie-rodgers.com/ |date=14 June 2018 |title=Jimmie Rodgers official website}}\n* {{IMDb name|734720}}\n* {{discogs artist|Jimmie Rodgers (2)}}\n* [https://www.45cat.com/artist/jimmie-rodgers Entry at 45cat.com]\n* [http://www.bsnpubs.com/discog.html Bsnpubs.com]\n* {{Internet Archive short film|id=gov.dod.dimoc.25349|name=\"The Navy Sings It Like It Is (1970)\"}}\n* [http://www.thespectrum.com/story/entertainment/2016/05/26/jimmie-rodgers-singing-and-surviving/84813944/ Interview with Jimmie Rodgers \u2013 The Spectrum, May, 2016.]\n* [https://www.namm.org/library/oral-history/jimmie-rodgers Interview with Jimmie Rodgers - NAMM Oral History Program, October, 2002.]\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Rodgers, Jimmie}}\n[[Category:1933 births]]\n[[Category:2021 deaths]]\n[[Category:American folk guitarists]]\n[[Category:American male guitarists]]\n[[Category:American rock guitarists]]\n[[Category:American male pop singers]]\n[[Category:Traditional pop music singers]]\n[[Category:Singers from Washington (state)]]\n[[Category:Dot Records artists]]\n[[Category:Apex Records artists]]\n[[Category:Roulette Records artists]]\n[[Category:A&M Records artists]]\n[[Category:People from Camas, Washington]]\n[[Category:Guitarists from Washington (state)]]\n[[Category:20th-century American guitarists]]\n[[Category:20th-century American pianists]]\n[[Category:American male pianists]]\n[[Category:21st-century American pianists]]\n[[Category:20th-century American male musicians]]\n[[Category:21st-century American male musicians]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Spirit_Family_Reunion","to":"Spirit Family Reunion"}],"pages":{"47426541":{"pageid":47426541,"ns":0,"title":"Spirit Family Reunion","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Use mdy dates|date=March 2023}}\n{{Short description|American country band}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name              = Spirit Family Reunion\n| image             = Spirit Family Reunion (7668484378).jpg\n| image_size        = \n| landscape         = yes\n| alt               = \n| caption           = \n| origin            = [[Brooklyn]], New York\n| genre             = [[Folk music|Folk]], [[Bluegrass music|bluegrass]], [[Country music|country]]\n| instrument        = Vocals, acoustic guitar, banjo, bass drum, [[Washboard (musical instrument)|washboard]], [[tambourine]], [[fiddle]], [[accordion]], [[Double bass|bass]], drums\n| years_active      = 2010&ndash;present\n| label             = \n| associated_acts   = \n| website           = {{URL|https://www.spiritfamilyreunion.com/}}\n| current_members   = * Nick Panken\n* Maggie Carson\n* Stephen Weinheimer\n* Ken Woodward\n* Or Zubalsky\n| past_members      = * Noah Block-Harley\n* Dylan Block-Harley\n* [[Twain (musician)|Mat Davidson]]\n* Peter Pezzimenti<ref>{{cite web|url=http://freshgrass.com/artist/1023-2/|title=Spirit Family Reunion|work=freshgrass.com}}</ref>\n}}\n\n'''Spirit Family Reunion''' is a band from [[Brooklyn]], New York influenced by traditional American music such as country, folk and gospel. Founded in 2009 by core members Nick Panken (vocals, acoustic guitar), Maggie Carson (five string banjo, vocal), and Stephen Weinheimer (washboard, bass drum, tambourine, vocals), and featuring a rotating cast of musicians such as Ken Woodward (bass, vocals), Or Zubalsky (drums), Noah Block-Harley (fiddle, vocals), Dylan Block-Harley (drums, vocals), [[Twain (musician)|Mat Davidson]] (fiddle, accordion, mandolin, vocals), and Pete Pezzimenti (drums, vocals).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blog.cleveland.com/minkinsmusic/2015/06/put_your_hands_together_for_sp.html|title=Put Your Hands Together for Spirit Family Reunion|work=cleveland.com}}</ref> They have referred to their style as \"homegrown American music\" and \"open-door gospel\", and are often compared to [[Bluegrass music|bluegrass]], [[Country music|country]] and [[Appalachian music|appalachian]] music.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Greene|first1=David|title=Spirit Family Reunion: Music For Church Basements|url=https://www.npr.org/2012/07/29/157532251/spirit-family-reunion-music-for-church-basements|website=NPR Music|publisher=NPR Music|accessdate=August 9, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Minkin|first1=Jay|title=Put Your Hands Together for Spirit Family Reunion|url=http://nodepression.com/live-review/put-your-hands-together-spirit-family-reunion|website=No Depression|accessdate=November 11, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Horowitz|first1=Hal|title=Spirit Family Reunion: Hands Together|url=http://americansongwriter.com/2015/04/spirit-family-reunion-hands-together/|website=American Songwriter|accessdate=November 11, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Jackson|first1=Michael|title=Brooklyn \u2018buskers' Spirit Family Reunion are Bangor-bound|url=http://www.irishnews.com/arts/2016/08/12/news/brooklyn-buskers-spirit-family-reunion-are-bangor-bound-647745/|website=The Irish Times|accessdate=November 11, 2018}}</ref>\n\n== History ==\n\nThe band started out as Panken and Weinheimer playing with different people each night at the bar where they worked, and eventually became Spirit Family Reunion.<ref name=\":0\">{{cite web|url=http://www.abeerwiththeband.com/spirit-family-reunion/?rq=spirit%20family%20reunion|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170428051136/http://www.abeerwiththeband.com/spirit-family-reunion/?rq=spirit%20family%20reunion|url-status=dead|archive-date=April 28, 2017|title=A Beer With Spirit Family Reunion|website=A Beer With the Band|publisher=A Beer With the Band|last1=Mitchell|first1=Kristen|accessdate=August 9, 2015}}</ref> Officially formed in 2010, Spirit Family Reunion has self-produced and self-released two full-length albums, ''No Separation'' (2013) and ''Hands Together'' (2015).<ref>{{cite web|title=About|url=http://www.spiritfamilyreunion.com/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160321121429/http://www.spiritfamilyreunion.com/|url-status=dead|archive-date=March 21, 2016|website=Spirit Family Reunion|accessdate=August 10, 2015}}</ref> They have toured with bands such as [[Trampled by Turtles]], [[Levon Helm]], [[Tedeschi Trucks Band]], [[Dr. Dog]], [[The Felice Brothers]], and [[Alabama Shakes]] and performed at the [[Newport Folk Festival]], [[Hardly Strictly Bluegrass]], [[Celebrate Brooklyn!]], [[FloydFest]], [[Bristol Rhythm & Roots Reunion]], [[Flood City Music Festival]], [[Buckle Up Music Festival|The Buckle Up Music Festival]], [[Shakori Hills Grassroots Festival]], and the [[Americana Music Festival & Conference]] among others.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Leahey|first1=Andrew|title=Hear Spirit Family Reunion Sing Away Blues With 'It Does Not Bother Me'|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/premieres/hear-spirit-family-reunion-sing-away-blues-with-it-does-not-bother-me-20150129|website=Rolling Stone Country|accessdate=August 10, 2015}}</ref> They played a [[Tiny Desk Concerts|Tiny Desk Concert]] in 2012 and took part in the [[Bob Dylan in the 80s: Volume One|''Bob Dylan in the 80s'' project]]. They were also featured in [[The Deli Magazine|issue No. 34 of ''The Deli Magazine'']] in 2013.\n\n== Discography ==\n\n=== Albums ===\n\n* ''No Separation'' (2012)\n* ''Hands Together'' (2015)\n* ''Harvest Festival Live'' (2016)\n* ''Ride Free'' (2019)\n\n=== Extended plays ===\n\n* ''Spirit Family Reunion'' (2010)\n\n=== Singles ===\n\n==== ''When My Name Is Spoken 7\"'' ====\n\n* ''When My Name Is Spoken'' (2010)\n* ''On That Day (2010)\n\n==== ''I Want To Be Relieved 7\"'' ====\n\n* ''I Want To Be Relieved'' (2012)\n* ''Green Rocky Road'' (2012)\n*''Goin' Out To Cannon Ball'' (2016)\n\n==References==\n{{reflist}}\n\n== External links ==\n\n* [http://www.spiritfamilyreunion.com/ Official Website]\n\n[[Category:Musical groups from Brooklyn]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Jody_Miller","to":"Jody Miller"}],"pages":{"6009565":{"pageid":6009565,"ns":0,"title":"Jody Miller","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American singer (1941\u20132022)}}\n{{for|the American criminologist|Jody Miller (criminologist)}}\n{{Use American English|date = September 2019}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=October 2022}}\n{{Infobox person\n| name               = Jody Miller\n| image              = Jody Miller.png\n| caption            = Miller in a trade ad for her 1965 single, \"Queen of the House\"\n| birth_name         = Myrna Joy Miller\n| birth_date         = {{Birth date|1941|11|29}}\n| birth_place        = [[Phoenix, Arizona]], U.S.\n| death_date         = {{Death date and age|2022|10|06|1941|11|29}}\n| death_place        = [[Blanchard, Oklahoma]], U.S.\n| occupation         = {{hlist|Singer}}\n| years_active       = 1963\u20132022\n| known_for          = \"[[Queen of the House]]\"\n| spouse             = {{marriage|Monty Brooks|1962}}\n| children           = 1\n| module             = {{Infobox musical artist\n| embed              = yes\n| origin             = [[Blanchard, Oklahoma]]\n| genre              = {{hlist|[[Country music|Country]]|[[Folk music|folk]]|[[Gospel music|gospel]]|[[American patriotic music|patriotic]]|[[Pop music|pop]]}}\n| instrument         = {{hlist|Vocals|guitar}}\n| label              = {{hlist|[[Capitol Records|Capitol]]|[[Epic Records|Epic]]|Jody Miller Music|Amethyst|Zero|C.E.O. Nashville|White Dove|Heart of Texas}}\n| website            = {{URL|jodymillermusic.com}}\n}}\n}}\n'''Myrna Joy''' \"'''Jody'''\" '''Miller''' (November 29, 1941 \u2013 October 6, 2022)<ref name=\"NY Times\">{{cite news |last1=Shanahan |first1=Ed |title=Jody Miller, Singer of 'Queen of the House' and More, Dies at 80 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2022/10/26/arts/music/jody-miller-dead.html |access-date=15 April 2023 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=October 26, 2022}}</ref> was an American singer, who had commercial success in the genres of [[Country music|country]], [[Folk music|folk]] and [[Pop music|pop]]. She was the second female artist to win a country music accolade from the [[Grammy Awards]], which came off the success of her 1965 song \"[[Queen of the House]]\". By blending multiple genres together, Miller's music was considered influential for other music artists.\n\nMiller was born in Arizona, but raised in [[Blanchard, Oklahoma]]. With a passion for folk music, she moved to [[Los Angeles, California]] following high school to pursue a music career. Her singing attracted the attention of [[Capitol Records]], which signed her to a recording contract in 1963. The label released her debut studio album titled ''[[Wednesday's Child Is Full of Woe (album)|Wednesday's Child Is Full of Woe]]'' in 1963. It was Miller's [[answer song]] to [[Roger Miller]]'s \"[[King of the Road (song)|King of the Road]]\" titled \"Queen of the House\" that became her first commercial success. It became a top 20 pop song and a top five country song. It was followed by the top 25 pop single \"[[Home of the Brave (song)|Home of the Brave]]\" that discussed social conformity. Miller remained at Capitol recording various material until 1969.\n\nMiller was then signed to the country music label, [[Epic Records]]. Under the direction of [[Billy Sherrill]], she remade pop hits into singles for the country market. She had top ten country singles with covers of \"[[He's So Fine]]\" (1971), \"[[Baby I'm Yours (Barbara Lewis song)|Baby I'm Yours]]\" (1971) and original songs like \"[[There's a Party Goin' On]]\" (1972). The Epic label released a series of singles and albums that made the North American country music charts through the end of the 1970s. She was nominated for another Grammy for Epic material and appeared on several popular country television programs during the decade.\n\nMiller left her recording career in the early 1980s. She spent time with her domestic duties and to assist her husband's new business raising quarter horses in Oklahoma. In 1988, she returned with a pair of new studio albums including a project of [[American patriotic music|patriotic music]] called ''My Country''. It attracted the attention of [[George H. W. Bush]], who had Miller perform at his campaign rallies and other presidential events. In the 1990s, Miller found solace in the religion of [[Christianity]] and released several albums of [[Gospel music|gospel]] material. This included ''Real Good Feelin'' (1992) and ''Higher'' (1999). Miller continued her career through the 2020s, before her death from [[Parkinson's disease]] in 2022.\n\n==Early life==\nMyrna Joy Miller was born in [[Phoenix, Arizona]] in 1941 while her family was on their way to start a new life in [[Oakland, California]].<ref name=McDonnell>{{cite news|title=Country singer Jody Miller, one of Oklahoma's first Grammy winners, dies|url=https://www.oklahoman.com/story/entertainment/2022/10/06/singer-jody-miller-one-of-oklahomas-first-grammy-winners-dies/69545567007/|first=Brandy|last=McDonnell|date=October 6, 2022|access-date=October 6, 2022|newspaper=[[The Oklahoman]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20221007033601/https://www.oklahoman.com/story/entertainment/2022/10/06/singer-jody-miller-one-of-oklahomas-first-grammy-winners-dies/69545567007/|archivedate=October 7, 2022}}</ref> She was the youngest of four sisters<ref name=\"LarkinCountry\">{{cite book|title=[[Encyclopedia of Popular Music|The Guinness Who's Who of Country Music]]|editor=[[Colin Larkin (writer)|Colin Larkin]]|publisher=[[Guinness Publishing]]|date=1993|edition=First|isbn=0-85112-726-6|pages=264/5}}</ref> born to Johnny Bell Miller and Fay Miller. Miller's father was a mechanic, who made [[fiddle]]s and played them too. Her mother was a homemaker who enjoyed singing around the house. Together, Miller would sing harmony with her four sisters.<ref name=\"McDonnell\"/><ref name=\"NY Times\"/> Her parents discovered their daughter's unique singing ability and entered her in talent contests during her early childhood. Miller's father also illegally brought her into bars where his daughter would stand on tables singing. She became locally known as \"the little girl with the big voice\".<ref name=\"NY Times\"/>\n\nMr. and Mrs. Miller divorced when their daughter was eight. She took a [[Greyhound Lines|Greyhound bus]] and ended up in [[Blanchard, Oklahoma]] where she was raised by her paternal grandmother.<ref name=\"McDonnell\"/> At her grandmother's home, she heard [[Mario Lanza]] singing \"[[La donna \u00e8 mobile]]\". \"That is when I first realized that I would be a singer. I was bitten,\" Miller wrote on her official website. She also joined choir in high school and sang in a trio that performed songs by [[The McGuire Sisters]].<ref name=\"Website\">{{cite web |title=Bio \u2013 Jody Miller Music |url=http://www.jodymillermusic.com/bio/ |website=Jody Miller Music.com |access-date=15 April 2023}}</ref> Miller graduated from Blanchard High School in 1959.<ref name=\"NY Times\"/><ref name=\"McDonnell\"/> She then got a job as a secretary in [[Oklahoma City, Oklahoma|Oklahoma City]] and learned to sing folk music.<ref name=\"NY Times\"/>\n\nMiller was performing in coffeehouses throughout her local area. She was singing in one particular coffeehouse in [[Norman, Oklahoma]] when she was heard by [[Lou Gottlieb]]. Impressed by her singing, Gottlieb encouraged Miller to move to California. However, she turned down his offer and married instead. Shortly after her wedding, Miller and husband moved to [[Los Angeles, California]] in hopes of launching her music career. The couple got in touch with Gottlieb her brought her in contact with his agent. However, Miller did not like Gottlieb's agent. She instead contacted actor [[Dale Robertson]], who was connected to her husband's family.<ref name=\"Extended interview\">{{cite news |last1=McDonnell |first1=Brandy |title=Extended interview, photos and video: Grammy winner Jody Miller continues to perform, record and call small-town Oklahoma home |url=https://www.oklahoman.com/story/entertainment/columns/brandy-mcdonnell/2018/07/06/extended-interview-photos-video-grammy-winner-miller-continues-perform-record-small-oklahoma-home/60515121007/ |access-date=15 April 2023 |work=[[The Oklahoman]]}}</ref> Robertson helped Miller get an audition with [[Capitol Records]] and she signed with the label in 1963.<ref name=\"Extended interview\"/><ref name=\"NY Times\"/> The label then changed her name from \"Myrna Miller\" to \"Jody Miller\".<ref name=\"NY Times\"/>\n\n==Career==\n===1963\u20131969: \"Queen of the House\" and success in multiple genres===\nAt Capitol, Miller was signed as a folk recording artist.<ref name=\"CNN\">{{cite news |last1=Respers France |first1=Lisa |title=Jody Miller, 'Queen of the House' singer, dead at 80 |url=https://www.cnn.com/2022/10/07/entertainment/jody-miller-obit/index.html |access-date=23 April 2023 |work=[[CNN]] |date=October 7, 2022}}</ref> In 1963, the label released her debut LP titled ''[[Wednesday's Child Is Full of Woe]]''. Its background session performers included [[Cher]] and [[Glen Campbell]], both of whom were not yet artists.<ref name=\"NY Times\"/> Miller then made appearances on [[Tom Paxton]]'s folk television show.<ref name=\"Allmusic\">{{cite web |last1=Brennan |first1=Sandra |title=Jody Miller Biography |url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/jody-miller-mn0000010015/biography |website=[[AllMusic]] |access-date=23 April 2023}}</ref> The album failed to become a commercial success due to the decline of folk music's popularity.<ref name=\"Extended interview\"/> Miller's career was then taken into other genres. In 1964, her debut [[Single (music)|single]] \"He Walks Like a Man\" made America's ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Billboard Hot 100|pop chart]].<ref name=\"NY Times\"/> In Australia, it climbed into the top ten.<ref name=aus>{{cite book|last=Kent|first=David|author-link=David Kent (historian)|title=Australian Chart Book 1970\u20131992|edition=illustrated|publisher=Australian Chart Book|location=St Ives, N.S.W.|year=1993|isbn=0-646-11917-6|page=201}}</ref> In 1965, Miller participated in Italy's [[Sanremo Music Festival|Sanremo Festival]] as a team companion of [[Pino Donaggio]]. Since the festival was created as a composers' competition, Miller and Donaggio presented differently arranged versions of the entry \"Io che non vivo (senza te)\". The song came placed at number seven and was moderately successful in Italy. It was then recorded in English by [[Dusty Springfield]] and released as \"[[You Don't Have to Say You Love Me]]\".<ref>{{cite news|title=You Don't Have to Say You Love Me \u2013 Dusty Springfield's 1966 hit is rich in drama and history|url=https://ig.ft.com/life-of-a-song/you-dont-have-to-say-you-love-me.html|first=David|last=Cheal|date=January 24, 2022|access-date=October 7, 2022|newspaper=[[Financial Times]]|location=London}}</ref>\n\nUpon returning to the United States, Miller was given a new record producer named [[Steve Douglas (musician)|Steve Douglas]]. Douglas was given a song recently written in response to [[Roger Miller]]'s (no relation) cross-genre hit \"[[King of the Road (song)|King of the Road]]\".<ref name=\"Wide Open Country\">{{cite web |last1=Moore |first1=Addie |title='Queen of the House' Singer Jody Miller Discusses Her Unlikely Climb to Country Stardom |url=https://www.wideopencountry.com/jody-miller-discusses-her-unlikely-climb-to-country-stardom/ |website=Wide Open Country |date=September 4, 2018 |access-date=23 April 2023}}</ref> Titled \"[[Queen of the House]]\", the song described the domestic duties of a housewife.<ref name=\"NY Times\"/> Douglas believed the song to be a hit and had [Jody] Miller cut the track while \"King of the Road\" was still on the charts.<ref name=\"Wide Open Country\"/> \"Queen of the House\" was then rush-released as a single in 1965 and was played simultaneously with \"King of the Road\".<ref name=\"Extended interview\"/> It reached number 12 on the ''Billboard'' pop chart,<ref name=\"Hot 100\">{{cite book|last=Whitburn|first=Joel|title=Top Pop Singles 1955\u20132010|publisher=Record Research, Inc|year=2011|pages=605|isbn=978-0-89820-188-8}}</ref> number four on the ''Billboard'' [[Adult contemporary (chart)|adult contemporary]] chart<ref name=\"AC Songs\">{{cite book |last1=Whitburn |first1=Joel |title=Joel Whitburn Presents Billboard Top Adult Songs, 1961-2006 |date=2007 |publisher=Record Research, Inc. |isbn=978-0898201697 |page=309}}</ref> and number five on the ''Billboard'' [[Hot Country Songs]] chart.<ref name=\"Country Songs\">{{cite book|last=Whitburn|first=Joel|title=Hot Country Songs 1944 to 2008|publisher=Record Research, Inc|year=2008|pages=277|isbn=978-0-89820-177-2|authorlink=Joel Whitburn}}</ref> Miller's second LP of the [[Queen of the House (album)|same name]] then appeared on Capitol in June 1965.<ref name=\"Liner Notes\">{{cite journal |last1=Miller |first1=Jody |title=''Queen of the House'' (Liner Notes) |journal=[[Capitol Records]] |date=June 1965 |id=T-2349 (Mono); ST-2349 (Stereo)}}</ref> At the [[8th Annual Grammy Awards]], Miller took home the [[Grammy Award for Best Female Country Vocal Performance|Best Female Country Vocal Performance]] accolade, only becoming the second female artist to win a country Grammy.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.grammy.com/nominees/search?artist=&title=&year=1965&genre=All|title=1965 Grammy Award Winners|publisher=[[Grammy Awards]] |access-date=1 May 2011}}</ref><ref name=\"People\">{{cite magazine |last1=Vasquez |first1=Ingrid |title=Country Music Legend Jody Miller Dead at 80 Following Complications from Parkinson's Disease |magazine=[[People (magazine)|People]] |date=October 6, 2022 |url=https://people.com/country/country-music-legend-jody-miller-strong-dead-at-80/ |access-date=23 April 2023}}</ref>\n\nMiller toured amidst her commercial breakthrough. Among her gigs was a tour of [[Hawaii]] alongside [[The Beach Boys]]. Capitol Records paired Miller alongside [[The Rolling Stones]] for television appearances including ''[[Shindig!]]'' and ''[[Hollywood a Go-Go]]''. A new agent booked her for shows with entertainers [[Bob Hope]] and [[Bob Newhart]].<ref name=\"Extended interview\"/> Miller's follow-up singles made the pop charts in North America and Australia. This included \"[[Silver Threads and Golden Needles]]\" (1965) along with \"[[Home of the Brave (song)|Home of the Brave]]\" (1965). The latter recording reached number 25 on the ''Billboard'' pop chart, number 29 in Australia and number five on Canada's ''[[RPM (magazine)|RPM]]'' Top Singles chart.<ref name=\"RPM Top Songs\">{{cite web |title=Search results for \"Jody Miller\" under Top Singles |url=https://www.bac-lac.gc.ca/eng/discover/films-videos-sound-recordings/rpm/Pages/list.aspx?OCRText=Jody+Miller&ChartEn=Top+Singles& |website=[[RPM (magazine)|RPM]] | date=July 17, 2013 |access-date=15 April 2023}}</ref><ref name=\"Hot 100\"/><ref name=\"aus\"/> The song was considered \"anti-establishment\" because it described how a boy was banned from public school for dressing different than the other children. It was banned from many radio stations yet was Miller's best-selling single in the United States.<ref name=\"NY Times\"/> \"I loved that song. Unfortunately it got a bad rep,\" she said in 2020.<ref>{{cite journal |title=Oral history interview with Jody Miller |journal=[[Oklahoma State University]] |date=January 1, 2020 |url=https://dc.library.okstate.edu/digital/collection/Spot/id/847/ |access-date=23 April 2023}}</ref>\n\nMiller's country radio success from \"Queen of the House\" also influenced her label to have her record more country music, despite her original opposition to the genre.<ref name=\"Wide Open Country\"/> Ultimately, she ended up enjoying recording the genre. \"They gave me a Grammy Award for 'Queen of the House', and it thrust me into country and western music,\" she told ''Texas Hot Country'' magazine.<ref name=\"Texas Hot Country\">{{cite magazine |last1=Beck |first1=Leon |title=COUNTRY TREASURE: FROM QUEEN OF THE HOUSE TO QUEEN OF THE COUNTRY CHARTS |magazine=Texas Hot Country |date=May 14, 2020 |url=http://www.texashotcountrymagazine.com/articles/jody-miller?article_id=3674331 |access-date=23 April 2023}}</ref> Producer Steve Douglas attempted to embed country into Miller's Capitol recordings, but his formula was not successful. \"They saw right through us! We weren't country people,\" she explained in 2018.<ref name=\"Wide Open Country\"/> Despite this, Capitol issued a [[Jody Miller Sings the Great Hits of Buck Owens|country album]] of [[Buck Owens]] songs in 1966<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Miller |first1=Jody |title=''Jody Miller Sings the Great Hits of Buck Owens'' (Disc Information) |journal=[[Capitol Records]] |date=March 1966 |id=ST-2446}}</ref> and another country album in 1968 titled ''[[The Nashville Sound of Jody Miller]]''.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Miller |first1=Jody |title=''The Nashville Sound of Jody Miller'' (Disc Information) |journal=[[Capitol Records]] |date=November 1968 |id=ST-2996}}</ref> The latter featured a cover of \"[[Long Black Limousine]]\", a song about a funeral procession. Although [[Elvis Presley]] recorded its most notable version, Miller's cover made the ''Billboard'' country chart in 1968.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Wolfson |first1=Eric |title=Elvis Presley's From Elvis in Memphis |date=2020 |publisher=[[Bloomsbury Publishing]] |isbn=978-1501355394}}</ref>\n\n===1970\u20131979: Country music focus and newfound commercial success===\nMiller briefly retired from her music career due to limited commercial success and a lack of well-run management.<ref name=\"Oklahoman 1990\">{{cite news |last1=Goff |first1=Kevan |title=Blanchard's Jody Miller Prepares To \"Hit the Road' With Daughter |url=https://www.oklahoman.com/story/news/1990/02/02/blanchards-jody-miller-prepares-to-hit-the-road-with-daughter/62576400007/ |access-date=30 April 2023 |work=[[The Oklahoman]] |date=February 2, 1990}}</ref> Instead her family moved back to Oklahoma and spent time on their newly acquired ranch.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Randolph |first1=Marvin |title=VOCALIST JODY MILLER HAS RETIRED -- TWICE |url=https://www.sun-sentinel.com/news/fl-xpm-1999-07-30-9907280846-story.html |access-date=30 April 2023 |work=[[Sun Sentinel]] |date=July 30, 1999}}</ref> Miller was determined to restart her career after hearing [[Tammy Wynette]]'s \"[[Stand by Your Man]]\". She located the song's producer, [[Billy Sherrill]], called his office in [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]] and the two later met.<ref name=\"Oklahoman 1990\"/> This led to her signing a country music recording contract with [[Epic Records]] in 1970.<ref name=\"People\"/> The first Sherrill-produced album was ''[[Look at Mine]]'' in 1970. The album included both country and pop tunes<ref name=\"Allmusic\"/> and reached the top 20 of the ''Billboard'' country albums chart.<ref name=\"Country Albums\">{{cite book |last1=Whitburn |first1=Joel |title=Joel Whitburn Presents Hot Country Albums, 1964-2007 |date=2008 |publisher=Record Research, Inc. |isbn=978-0898201734 |page=301}}</ref> Both of the LP's singles (the [[Look at Mine (song)|title track]] and \"[[If You Think I Love You Now (I've Just Started)|If You Think I Love You Now]]\") reached the top 40 of the American and Canadian country charts.<ref name=\"Country Songs\"/><ref name=\"RPM Country Songs\">{{cite web |title=Search results for \"Jody Miller\" under Country Singles |url=https://www.bac-lac.gc.ca/eng/discover/films-videos-sound-recordings/rpm/Pages/list.aspx?OCRText=Jody+Miller&ChartEn=Country+Singles& |website=[[RPM (magazine)|RPM]] | date=July 17, 2013 |access-date=15 April 2023}}</ref>\n\n[[File:Jody Miller--1971.jpg|thumb|left|180px|A publicity shot of Miller in ''[[Cashbox (magazine)|Cashbox]]'' magazine, 1971.]]\nAt first, Sherrill found it challenging to find Miller's musical identity. This was because Miller did not have the phrasing of a country performer. His idea instead was to pair Miller's voice with older pop songs and rework them for the country market. \"We were pioneers of sorts putting pop music into country and we sold a lot of records,\" she recalled in 1990.<ref name=\"Oklahoman 1990\"/> Miller's 1971 remake of [[The Chiffons]]'s \"[[He's So Fine]]\" reached number five on the ''Billboard'' country chart, crossed over to number 53 on the ''Billboard'' Hot 100<ref name=\"Country Songs\"/><ref name=\"NY Times\"/> and reached the number two position on the ''Billboard'' adult contemporary chart.<ref name=\"AC Songs\"/> Her next Epic LP (also titled ''[[He's So Fine (album)|He's So Fine]]'') reached number 12 on the Top Country Albums chart in 1971.<ref name=\"Country Albums\"/> The song brought Miller her second nomination from Grammy Awards.<ref>{{cite web |title=14th Annual Grammy Awards |url=https://www.grammy.com/awards/14th-annual-grammy-awards |website=[[Grammy Awards]] |access-date=30 April 2023}}</ref> Miller had continued country chart success during the early 1970s.<ref name=\"Allmusic\"/>\n\nHer next single was a cover of \"[[Baby I'm Yours (Barbara Lewis song)|Baby I'm Yours]]\", which reached the ''Billboard'' country top five and Canada's ''RPM'' top ten. She also covered \"[[To Know Him Is to Love Him]]\" and \"[[Be My Baby]]\", which both reached the top 20 respectively.<ref name=\"Country Songs\"/><ref name=\"RPM Country Songs\"/> According to Miller, Billy Sherrill made decisions about what she would record. It was often difficult for him to find quality material because Miller was not a songwriter. \"I had to wait until someone brought me some songs,\" she told ''Wide Open Country''.<ref name=\"Wide Open Country\"/>\n\nSome of the songs Miller recorded were new material. Her 1972 single \"[[There's a Party Goin' On]]\" was penned by Sherrill and [[Glenn Sutton]]. It became her highest peaking country single, climbing to number four on the ''Billboard'' country chart<ref name=Whitburn>{{cite book|title=The Billboard Book of Top 40 Country Hits|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=eKicir5sZr4C&pg=PA230|publisher=Billboard Books|year=2006|last=Whitburn|first=Joel|pages=230\u2013231|isbn=9780823082919}}</ref> and number one on the ''RPM'' country chart.<ref name=\"RPM Country Songs\"/> A subsequent LP of the [[There's a Party Goin' On (Jody Miller album)|same name]] reached the ''Billboard'' country top 30.<ref name=\"Country Albums\"/> Miller's next pair of singles were also original recordings: \"[[Good News (Jody Miller song)|Good News]]\" and \"[[Darling, You Can Always Come Back Home]]\". Both reached the ''Billboard'' and ''RPM'' top ten in 1973.<ref name=\"Whitburn\"/><ref name=\"RPM Country Songs\"/> The singles appeared on her 1973 LP, ''[[Good News!]]'', which reached number 18 on the country LP's chart.<ref name=\"Country Albums\"/>\n\nDespite several years of country commercial success, her popularity began to wane by 1974.<ref name=\"Allmusic\"/> Among her final top 40 country singles was a cover of \"[[The House of the Rising Sun]]\".<ref name=\"Whitburn\"/> The Epic label continued releasing Miller's material regularly despite reaching progressively lower chart positions. Fourteen more songs made the ''Billboard'' Hot Country Songs chart. However, most of these singles made entry-level positions. Among her chart records were covers of \"[[(You Make Me Feel Like) A Natural Woman]]\", \"[[Will You Love Me Tomorrow]]\", \"[[I Wanna Love My Life Away]]\" and \"[[Lay a Little Lovin' on Me]]\".<ref name=\"Country Songs\"/> An original 1976 single, \"[[When the New Wears Off Our Love]]\", went to number 25 on the ''Billboard'' country chart.<ref name=\"Whitburn\"/> Its subsequent album, ''[[Here's Jody Miller]]'', was considered Miller's \"best late-period LP\" by writers [[Robert K. Oermann]] and Mary A. Bufwack, who noted its [[Linda Ronstadt]] influence.<ref name=\"Finding Her Voice\">{{cite book |last1=Bufwack |first1=Mary A. |last2=Oermann |first2=Robert K. |title=''Finding Her Voice: The History of Women in Country Music'' |date=2003 |publisher=[[Vanderbilt University|Vanderbilt University Press]] |location=[[Nashville, Tennessee]] |isbn=978-0826514325 |page=373}}</ref> Her final chart appearance occurred in 1979<ref>{{cite news|title=On the road, again \u2013 Jody Miller was a Grammy-winning singer, but then her career faded. Now, a spiritual rebirth has her on tour singing gospel music. She was in Blue Ball Saturday.|url=https://www.proquest.com/docview/306822003|page=B1|first=Marty|last=Crisp|date=January 26, 1997|access-date=October 7, 2022|newspaper=Sunday News|location=Lancaster County, Pennsylvania|id={{ProQuest|306822003}}|via=[[ProQuest]]}}</ref> and her Epic contract expired the same year.<ref name=\"Allmusic\"/>\n\n===1980\u20132022: Semi-retirement and new musical directions===\nMiller went into a period of semi-retirement after her Epic contract ended.<ref name=\"Allmusic\"/> She supported her husband's quarter horse business and attended to domestic duties on her Oklahoma ranch.<ref name=\"Finding Her Voice\"/> In the late eighties, Miller got the idea to record an album of [[American patriotic music]]. People around her did not believe it would be successful and told her she was \"crazy\".<ref name=\"Wide Open Country\"/> In 1988, ''My Country'' was released by the independent Amethyst label on [[Audio cassette|cassette]].<ref name=\"My Country\">{{cite journal |last1=Miller |first1=Jody |title=''My Country'' (Disc Information) |journal=Amethyst Records |date=1988 |id=AR-8819}}</ref> It included covers of \"[[The Star-Spangled Banner]]\" and \"[[Ragged Old Flag (song)|The Ragged Old Flag]]\".<ref name=\"Oklahoman 1990\"/> It was discovered by future American [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] president [[George H. W. Bush]], who was then [[George H. W. Bush 1988 presidential campaign|campaigning]]. Bush was impressed by Miller's album and asked her to perform at some of his campaign stops. Despite being a registered [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]], Miller agreed to the performances.<ref name=\"Wide Open Country\"/> Miller then performed at the [[United States presidential inaugural balls|Presidential inaugural ball]] after he was elected. \"It was one of the highlights of my life,\" she later said.<ref name=\"Oklahoman 1990\"/>\n\nIn 1988, the Amethyst label also issued an album of country recordings titled ''A Home for My Heart''.<ref name=\"Home for My Heart\">{{cite journal |last1=Miller |first1=Jody |title=''A Home for My Heart'' (Disc Information) |journal=Amethyst Records |date=1988 |id=AR-8820}}</ref> Miller's daughter Robin coaxed her into recording as a mother-daughter duo and the pair attempted to sign a country music recording contract in Nashville. Their first gig was at the 1989 [[Oklahoma State Fair]]. \"Robin and I really do split the vocals 50-50, so we're more like [[the Everly Brothers]] than [[the Judds]]. It's an honest sound,\" she told the press in 1990.<ref name=\"Oklahoman 1990\"/> However, they were unsuccessful.<ref name=\"Allmusic\"/> Despite not getting a major-label contract, the duo recorded an album. Under the names \"Jody and Robin\", the duo independently released ''Real Good Feelin'' in 1991.<ref name=\"Jody and Robin\">{{cite journal |title=''Real Good Feelin'' (Disc Information) |journal=Zero Records |date=1991 |id=NOD-7569}}</ref>\n\nIn 1993, Miller discovered [[Christianity]] and began recording music in the [[Gospel music|gospel]] format in the years that followed. \"It's the gift that I've been given, to sing. I think my Lord deserves recognition for that ... so I love to use that gift,\" she later commented.<ref name=\"McDonnell\"/> On independent record labels, Miller released ''I'll Praise the Lamb'' and ''The Baby from Bethlehem'', both in 1996.<ref name=\"Lamb\">{{cite journal |last1=Miller |first1=Jody |title=''I'll Praise the Lamb'' (Disc Information) |journal=White Dove |date=1996 |id=403097-12}}</ref><ref name=\"Bethlehem\">{{cite journal |last1=Miller |first1=Jody |title=''The Baby from Bethlehem'' (Disc Information) |journal=Jody Miller Music |date=1996 |id=JM-0096}}</ref> It was followed in 1999 by another gospel project titled ''Higher''.<ref name=\"Allmusic\"/>\n\nIn the final years of her career, Miller formed a trio with daughter Robin and grandson Montana. They played gigs and concerts under the name Jody Miller and Three Generations.<ref name=\"McDonnell\"/> The trio performed throughout the state of Oklahoma<ref>{{cite news |last1=Beutler |first1=Mark |title=Three generations make performing a family affair for Jody Miller |url=https://www.okgazette.com/music/three-generations-make-performing-a-family-affair-for-jody-miller-2954465 |access-date=6 May 2023 |work=[[Oklahoma Gazette]] |date=June 26, 2015}}</ref> by opening their shows together, followed by Miller performing her own songs and concluded by her family performing separately.<ref name=\"Magazine 405\">{{cite journal |last1=Beautler |first1=Mark |title=Jody Miller's Mother's Day |journal=[[The 405 (magazine)|The 405]] |date=May 7, 2019 |url=https://www.405magazine.com/jody-millers-mothers-day/ |access-date=6 May 2023}}</ref> Following Miller's death in 2022, the Heart of Texas label released an [[extended play]] of her final recordings titled ''Wayfaring Stranger''. The project was described as being a collection of \"old-time spirituals\".<ref>{{cite news |last1=McCourry |first1=Olivia |title=Jody Miller's final album released on Heart of Texas Records |url=https://tulsaworld.com/entertainment/music/jody-millers-final-album-released-on-heart-of-texas-records/article_3c7c3d4a-96a8-11ed-82ce-1f54014b5ddd.html |access-date=6 May 2023 |work=[[Tulsa World]] |date=January 17, 2023}}</ref>\n\n==Artistry==\nMiller's artistry was defined by the musical genres of folk,<ref name=\"Finding Her Voice\"/> country,<ref name=\"Allmusic\"/> gospel,<ref name=\"Oklahoman 1990\"/> and pop.<ref name=\"The Story Of\">{{cite web |last1=Unterberger |first1=Richie |title=''The Story of...'': Jody Miller: Songs, reviews, credits |url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/the-story-of-mw0001262461 |website=[[AllMusic]] |access-date=8 May 2023}}</ref> Critics have commented that Miller's musical versatility lacked consistency for her as an artist. In reviewing her 1970 ''Look at Mine'' album, Greg Adams of [[AllMusic]] commented, \"The wide variety of songs she recorded and her chameleonic vocals prevented Miller from establishing a signature sound.\"<ref name=\"Look at Mine\">{{cite web |last1=Adams |first1=Greg |title=''Look at Mine'': Jody Miller: Songs, reviews, credits |url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/look-at-mine-mw0001069270 |website=[[AllMusic]] |access-date=8 May 2023}}</ref> In reviewing one of her compilations, Richie Unterberger wrote, \"Miller is most often categorized as a country singer, but in the 1960s she was actually pretty eclectic, roving among and combining country, folk, pop, and girl group-like pop\\rock. That means there isn't much stylistic consistency here, though there are some good songs.\"<ref name=\"The Story Of\"/> On her own artistic diversity, Miller commented, \"I like to sing all kinds of songs, so I didn\u2019t fit into a mold.\"<ref name=\"NY Times\"/>\n\nWriters have also remarked on Miller's voice. Greg Adams commented that Miller's voice resembled that of [[Bobbie Gentry]]'s but with more \"technical ability\".<ref name=\"Look at Mine\"/> In a separate AllMusic review, Adams commented that Miller's also drew similarities to that of sixties pop singer [[Vicki Carr]] and found that it lacks any \"rural or working-class character\" in comparison to country performers.<ref name=\"Anthology\">{{cite web |last1=Adams |first1=Greg |title=''Anthology'': Jody Miller: Songs, reviews, credits |url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/anthology-mw0000603623 |website=[[AllMusic]] |access-date=8 May 2023}}</ref> Ed Shanahan of ''[[The New York Times]]'' described Miller's as \"a versatile singer with a rich, resonant voice\".<ref name=\"NY Times\"/>\n\n==Legacy==\nMiller's fusion of country, folk and pop were said to influence other female artists that followed. Writers Mary A. Bufwack and Robert K. Oermann described Miller as having a \"variety pack approach\" to her musical style, influencing crossover future country crossover artists like [[Linda Ronstadt]], [[Jennifer Warnes]] and [[Nicolette Larson]]. They further commented on Miller's legacy, \"The country-pop approach Jody pioneered was a profitable one for many successors.\"<ref name=\"Finding Her Voice\"/> Greg Adams commented that Miller, along with [[Jan Howard]] and [[Jeannie Seely]] \"pioneered pop-oriented country music in the '60s, and their sound has since come to dominate the field.\"<ref name=\"Anthology\"/>\n\nMiller has since been recognized for her contributions to the music industry. In 1999, the Country Gospel Music Association inducted Miller into its Hall of Fame, along with [[Loretta Lynn]], [[Barbara Mandrell]], [[Andy Griffith]], David L. Cook and [[Lulu Roman]].<ref name=\"Country Gospel\">{{cite news|title='Hee Haw' star moved by song|url=https://www.bransontrilakesnews.com/entertainment/article_358345b6-22ec-5abb-a42f-87cd47d83791.html|first=Joshua|last=Clark|date=July 11, 2009|access-date=October 6, 2022|newspaper=[[Branson Tri-Lakes News]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20221007035931/https://www.bransontrilakesnews.com/entertainment/article_358345b6-22ec-5abb-a42f-87cd47d83791.html|archivedate=October 7, 2022}}</ref> In 2018, Miller was among several recording artists that were inducted into the [[Oklahoma Music Hall of Fame]].<ref name=\"OK Hall of Fame\">{{cite web |title=Inductees |url=https://omhof.com/inductees/ |website=[[Oklahoma Music Hall of Fame]] |date=June 17, 2022 |access-date=8 May 2023}}</ref> In 2021, Miller's hometown of Blanchard named a new performing arts center after Miller. In November 2021, she participated in a ceremony dedicated to its opening. It will be named the \"Jody Miller Performing Arts Center\"<ref>{{cite news |title=Blanchard Schools breaks ground on new performance Arts Center dedicated to Jody Miller |url=https://www.oklahoman.com/story/lifestyle/2021/11/10/blanchard-schools-breaks-ground-new-performance-arts-center/6279031001/ |access-date=8 May 2023 |work=[[Oklahoman]] |date=November 10, 2021}}</ref> Miller's career was also shown in a Grammy exhibit titled ''Stronger Together: The Power of Women in Country Music'' that was shown at the [[Woody Guthrie Center]] in [[Tulsa, Oklahoma]].<ref>{{cite web |last1=Sexton |first1=Paul |title=Jody Miller, Country-Pop Star And 'Queen Of The House' Hitmaker, Dies At 80 |url=https://www.udiscovermusic.com/news/jody-miller-country-pop-star-dies-at-80/ |website=U Discover Music |date=October 7, 2022 |access-date=9 May 2023}}</ref>\n\n==Personal life==\nIn January 1962 Miller married her high school sweetheart, Monty Brooks.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Shanahan |first1=Ed |title=Jody Miller, versatile singer of 'Queen of the House' and more |url=https://buffalonews.com/jody-miller-versatile-singer-of-queen-of-the-house-and-more/article_3ab0d439-48f3-5e31-92f3-0d9741849914.html |access-date=8 May 2023 |work=[[The Buffalo News]] |date=October 28, 2022}}</ref> The couple lived in [[Los Angeles, California]] for the first eight years of the marriage.<ref name=\"Wide Open Country\"/> In 1965 Miller gave birth to her only child, Robin.<ref name=\"Magazine 405\"/> In 1970, the family moved to Blanchard, Oklahoma so their daughter could attend school in their home state. For many years, Brooks and Miller operated a quarter horse breeding and training business on their Blanchard ranch.<ref name=\"McDonnell\"/>\n\nMiller was diagnosed with [[Parkinson's disease]] in the final seven years of her life.<ref name=\"Economic Times\">{{cite news |title=Who was Jody Miller? Grammy-winning country singer passed away at age of 80 |url=https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/international/uk/who-was-jody-miller-grammy-winning-country-singer-passed-away-at-age-of-80/articleshow/94710572.cms?from=mdr |access-date=8 May 2023 |work=[[The Economic Times]]}}</ref> Miller died on October 6, 2022, in Blanchard from complications caused by the disease.<ref name=McDonnell/> She was 80 years old.<ref name=\"NY Times\"/>\n\n==Discography==\n{{main article|Jody Miller discography}}\n\n;Studio albums\n* ''[[Wednesday's Child Is Full of Woe]]'' (1963)\n* ''[[Queen of the House (album)|Queen of the House]]'' (1965)\n* ''[[Home of the Brave (album)|Home of the Brave]]'' (1965)\n* ''[[Jody Miller Sings the Great Hits of Buck Owens]]'' (1966)\n* ''[[The Nashville Sound of Jody Miller]]'' (1968)\n* ''[[Look at Mine]]'' (1970)\n* ''[[He's So Fine (album)|He's So Fine]]'' (1971)\n* ''[[There's a Party Goin' On (Jody Miller album)|There's a Party Goin' On]]'' (1972)\n* ''[[Good News!]]'' (1973)\n* ''[[House of the Rising Sun (Jody Miller album)|House of the Rising Sun]]'' (1974)\n* ''[[Country Girl (Jody Miller album)|Country Girl]]'' (1975)\n* ''[[Will You Love Me Tomorrow? (album)|Will You Love Me Tomorrow?]]'' (1976)\n* ''[[Here's Jody Miller]]'' (1977)\n* ''My Country'' (1988)<ref name=\"My Country\"/>\n* ''A Home for My Heart'' (1988)<ref name=\"Home for My Heart\"/>\n* ''Real Good Feelin''' (1991) {{small|(as Jody & Robin)}}<ref name=\"Jody and Robin\"/>\n* ''Greatest Hits'' (1992)<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Miller |first1=Jody |title=''Greatest Hits'' [Album of re-recordings] (Disc Information) |journal=C.E.O. Nashville |date=1992 |id=9203 (CD)}}</ref>\n* ''I'll Praise the Lamb'' (1996)<ref name=\"Lamb\"/>\n* ''The Baby from Bethlehem'' (1996)<ref name=\"Bethlehem\"/>\n* ''Higher'' (1999)<ref name=\"Allmusic\"/>\n* ''Bye Bye Blues'' (2002)<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Miller |first1=Jody |title=''Bye Bye Blues'' (Disc Information) |journal=Jody Miller Music |date=2002 |id=82702-03}}</ref>\n\n==Awards and nominations==\n{{awards table}}\n!{{Abbr|Ref.|Reference}}\n|-\n| 1965\n| [[Academy of Country Music Awards]]\n| Top Female Vocalist\n| {{nom}}\n| align=\"center\"| from Blanchard, Oklahoma]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at singer-songwriter (born 1983)}}\n{{for|a list of the tallest people on earth|List of tallest people}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name             = The Tallest Man on Earth\n| background       = solo_singer\n| image            = Tallest Man On Earth Newport 2015.jpg\n| image_size       = \n| caption          = Newport Folk Festival in 2015\n| birth_name       = Kristian Matsson\n| birth_date       = {{Birth date and age|1983|4|30|df=yes}}\n| birth_place      = [[Leksand]], [[Dalarna]], Sweden\n| module =\n{{Infobox person | embed=yes\n|height = 5 ft 7 in<ref>{{cite news |author=<!--not 25, 2023}}</ref>\n}}\n| genre            = {{hlist|[[Folk music|Folk]]|[[indie folk]]<ref>{{cite web|last1=Deming|first1=Mark|title=The Tallest Man on Earth \u2013 Biography &
