2017|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150903052127/http://www.allmusic.com/artist/the-tallest-man-on-earth-mn0001923376/biography|archive-date=3 September 2015}}</ref>}}\n| instrument       = {{hlist|Vocals|guitar|banjo|piano}}\n| years_active     = 2005\u2013present\n| label            = {{hlist|Gravitation|[[Dead Oceans]]|[[Mexican Summer]]|[[ANTI-]]}}\n| associated_acts  = Montezumas, [[Bon Iver]], [[Strand of Oaks]], [[Amanda Hollingby Matsson|Idiot Wind]], [[First Aid Kit (band)|First Aid Kit]]\n| website          = {{URL|thetallestmanonearth.com/}}\n| instruments      = [[Furch D40]], [[Guild GAD F20]], [[Gretsch Duo Jet]]\n}}\n\n'''Kristian Matsson''' (born 30 April 1983) is a Swedish singer-songwriter who performs under the stage name '''The Tallest Man on Earth'''. Matsson grew up in [[Leksand]], and began his solo career in 2006, having previously been the lead singer of the [[Independent music|indie]] band Montezumas. His music has often drawn comparisons to the music of [[Bob Dylan]].<ref name=\"shallow\">{{cite web |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/shallow-grave-r1437851 |title=Review: Shallow Grave |access-date=14 November 2010 |last=Ross Hoffmann |first=K |publisher=Allmusic.com}}</ref><ref name=\"deadbio\">{{cite web|url=http://www.deadoceans.com/artist.php?name=tallestmanonearth|title=The Tallest Man on Earth|access-date=14 November 2010|publisher=[[Dead Oceans]]|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100202114634/http://www.deadoceans.com/artist.php?name=tallestmanonearth|archive-date=2 February 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=130217980 |title=The Tallest Man on Earth in Concert |access-date=14 November 2010 |last=Hilton |first=Robin |website=NPR.org |publisher=NPR Music}}</ref>\n\nSince 2006, Matsson has released seven full-length albums and four EPs. He records and produces these in his home, and usually records his voice and guitar together on one track. He is known for his charismatic stage presence.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://musicreflections.wordpress.com/2010/09/20/live-review-the-tallest-man-on-earth-antones-sept-18/ |title=Live Review: The Tallest Man On Earth: Antone's; Sept. 18|publisher=Flipsidesounds.com |date=2010-09-20 |access-date=2012-06-29}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Steinborn |first=Derek |url=http://themidwestman.com/2011/02/artist-spotlight-the-tallest-man-on-earth/ |title=Artist Spotlight: The Tallest Man On Earth |publisher=The Midwest Man |date=2011-02-03 |access-date=2012-06-29 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120712071724/http://themidwestman.com/2011/02/artist-spotlight-the-tallest-man-on-earth/ |archive-date=2012-07-12 }}</ref>\n\nHe was previously married to [[Amanda Bergman]], also known by the stage name ''Idiot Wind''.<ref>{{cite web|title=Idiot Wind \u00e4r fortfarande kluven|url=http://www.dt.se/nojekultur/1.5229791-idiot-wind-ar-fortfarande-kluven|publisher=DT|access-date=29 August 2013}}</ref> Together, they wrote the music for the Swedish drama film ''Once a Year''.<ref>Swedish: ''En g\u00e5ng om \u00e5ret''.</ref>\n\n==Musical career==\nBefore Kristian Matsson began his solo career, he was the lead singer of the indie band Montezumas.\n\nMatsson's first solo release, ''[[The Tallest Man on Earth (EP)|The Tallest Man on Earth]]'', was released in 2006. The EP received positive reviews.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/the-tallest-man-on-earth-mw0001489534 |title=The Tallest Man on Earth |access-date=1 March 2016 |last=Deming |first=Mark |publisher=Allmusic.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://kritiker.se/skivor/tallest-man-on-earth/the-tallest-man-on-earth/ |title=The Tallest Man on Earth |department=Review |access-date=1 March 2016 |date=10 April 2010 |publisher=Kritiker.se |df=dmy-all}}</ref>\n\nAt the start of his solo career, Matsson didn't plan to make music full-time, and he released his music without providing personal information or photographs of himself to journalists.<ref name=\"dt\">{{cite news |author=Gustafsson, Anders K. |title=Friheten och musiken viktigast |url=http://www.dt.se/noje/article623930.ece |newspaper=[[Dalarnas Tidningar]] |date=10 April 2010 |access-date=31 December 2010 |language=sv |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100413170355/http://www.dt.se/noje/article623930.ece |archive-date=13 April 2010 |url-status=dead |df=dmy-all}}</ref>\n\nTo celebrate the 10-year anniversary of The Wild Hunt, Matsson released a cover of \"Graceland\" by [[Paul Simon]] through [[Dead Oceans]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.jambase.com/article/tallest-man-on-earth-paul-Simon-cover-graceland/|title= The Tallest Man On Earth Covers Paul Simon's 'Graceland'|access-date=14 April 2020|last=Bernstein|first=Scott|date=14 April 2020}}</ref>\n\n===''Shallow Grave'' (2008\u20132009)===\nIn 2008, Matsson released an album, ''[[Shallow Grave (album)|Shallow Grave]]'', which was praised by the music site [[Pitchfork Media|Pitchfork]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/11359-shallow-graves/ |title=Review: Shallow Grave |access-date=17 November 2010 |last=Petrusich |first=Amanda |date=6 May 2008 |publisher=Pitchfork.com}}</ref> and was listed #47 on Pitchfork's list of the ''50 Best Albums of 2008''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://pitchfork.com/features/staff-lists/7573-the-50-best-albums-of-2008/ |title=The 50 Best Albums of 2008 |access-date=17 November 2010 |publisher=Pitchfork.com}}</ref> The album received generally favorable reviews.<ref name=\"shallow\" /><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sonicmagazine.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=2050&Itemid=85 |title=Recension: Shallow Grave |access-date=17 November 2010 |last=Hellquist |first=Pierre |date=4 March 2008 |publisher=Sonic Magazine}}</ref> Following ''Shallow Grave''<nowiki/>'s release, Matsson was chosen as the opening act for the American indie folk band [[Bon Iver]].<ref name=\"sodra\">{{cite web|url=http://www.sodrateatern.com/sv/Program-och-biljetter/Evenemang/The-Tallest-Man-On-Earth/|title=The Tallest Man on Earth|access-date=17 November 2010|publisher=Sodrateatern.com|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100829011446/http://www.sodrateatern.com/sv/Program-och-biljetter/Evenemang/The-Tallest-Man-On-Earth/|archive-date=29 August 2010}}</ref> The resulting publicity led to a solo tour throughout the United States, Australia and Europe, where he attracted large crowds, in spite of the lack of a record deal or distribution in the United States.<ref name=\"dt\"/>\n\nThe song \"Pistol Dreams\", also released as a single, appeared in the Swedish television serial [[How Soon Is Now? (TV series)|How Soon Is Now?]] <small>(Swedish: Upp till kamp)</small>.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.klicktrack.com/klicktrack/releases/filmmusik-mattias-barjed/upp-till-kamp |title=Soundtrack: Upp till kamp |access-date=17 November 2010 |publisher=Klicktrack.com}}</ref>\n\nOn 9 October 2009, Matsson visited the [[Daytrotter]] studio, where he recorded four songs, including a cover of Bob Dylan's \"I Want You.\"<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.daytrotter.com/dt/the-tallest-man-on-earth-concert/20030843-3738157.html |title=The Tallest Man on Earth |access-date=17 November 2010 |last=Moeller |first=Sean |date=9 October 2009 |publisher=Daytrotter.com |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110524165758/http://www.daytrotter.com/dt/the-tallest-man-on-earth-concert/20030843-3738157.html |archive-date=24 May 2011 }}</ref> At that time, Matsson cited [[Roscoe Holcomb]] as an influence for his singing style<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.transition.se/article.aspx?id=3400 |title=5x5 The Tallest Man on Earth |access-date=17 November 2010 |last=Gunnarsson |first=Fredrik |date=22 September 2008 |publisher=Transition.se |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100818180953/http://www.transition.se/article.aspx?id=3400 |archive-date=18 August 2010 }}</ref> and later included [[Emmylou Harris]], [[Feist (singer)|Feist]] and [[Cat Power]] as influences.<ref>{{cite news |author=Hansson, Nils |title=The Tallest Man on Earth, Idiot Wind p\u00e5 S\u00f6dra teatern |url=http://www.dn.se/kultur-noje/konsertrecensioner/the-tallest-man-on-earth-idiot-wind-pa-sodra-teatern |newspaper=Dagens Nyheter |date=8 December 2010 |language=sv }} (login required)</ref>\n\n===''The Wild Hunt'' (2010\u20132012)===\n[[File:The Tallest Man on Earth 03 - 20101117.jpg|thumb|left|Matsson performing as The Tallest Man on Earth on 17 November 2010]]\n\nMattson signed with the American label [[Dead Oceans]]; in April 2010, he released his second album, ''[[The Wild Hunt (The Tallest Man on Earth album)|The Wild Hunt]]''.<ref name=\"dt\"/> The album was well received.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://kritiker.se/skivor/recension/?skiva=Tallest_Man_On_Earth__-__The_Wild_Hunt |title=Recensioner av The Wild Hunt |access-date=24 November 2010 |publisher=Kritiker.se}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |author=Larson, Annika |title=New Music Tuesday: The Tallest Man on Earth and Two Door Cinema Club |url=http://oudaily.com/news/2010/apr/20/new-music-tuesday-tallest-man-earth-and-two-door-c/ |newspaper=The Oklahoma Daily |date=20 April 2010 |access-date=24 November 2010 |language=en |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100424054439/http://www.oudaily.com/news/2010/apr/20/new-music-tuesday-tallest-man-earth-and-two-door-c/|url-status=dead |archive-date=2010-04-24}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/14110-the-wild-hunt/ |title=Review: The Wild Hunt |access-date=24 November 2010 |last=Deusner |first=Stephen M. |date=15 April 2010 |publisher=Pitchfork.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/the-wild-hunt-r1736786 |title=Review: The Wild Hunt |access-date=24 November 2010 |last=Ross Hoffman |first=K |publisher=Allmusic.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |author=Howe, Brian |title=Review: The Wild Hunt |url=http://www.pastemagazine.com/articles/2010/04/the-tallest-man-on-earth-the-wild-hunt.html |newspaper=Paste Magazine |date=14 April 2010 |language=en }}</ref> The single \"King of Spain\"  contains, besides the title track, a cover of [[Paul Simon]]'s \"Graceland\" and the previously unreleased track \"Where  I Thought I Met the Angels\"; it was sold exclusively at the subsequent European tour. During the late summer and autumn of 2010 Matsson went on tour in North America and Europe.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.deadoceans.com/artist.php?name=tallestmanonearth&p=2|title=The Tallest Man on Earth|access-date=24 November 2010|publisher=Dead Oceans|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111015172343/http://deadoceans.com/artist.php?name=tallestmanonearth&p=2|archive-date=15 October 2011}}</ref>\n\nThe album was followed that same year by an EP, ''[[Sometimes the Blues Is Just a Passing Bird]]'', which also got good reviews.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/sometimes-the-blues-is-just-a-passing-bird-r2027939 |title=Review: Sometimes the Blues is Just a Passing Bird |access-date=24 November 2010 |last=Lymangrover |first=Jason |publisher=Allmusic.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/14639-sometimes-the-blues-is-just-a-passing-bird-ep/ |title=Review: Sometimes the Blues is Just a Passing Bird |access-date=24 November 2010 |last=Deusner |first=Stephen M. |date=16 September 2010 |publisher=Pitchfork.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=The Tallest Man on Earth |url=http://www.dt.se/noje/skivor/article745418.ece |newspaper=Dalarnas Tidningar |access-date=24 November 2010 |language=sv |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101012084709/http://www.dt.se/noje/skivor/article745418.ece|url-status=dead|archive-date=2010-10-12}}</ref> The EP was released through the iTunes Store in September, and in November was published on CD, LP and MP3. The album consists of five songs, all written for ''The Wild Hunt''; \"Like the Wheel\" the conclusion of many of Matsson's gigs, and \"The Dreamer\", was the first recording on which he plays electric guitar.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://deadoceans.com/blog/2010/09/surprise-new-ep-from-the-tallest-man-on-earth-available-for-download-today-on-itunes/ |title=Surprise! New EP from The Tallest Man on Earth Available for Download Today on iTunes |access-date=24 November 2010 |date=7 September 2010 |publisher=Dead Oceans |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100913134943/http://deadoceans.com/blog/2010/09/surprise-new-ep-from-the-tallest-man-on-earth-available-for-download-today-on-itunes/ |archive-date=13 September 2010 |url-status=dead |df=dmy-all }}</ref>\n\n''The Wild Hunt'' garnered Matsson several award nominations. In 2011, he was nominated in the category \"Best Male Artist\" in [[Grammis|the Grammis Awards]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://poplight.zitiz.se/artikel/poplight-tippar-grammisvinnarna |title=Poplight tippar vinnarna p\u00e5 Grammisgalan 2011 |access-date=23 January 2011 |last=Linde |first=Eva |date=16 January 2011 |publisher=Poplight}}</ref> the Swedish equivalent of the American [[Grammy Award]]s, but lost to [[H\u00e5kan Hellstr\u00f6m]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://poplight.zitiz.se/artikel/robyn-och-hakan-hellstroem-dominerade-grammisgalan-2011 |title=Robyn och H\u00e5kan Hellstr\u00f6m dominerade Grammisgalan 2011 |access-date=23 January 2011 |last=Dahlander |first=Gustav |date=17 January 2011 |publisher=Poplight |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120316052909/http://poplight.zitiz.se/artikel/robyn-och-hakan-hellstroem-dominerade-grammisgalan-2011 |archive-date=16 March 2012 |url-status=dead |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Matsson was also nominated in the category \"pop\" in the 2011 [[P3 Guld|P3 Gold Awards]],<ref>{{cite news |url=http://sverigesradio.se/sida/artikel.aspx?programid=3964&artikel=4220806 |title=Alla nominerade till P3 Guld 2011 |access-date=16 February 2011 |newspaper=Sveriges radio|date=7 December 2010 }}</ref> but lost to Malm\u00f6 indie pop band This Is Head.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://sverigesradio.se/sida/gruppsida.aspx?programid=3964&grupp=13659 |title=Vinnarna i P3 Guld 2011 |access-date=16 February 2011 |publisher=Sveriges radio}}</ref> In February 2011, Matsson won the Manifest Award in the \"singer/songwriter\" category; he was also nominated in the \"live\" category, lost to [[Robyn]].<ref>{{cite news |author=Gustafsson, Anders K |title=Tallest Man on Earth fick Manifestpris |url=http://www.dt.se/noje/musik/article887188.ece |newspaper=Dalarnas Tidningar |date=5 February 2011 |access-date=3 March 2011 |language=sv |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110209112323/http://www.dt.se/noje/musik/article887188.ece|url-status=dead |archive-date=2011-02-09}}</ref>\n\nOn 5 April 2011, Matsson participated in the BBC's program, ''[[Later... with Jools Holland]]'', where he performed the songs \"King of Spain\" and \"Love Is All\".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://deadoceans.com/blog/2011/04/tallest-man-on-earth-on-bbcs-later-with-jools-holland/#more-2400 |title=Tallest Man on Earth on BBC's Later with Jools Holland |access-date=12 April 2011 |date=8 April 2011 |publisher=Dead Oceans |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111015172336/http://deadoceans.com/blog/2011/04/tallest-man-on-earth-on-bbcs-later-with-jools-holland/#more-2400 |archive-date=15 October 2011 |url-status=dead |df=dmy-all }}</ref> In June of the same year, Matsson's debut EP, The Tallest Man on Earth, was reissued with the previously unreleased track \"In the Pockets\" exclusive to the vinyl edition of the reissue. In July, he released the single \"Weather of a Killing Kind\" as part of the 2011 Adult Swim Singles program.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.impossibletrees.com/2011/07/weather-of-a-killing-kind-available-for-free-download/|title=Weather of a Killing Kind|access-date=12 July 2011|publisher=Impossibletrees.com|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111204020402/http://www.impossibletrees.com/2011/07/weather-of-a-killing-kind-available-for-free-download/|archive-date=4 December 2011}}</ref>\n\nIn August 2011, Matsson had contributed to the soundtrack of the Swedish drama film ''En g\u00e5ng om \u00e5ret'' <small>(English: Once a Year)</small>, along with the [[Amanda Bergman|Idiot Wind]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.pastemagazine.com/articles/2011/08/the-tallest-man-on-earth-and-idiot-wind-to-score-f.html|title=The Tallest Man On Earth and Idiot Wind to Score Film |access-date=12 July 2011 |publisher=Paste Magazine}}</ref> The film premiered at the [[Gothenburg Film Festival]] on 29 January 2012 and had a theatrical release on 17 May 2013.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sfi.se/sv/svensk-filmdatabas/Item/?itemid=75431&type=MOVIE&iv=Basic&ref=/templates/SwedishFilmSearchResult.aspx?id%3d1225%26epslanguage%3dsv%26searchword%3dEn+g%C3%A5ng+om+%C3%A5ret%26type%3dMovieTitle%26match%3dBegin%26page%3d1%26prom%3dFalse |title=''En g\u00e5ng om \u00e5ret'' |access-date=23 July 2013 |publisher=Svensk Filmdatabas}}</ref>\n\nOn 27 January 2012, Matsson took part in the Swedish [[TV]] [[game show]], P\u00e5 sp\u00e5ret where he, backed by a studio band, performed two cover songs: Thin Lizzy's \"Dancing in the Moonlight\" and  Cornelis Vreeswijk's \"En  Fattig Trubadur\" <small>(English: A Poor Troubadour)</small>.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://deadoceans.com/blog/2012/02/the-tallest-man-on-earth-plays-thin-lizzy-cover-on-swedish-game-show/|title=The Tallest Man on Earth Plays Thin Lizzy Cover on Swedish Game Show|access-date=11 June 2012|publisher=Dead Oceans|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120505192732/http://deadoceans.com/blog/2012/02/the-tallest-man-on-earth-plays-thin-lizzy-cover-on-swedish-game-show/|archive-date=5 May 2012|url-status=dead|df=dmy-all}}</ref> In February of that year, he re-released \"King of Spain\" as 12\" vinyl for the event Record Store Day. the album was limited to 2000 copies.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://deadoceans.com/blog/2012/02/the-tallest-man-on-earth-releases-12-for-record-store-day-2012/|title=The Tallest Man On Earth Releases Exclusive 12\u2033 for Record Store Day 2012|access-date=11 June 2012|publisher=Dead Oceans|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120511074758/http://deadoceans.com/blog/2012/02/the-tallest-man-on-earth-releases-12-for-record-store-day-2012/|archive-date=11 May 2012|url-status=dead}}</ref>\n\n===''There's No Leaving Now'' (2012\u20132013)===\n[[File:KristianMatsson 20130615.jpg|thumb|Mattsson performing as The Tallest Man on Earth at Bonnaroo 2013]]\n\nOn 12 June 2012 (June 11 in the UK), Matsson released his third studio album as The Tallest Man on Earth, ''[[There's No Leaving Now]]'', on [[Dead Oceans]]. The album was recorded by Matsson himself in his home studio in Dalarna during the latter part of 2011 and early 2012.<ref name=\"deadbio\"/> The album was streamed on Dead Oceans' website a week before its official release.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://deadoceans.com/blog/2012/06/the-tallest-man-on-earths-theres-no-leaving-now-available-for-streaming/|title=LISTEN: The Tallest Man On Earth's \"There's No Leaving Now\" Available for Streaming on NPR|access-date=11 June 2012|publisher=Dead Oceans|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120609010236/http://deadoceans.com/blog/2012/06/the-tallest-man-on-earths-theres-no-leaving-now-available-for-streaming/|archive-date=9 June 2012|url-status=dead|df=dmy-all}}</ref>\n\nAt the same time, Matsson released ''1904 b/w Cycles'', a 7\" LP of his song \"1904\" as well his cover of the song \"Cycles,\" written by Gayle Caldwell and [[Cycles (Frank Sinatra album)|made famous by Frank Sinatra]].<ref>{{Cite web|title=The Tallest Man On Earth \u2013 1904 (2012, Vinyl)|url=https://www.discogs.com/The-Tallest-Man-On-Earth-1904/release/3660631|access-date=2020-12-16|website=Discogs|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=the tallest man on earth \u2013 Page 3 \u2013 Indie Music Filter|url=https://indiemusicfilter.com/tag/the-tallest-man-on-earth/page/3|access-date=2020-12-16|website=indiemusicfilter.com}}</ref> He has also covered this song in live performances.<ref>{{Cite web|title=The Tallest Man on Earth and Idiot Wind Cover \"Cycles\" \u2013 TwentyFourBit|date=5 May 2012 |url=https://www.twentyfourbit.com/2012/05/the-tallest-man-on-earth-and-idiot-wind-cover-cycles/|access-date=2020-12-16|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|last=Rydin|first=Brent|date=2012-05-09|title=Idiot Wind and The Tallest Man on Earth Breeze Through Sinatra's \"Cycles\"|url=https://www.covermesongs.com/2012/05/idiot-wind-and-the-tallest-man-on-earth-breeze-through-sinatras-cycles.html|access-date=2020-12-16|website=Cover Me|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=Top 10 Sinatra covers|url=https://radiomilwaukee.org/discover-music/music-news/top-10-covers-of-sinatra-on-his-100th-birthday/|access-date=2020-12-16|website=88Nine Radio Milwaukee|date=12 December 2015 |language=en-US}}</ref>\n\nAlong with the album, Matsson announced a summer tour throughout Europe and the United States including two gigs in Sweden (at the [[S\u00f6dra Teatern]] <small>(English: Southern Theatre)</small> in [[Stockholm]]) and a performance at the [[Newport Folk Festival]] in [[Newport, Rhode Island]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://deadoceans.com/blog/2012/03/the-tallest-man-on-earth-announces-new-album-theres-no-leaving-now-and-select-summer-tour-dates/|title=The Tallest Man On Earth Announces New Album \"There's No Leaving Now,\" & Select Summer Tour Dates|access-date=11 June 2012|publisher=Dead Oceans|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120511073738/http://deadoceans.com/blog/2012/03/the-tallest-man-on-earth-announces-new-album-theres-no-leaving-now-and-select-summer-tour-dates/|archive-date=11 May 2012|url-status=dead|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Matsson also toured in Europe in October 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://deadoceans.com/blog/2012/05/the-tallest-man-on-earth-announce-new-tour-dates/|title=The Tallest Man On Earth Announces New Tour Dates|access-date=11 June 2012|publisher=Dead Oceans|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120613221054/http://deadoceans.com/blog/2012/05/the-tallest-man-on-earth-announce-new-tour-dates/|archive-date=13 June 2012|url-status=dead|df=dmy-all}}</ref>\n\nOn 28 January 2013, Matsson took part in a benefit concert for the American musician [[Jason Molina]], who did not have health insurance and, consequently, was in debt after a hospital stay. The concert took place at the S\u00f6dra Teatern <small>(English: Southern Theatre)</small> in [[Stockholm]], where Matsson played alongside, among others, I'm Kingfisher and [[Amanda Bergman|Idiot Wind]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sodrateatern.com/sv/Program-och-biljetter/Evenemang/Cross-the-Road-Molina/|title=Cross the Road Molina|access-date=29 January 2013|publisher=S\u00f6dra Teatern}}{{Dead link|date=June 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }}</ref> Molina died on 16 March 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://pitchfork.com/news/50000-rip-jason-molina/|title=R.I.P. Jason Molina|website=Pitchfork|date=18 March 2013 |access-date=28 June 2019}}</ref>\n\n===''Dark Bird Is Home'' (2015)===\nMatsson's fourth studio album as The Tallest Man on Earth, ''[[Dark Bird Is Home]]'', was released on 12 May 2015 on [[Dead Oceans]]. The album was largely inspired by Matsson's divorce from [[Amanda Bergman]] as well as the death of a close family member, and its more elaborate instrumentation represented a musical shift from previous albums.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Barton|first1=Laura|title=The Tallest Man on Earth: 'It feels like such a freedom to be loud'|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/jun/23/the-tallest-man-on-earth-dark-bird-is-home-interview|website=The Guardian|date=23 June 2015 |access-date=10 June 2017}}</ref>\n\nFollowing its release, Matsson performed\u2014with a full band\u2014at several festivals, including the [[Roskilde Festival]] in 2015<ref>{{cite web |url=http://pitchfork.com/news/58399-the-tallest-man-on-earth-returns-with-new-album-dark-bird-is-home/ |title=''Dark Bird Is Home'' |access-date=14 February 2015 |last=Gordon |first=Jeremy |date=10 February 2015 |publisher=Pitchfork}}</ref> and the [[Edmonton Folk Music Festival]] in 2016.<ref>[http://www.edmontonsun.com/2016/08/07/2016-edmonton-folk-fest-an-understated-wonderful-weekend \" 2016 Edmonton Folk Fest an understated, wonderful weekend\"]. ''Edmonton Sun'', By Fish Griwkowsky. August 07, 2016</ref>\n\n===''I Love You. It's a Fever Dream.'' (2019)===\nOn 4 February 2019, Matsson revealed that a new album would be released in 2019. In late February 2019, he revealed that his new album, now titled ''[[I Love You. It's a Fever Dream.]]'', would be released sometime in April. He also released the first single, \"The Running Styles of New York\" the same day. The second single, \"I'm a Stranger Now\" was released on 27 March. The album was released on April 19 2019.\n\nMatsson's song ''It Will Follow the Rain'' from his [[eponymous]] EP was featured in a 2019 commercial for the [[Infiniti QX50]] automobile.\n\n===''Too Late for Edelweiss'' (2022)===\nOn 19 September 2022, Matsson announced a new album of covers. It was released later that week on 23 September 2022 and includes covers of songs from [[The National (band)|The National]] and [[Bon Iver]], among others. The album's title, ''Too Late for Edelweiss'', is a reference to the album ''[[F\u00f6r sent f\u00f6r Edelweiss]]'' by Swedish singer [[H\u00e5kan Hellstr\u00f6m]], the title track of which is the first song covered on the album.<ref name=\"pitchfork-edelweiss\">{{Cite web |title=The Tallest Man on Earth Announces New Covers Album Too Late for Edelweiss |last=Arcand |first=Rob |work=[[Pitchfork (website)|Pitchfork]] |date=19 September 2022 |access-date=23 September 2022 |url= https://pitchfork.com/news/the-tallest-man-on-earth-announces-new-covers-album-too-late-for-edelweiss/ }}</ref>\n\n===''Henry St.'' (2023)===\nOn 1 February 2023, Matsson revealed that a new album titled ''Henry St.'' would be released on 14 April 2023.<ref>{{Cite web |last=ANTI- |title=The Tallest Man On Earth Announces Henry St., First New Album in Four Years, Out April 14th Via ANTI-, And Spring North American Tour Dates {{!}} News |url=http://www.anti.com/news/the-tallest-man-on-earth-announces-henry-st-first-new-album-in-four-years-o/ |access-date=2023-02-12 |website=Anti Records |language=en}}</ref> ''Henry St.'' is the first of Mattson's albums recorded in a band setting. The announcement of the album was followed by the release of the single \"Every Little Heart\". On 19 April, five days after the album's release, Pitchfork gave the album a 6.0,<ref name=\"Currin\">{{cite web |last1=Currin |first1=Grayson Haver |title=The Tallest Man on Earth: Henry St. |url=https://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/the-tallest-man-on-earth-henry-st/ |website=Pitchfork |access-date=19 April 2023 |ref=2}}</ref> praising the instrumentals and full-band sound but saying that the writing was \"just bad\". Writing for ''[[No Depression (magazine)|No Depression]]'', John Amen concluded that \"While Matsson\u2019s latest set occasionally loses traction, it certainly includes its memorable moments, most of which reiterate the confessional pitch and rougher vocal stylings of his earlier work.\"<ref>{{Cite web |title=ALBUM REVIEW: The Tallest Man on Earth Hones Craft and Wisdom on 'Henry St.' |url=https://www.nodepression.com/album-reviews/album-review-the-tallest-man-on-earth-hones-craft-and-wisdom-on-henry-st/ |access-date=2023-04-29 |website=No Depression |language=en-US}}</ref>\n\n==Musical style==\nCritics have compared The Tallest Man on Earth to [[Bob Dylan]] both in terms of songwriting ability and vocal style.<ref name=nyt10Dec2008>{{cite news|last=Pareles|first=Jon|title=Two Variations on an Acoustic Theme|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/12/11/arts/music/11nadl.html|access-date=7 April 2011|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=10 December 2008}}</ref><ref name=bglobe4Oct2010>{{cite news|last=O'Neil|first=Luke|title=Tallest Man on Earth is a player with range|url=http://www.boston.com/ae/music/articles/2010/10/04/tallest_man_on_earth_is_a_player_with_range/|access-date=7 April 2011|newspaper=[[The Boston Globe]]|date=4 October 2010}}</ref><ref name=ind9Apr2010>{{cite news|last=Gill|first=Andy|title=Album: The Tallest Man On Earth, The Wild Hunt (Dead Oceans)|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/reviews/album-the-tallest-man-on-earth-the-wild-hunt-dead-oceans-1939532.html |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/archive/20220620/https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/reviews/album-the-tallest-man-on-earth-the-wild-hunt-dead-oceans-1939532.html |archive-date=2022-06-20 |url-access=subscription |url-status=live|access-date=7 April 2011|newspaper=[[The Independent]]|date=9 April 2010}}</ref> When asked about his lyrical style, Matsson explains that he began listening to Bob Dylan at fifteen, and upon hearing Dylan's cover material, he \"tried to figure out where those songs came from\" and became slowly exposed to early American folk, such as [[Pete Seeger]] and [[Woody Guthrie]]. But he is careful to qualify this, saying \"I don't consider my work to be a part of any tradition. This is how I play. This is how I write songs.\"<ref name=\"youtube1\">{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oQAV7cRDbWA |title=The Tallest Man On Earth interview - Suhaib Shaikh (part 1) |date=25 March 2010 |publisher=YouTube |access-date=2012-06-29}}</ref>\n\nWith regard to his guitar technique, Matsson uses a variety of [[open tunings]], and standard tuning to a lesser degree. He had classical guitar training in his youth, but says he \"never really focused on it\" and that by the end of high school he \"got bored playing guitar because it was like math\",<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=q2IX5FoRRis&feature=relmfu |title=The Tallest Man On Earth interview - Kristian Matsson (part 3) |date=12 September 2011 |publisher=YouTube |access-date=2012-06-29}}</ref> until he then discovered open tunings while listening to [[Nick Drake]] in his early twenties. He was drawn to this style of playing because it allowed him to focus on singing while still performing intricate music.\n\n==Discography==\n\n===Studio albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|+ List of albums, with selected chart positions, sales, and certifications\n! scope=\"column\" rowspan=\"2\"|Title\n! scope=\"column\" rowspan=\"2\"|Details\n! scope=\"column\" colspan=\"10\"|Peak chart positions\n|-\n! scope=\"col\" style=\"width:3em;font-size:90%;\"|[[Sverigetopplistan|SWE]]<br/><ref>{{cite web | url = http://swedishcharts.com/search.asp?search=The+Tallest+Man+on+Earth&cat=a | publisher = Swedishcharts.com. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"The_Carter_Family","to":"The Carter Family"}],"pages":{"286922":{"pageid":286922,"ns":0,"title":"The Carter Family","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"#REDIRECT [[Carter Family]]\n\n{{Rcat shell|\n{{R from longer title}}\n{{R printworthy}}\n}}"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Doyle_Dykes","to":"Doyle Dykes"}],"pages":{"8118601":{"pageid":8118601,"ns":0,"title":"Doyle Dykes","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer-songwriter}}\n\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = Doyle Dykes\n| image           = Doyle Dykes.jpg\n| caption         = Dykes, April 2006\n| birth_date      = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1954|05|23}}\n| birth_place     = [[Cleveland, Tennessee|Cleveland]], Tennessee\n| genre           = [[Country music|Country]], [[Folk music|folk]], [[Blues music|blues]], [[Christian music|Christian]]\n| instrument      = [[Guitar]]\n| occupation      = [[Musician]], [[songwriter]], [[Minister (Christianity)|minister]]\n| associated_acts =\n| label           =\n| years_active    =\n| website         = [http://www.doyledykes.com Official website]\n}}\n\n'''Doyle Dykes''' (born May 23, 1954) is an American [[Country music|country]] [[Acoustic Guitar|acoustic guitarist]] from [[Jacksonville, Florida|Jacksonville]], Florida. Cited along with guitarists such as [[Tommy Emmanuel]] as one of the best fingerstyle guitarists in the world,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tomleemusic.com/specialpage/event/ev224/review/index.html|title=Event review|publisher=Tom Lee Music|accessdate=18 August 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110928115816/http://www.tomleemusic.com/specialpage/event/ev224/review/index.html|archive-date=28 September 2011|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref name=\"NAMM\">{{cite web|url=http://www.namm.org/taxonomy/term/1146?page=3|title=Doyle Dykes|publisher=NAMM|accessdate=18 August 2011}}</ref> he is also known for his capability of playing proficiently with a wide range of different guitar tunings. \n\nDykes is influenced by a wide variety of musical styles and musicians, from [[Chet Atkins]], [[Jerry Reed]], and [[Duane Eddy]], to [[the Beatles]] and [[U2]]. Some of his best-known works and interpretations are \"[[Wabash Cannonball]]\", \"Country Fried Pickin'\", \"U2 Medley\", \"Be Still\", \"[[Amazing Grace]]\" and \"[[While My Guitar Gently Weeps]]\". Dykes is a devout [[Christians|Christian]] and has served as a minister in a small church in Florida;<ref name=\"Dykes2011, p.75\">Dykes (2011), p.75</ref> the influence of Christianity is present in much of his work. He was a major endorser of [[Taylor Guitars]] and [[Rivera Amplifiers|Rivera]] Sedona amplifiers, with his own signature models of each. In 2013 he began endorsing the [[Guild Guitar Company]]. Since 2015 he has touted his custom steel-fret Olson guitar as his \"favorite guitar.\"\n\n== Biography ==\nDykes was born in [[Cleveland, Tennessee|Cleveland]], [[Tennessee]] and grew up in Jacksonville, Florida in a Christian community. His father is referred to as \"Bubba Dykes\" and he has a brother named Aubrey.<ref name=\"Dykes2011, p.35\"/> He cites June 1965 during his church's \"summer revival\" as the moment he became a lifelong Christian as an 11-year-old boy, seeing \"the lights of salvation and a new purpose and desire for my life and since that day, I've never been the same\".<ref name=\"Dykes2011, p.35\">Dykes (2011), p.35</ref> His first guitar was a $30 Sears Roebuck Silvertone acoustic.<ref name=\"Dykes2011, p.32\">Dykes (2011), p.32</ref> Dykes claims a sailor named Barry Lackey was the most important influence in his development as a guitarist. Lackey attended his church one day, and using a thumbpick from his pocket, \"completely blew him away\" with his \"spider picking\", playing just like [[Chet Atkins]] and [[Merle Travis]], Doyle's heroes.<ref name=\"Dykes2011, p.45\">Dykes (2011), p.45-7</ref> Lackey was then invited to his home for supper that night and showed him a right-hand picking pattern that \"got his fingers working together in the right way, where the thumb played the bass and after-beat rhythm, and the three fingers took care of the rest.\"<ref name=\"Dykes2011, p.45\"/> He later reunited with Lackey at a Taylor Guitars event in [[Detroit]] in 2002, and said that were it not for him, he would never have become a successful guitarist.<ref name=\"Dykes2011, p.45\"/>\n\nDykes' early years as a guitarist took him around the world as he toured with [[J. D. Sumner|the Stamps Quartet]] and later with [[Grand Ole Opry]] star [[Grandpa Jones]]. Dykes has since returned to the Grand Ole Opry for numerous performances. Although a world-renowned guitarist, Dykes frequently plays church venues with small audiences, and some intimate shows that aren't advertised, stating, \"I've been blessed with the opportunity to play music for people.\"<ref name=\"NAMM\"/>\n[[File:Dykes and Emmanuel.jpg|thumb|right|300px|Performing with [[Tommy Emmanuel]] in the Netherlands, April 2006]]\nDykes was a longtime endorser of [[Taylor Guitars]]. According to owner [[Bob Taylor (luthier)|Bob Taylor]], \"If I had to pick the artist who most represented the Taylor Guitars brand and who has done the most for us, I would say Doyle Dykes. Doyle has represented Taylor Guitars to more players for more years than anyone.\"<ref>{{cite book|last=Taylor|first=Bob|title=Guitar Lessons: A Life's Journey Turning Passion Into Business|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZvahAJJmN60C&pg=PT111|year=2011|publisher=John Wiley|isbn=978-0-470-93787-7|page=111}}</ref> The Doyle Dykes Signature Model Taylor guitar (\u201cDDSM\u201d) features an amplification system by L.R. Baggs.\n\nOn December 23, 2004, Dykes had an operation on a brain tumor in which the surgeon compressed his brain. The operation left him with a temporary loss of balance (meaning he had to learn to walk again) and suffered from extreme headaches and nausea for several years afterwards and ultimately left him deaf in his right ear.<ref name=\"Dykes2011, p.197\">Dykes (2011), p.197-8</ref> He and his wife, Rita, a high school sweetheart, have been married for at least 37 years and have four children, including daughters named Holly, Heidi and Hayley and a son named Caleb, also an accomplished guitarist. He has resided for many years in the [[Nashville]] area and is a close friend of [[Duane Eddy]]. Dykes is an avid collector of old Western movies, including the films of [[John Wayne]], [[Gene Autry]], [[Roy Rogers]], and [[Steve McQueen]].<ref name=\"Dykes2011, p.221\">Dykes (2011), p.221</ref> In 2011 he released a book ''The Lights of Marfa'', a semi-autobiographical book documenting his encounters with God, with numerous Christian references to events in his own life.\n\n==Discography==\n* 1996: ''Fingerstyle Guitar''\n* 1997: ''H.E.A.T''\n* 1998: ''Gitarre 2000''\n* 2000: ''Zelf: A Self Portrait on Guitar''\n* 2001: ''Country Fried Pickin'''\n* 2003: ''Songs of Faith and Freedom''\n* 2004: ''Chameleon''\n* 2008: ''Bridging the Gap''\n* 2013: ''Christmas with Doyle Dykes''\n* 2017: ''Return of the Falcon''\n* 2017: ''Life Behind the Guitar''\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n===Bibliography===\n*{{citation|last=Dykes|first=Doyle|title=The Lights of Marfa: One of the World's Great Guitar Player's Amazing Encounters with God|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=X8_Fe47CHBAC|accessdate=18 August 2011|date=1 April 2011|publisher=Moody Publishers|isbn=978-0-8024-0037-6}}\n\n==External links==\n*[http://www.doyledykes.com Official website]\n*[https://www.namm.org/library/oral-history/doyle-dykes Doyle Dykes Interview - NAMM Oral History Library (2002/2017)]\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Dykes, Doyle}}\n[[Category:1954 births]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:20th-century American guitarists]]\n[[Category:20th-century American male musicians]]\n[[Category:American acoustic guitarists]]\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:American country guitarists]]\n[[Category:American fingerstyle guitarists]]\n[[Category:American male guitarists]]\n[[Category:American male singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Country musicians from Florida]]\n[[Category:Guitarists from Florida]]\n[[Category:Musicians from Jacksonville, Florida]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from Florida]]\n[[Category:Southern Baptist ministers]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Nothin'_Fancy","to":"Nothin' Fancy"}],"pages":{"15727628":{"pageid":15727628,"ns":0,"title":"Nothin' Fancy","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|Bluegrass band from Virginia, US}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name             = Nothin' Fancy\n| background       = group_or_band\n| image            = Nothin' Fancy with SPBGMA award trophy Nashville TN February 2009.jpg\n| landscape        = yes\n| caption          = \"Entertaining Group Of The Year\"<br />35th Annual National [http://www.spbgma.com/ SPBGMA] Awards<br />February 5, 2009\n| origin           = [[Timberville, Virginia]], [[United States]]<br />[[Buena Vista, Virginia]]<br />[[Lexington, Virginia]]<br />[[Manassas, Virginia]]\n| genre            = {{hlist|[[Folk music|Folk]]|[[Country music|country]]|[[Americana (music)|Americana]]|[[Bluegrass music|bluegrass]]}}\n| years_active     = 1994&ndash;present\n| label            = {{hlist|[[Mountain Fever Records|Mountain Fever]]|[[Pinecastle Records|Pinecastle]]}}\n| website          = [http://www.nothinfancybluegrass.com/ Official Site]\n| current_members  = Mike Andes<br /> Chris Sexton<br />James Cox<br />Jacob Flick<br />Curt Gausman\n| past_members     = Gary Farris<br /> Buster Sexton<br />Frankie Hawkins<br />Darin Lawrence<br />Bill Ledbetter<br />Eli Johnston<br  />Justin Tomlin<br />Jesse Smathers<br />Tony Shorter<br/> Mitchell Davis<br />Caleb Cox<br />Jake Lauzon\n}}\n'''Nothin' Fancy'''<ref name=belleville>[http://www.insidebelleville.com/whatson-story/3956437-nothing-fancy-is-fancy-perfection/ \"Nothing Fancy is fancy perfection\"]. ''Inside Belleville'', May 03, 2012</ref> is a [[bluegrass music|bluegrass]] [[musical group|band]] based in [[Buena Vista, Virginia]] and was formed in September 1994. Its \"parent band\"{{clarify|date=June 2022}} East Coast Bluegrass Band was formed Summer 1985 to compete in the East Coast Bluegrass Championship in [[Crimora, Virginia]].<ref>*[http://bluegrasscountry.org/programs/aotm/nothin-fancy/ Bluegrass Country] profile \"October 2004: Nothin' Fancy\".</ref>\n\n== History ==\n=== East Coast Bluegrass Band ===\nThe East Coast Bluegrass Band was the predecessor to Nothin' Fancy formed in 1985. It was formed to compete in the East Coast Bluegrass Championship in [[Crimora, Virginia]].<ref name=belleville /> In 1986 the group won the Virginia Folk Music Society State Bluegrass Band Championship.<ref name=\"samhillbands.com\">[http://www.samhillbands.com/bands/eastcoast/index.shtml \"Biography: East Coast Bluegrass Band\"] Sam Hill Entertainment.</ref> After winning the contest, the band continued to play together at local functions.   The members of the band developed some original material, but remained true to the traditional style of the great [[bluegrass band]]s of the 1940s and 1950s.<ref name=\"samhillbands.com\"/> Nothin' Fancy was formed in 1994. Mike Andes and Mitchell Davis joined forces with Gary Farris on guitar, Tony Shorter on bass, and Guy Carawan on fiddle to play the same East Coast Bluegrass Championship in September 1994 that East Coast Bluegrass Band had once played almost a decade earlier. Nothin' Fancy released their first project \"Bluegrass in a Plain Brown Wrapper\" shortly afterwards.\n\nNothin' Fancy and East Coast Bluegrass Band continued to coexist until 2000 when East Coast Bluegrass Band's members drifted apart and had to reorganize.\n\n=== Notable Changes ===\nChris Sexton, who had appeared with Nothin' Fancy for their first-place victory in the band competition at the Maury River Fiddler's Convention in 1998 and recorded as a guest fiddler on the band's second and third releases (\"Earn Your Ticket\" and \"Field of Dreams,\" respectively), officially became the newest member of Nothin' Fancy in 2000.  The fourth project, ''Now and Then'' is the first album to feature the five-piece group as it is today.\n\nShorter departed from the group in 2005, and was replaced by Eli Johnston of [[Branson, MO]].  Nothin' Fancy released \"Album No.&nbsp;7\" under Pinecastle with Johnston and featured him as the lead vocal on the song \"Tupelo County Jail,\" but Johnston only stayed with the group for 13 months.  Citing artistic differences, he left the group and joined the band Pine Mountain Railroad.  Nothin' Fancy's members called Shorter back into service in time for the 6th Annual Nothin' Fancy Bluegrass Festival.  Shorter, who at the time was playing bass for country star [[Keith Bryant]], happily agreed and the band was re-united with its original cast and has stayed as such since.\n\nGary Farris, the guitar player, also departed the group in July 2012 and was replaced by Justin Tomlin.<ref>[http://bluegrasstoday.com/justin-tomlin-to-nothin-fancy/ \"Justin Tomlin to Nothin\u2019 Fancy\"]. ''Bluegrass Today''.</ref> Tomlin left in March 2014, and Jesse Smathers joined the group in his place.<ref>[http://bluegrasstoday.com/jesse-smathers-to-nothin-fancy \"Jesse Smathers to Nothin Fancy\"]. ''Bluegrass Today''.</ref> In June 2015, Jesse Smathers departed the group and was replaced by guitar and dobro player, Caleb Cox.<ref>[http://bluegrasstoday.com/jesse-smathers-to-lonesome-river-band \"Jesse Smathers to Lonesome River Band\"]. ''Bluegrass Today''.</ref> A month later, the band signed a recording contract with Mountain Fever Records and released their first project for the label \"By Any Other Name\" in August 2015.<ref>[http://bluegrasstoday.com/nothin-fancy-to-mountain-fever \"Nothin\u2019 Fancy to Mountain Fever\"]. ''Bluegrass Today''.</ref>\n\nIn 2019, founding member Mitchell Davis announced that he would be leaving the band. Following his departure, the band announced in March of that year that it had signed on Jacob Flick to take up Davis' role on the banjo.<ref>[https://bluegrasstoday.com/jacob-flick-to-nothin-fancy \"Jacob Flick to Nothin\u2019 Fancy\"]. ''Bluegrass Today''.</ref>\n\nIn June 2021, it was announced that Jacobe \"Jake\" Lauzon would be joining the band to play guitar and provide vocals. Jake, originally from Ontario, Canada, was a welcome addition to the group, having been was recognized as the Bluegrass Guitar Player of the Year in 2018 and 2019 at the Central Canadian Bluegrass Awards.<ref>[https://bluegrasstoday.com/jake-lauzon-to-nothin-fancy-on-guitar/ \"Jake Lauzon to Nothin\u2019 Fancy\"]. ''Bluegrass Today''.</ref>\n\nIn September 2022, it was announced that Jake Lauzon would be departing from the band to pursue new musical interests after playing one final set at the 20th Nothin' Fancy Festival.\n\nIn December 2022, the band announced that it had found its new guitar player, Curt Gausman. Curt, who got his bluegrass start in the 1980s, was part of Hobbs and Partners, which was led by Arnold Hobbs. The group also included John Paganoni, John\u2019s son Chris (who filled in as a substitute with Nothin\u2019 Fancy on more than one occasion), and Mark Delaney. From his work with Hobbs, he later formed the Hazel River Band, which he led through 1996 and recorded two albums with the Hay Holler label. <ref>[https://bluegrasstoday.com/curt-gausman-to-nothin-fancy/ \"Curt Gausman to Nothin\u2019 Fancy\"]. ''Bluegrass Today''.</ref>\n\n== Recordings ==\n\nEast Coast Bluegrass Band released four self-produced albums.  They then contracted [[Tim Austin]] of [[Doobie Shea Records|Doobie Shea Studios]] to produce and record the project. Recording began in February 1996. Later that spring, lightning struck and destroyed the studio and all the recorded sessions. Once it was up and running again they were one of the first acts to record in the new studio.<ref name=\"samhillbands.com\"/> After four albums, thirteen years, and hundreds of performances, the band released their first nationally distributed recording project, ''Life's Mysteries'' on [[Copper Creek Records]].\n\nThe group, now appearing as Nothin' Fancy, was approached by [[Pinecastle Records]] and signed to the label in 2002.  They recorded their fifth project, \"Once Upon a Road\" with the title song written for the band by [[Tom T. Hall]] and his wife Dixie.  \"Once Upon a Road\" rose to number 10 on the Bluegrass Charts as posted by [[Bluegrass Unlimited]].  Their bluegrass gospel song \"When the Angels Take My Hand\" rose to the Number 1 spot on the Bluegrass Gospel charts as posted by (the now-defunct) ''Bluegrass Now'' magazine.  The album also earned them a showcase at the [[International Bluegrass Music Association]] (IBMA) Convention in October 2002 and a nomination for the [[International Bluegrass Music Awards|IBMA]] Emerging Artist of the Year Award.\n\nTheir sixth album, \"Reflections,\" was a much more personal album, with Andes penning 10 of the 13 songs.  It featured the novelty single \"I Met My Baby in the Porta-John Line\" as a bonus track, also by Andes.  \"Reflections\" was not as commercially successful as \"Once Upon a Road,\" but it was from these two albums and the performances from this period that Nothin' Fancy had found its highly unique voice, which paid homage to bands such as the [[The Country Gentlemen|Country Gentlemen]] and the [[Seldom Scene]].  The late [[Charlie Waller (American musician)|Charlie Waller]], a founding member of the [[The Country Gentlemen|Country Gentlemen]] who went on to lead that group until his death in 2004, met with Andes at the [http://www.spbgma.com/ Society for the Preservation of Bluegrass Music of America] annual convention and learned the song \"Heaven Got an Angel\" from Andes (that was recorded originally on \"Field of Dreams\") and recorded it on the [[The Country Gentlemen|Country Gentlemen]] album \"Cryin' in the Chapel.\"\n\nTheir eighth album, ''Lord Bless This House'', the first all-gospel recording for the group, was officially released January 27, 2009 through [http://www.pinecastle.com/ Pinecastle].  Co-produced by Grammy-nominated bluegrass artist [[Rhonda Vincent]] and her brother Darrin Vincent (of Dailey and Vincent fame) with guest appearances from the both of them, it is frequently played on [[Sirius XM]] Radio's [[Bluegrass Junction]] station, along with other selections from their discography.\n\n''Undeniable'' is the group's 16th studio recording, released in 2019 to celebrate their 25th year together. The album includes all-original songwriting by Mike Andes, Caleb Cox, and Chris Sexton. It features Mike Andes (mandolin, lead/harmony vocals), Chris Sexton (fiddle, harmony vocals), Caleb Cox (guitar, lead/harmony vocals), James Cox (bass), and Jacob Flick (banjo). Cello, viola, and string arrangements on \u201cHere\u2019s To My Life\u201d were provided by Chris Sexton. The album was recorded, mixed, and mastered at Mountain Fever Studios in [[Willis, Floyd County, Virginia|Willis, Virginia]] and released by [[Mountain Fever Records]].\n\n== Performance ==\n\nEast Coast Bluegrass Band paid their dues at lawn parties and bars in and around the [[Harrisonburg, Virginia]] area and the [[Charlottesville, Virginia]] area for many years.  In years since, the band, as Nothin' Fancy, has played the [[Grand Ole Opry]] at the historic [[Ryman Auditorium]] in [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]],<ref>[http://www.bluegrassworks.com/profile.php?profileID=31 Bluegrass Works] interview \"Nothin' Fancy\" with Loretta Sawyer, 03/25/2004.</ref> and with the \"Bluegrass Series with [[Rhonda Vincent]] & Nothin' Fancy\".<ref>[http://nemr.net/~rhondav/ Official Website] Rhonda Vincent.</ref> They have played such other major venues as [[Lincoln Center]] in [[New York City]], and [[The Birchmere]] in [[Alexandria, Virginia]].  Nothin' Fancy plays about 140 shows a year and is a staple on the bluegrass festival circuit.<ref>[http://journalstar.com/articles/2007/09/28/living/gz/performances/doc46fb0ee5f118e173797113.txt Lincoln Journal Star] \"Members of Nothin' Fancy tell bluegrass listeners to expect something different\" by L. Kent Wolgamott, September 28, 2007.</ref> The band has been known to take fans on bus trips to festivals and accompanying them on bluegrass cruises aboard the [[Royal Caribbean International|Royal Caribbean]] and [[Carnival]] cruises.<ref>[http://bluegrasscountry.org/programs/aotm/nothin-fancy/ Bluegrass Country] profile \"October 2004: Nothin' Fancy\".</ref> Nothin' Fancy performed in June 2010 at the Tottenhan Bluegrass Festival in [[Ontario, Canada]], and the band toured as part of the 2012 Bluegrass Sundays Winter Concert series organized by the Northern Bluegrass Committee in Scarborough, Ontario.<ref>\"Bluegrass Sundays\" concert program, Northern Bluegrass Committee, 2012</ref>\n\n== Musical style and sound ==\nThe band seeks to remain \"true to the traditional sounds of the great bluegrass bands of the 1940s and '50s\",<ref name=\"samhillbands.com\"/> while also performing and recording original songs by their prolific songwriter, lead singer Mike Andes.  Classic bluegrass material draws from [[Bill Monroe]], [[Ralph Stanley]], the [[The Country Gentlemen|Country Gentlemen]], and the [[Seldom Scene]]; but song selection ranges from original material to gospel classics to covers of pop artists such as [[Bob Seger]], [[Bruce Springsteen]], [[Bill Withers]], [[Bob Dylan]], and [[Creedence Clearwater Revival]].\n\nIn live performance Nothin' Fancy has been noted for its strong vocals, four-part arrangements, and its high-energy shows well-seasoned with humor.  The quintet's early years saw the band gathering around one microphone, employing a shell-game choreography for solos and back-up which keeps the show visually active as well as aurally pleasing, although the most recent configuration is more traditional with individual microphones for instruments and vocals. Andes' clear singing style is attributed to the unique stylings of [[Charlie Waller (American musician)|Charlie Waller]], whose earthy bass-baritone voice sang with clear enunciation.  Farris sings a bold tenor harmony remarkable for its projection; his powerful delivery has been likened to the late [[John Duffey]] of the [[Seldom Scene]].  Shorter occasionally sings baritone harmonies an octave higher, while Davis sings bass vocals, more on gospel songs. In later recordings, Davis gave up singing bass and allowed Sexton to sing bass on gospel songs\n\n==Nothin' Fancy Bluegrass Festival==\nIn 2001, a Rockbridge County entrepreneur, Morris O'Shields, created a bluegrass festival at the Glen Maury Park, the site of the Maury River Fiddler's Convention where Nothin' Fancy won its victory three years before.  The festival was named for Nothin' Fancy, who have served as the host act in years since.<ref>[http://www.rockbridgeweekly.com/rw_article.php?ndx=9737 Rockbridge Weekly] \"Virginia Based Bluegrass Band Nothin' Fancy Garners National Music Award\".</ref>  Just as the band originally named itself after the first music festival in which it competed\u2014subsequently winning the prize\u2014it then had a music festival, whose competition it had also won, subsequently named for it.\n\nThe so-named festival has become a much-loved annual event that brings scores of bluegrass fans to the [[Shenandoah Valley]] and to the little town of [[Buena Vista, VA]], where Farris calls home (and from which the band operates).  Held each year at the Glen Maury Park in [[Buena Vista, Virginia]], the [[music festival|festival]] has perennially played host to major [[bluegrass music|bluegrass]] [[musical group|band]]s.  The 2008 [[music festival|festival]], for example, included such names as [[Rhonda Vincent]], [[Michelle Nixon]], Blue Mountain Sunrise, The Deer Creek Boys, [[The Country Gentlemen|Randy Waller & the Country Gentlemen]], Blue Moon Rising, and the [http://www.thegarywaldrepband.com/ Gary Waldrep Band].<ref>*[http://www.cybergrass.com/modules.php?name=News&file=article&sid=5313 Cybergrass] \"SPBGMA Entertaining Group Of The Year Nothin' Fancy To Host Bluegrass Fest\" September 10, 2008.</ref>  It has also hosted bands and artists such as [[IIIrd Tyme Out]], the [http://www.lonesomeriverband.com/ Lonesome River Band], [[Missy Raines]], [[Marty Raybon]], [[The Dillards]], the [[Lewis Family]], [http://www.goldwingexpress.net/ Goldwing Express], [http://www.larrystephensonband.com/ Larry Stephenson], [http://www.marknewtonband.com/ Mark Newton], [[Doyle Lawson]], and [http://www.charliesizemoreband.com/ Charlie Sizemore].\n\n==Discography==\n*''Bluegrass In A Plain Brown Wrapper'' 2009.<ref>[http://www.spbgma.com/level2/natawd2010.html 36th ANNUAL SPBGMA BLUEGRASS MUSIC AWARDS] HELD FEBRUARY 4-5-6-7, 2010; Sheraton Music City - Nashville, Tennessee.</ref>\n**\"Entertaining Group Of The Year\" at the 34th Annual National [http://www.spbgma.com/ SPBGMA] Awards February 2008.<ref>[http://www.bluegrassjournal.com/2008/02/04/nothin-fancy-takes-top-award-at-spbgma-convention/ Bluegrass Journal] \"Nothin' Fancy takes top award at SPBGMA Convention\" by Travis Tackett, February 4, 2008.</ref>\n*September 25, 2010 was named \"Nothin' Fancy Day\" by order of the mayor of Buena Vista, Virginia.\n*Named as \"Honorary Mountaineers\" by order of Governor [[Joe Manchin]] III of West Virginia while playing a benefit concert in 2007 in Weston, W. Va., for the Lewis County Blue Brass Band to raise funds for student instruments.  The governor commended them for \"demonstrating an expression of good will and respect for the people of the Mountain State.\"<ref>[http://www.ibma.org/Articles/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=475 Bluegrass Industry News, Nov. 2007--Artists & Agents] [[International Bluegrass Music Association|IBMA]].</ref>\n*''Once Upon A Road'' earned them a showcase at the IBMA Convention October 2002 and a nomination for the 14th annual [[International Bluegrass Music Awards|IBMA]] Emerging Artist of the Year Award (2003).<ref>[http://www.bmi.com/news/entry/233837 BMI.com] \"2003 IBMA Awards Noms Led By BMI Writers\" September 8, 2003.</ref>\n*Winner at the 1998 Maury River Fiddler's Convention.\n*Winner at the 1986 Virginia Folk Music Society State Bluegrass Band Championship (as East Coast Bluegrass Band).\n*Winner at the 1985 East Coast Bluegrass championship (as East Coast Bluegrass Band).\n\n==Members==\n*Mike Andes--[[mandolin]]/[[vocals]]\n*Chris Sexton--[[fiddle]]/[[vocals]]\n*James Cox--[[double bass|bass]]/[[vocals]]\n*Curt Gausman--[[guitar]]/[[vocals]]\n*Jacob Flick--[[banjo]]/[[vocals]]\n\n== Reviews, articles, notices ==\n*[http://www.bluegrassjournal.com/2008/09/10/nothin-fancy-bluegrass-festival-kicks-off-sept-25-for-3-day-run/ BluegrassJournal.com] \"Nothin' Fancy Bluegrass Festival kicks off Sept. 25 for 3 day run\" by Travis Tackett, September 10, 2008.\n*[http://www.cybergrass.com/modules.php?name=News&file=article&sid=5313 Cybergrass] \"SPBGMA Entertaining Group Of The Year Nothin' Fancy To Host Bluegrass Fest\" September 10, 2008.\n*[http://www.bluegrassjournal.com/2008/02/04/nothin-fancy-takes-top-award-at-spbgma-convention/ BluegrassJournal.com] \"Nothin' Fancy takes top award at SPBGMA Convention\" by Travis Tackett, February 4, 2008.\n*[http://journalstar.com/articles/2007/09/28/living/gz/performances/doc46fb0ee5f118e173797113.txt Lincoln Journal Star] \"Members of Nothin' Fancy tell bluegrass listeners to expect something different\" by L. Kent Wolgamott, September 28, 2007.\n*[http://www.dnronline.com/artsandentertainment_details.php?AID=11951&CHID=5 Daily News Record] \"New Grass King Sam Bush, Nothin' Fancy To Visit Shenandoah Valley Music Festival\" posted 2007-08-30.\n*[http://www.bluegrassworks.com/review.php?reviewID=90 Bluegrass Works] review \"Nothin' Fancy - Reflections (CD, 2004)\" by Jason Hooker, 09/03/2004.\n*[http://www.bluegrassworks.com/profile.php?profileID=31 Bluegrass Works] interview \"Nothin' Fancy\" with Loretta Sawyer, 03/25/2004.\n*[http://www.bluegrassworks.com/review.php?reviewID=9 Bluegrass Works] review \"Nothin' Fancy - Once Upon A Road (CD, 2002)\" by Lewis Geffen, 06/01/2004.\n*[http://bluegrasscountry.org/programs/aotm/nothin-fancy/ Bluegrass Country] profile \"October 2004: Nothin' Fancy\".\n*[http://www.rockbridgeweekly.com/rw_article.php?ndx=9737 Rockbridge Weekly] \"Virginia Based Bluegrass Band Nothin' Fancy Garners National Music Award\".\n\n== See also ==\n*[[Bluegrass music]]\n*[[Shenandoah Valley]]\n*[[The Country Gentlemen|Country Gentlemen]]\n*[[Seldom Scene]]\n*[[Rhonda Vincent]]\n*[[Grand Ole Opry]]\n*[[International Bluegrass Music Association]]\n*[[Nashville, Tennessee]]\n\n== References ==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n*[http://www.nothinfancybluegrass.com/default.asp?loadpage=home Official Website] Nothin' Fancy\n*[http://www.nothinfancybluegrass.com/festival08/default.html Nothin' Fancy Bluegrass Festival]\n*[http://www.spbgma.com/ Society for the Preservation of Bluegrass Music of America] official webpage\n*[http://www.samhillbands.com/bands/eastcoast/index.shtml Sam Hill Entertainment] band description\n*[http://www.pinecastle.com/artists.php?id=8 Pinecastle Records] Artist Press Kit.\n*[http://nemr.net/~rhondav/ Official website] Rhonda Vincent.\n\n{{Bluegrass music}}\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:Country music groups from Virginia]]\n[[Category:American folk musical groups]]\n[[Category:American bluegrass music groups]]\n[[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]]\n[[Category:Timberville, Virginia]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Anita_Carter","to":"Anita Carter"}],"pages":{"4008191":{"pageid":4008191,"ns":0,"title":"Anita Carter","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer-songwriter}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=January 2020}}\n{{More citations needed|date=January 2020}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| image           = Anita Carter.jpg\n| caption         = Anita Carter in 1977\n| image_size      = 220px\n| birth_name      = Ina Anita Carter\n| alias           =\n| birth_date      = {{birth date|1933|3|31}}<ref name=\"AMbio\"/>\n| birth_place     = [[Maces Spring, Virginia|Maces Spring]], Virginia, US\n| death_date      = {{death date and age|1999|7|29|1933|3|31}}<ref name=\"AMbio\"/>\n| death_place     = [[Hendersonville, Tennessee|Hendersonville]], Tennessee, U.S.\n| instrument      = Bass, 12-string guitar, autoharp, vocals\n| genre           = [[Country music|Country]], [[folk music|folk]]\n| occupation      = Singer-songwriter\n| years_active    =\n| label           = [[RCA Victor]], Cadence, Columbia, [[Audiograph]], United Artists, Liberty, Capitol, [[House of Cash]]\n| past_member_of = [[Carter Family]], [[The Carter Sisters]]\n| website         = \n}}\n'''Ina Anita Carter''' (March 31, 1933 \u2013 July 29, 1999) was an American singer who played upright bass, guitar, and [[autoharp]]. She performed with her sisters, [[Helen Carter|Helen]] and [[June Carter Cash|June]], and her mother, [[Maybelle Carter|Maybelle]], initially under the name The Carter Sisters and Mother Maybelle. Carter had three top ten hits as well as other charting singles. She was the first to record the songs \"[[Blue Boy (song)|Blue Boy]]\" and \"[[Ring of Fire (song)|Ring of Fire]]\". Carter was also a songwriter, most notably co-writing the [[Johnny Cash]] hit \"[[Rosanna's Going Wild]].\"\n\nCarter recorded for a number of labels, both as a solo artist and with her family, including [[RCA Victor]], [[Cadence Records|Cadence]], [[Columbia Records|Columbia]], [[Audiograph]], [[United Artists]], [[Liberty Records|Liberty]] and [[Capitol Records|Capitol]].\n\n==Biography==\nAnita was the third daughter of [[Ezra Carter|Ezra]] and Maybelle Carter.\nBorn in [[Maces Spring, Virginia]], she scored two top ten hits in 1951 with \"[[Down the Trail of Achin' Hearts]]\" and \"[[Bluebird Island]],\" both duets with [[Hank Snow]]. In 1962, she recorded \"[[Ring of Fire (song)|Love's Ring of Fire]],\" written by her sister June and [[Merle Kilgore]]. After the song failed to make the charts, Johnny Cash recorded it as \"Ring of Fire\" in March 1963 with the horns and the Carter Sisters (along with Mother Maybelle). This version became a hit for Cash.\n\nShe reached the top ten again in 1968 with \"I Got You,\" a duet with [[Waylon Jennings]].<ref name=\"AMbio\">{{cite web |url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/anita-carter-mn0000920617/biography |title=Anita Carter Biography |last=Bush |first=John |publisher=AllMusic |access-date=January 5, 2020}}</ref> Carter also reached the top 50 with hits like \"I'm Gonna Leave You\" in 1966 and \"Tulsa County\" in 1971.\n\nOn March 26, 1952, she appeared on ''[[Kate Smith|The Kate Smith Evening Hour]]'' with her family band \"[[The Carter Sisters and Mother Maybelle]]\" as the first females to represent hillbilly/country music and Music City [[Nashville]] on national television.<ref>{{Citation |title=''The Kate Smith Evening Hour'' - 26 March 1952 |date=1952 |url=http://archive.org/details/TheKateSmithEveningHour26March1952 |publisher=National Broadcasting Company |access-date=2022-10-15}}</ref> On April 23, she returned to the program, where she performed a duet with [[Hank Williams]], on his song \"[[I Can't Help It (If I'm Still in Love with You)]]\".<ref>{{Cite web |title=Hank Williams Duets With Anita Carter On 1952 Episode Of 'The Kate Smith Evening Hour' |url=https://countrymusicfamily.com/hank-williams-duets-with-anita-carter-on-1952-episode-of-the-kate-smith-evening-hour/ |access-date=2022-10-15 |website=Country Music Family |language=en-US}}</ref> Then on May 21, she became the first female star of the Grand Ole Opry to sing a solo on [[The Kate Smith Evening Hour]] when she sang \"Just When I Needed You\".<ref>{{Cite web |title=The Kate Smith Evening Hour w/ WSM's Grand Ole Opry Guests, May 21st, 1952 [video recording] |url=https://digi.countrymusichalloffame.org/digital/collection/movingimage/id/1322/ |access-date=2022-10-15 |website=digi.countrymusichalloffame.org |language=en}}</ref>\n\n===Marriages===\nCarter married fiddler Dale Potter in 1950 (marriage was annulled shortly thereafter), [[session musician]] Don Davis in 1953 (divorced and then remarried), and [[Bob Wootton]] (lead guitarist for Johnny Cash's band [[Tennessee Three|The Tennessee Three]]) in 1974 (divorced). She had two children.\n\n===Death===\nCarter suffered from [[rheumatoid arthritis]] for many years, and the drugs used to treat it severely damaged her pancreas, kidneys, and liver. She died on July 29, 1999, at the age of 66,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://elvispelvis.com/anitacarter.htm |title=Anita Carter |last=Polatnick |first=Gordon |website=Fuller Up The Dead Musician Directory |access-date=January 20, 2016 |archive-date=August 25, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180825002923/http://elvispelvis.com/anitacarter.htm |url-status=dead }}</ref> a year after eldest sister Helen and four years before middle sister June. She was under hospice care at the home of Johnny and June Carter Cash in [[Hendersonville, Tennessee]]. Her interment was in [[Hendersonville Memory Gardens]] in [[Hendersonville, Tennessee]].\n\n=== Album discography apart from Carter Family ===\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n|-\n! Albums !! Label !! You\" || 4 || duet with [[Waylon Jennings]]\n|-\n|\"Cry Softly\"\n|N/A\n|\n|-\n| \"To Be a Child Again\" || 65 ||\n|-\n| 1969 || \"Coming of the Roads\" || 50 || duet with [[Johnny Darrell]]\n|-\n|
