lead vocal on chorus of 1967 single \"The Last Thing on My Mind\" \n|-\n| 1968 || Porter Wagoner & Dolly Parton: ''Just the Two of Us'' || 5 || backing vocals\n|-\n| 1968 || Dolly Parton: ''Just Because I'm a Woman'' || 22 || backing vocals\n|-\n| 1969 || Porter Wagoner & Dolly Parton: ''Always, Always'' || 5 || backing vocals\n|-\n| 1969 || Waylon Jennings: ''Just to Satisfy You'' || 7 || two duet vocals\n|-\n| 1970 || Porter Wagoner & Dolly Parton:'' Porter Wayne & Dolly Rebecca'' || 4 || backing vocals\n|-\n| 1980 || Porter Wagoner & Dolly Parton: single \"Making Plans\" || 2 || backing vocals on original recording, 1968\n|-\n| 1987 || Johnny Cash: ''[[Johnny Cash is Coming to Town]]'' || 36 || backing vocals with the Carter Family\n|-\n| 1991 || Johnny Cash: ''[[The Mystery of Life]]'' || 70 || backing vocals\n|-\n|}\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n{{Carter Family}}\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Carter Family}}\n[[Category:1933 births]]\n[[Category:1999 deaths]]\n[[Category:People from Scott County, Virginia]]\n[[Category:American women country singers]]\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:American folk singers]]\n[[Category:Apex Records artists]]\n[[Category:RCA Victor artists]]\n[[Category:Cash\u2013Carter family]]\n[[Category:Country musicians from Virginia]]\n[[Category:Folk musicians from Virginia]]\n[[Category:Audiograph artists]]\n[[Category:Cadence Records artists]]\n[[Category:20th-century American singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:The Carter Family members]]\n[[Category:20th-century American women singers]]\n[[Category:20th-century American singers]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from Virginia]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Hoyt_Axton","to":"Hoyt Axton"}],"pages":{"772828":{"pageid":772828,"ns":0,"title":"Hoyt Axton","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American singer-songwriter and actor (1938\u20131999)}}\n{{Infobox musical artist  <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject Musicians -->\n| name                = Hoyt Axton\n| image                 = Hoyt Axton 1976.jpg\n| caption            = Hoyt Axton on July 4, 1976\n| image_size            = \n| background          = solo_singer\n| birth_name          = Hoyt Wayne Axton\n| alias               = \n| birth_date          = {{Birth date|1938|03|25}}\n| birth_place         = [[Duncan, Oklahoma|Duncan]], Oklahoma, U.S.\n| death_date          = {{death date and age|1999|10|26|1938|03|25}}\n|death_place          = [[Victor, Montana]], U.S.\n| origin              = [[Comanche, Oklahoma]]\n| instrument          = Vocals, guitar\n| genre               = [[Country music|Country]], [[Folk music|folk]], [[Blues music|blues]], [[Rock music|rock]]\n| occupation          = {{flatlist|\n* Singer\n* songwriter\n* actor}}\n| years_active        = 1962\u20131999\n| label               = [[A&M Records]], [[Brylen Records]], [[Vee Jay Records]]\n| associated_acts     = \n| website             = {{official website|https://web.archive.org/web/20050826150814/http://sixcats.com/axton/hoyt.htm}}\n}}\n\n'''Hoyt Wayne Axton''' (March 25, 1938 \u2013 October 26, 1999)<ref name=\"British Hit Singles & Albums\">{{cite book| first= David| last= Roberts| year= 2006| title= British Hit Singles & Albums| edition= 19th| publisher= Guinness World Records, Ltd| location= London| isbn= 1-904994-10-5| page= 34}}</ref> was an American singer-songwriter, guitarist and actor. He became prominent in the early 1960s, establishing himself on the West Coast as a folk singer with an earthy style and powerful voice. Among his best-known songs are \"[[Joy to the World (Three Dog Night song)|Joy to the World]]\", \"[[The Pusher]]\", \"[[No No Song]]\", \"Greenback Dollar\", \"Della and the Dealer\" and \"[[Never Been to Spain]]\".<ref name= \"LATimes obit\">{{cite news| url= https://www.latimes.com/archives/la-xpm-1999-oct-27-mn-26812-story.html| work= [[Los Angeles Times]] | date= October 27, 1999| title= Hoyt Axton, Singer, Character Actor and Hit Songwriter, Dies| first= Myrna| last= Oliver| access-date= January 5, 2018 |url-access=subscription}}</ref>\n\nHe was also a prolific character actor with many film and television roles to his credit, often playing a father figure in a number of films including ''[[The Black Stallion (film)|The Black Stallion]]'' (1979), ''[[Heart Like a Wheel (film)|Heart Like a Wheel]]'' (1983) and ''[[Gremlins]]'' (1984).\n\n==Early life==\nBorn in [[Duncan, Oklahoma]], Axton spent his preteen years in [[Comanche, Oklahoma]], with his brother John.<ref name=axtonallm>{{cite web|url={{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p1512|pure_url=yes}}|title=Biography: Hoyt Axton|last=Ankeny|first=Jason| publisher= AllMusic |access-date=September 6, 2011}}</ref> His mother [[Mae Boren Axton]], a songwriter, cowrote the song \"[[Heartbreak Hotel]]\", which became a major hit for [[Elvis Presley]].<ref name=Pareles>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1999/10/27/arts/hoyt-axton-61-songwriter-singer-and-actor-in-movies.html|title=Hoyt Axton, 61, Songwriter, Singer and Actor in Movies|website=[[The New York Times]]|date=October 27, 1999|author=Pareles, Jon |url-access=limited}}</ref> Some of Hoyt's own songs were later recorded by Presley. Axton's father John Thomas Axton<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.filmreference.com/film/90/Hoyt-Axton.html|title=Hoyt Axton Biography (1938\u2013)| website= filmreference.com}}</ref> was a naval officer stationed in [[Jacksonville, Florida|Jacksonville]], Florida, where the family joined him in 1949.\n\nAxton graduated from [[Robert E. Lee High School (Jacksonville, Florida)|Robert E. Lee High School]] in 1956 and left town after a hardware store was destroyed by fire on graduation night following a misguided prank.<ref>{{cite web| url= http://larrycohenproductions.com/N_Fla_Music.htm| title= North Florida Music Hall of Fame| first= Larry| last= Cohen| publisher= Larry Cohen Productions| access-date= January 5, 2018| archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20170820124706/http://larrycohenproductions.com/N_Fla_Music.htm| archive-date= August 20, 2017}}</ref>\n\nHe attended [[Oklahoma State University\u2013Stillwater|Oklahoma State University]] on a scholarship,<ref name=Pareles /> where he played football, but he left to enlist in the [[United States Navy|U.S. Navy]]. Axton held the rank of [[Petty officer second class|Petty Officer Second Class]] and served on two ships, the [[USS Princeton (CV-37)|USS ''Princeton'' (CV-37)]] and the [[USS Ranger (CV-61)|USS ''Ranger ''(CVA-61)]].<ref name= \"LATimes obit\" />\n\nAxton was a cousin of musician [[Arlo Guthrie]]. He was also the first cousin of [[David Boren]], who served as governor of Oklahoma and three terms in the [[United States Senate]] and was also president of the [[University of Oklahoma]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.okhistory.org/publications/enc/entry.php?entry=AX002|website=Oklahoma Historical Society|title=Axton, Mae Boren (1914\u20131997)|access-date=December 20, 2020}}</ref>\n\n==Career==\nAfter his discharge from the Navy, Axton began singing folk songs in coffee houses and nightclubs in Southern California. In the early 1960s, he released his first folk album, ''The Balladeer'' (recorded at [[The Troubadour (Los Angeles)|the Troubadour]]), which included his song \"Greenback Dollar.\" It became a 1963 hit for [[the Kingston Trio]].<ref name= \"LATimes obit\" />\n\nAxton released numerous albums throughout the 1960s and 1970s. In the mid-1970's he produced studio covers of his own music for [[John Davidson (entertainer)|John Davidson]], and also produced ''Tales From the Ozone'', a 1975 album by [[Commander Cody and His Lost Planet Airmen]]. He released many minor hits of his own, such as \"Boney Fingers\", \"When the Morning Comes\" and 1979's \"Della and the Dealer\".<ref name=Pareles /> His vocal style featured his distinctive bass-baritone (which later deepened to near-bass) and use of [[characterization]].\n\nAxton first appeared on television in a [[David L. Wolper]] ABC production of ''The Story of a Folksinger'' (1963). He appeared on ''[[Hootenanny (US TV series)|Hootenanny]]'', hosted by [[Jack Linkletter]], during this period. In 1965, he appeared in an episode of ''[[Bonanza]]''<ref name=Pareles /> in which he sang duets with [[Pernell Roberts]]. In 1966, he made his film debut in ''[[Smoky (1966 film)|Smoky]]'' playing the role of Fred Denton, the evil brother of the character played by [[Fess Parker]]. He gained fame in the 1970s and 1980s through his film roles, including those in ''[[The Black Stallion (film)|The Black Stallion]]'' (1979), ''[[Liar's Moon]]'' (1982), ''[[Heart Like a Wheel (film)|Heart Like a Wheel]]'' (1983) and ''[[Gremlins (film)|Gremlins]]'' (1984). His television appearances included ''[[McCloud (TV series)|McCloud]]'' (1976), ''[[The Bionic Woman]]'' (1976), ''[[WKRP In Cincinnati|WKRP in Cincinnati]]'' (1979) and ''[[Diff'rent Strokes]]'' (1984, 1985). In 1980, he sang the theme song to the short-lived series ''[[Flo (TV series)|Flo]]'', and guest-starred as himself in the episode titled \"You Gotta Have Hoyt\". Axton sang the jingle \"The Ballad of Big Mac\" for a 1969 [[McDonald's]] [[Big Mac]] television commercial as well as \"Head for the Mountains\" in voiceovers for [[Busch Beer|Busch]] beer in the 1980s. He appeared in a [[Pizza Hut]] commercial in 1985 and in a TV spot for [[Florists' Transworld Delivery|FTD]] with [[Merlin Olsen]] in 1989.{{citation needed|date=November 2022}} In 1991 Axton was awarded an induction to The Walk of Western Stars in Newhall, California.\n\nAxton's most lasting contributions, however, were songs made famous by others: \"[[Joy to the World (Three Dog Night song)|Joy to the World]]\" ([[Three Dog Night]]) and \"[[Never Been to Spain]]\" for both Three Dog Night and [[Elvis Presley]], \"Greenback Dollar\" for the Kingston Trio, \"[[The Pusher]]\" and \"Snowblind Friend\"  for [[Steppenwolf (band)|Steppenwolf]], \"[[No No Song]]\" for [[Ringo Starr]], and songs covered by singers such as [[Joan Baez]], [[Arlo Guthrie]], [[John Denver]], [[Nina Simone]], [[Waylon Jennings]], [[Martha Reeves]], [[Jonathan Edwards (musician)|Jonathan Edwards]], [[Glen Campbell]], [[Anne Murray]], [[David Clayton-Thomas]] and [[Colter Wall]]. Axton sang [[Duet (music)|duets]] with [[Linda Ronstadt]] on the songs \"Lion in the Winter\" and \"[[When the Morning Comes (song)|When the Morning Comes]]\", with Renee Armand on \"Boney Fingers\" and with [[Tanya Tucker]] on \"You Taught Me How to Cry.\" His composition \"Joy to the World\", performed by Three Dog Night, reached #1 on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] chart for six straight weeks in 1971, making it the top hit of the year. He named his record label Jeremiah after the bullfrog mentioned in the song.<ref name= \"LATimes obit\" />\n\n==Personal life==\nAxton was married four times; his first three marriages ended in divorce.<ref name= \"LATimes obit\"/> He had five children.<ref name= \"LATimes obit\"/> One of his children, Matt Axton, is a musician.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mattaxton.com| title=Matt Axton Music|access-date=February 5, 2024}}</ref>\n\nAxton struggled with [[cocaine]] addiction, and several of his songs, including \"The Pusher\", \"Snowblind Friend\" and \"No No Song\", partly reflect his experiences with the drug.<ref name= \"LATimes obit\"/> He was a proponent of medical marijuana use, but he and his wife Deborah were arrested in February 1997 at their Montana home for possession of about {{cvt|500|g|lb|abbr=on}} of [[cannabis (drug)|marijuana]]. His wife later explained that she offered Axton marijuana to relieve his pain and stress following his 1995 stroke. They were fined and received [[deferred sentence]]s. Axton never fully recovered from his stroke, and he used a wheelchair for the remainder of his life.{{fact|date=June 2024}}\n\n==Death==\nAxton died at age 61 at his home in [[Victor, Montana|Victor]], Montana on October 26, 1999, after suffering two heart attacks in two weeks.<ref name= \"LATimes obit\"/><ref name=axton2>{{cite news|title=Songwriter Hoyt Axton Dead at 61 In Montana| work= Daily News|location=New York |last= Hinckley| first= David| url= http://articles.nydailynews.com/1999-10-27/news/18115330_1_greenback-dollar-hoyt-axton-boney-fingers| archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20120614052803/http://articles.nydailynews.com/1999-10-27/news/18115330_1_greenback-dollar-hoyt-axton-boney-fingers| url-status= dead| archive-date= June 14, 2012|date=October 27, 1999|access-date=September 3, 2011}}</ref><ref name=axton3>{{cite encyclopedia| title= Axton, Hoyt Wayne (1938\u20131999)| encyclopedia= Encyclopedia of Oklahoma History & Culture| publisher= Oklahoma Historical Society| last= Burke| first= Brad| url= http://digital.library.okstate.edu/encyclopedia/entries/A/AX001.html| date= October 27, 1999| access-date= September 3, 2011| archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20110805103414/http://digital.library.okstate.edu/encyclopedia/entries/A/AX001.html| archive-date= August 5, 2011}}</ref>\n\nOn November 1, 2007, Axton and his mother [[Mae Boren Axton]] were inducted posthumously into the [[Oklahoma Music Hall of Fame]] in [[Muskogee, Oklahoma]].<ref>{{cite news| url= http://www.tulsatoday.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=980:oklahoma-music-hall-of-fame-induction-2007&catid=55:out-a-about&Itemid=111|title= Oklahoma Music Hall of Fame Induction 2007|work= [[Tulsa Today]]| first= Jim| last= Downing | date= November 17, 2007 | archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20120318054713/http://www.tulsatoday.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=980:oklahoma-music-hall-of-fame-induction-2007&catid=55:out-a-about&Itemid=111| archive-date= March 18, 2012| access-date= January 5, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url= http://muskogeephoenix.com/local/x2128977011/-Thank-God-I-m-from-Oklahoma-inductee-says| first= D. E.| last= Smoot| work= [[Muskogee Phoenix]]| location= Muskogee, Oklahoma | title= 'Thank God I'm from Oklahoma,' inductee says| archive-url=https://archive.today/20120904192238/http://www.muskogeephoenix.com/local/local_story_306001635.html |archive-date=September 4, 2012 | access-date= January 5, 2018}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Year\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Album\n! colspan=\"3\"| Chart positions\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Label\n|-\n! class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\"\n|-\n! Year\n! style=\"width:12em;\"| Video\n|-\n| 1990\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Heartbreak Hotel\"\n|}\n\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\"\n|-\n! Year\n! style=\"width:12em;\"| Video\n|-\n| 1990\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Mountain Right\"\n|}\n\n==Selected list of songs==\nAmong Axton's best-known compositions (or co-writing credits) are:\n* \"Greenback Dollar\" - [[cover version|covered by]] [[the Kingston Trio]]  and many others.\n* \"[[The Pusher]]\" - covered by [[Steppenwolf (band)|Steppenwolf]] on their debut album in 1968; this version was also used in the soundtrack of the 1969 film ''[[Easy Rider]]''. [[Nina Simone]] recorded the song in 1971. [[Blind Melon]], [[Isla Grant]], [[Helix (band)|Helix]] and [[The Flaming Lips]] also covered the song.\n* \"Have a Nice Day\" (1971) - covered by [[Bing Crosby]] and [[John Davidson (entertainer)|John Davidson]]\n* \"Less Than The Song\" (1972) - covered by [[Joan Baez]], John Davidson and [[Patti Page]]\n* \"Lion In The Winter\" (1974) - duet with [[Linda Ronstadt]]. Covered by Faan Rousseau Family Band, Isla Grant and Guthrie Girls\n* \"Southbound\" (1975) - covered by [[Three Dog Night]] and [[Commander Cody & His Lost Planet Airmen]]\n* \"[[No No Song]]\" (1975) - became a #3 hit for [[Ringo Starr]] in March 1975\n* \"[[Never Been to Spain]]\" - covered by Three Dog Night, [[Waylon Jennings]], [[Elvis Presley]], [[Cher]], and [[Ike & Tina Turner]], and others\n* \"[[Joy to the World (Three Dog Night song)|Joy to the World]]\" - Three Dog Night hit from 1971 that spent six weeks atop the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] chart. [[Little Richard]] and Matt Axton also covered the song.\n* \"Snowblind Friend\" (1971) - covered by [[Steppenwolf (band)|Steppenwolf]], [[David Allan Coe]], and Chestnut Station\n* \"Lightning Bar Blues\" (1973) - covered by Commander Cody, [[Brownsville Station (band)|Brownsville Station]], [[Linda Ronstadt]], [[Arlo Guthrie]] and [[Hanoi Rocks]]\n* \"Sweet Misery\" (1974) - [[cover version|covered by]] [[John Denver]], [[Martha Reeves]], and Matt Axton\n* \"Sweet Fantasy\" (1974) - covered by [[Glen Campbell]] and [[David Clayton-Thomas]]\n* \"Ease Your Pain\" (1971) - covered by [[Bobby Whitlock]], [[Anne Murray]], [[Glenn Yarbrough]] and [[Jackie DeShannon]]\n* \"[[When the Morning Comes (song)|When the Morning Comes]]\" (1974) - duet with [[Linda Ronstadt]]\n* \"You Taught Me How to Cry\" - 1977 duet with [[Tanya Tucker]]. Covered by Matt Axton.\n* \"Boney Fingers\" (1974) - duet with Renee Armand. Armand was co-writer.\n* \"Jealous Man\" (1976) - performed on ''[[WKRP in Cincinnati]]''; covered by [[John Fullbright]]\n* \"Della and the Dealer\" (1979) - also performed on ''WKRP''; reached the top 20 of the ''Billboard'' country chart in the U.S. and the top 50 of the British pop chart\n* \"Evangelina\" (1974) - covered by [[Arlo Guthrie]], [[Albert Lee]], [[Jonathan Edwards (musician)|Jonathan Edwards]], [[Colter Wall]] and others\n* \"Flash of Fire\" (1976) - co-written by [[Cathy Smith]]\n* \"Gypsy Moth\" (1976) - covered by [[Freddie White]] and [[Nathaniel Rateliff]]\n* \"In a Young Girl's Mind\" (1975) - covered by [[Johnny Cash]]\n\n==Film and television appearances==\n\n===Film appearances===\n\n* ''[[Smoky (1966 film)|Smoky]]'' (1966) \u2013 Fred Denton\n* ''[[The Black Stallion (film)|The Black Stallion]]'' (1979) \u2013 Alec's father\n* ''Skinflint: A Country Christmas Carol'' (1979, TV Movie) \u2013 Cyrus Flint\n* ''[[Cloud Dancer]]'' (1980) \u2013 Brad's mechanic\n* ''[[Liar's Moon]]'' (1982) \u2013 Cecil Duncan\n* ''[[The Junkman]]'' (1982) \u2013 Himself / Cap. Gibbs / Rev. Jim Beam (voice)\n* ''[[Endangered Species (1982 film)|Endangered Species]]'' (1982) \u2013 Ben Morgan\n* ''[[The Black Stallion Returns]]'' (1983) \u2013 Narrator (voice)\n* ''[[Heart Like a Wheel (film)|Heart Like a Wheel]]'' (1983) \u2013 Tex Roque\n* ''[[Deadline Auto Theft]]'' (1983) \u2013 Captain Gibbs\n* ''Fred C. Dobbs Goes to Hollywood'' (1983)\n* ''[[Gremlins]]'' (1984) \u2013 Randall Peltzer\n* ''[[Act of Vengeance (1986 film)|Act of Vengeance]]'' (1986, TV Movie) \u2013 Silous Huddleston\n* ''[[Retribution (1987 film)|Retribution]]'' (1987) \u2013 Lt. Ashley\n* ''[[Christmas Comes to Willow Creek]]'' (1987, TV Movie) \u2013 Al Bensinger\n* ''Guilty of Innocence: The Lenell Geter Story'' (1987, TV Movie) - Charlie Hartford\n* ''Dixie Lanes'' (1988) \u2013 Clarence Laidlaw\n* ''[[Disorganized Crime]]'' (1989) \u2013 Sheriff Henault\n* ''[[We're No Angels (1989 film)|We're No Angels]]'' (1989) \u2013 Father Levesque\n* ''[[Buried Alive (1990 TV film)|Buried Alive]]'' (1990, TV Movie) \u2013 Sheriff Sam Eberly\n* ''[[Harmony Cats]]'' (1992) \u2013 Bill Stratton\n* ''[[Space Case (1992 film)|Space Case]]'' (1992) - Charlie\n* ''Season of Change'' (1994) \u2013 Big Upton\n* ''[[Kingfish: A Story of Huey P. Long]]'' (1995, TV Movie) \u2013 Huey P. Long, Sr.\n* ''Number One Fan'' (1995) \u2013 Lt. Joe Halsey\n* ''[[King Cobra (1999 film)|King Cobra]]'' (1999) \u2013 Mayor Ed Biddle \n\n\nSeveral songs for the 1977 film ''[[Outlaw Blues]]'' were composed by Axton and sung by [[Peter Fonda]].<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.tcm.com/tcmdb/title.jsp?stid=85996&category=Full%20Credits |title=Outlaw Blues (1977) \u2013 Overview | website=  TCM.com| publisher= Turner Classic Movies| access-date= January 5, 2018}}</ref> \nAxton also contributed songs for the films ''The Legend of Hillbilly John'' (1972), ''[[Buster and Billie]]'' (1974), ''[[Mitchell (film)|Mitchell]]'' (1975), and ''[[The Junkman]]'' (1982).\n\n===Television appearances===\n*''The Story of a Folksinger'' (TV special, 1963) - Himself\n* ''[[Hootenanny (US TV series)|Hootenanny]]'' (1964) \u2013 Himself\n*''[[Bonanza]]'' (1965, Season 6, Episode 27: \"Dead and Gone\") \u2013 Howard Mead\n* ''[[Iron Horse]]'' (1966) \u2013 Slash Birney\n* ''[[I Dream of Jeannie]]'' (1966, Season 2, Episode 7: \"Fastest Gun in the East\") \u2013 Bull\n* ''[[The Midnight Special (TV series)|The Midnight Special]]'' (1973) (musical guest)\n* ''The Hoyt Axton Country Western Boogie Woogie Gospel Rock and Roll Show'' (1975) \u2013 Himself. NBC TV special featuring Linda Ronstadt, Arlo Guthrie and Ringo Starr.<ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2759452/| publisher= IMDb| title=The Hoyt Axton Country Western Boogie Woogie Gospel Rock and Roll Show|access-date= August 26, 2019}}</ref>\n* ''[[The Bionic Woman]]'' (1976) \u2013 Buck Buckley\n* ''[[Dinah!]]'' (1976) (musical guest)\n* ''[[McCloud (TV series)|McCloud]]'' (1977) \u2013 Johnny Starbuck\n* ''[[Hee Haw]]'' (1977) (musical guest)\n* ''[[Flying High (TV series)|Flying High]]'' (1978) - Himself\n* ''Hee Haw Honeys'' (1979) (musical guest)\n* ''[[The Tonight Show Starring Johnny Carson]]'' (1979) (musical guest)\n* ''[[WKRP in Cincinnati]]'' (1979, performed \"Della and the Dealer\" and \"Jealous Man\") \u2013 T.J. Watson\n* ''[[Austin City Limits]]'' (1979)  (musical guest)\n* ''[[The Dukes of Hazzard]]'' (1981)  (musical guest)\n* ''[[Flo (TV series)|Flo]]'' (1981) - Himself\n* ''[[Barbara Mandrell & the Mandrell Sisters]]'' (1981) (musical guest)\n* ''Seven Brides for Seven Brothers'' (1982, Season 1, Episode 3: \"Challenges,\" and Episode 8: \"Rodeo\", in which he sang \"I Dream of Highways\") \u2013 Cooper Johnson\n* ''[[The Rousters]]'' (1983\u20131984) \u2013 Cactus Jack Slade\n* ''[[Diff'rent Strokes]]'' (1984-1985) \u2013 Wes McKinney\n* ''[[Domestic Life (TV series)|Domestic Life]]'' (1984) \u2013 Rip Steele\n* ''[[Faerie Tale Theatre]]'' (1984, \"[[Goldilocks and the Three Bears (Faerie Tale Theatre episode)|Goldilocks and the Three Bears]]\") \u2013 Forest Ranger\n* ''[[Cover Up (TV series)|Cover Up]]'' (1984) - John Cody\n* ''[[Glitter (American TV series)|Glitter]]'' (1985) - Christie's father\n* ''The Steel Collar Man'' (series pilot, 1985) - Red\n* ''[[Trapper John, M.D.]]'' (1985) - Jack Dearborne\n* ''[[Dallas: The Early Years]]'' (1986, TV Movie) \u2013 Aaron Southworth\n* ''[[Murder, She Wrote]]'' (1988) \u2013 Sheriff Tate\n* ''[[Midnight Caller]]'' (1990) \u2013 Ralston Cash Dollar \n* ''[[Growing Pains]]'' (1990) \u2013 Claver Jackson\n* ''[[Railfair 91]]'' (1991, VHS Documentary) - Guest Host and Musical Guest\n* ''[[Doorways]]'' (1993, series pilot) - Jake Mitchell\n\n\nIn 1992 Axton narrated ''The Alaska Highway: 1942-1992'' a documentary about the history of the [[Alaska Highway]] that was produced by public television station [[KAKM]] of [[Anchorage, Alaska|Anchorage]] and shown nationally on [[PBS]]. In the mid-1990s, Axton was chosen to host and narrate the profile series ''[[Life and Times (TV series)|Life and Times]]'' on [[The Nashville Network]], in which a different country music figure was spotlighted each hour. His voice was heard throughout and he was seen on camera doing the introduction and closing of each show in which he participated.\n\nAxton also served as the narrator for two documentaries about the [[Western States Endurance Run|Western States Endurance Race]] in 1982 and 1983 titled ''Desperate Dreams''.\n\n==References==\n{{reflist|2}}\n{{Refbegin}}\n* {{cite book |last=Allen |first=Bob Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Sara_Carter","to":"Sara Carter"}],"pages":{"232552":{"pageid":232552,"ns":0,"title":"Sara Carter","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{for-multi|the African-American model|Sara Lou Harris Carter|the Canadian actress|Sarah Carter|the American author and editor|Sarah Carter Edgarton Mayo}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=March 2017}}\n{{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject Musicians -->\n| name             = Sara Carter\n| image            = File:Carter Family 1927.jpg\n| caption          = Carter (holding the autoharp) with the rest of the [[Carter Family]] in 1927\n| image_size       = 250 px\n| background       = solo_singer\n| birth_name       = Sara Elizabeth Dougherty\n| alias            = \n| birth_date       = {{Birth date|mf=yes|1898|7|21}}\n| birth_place      = [[Copper Creek, Virginia]], U.S.\n| death_date       = {{Death date and age|mf=yes|1979|1|8|1898|7|21}}\n| death_place      = [[Lodi, California]], U.S.\n| instrument       = [[lead vocalist|Vocals]], [[autoharp]], guitar, [[guitaro]]\n| genre            = [[Country music|Country]], [[Folk music|folk]], [[Gospel music|gospel]]\n| occupation       = Singer-songwriter, musician\n| years_active     = 1927\u20131971\n| label            = [[Victor Records|Victor]], [[ARC Records|ARC]], [[Decca Records|Decca]]\n| past_member_of  = [[Carter Family]]\n}}\n\n'''Sara Elizabeth Carter''' (n\u00e9e '''Dougherty''', later '''Bayes'''; July 21, 1898 \u2013 January 8, 1979) was an American [[country music]] musician, singer, and songwriter. Remembered mostly for her deep, distinctive, mature singing voice, she was the lead singer on most of the recordings of the historic [[Carter Family]] act in the 1920s and 1930s. In her earliest recordings her voice was pitched very high.<ref name=\"Zwonitzer\">{{cite book|last=Zwonitzer|first=Mark|author2=Hirshberg, Charles|title=Will You Miss Me When I'm Gone?: The Carter Family & Their Legacy in American Music|publisher=Simon & Schuster|year=2004|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qTdns8tiSqUC&q=Will+You+Miss+Me+When+I'm+Gone%3F+The+Carter+Family+%26+Their+Legacy+in+American+Music|isbn=0-7432-4382-X}}</ref>\n\n== Life and career ==\n{{more citations needed section|date=January 2016}}\nBorn in [[Copper Creek, Virginia]], the daughter of William Sevier Dougherty and Nancy Elizabeth Kilgore, at age 16 she married [[A. P. Carter]] on June 18, 1915; they divorced in 1936.<ref name=\"Zwonitzer\"/> They had three children: Gladys (Mrs. Millard), [[Janette Carter|Janette]] (Mrs. Jett), and [[Joseph Dougherty Carter|Joe]].<ref name=\"Zwonitzer\"/>\n\nIn 1927, she and A. P. began performing as the [[Carter Family]], perhaps the first commercial rural country music group. They were joined by her cousin, [[Maybelle Carter|Maybelle]], who was married to A. P.'s brother, [[Ezra Carter]]. Later, Sara married Coy Bayes, A. P.'s first cousin, and moved to California in 1943, and the original group disbanded. In the late 1940s, Maybelle began performing with her daughters [[Helen Carter|Helen]], [[June Carter Cash|June]], and [[Anita Carter|Anita]] as The Carter Sisters and Mother Maybelle (the act was renamed The Carter Family during the 1960s).<ref>{{Cite book |last=Wolfe |first=Charles K. |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tFWSAgAAQBAJ |title=Classic Country: Legends of Country Music |date=2002-05-03 |publisher=Routledge |isbn=978-1-135-95734-6 |page=17 |language=en}}</ref>\n\nOn Carter Family recordings, Sara is credited as author of the songs \"Fifty Miles of Elbow Room\" and \"Keep on the Firing Line\"; in truth she discovered these [[public domain]] songs when they were being sung at a [[Seventh-day Adventist]] church she visited.\n\nRCA gave her songwriter credit, as it did A.P. Carter on his public domain discoveries. The Carter Family recordings of these tunes brought the songs worldwide fame. Sara wrote or co-wrote several other songs, including \"My Foothills Home\", \"The Dying Soldier\", \"Lonesome Pine Special\", \"Farther On\", and \"Railroading on the Great Divide\".\n\nSara reunited with Maybelle in 1966 for a Columbia Records album titled \"An Historic Reunion,\" which was later re-issued on Bear Family Records, with additional songs, as \"Sara and Maybelle Carter.\" They performed together during the folk music craze of the 1960s at the Newport Folk Festival.<ref name=\"Zwonitzer\"/> The duo were featured as guests in a late 1960s episode of [[the Wilburn Brothers]] television show, singing \"Little Moses\" and \"As the Band Played Dixie\". Following this period, Sara retired to California,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.encyclopediavirginia.org/Carter_Sara_1898-1979|title=Carter, Sara (1898\u20131979)|last=Lornell|first=Kip|website=Encyclopedia Virginia|access-date=2016-05-04}}</ref> although she and Maybelle remained close for the rest of their lives and Sara and Coy journeyed yearly from California to Virginia by car, pulling a travel trailer.\n\nIn the early 1970s, Sara and Maybelle reunited to appear on [[Johnny Cash]]'s network television show and to perform together at the first annual A.P. Carter Memorial Festival in [[Hiltons, Virginia]].\n\n== Family tree==\n{{Tree chart/start|align=center|summary=Carter Family Tree}}\n{{Tree chart| | | | | | | | | | | W.K. |~|y|~| NAK | |W.K.=William Kilgore|NAK=Nancy Kilgore}}\n{{Tree chart| | | | | | | | | | | | | ||)|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|.| }}\n{{Tree chart| | | | | | | |H.J.A. |~|y|~| M.E.K. | | | | | | | | N.E.K. |~|y|~| W.S.D. | | H.J.A.=Hugh J. Addington|M.E.K.=Margaret E. Kilgore|N.E.K.=Nancy E. Kilgore|W.S.D.=William S. Dougherty}}\n{{Tree chart| | | | | | | | | | ||!| | | | | | | | | | | | | | | |!| | }}\n{{Tree chart| | | | EZRA |~|y|~| MAY | | | | | | | | |A.P. |~|y|~| SARA |-|y|-| C.B. |EZRA=[[Ezra Carter]]|MAY=[[Maybelle Carter]]|A.P.=[[A. P. Carter|A.P. Carter]]|SARA='''Sara Carter'''|C.B.= Coy Bayes}}\n{{Tree chart| | | |,|-|-|-|+|-|-|-|.| | | | | | | | |,|-|-|-|+|-|-|-|.| | | }}\n{{Tree chart| | | H.C. | | A.C. | | J.C.C. |~|y|~| J.C. | | G.C. | | JETT | | JOE | |H.C.=[[Helen Carter]]|A.C.=[[Anita Carter]]|J.C.C.=[[June Carter Cash]]|J.C.=[[Johnny Cash]]|G.C.=Gladys Carter|JETT=[[Janette Carter]]|JOE=[[Joseph Dougherty Carter|Joe Carter]]}}\n{{Tree chart| | | | | | | | | | | | | | |!| | | }}\n{{Tree chart| | | | | | | | | | | | | | JOHN | |JOHN=[[John Carter Cash]]}}\n{{Tree chart/end}}\n\n== Legacy ==\nCarter was inducted as part of the Original [[Carter Family]] in the [[Country Music Hall of Fame]] in 1970, along with [[Bill Monroe]].\n<ref name=\"CMHF\">{{cite web|last=Wolfe|first=Charles|title=Carter Family|publisher=Country Music Hall of Fame & Museum|url=http://www.countrymusichalloffame.org/full-list-of-inductees/view/carter-family|accessdate=February 17, 2010|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110807062544/http://countrymusichalloffame.org/full-list-of-inductees/view/carter-family|archivedate=August 7, 2011|df=mdy-all}}</ref> In 1993, her image appeared on a U.S. postage stamp honoring the Carter Family.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/1993-09-12/entertainment/9309080581_1_american-music-series-customer-affixed-stamps-first-day-cancellations|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170325202522/http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/1993-09-12/entertainment/9309080581_1_american-music-series-customer-affixed-stamps-first-day-cancellations|url-status=dead|archive-date=March 25, 2017|title='Legends' Series Salutes Country-western Stars|website=Sun-Sentinel|access-date=2016-05-04}}</ref> In 2001 she was inducted into the [[International Bluegrass Music Hall of Honor]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bluegrassmuseum.org/sara-carter/|title=Sara Carter|website=International Bluegrass Music Museum|access-date=2016-05-04}}</ref>\n\nOn her 2008 album ''[[All I Intended to Be]]'', [[Emmylou Harris]] includes the song \"How She Could Sing the Wildwood Flower\", co-written with [[Kate and Anna McGarrigle]] about the relationship between Sara and A.P., inspired by a documentary that the three of them saw on television.{{citation needed|date=November 2015}}\n\n==Death==\n[[File:Grave of Sara Carter Bayes and children at Mount Vernon United Methodist Church at Maces Springs, Virginia now Hiltons, Virginia.jpg|thumb|right|Grave of Sara Carter Bayes and children at [[Mount Vernon United Methodist Church]] at [[Hiltons, Virginia]]]]\nSara Carter died in [[Lodi, California]], aged 80,<ref>{{Cite news |date=1979-01-09 |title=Sara Carter Bayes obit-Lodi 1979 |pages=28 |work=The San Francisco Examiner |url=https://www.newspapers.com/article/the-san-francisco-examiner-sara-carter-b/36095944/ |access-date=2023-12-12}}</ref> and is interred in the Mt. Vernon United Methodist Church graveyard in [[Hiltons, Virginia]]. The [[A. P. and Sara Carter House]], [[A. P. Carter Homeplace]], [[A. P. Carter Store]], [[Maybelle and Ezra Carter House]], and [[Mt. Vernon Methodist Church]] are listed on the [[National Register of Historic Places]] as components of the Carter Family Thematic Resource.<ref name=\"nris\">{{NRISref|version=2010a}}</ref><ref>{{NRHP url|id=64000880|title=Carter family profile}}, pdfhost.focus.nps.gov (PDF); accessed November 14, 2015.</ref>\n\n== See also ==\n*[[Carter Family]]\n\n== References ==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n== Sources ==\n* Wolfe, Charles (1998). \"The Carter Family\". In ''The Encyclopedia of Country Music''. Paul Kingsbury, Editor. New York: Oxford University Press. pp.&nbsp;84\u20135, 617.<!--ISSN/ISBN needed-->\n\n==External links==\n*[https://adp.library.ucsb.edu/names/106602 Sara Carter recordings] at the [[Discography of American Historical Recordings]].\n\n{{Carter Family}}\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Carter, Sara}}\n[[Category:1898 births]]\n[[Category:1979 deaths]]\n[[Category:People from Russell County, Virginia]]\n[[Category:Country musicians from Virginia]]\n[[Category:American women country singers]]\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:American autoharp players]]\n[[Category:20th-century American singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Cash\u2013Carter family]]\n[[Category:American United Methodists]]\n[[Category:The Carter Family members]]\n[[Category:20th-century American women singers]]\n[[Category:20th-century American singers]]\n[[Category:20th-century Methodists]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from Virginia]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Will_Kimbrough","to":"Will Kimbrough"}],"pages":{"8165811":{"pageid":8165811,"ns":0,"title":"Will Kimbrough","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer-songwriter}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=December 2020}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name             = Will Kimbrough\n| image            = Will Kimbrough acoustic.jpg\n| caption          = Austin City Limits Music Festival (2008)\n| landscape        = yes\n| background       = solo_singer\n| birth_date       = {{birth date and age|1964|5|1}}\n| birth_place      = [[Mobile, Alabama|Mobile]], [[Alabama]], United States\n| death_date       = \n| instrument       = Vocals, guitar, [[accordion]], [[banjo]], bass guitar, [[dobro]], harmonica\n| genre            = [[Country music|Country]]<br>[[Folk music|Folk]]\n| occupation       = Musician, songwriter, producer\n| years_active     = 1985\u2013present\n| label            = [[Lost Highway Records|Lost Highway]], [[Oh Boy Records]]\n| associated_acts  = Will and the Bushmen<br>[[The Bis-quits]]<br>Daddy<br>Willie Sugarcapps\n| website          = [http://www.willkimbrough.com/ www.willkimbrough.com]\n}}\n\n'''William Adams Kimbrough''' (born May 1, 1964) is an American singer-songwriter, multi-instrumentalist and producer based in [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]], [[Tennessee]], United States.\n\n==Biography==\nKimbrough was born in [[Mobile, Alabama]], and started his musical career as a founding member of Will & the Bushmen,<ref name=\"Gordon\">{{cite web|url={{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p219242|pure_url=yes}}|title=Biography: Will Kimbrough|last=Gordon|first=Rev. Keith A.|publisher=[[Allmusic]]|access-date=May 24, 2010}}</ref> a college band in the 1980s that recorded a handful of albums and singles and made it to [[MTV]]. He then went on to form the [[Bis-Quits]] with long-time friend Tommy Meyer.<ref name=\"Gordon\" /> The Bis-quits produced an [[eponymous]] album which was released on [[John Prine]]\u2019s [[Oh Boy Records]] label.\n\nKimbrough is also a producer and has produced albums for [[Adrienne Young]], [[Rodney Crowell]],<ref name=\"Gordon\" /> [[Todd Snider]],<ref name=\"Gordon\" /> [[Kate Campbell]], [[Steve Poltz]], [[Kim Richey]], [[Garrison Starr]], [[Matthew Ryan (musician)|Matthew Ryan]], and [[Josh Rouse]].\n\nHis songs have been recorded by [[Jimmy Buffett]], [[Little Feat]], [[Jack Ingram]], [[Todd Snider]] and more. Kimbrough has also collaborated with many artists including [[Rosanne Cash]], [[Guy Clark]], [[Rodney Crowell]], [[Steve Earle]], [[Gomez (band)|Gomez]], [[Emmylou Harris]], [[The Jayhawks]], [[Mark Knopfler]], [[Buddy Miller]], [[John Prine]], [[Toumani Diabat\u00e9]], [[Kim Richey]], [[Josh Rouse]], [[Matthew Ryan (musician)|Matthew Ryan]], [[Billy Joe Shaver]], [[Todd Snider]], [[Michael C. Parris]], [[Mavis Staples]], [[Garrison Starr]], [[Adrienne Young]], and others.<ref name=\"Will Kimbrough\">{{cite web|last=Farley|first=Mike|title=Will Kimbrough Bio|url=http://www.willkimbrough.com/bio/|website=Willkimbrough.com|access-date=October 7, 2012}}</ref>\n\nKimbrough was recognized in 2004 as the 'Instrumentalist of the Year' by the [[Americana Music Association]] \u2013 an award that had previously been awarded three years in a row to [[Jerry Douglas]].<ref name=\"Will Kimbrough\" /> His songs demonstrate a literate facility that he pairs with guitar playing so fluid that his fans created a t-shirt suggesting he is an alien.<ref name=Phillips>{{cite news|last=Phillips|first=Casey|title=Will Kimbrough is an Alien|url=http://ehis.ebscohost.com/eds/detail?sid=7489a0c3-c5c8-4b4b-94f4-057a7590949b%40sessionmgr12&vid=4&hid=4&bdata=JnNpdGU9ZWRzLWxpdmUmc2NvcGU9c2l0ZQ%3d%3d#db=nfh&AN=2W61475723427|access-date=October 7, 2012|newspaper=Chattanooga Times/Free Press (TN)|date=October 8, 2009}}</ref>\n\nKimbrough teamed up with [[Tommy Womack]], John Deaderick, Paul Griffith and Dave Jacques in 2005 to create the five piece band, Daddy.  They recorded a live album in Frankfort, Kentucky, ''Daddy at the Women's Club'', and another album, ''For a Second Time''.\n\nIn 2007, Kimbrough released an EP \u2013 his solo studio recording that revealed a hint of what would develop on his next album release.<ref name=\"Will Kimbrough\" />\n\nKimbrough has released several solo albums to date, and has collaborated on many more, as well as serving as a [[session musician]] and [[sideman]]. Kimbrough was one of the guest artists at [[Jimmy Buffett]]'s Live from the Gulf Coast Concert on July 11, 2010.\n\nIn March 2012, it was announced that Kimbrough had joined [[Trigger Hippy]] in place of guitarist [[Audley Freed]].\n\nIn frequent visits to visit his family, Kimbrough joined a number of other Southern Alabama singer-songwriters beginning in 2013 to form Willie Sugarcapps.\n\nA song he co-wrote with John Hahn and recorded by [[Shemekia Copeland]], \"Too Far to Be Gone\", was nominated for a [[Blues Music Award]] in 2023.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.rockandbluesmuse.com/2023/01/10/2023-blues-music-award-nominees-announced/|title=2023 Blues Music Award Nominees Announced|first=Martine|last=Ehrenclou|website=Rockandbluesmuse.com|date=10 January 2023|access-date=19 April 2023}}</ref>\n\n==Influences==\nBorn and raised on the Alabama Gulf Coast, Kimbrough ingested eclectic FM radio sounds and the music of nearby [[New Orleans]] as a young man. His sound has been influenced by traditions of [[folk music|folk]], [[blues]], [[gospel music|gospel]], [[country music|country]], [[punk rock]] and [[jazz]].\n\nKimbrough described \"When Your Lovin' Comes Around\" from his 2014 release, ''Sideshow Love'', as \"a little bit of a tribute to [[J. J. Cale]],\" who he said was a significant influence on his music.<ref>From an interview on [http://americanamusicshow.com/episode178 episode 178 of the Americana Music Show], released February 10, 2014</ref>\n\n==Social commentary==\nThe songs on his album ''Americanitis'', such as \"Warring Ways\" and \"Everyone's in Love\", have been described by Kimbrough as anti-war and anti-greed themed.<ref name=Phillips />\n\nHis album ''Wings'' explores themes surrounding the conflicts between family and career, love and work, parents and children. The music is based in [[folk rock]], with touches of guitar, cello, saxophone, trumpet, banjo, and [[Hammond organ]].<ref name=\"Will Kimbrough\" />\n\n==Discography==\n[[File:Will-Kimbrough by Ron Baker.jpg|thumb|180px|right|Kimbrough playing accordion at ACL Festival (2008)]]\n{{Main article|Will Kimbrough discography}}\n===Solo albums===\n*''Fireworks, Vol. 2'' (1999)\n*''This'' (2000)\n*''Home Away'' (2002)\n*''Godsend'' (2003)\n*''Americanitis'' (2006)\n*''EP'' (2007)\n*''Wings'' (2009)\n*''Sideshow Love'' (2014)\n*''I Like It Down Here'' (2019)\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n*[http://www.willkimbrough.com/ Official website]\n*[http://www.daddymusic.net/ Daddy Band website]\n*[https://archive.org/details/WillKimbrough Will Kimbrough collection] at the [[Internet Archive]]'s live music archive\n*[https://www.williesugarcapps.com/ Willie Sugarcapps site]\n\n{{S-start}}\n{{S-ach|aw}}\n{{S-bef|before=[[Jerry Douglas]]}}\n{{s-ttl|title=[[Americana Music Association|AMA Instrumentalist of the Year]]|years=2004}}\n{{S-aft|after=[[Sonny Landreth]]}}\n{{S-end}}\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Kimbrough, Will}}\n[[Category:1964 births]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:American male singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:American rock songwriters]]\n[[Category:Musicians from Mobile, Alabama]]\n[[Category:American rock singers]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from Alabama]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Billy_Edd_Wheeler","to":"Billy Edd Wheeler"}],"pages":{"9876372":{"pageid":9876372,"ns":0,"title":"Billy Edd Wheeler","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American singer-songwriter (1932\u20132024)}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=August 2020}}\n{{Sources|date=September 2024}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = Billy Edd Wheeler\n| image           =\n| caption         =\n| image_size      =\n| birth_name      = Billy Edward Wheeler\n| alias           =\n| birth_date      = {{birth date |1932|12|09}}\n| birth_place     = [[Boone County, West Virginia]], U.S.\n| origin          = [[Whitesville, West Virginia]], U.S.\n| death_date      = {{death date and age|2024|9|16|1932|12|9}}\n| death_place     = [[Swannanoa, North Carolina]], U.S.\n| instrument      = Guitar\n| genre           = {{hlist|[[Folk music|Folk]]|[[Country music|country]]}}\n| occupation      = Singer-songwriter, playwright\n| years_active    = 1964\u20132012\n| label           = {{hlist|[[Kapp Records|Kapp]]|[[United Artists Records|United Artists]]|[[RCA Records|RCA]]|Radio Cinema|NSD}}\n| associated_acts =\n| website         = \n}}\n\n'''Billy Edward Wheeler'''<ref>[http://www.spencerleigh.demon.co.uk/Interview_Wheeler.htm Spencer Leigh interview] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080602145208/http://www.spencerleigh.demon.co.uk/Interview_Wheeler.htm |date=June 2, 2008 }}</ref> (December 9, 1932 \u2013 September 16, 2024) was an American songwriter, performer, writer, and visual artist.\n\nHis songs include \"[[Jackson (song)|Jackson]]\" ([[Grammy]] award winner for [[Johnny Cash]] and [[June Carter]]) \"[[The Reverend Mr. Black]]\", \"Desert Pete\", \"Ann\", \"[[High Flying Bird (song)|High Flyin' Bird]]\", \"The Coming of the Roads\", \"[[It's Midnight (song)|It\u2019s Midnight]]\", \"Ode to the Little Brown Shack Out Back\", \"Coal Tattoo\", \"Winter Sky\", and \"[[Coward of the County]]\" (which inspired a 1981 television movie of the same name) and have been performed by over 160 artists including [[Judy Collins]], [[Jefferson Airplane]], [[Bobby Darin]], [[Richie Havens]], [[The Kingston Trio]], [[Neil Young]], [[Kenny Rogers]], [[Hazel Dickens]], [[Florence and the Machine]], [[Kathy Mattea]], [[Nancy Sinatra]], and [[Elvis Presley]]. \"Jackson\" was also recorded by [[Joaquin Phoenix]] and [[Reese Witherspoon]] for the movie ''[[Walk the Line]]''. His song \"Sassafras\" was covered in the folk rock era by [[Modern Folk Quartet]] and [[The West Coast Pop Art Experimental Band]].\n\nWheeler was the author-composer of eight plays and musicals, a folk opera (''Song of the Cumberland Gap''), commissioned by the [[National Geographic Society]], and three outdoor dramas: the long-running ''Hatfields & McCoys'' at [[Beckley, West Virginia]], ''Young Abe Lincoln'' at [[Lincoln_State_Park#Lincoln_Amphitheatre|Lincoln Amphitheatre]], [[Lincoln City, Indiana]], and ''Johnny Appleseed'', at [[Mansfield, Ohio]]. He has authored six books of humor, four with [[Loyal Jones]] of [[Berea, Kentucky]]: ''Laughter in Appalachia'', ''Hometown Humor USA'', ''Curing the Cross-Eyed Mule'', and ''More Laughter in Appalachia'', and two as sole author: ''Outhouse Humor'', and ''Real Country Humor / Jokes from Country Music Personalities''. His first novel, ''Star of Appalachia'', was published in January 2004, and his second, co-written with [[Ewel Cornett]], ''Kudzu Covers Manhattan'', in 2005. ''Song of a Woods Colt'', a book of poetry, was published in 1969. ''Travis and Other Poems of the Swannanoa Valley (With Some Poems and Prayers by Dr. Henry W. Jensen)'' was published in 1977.  He was the featured author in ''Appalachian Heritage'' magazine's 2008 winter issue, which included 16 of his original paintings. [[North Carolina]]\u2019s ''[[Our State]]'' magazine featured him in its December 2007 issue. In 2018, Wheeler published a book of memoirs entitled ''Hotter Than A Pepper Sprout, a Hillybilly poet's journey from Appalachia to Yale to writing hits for Elvis, Johnny Cash & More''.\n\n==Biography==\nWheeler was born on December 9, 1932, in [[Boone County, West Virginia]]. He graduated from [[Warren Wilson College]] in 1953, and [[Berea College]] in 1955.<ref name=\"Allmusic\">{{cite web |last1=Manheim |first1=James |title=Billy Edd Wheeler: Biography |url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/billy-edd-wheeler-mn0000767622 |website=allmusic.com |access-date=December 19, 2019}}</ref> After serving as a student pilot in the Navy, he served as Alumni Director of Berea College. Wheeler recorded a couple of albums for [[Monitor Records (New York)|Monitor Records]], then from 1961 to 1962 he attended the [[Yale School of Drama]], majoring in playwriting.<ref name=\"Allmusic\"/> With Ewel Cornett, he co-wrote the musical ''Hatfields and McCoys'', which has been performed annually since 1970 by Theatre West Virginia in the Grandview Cliffside Amphitheatre (part of the [[New River Gorge National River]] area).<ref name=\"TWV\">{{cite web |title=Theatre West Virginia 2005 Program |url=http://www.theatrewestvirginia.com/files/program2005.pdf |publisher=Theatre West Virginia |access-date=December 19, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061119181326/http://www.theatrewestvirginia.com/files/program2005.pdf |archive-date=November 19, 2006 |url-status=dead}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Production History |url=http://theatrewestvirginia.com/production-history/ |publisher=Theatre West Virginia |access-date=December 19, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150511153315/http://theatrewestvirginia.com/production-history/ |archive-date=May 11, 2015 |url-status=dead}}</ref> He was married to the former Mary Mitchell Bannerman. They had two adult children, Lucy and Travis, and lived in [[Swannanoa, North Carolina]].<ref name=\"TWV\"/>\n\nIn the 1968 book by Milt Okun ''Something to Sing About: the personal choices of America's folk singers'',<ref>New York: Macmillan Company {{ISBN|978-0-02-592820-6}}; pp. 192-94</ref> Wheeler's choice was \"Turtle Dove\" (\"[[Fare Thee Well (song)|Fare Thee Well]]\"). He died at his home in [[Swannanoa, North Carolina]], on September 16, 2024, at the age of 91.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.wtrf.com/west-virginia/west-virginia-native-songwriter-billy-edd-wheeler-dies-at-91/|title=West Virginia native, songwriter Billy Edd Wheeler dies at 91|website=Wtrf.com|date=September 17, 2024|access-date=September 21, 2024}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Year\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Album\n! colspan=\"2\"| Chart Positions\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Label\n|-\n! width=\"50\"| <small>[[Top Country Albums|US Country]]</small>\n! width=\"50\"| <small>[[Billboard 200|US]]</small>\n|-\n| 1961\n| ''Billy Edd: USA''\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n| rowspan=\"2\"| [[Monitor Records (New York)|Monitor]]\n|-\n| 1962\n| ''Billy Edd and Bluegrass, Too''\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n|-\n| 1963\n| ''A New Bag of Songs''\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n| rowspan=\"6\"| [[Kapp Records|Kapp]]\n|-\n| 1964\n| ''Memories of America''\n| align=\"center\"| 6\n| align=\"center\"| 132\n|-\n| 1965\n| ''The Wheeler Man''\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n|-\n| 1966\n| ''Goin' Town and Country''\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n|-\n| 1967\n| ''Paper Birds''\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n|-\n| 1968\n| ''I Ain't the Worrying Kind''\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n|-\n| 1969\n| ''Nashville Zodiac''\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n| [[United Artists Records|United Artists]]\n|-\n| 1971\n| ''Love''\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n| [[RCA Records|RCA]]\n|-\n| 1972\n| ''Some Mountain Tales About Jack''\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n| Spoken Arts\n|-\n| 1979\n| ''Wild Mountain Flowers''\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n| [[Flying Fish Records|Flying Fish]]\n|-\n| 1995\n| ''Songs I wrote With Chet''\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n| rowspan=\"3\"| Sagittarius\n|-\n| 2001\n| ''Milestones (A Self Portrait)''\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n|-\n| 2006\n| ''New Wine From Old Vines''\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n|}\n\n===Singles===\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Year\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Single\n! colspan=\"3\"| Chart Positions\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Album\n|-\n! width=\"50\"| <small>[[Hot Country Songs|US Country]]</small>\n! width=\"50\"| <small>[[Billboard Hot 100|US]]</small>\n! width=\"50\"| <small>[[CHUM Chart|CAN]]</small><br><ref>{{cite web|url=http://chumtribute.com/65-01-25-chart.jpg| title=CHUM Hit Parade - January 25, 1965|website=Chumtribute.com}}</ref>\n|-\n| 1964\n| \"Ode to the Little Brown Shack Out Back\"\n| align=\"center\"| 3\n| align=\"center\"| 50\n| align=\"center\"| 3\n| ''Memories of America''\n|-\n| 1968\n| \"I Ain't the Worryin' Kind\"\n| align=\"center\"| 63\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n| ''I Ain't the Worryin' Kind''\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 1969\n| \"West Virginia Woman\"\n| align=\"center\"| 51\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n| single only\n|-\n| \"Fried Chicken and a Country Tune\"\n| align=\"center\"| 62\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n| ''Nashville Zodiac''\n|-\n| 1972\n| \"200 Lbs. O' Slingin' Hound\"\n| align=\"center\"| 71\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n| rowspan=\"5\"| singles only\n|-\n| 1979\n| \"Duel Under the Snow\"\n| align=\"center\"| 94\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n|-\n| 1979\n| \"Ring the Bells of Freedom\"\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n|-\n| 1980\n| \"Humperdink, the Coon-Hunting Monkey\"\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n|-\n| 1981\n| \"Daddy\" <small>(with Rashell Richmond)</small>\n| align=\"center\"| 55\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n| align=\"center\"| \u2014\n|}\n\n==Awards==\nWheeler was inducted into the [[Nashville Songwriters Hall of Fame]] in 2001, the West Virginia Music Hall of Fame in 2007, and the [[North Carolina Music Hall of Fame]] in 2011.<ref>{{cite web|title=2011 Inductees|url=http://northcarolinamusichalloffame.org/category/inductees/2011-inductees/|publisher=North Carolina Music Hall of Fame|access-date=September 10, 2012}}</ref> He received an honorary Doctor of Humane Letters degree from his two alma maters: [[Berea College]] in 2004, and [[Warren Wilson College]] in 2011.{{cn|date=September 2024}}\n\nHe has received 13 awards from [[ASCAP]]{{citation needed|date=June 2023}}, the \"Best Appalachian Poetry\" from [[Morris Harvey College]], and [[Billboard Magazine]]\u2019s \"Pacesetter Award for Music and Drama\". In June 2005, [[Country Music Television]] voted \"Jackson\" one of the 100 Greatest Duet Songs of Country Music.{{cn|date=September 2024}}\n\n==Bibliography==\n* ''Song of a Woods Colt'', Droke House (Anderson, SC) 1969\n* ''Travis & Other Poems of the Swannanoa Valley'', Wild Goose, Inc.\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n* [http://www.billyeddwheeler.com/ Billy Edd Wheeler], official web site\n* {{discogs artist|Billy Edd Wheeler}}\n* {{imdb name|2127675}}\n\n{{West Virginia Music Hall of Fame}}\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Wheeler, Billy Edd}}\n[[Category:1932 births]]\n[[Category:2024 deaths]]\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:American male poets]]\n[[Category:20th-century American dramatists and playwrights]]\n[[Category:People from Boone County, West Virginia]]\n[[Category:Berea College alumni]]\n[[Category:American male dramatists and playwrights]]\n[[Category:20th-century American male writers]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from West Virginia]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Owen_Temple","to":"Owen Temple"}],"pages":{"6620213":{"pageid":6620213,"ns":0,"title":"Owen Temple","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer-songwriter}}\n\n{{Infobox musical artist\n|name = Owen Temple\n|image =\n|caption =\n|background = solo_singer\n|birth_name =\n|alias =\n| birth_place  =\n| birth_date   = 1976\n|death_date =\n|origin = [[Kerrville, Texas|Kerrville]], Texas\n|instrument = [[Singing|Vocals]], [[Guitar]], [[Harmonica]]\n|genre = [[Folk music|Folk]], [[country music]]\n|label = El Paisano\n|associated_acts =\n| website = [http://www.owentemple.com www.owentemple.com]\n}}\n\n'''Owen Temple''' (born September 4, 1976 in [[Kerrville, Texas|Kerrville]], Texas) is an American [[Folk music|folk]] and [[country music]] songwriter and musician based in [[Austin, Texas|Austin]], Texas.\n\n== Career ==\nWork with producer and [[pedal steel guitar]] musician [[Lloyd Maines]] led to 1997's ''[[General Store (album)|General Store]]'' and 1999's ''[[Passing Through (Owen Temple album)|Passing Through]]''. The year 2002 saw the release of the [[Phil Madeira]]-produced ''[[Right Here and Now]].''\n\nIn 2007 and 2011, Temple was a [[Kerrville Folk Festival]] New Folk Finalist, and he was the winner of the 2007 [[B. W. Stevenson]] Songwriting Competition.\n\n''[[Two Thousand Miles]]'', a fourth studio project, was produced by Maines and was released on January 22, 2008 on El Paisano Records. A review in [[Allmusic]] noted \"great lyrics full of insight and plainspoken poetry.\"<ref>[{{AllMusic|class=album|id=r1268729|pure_url=yes}} ''Two Thousand Miles'' Allmusic, Poet, J.]</ref>\n\nA fifth studio album, ''[[Dollars and Dimes]]'', was released June 9, 2009.  It is a concept album focused on different regions of North America during hard times.<ref>[http://www.suntimes.com/lifestyles/hoekstra/1652006,TRA-News-Detours05.article] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090711140502/http://www.suntimes.com/lifestyles/hoekstra/1652006,TRA-News-Detours05.article |date=2009-07-11 }} Hoekstra, Dave (July 5, 2009). \"Playing off North America's regions, travel album delivers concept richly\". ''[[Chicago Sun-Times]]''.</ref> In July 2009, the album was the No.&nbsp;1 record on the Euro Americana Chart.<ref>[http://www.euroamericanachart.nl/0709.html] for July 2009. Retrieved July 5, 2009.</ref>  In August 2009, the album was No.&nbsp;5 on the Freeform American Roots chart.<ref>[http://www.tcmnradio.com/far/far120.htm] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131126065540/http://www.tcmnradio.com/far/far120.htm |date=2013-11-26 }} for August 2009.  Retrieved August 10, 2009.</ref>\n\nA sixth studio album, ''[[Mountain Home (album)|Mountain Home]]'', was released April 26, 2011, and the songs on the album focus on small Texas towns and the eccentrics inhabiting them.<ref>[http://www.austinchronicle.com/music/2011-05-13/owen-temple-mountain-home/] Caliguiri, Jim (May 13, 2011). \"Texas Platters: Owen Temple - Mountain Home\" ''[[Austin Chronicle]]''.</ref>\n\n''[[Stories They Tell]]'', a seventh studio album, was released on September 24, 2013.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://jennifinlaypromotions.com/owentemple.htm |title=Owen Temple - Stories They Tell |access-date=2013-09-03 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131214193357/http://jennifinlaypromotions.com/owentemple.htm |archive-date=2013-12-14 |url-status=dead }}</ref>\n\nAn eighth studio album, ''[[Rings on a Tree]]'', was released September 29, 2023, and its songs, many co-written with Walt Wilkins, [[Hal Ketchum]], and others, comprise a concept album focused on intergenerational interactions. <ref>[http://www.rootshighway.it/outsiders/2023/temple.htm] Ricaldone, Remo (December 19, 2023). \"Reviews: Owen Temple - Rings on a Tree\" ''RootsHighway''.</ref><ref>[https://www.americanaboogie.com/americana-music-releases-for-sept-29th/] Frater, Bill (September 28, 2023). \"Americana Music Releases for Sept. 29th\" ''Americana Boogie''.</ref>\n\nA book on songwriting, co-authored with Gordy Quist, titled ''Songfarmer: Writing More and Better Songs'' was published on November 1, 2015.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://songfarmer.com/post/140510862321/songfarmer-writing-more-and-better-songs|title=Songfarmer: Writing More and Better Songs published by El Paisano Press |access-date=December 28, 2022}}</ref>\n\nDreamer: A Tribute to Kent Finlay, released in early 2016 on Austin-based Eight 30 Records, features Temple's version of Finlay's \"Mines of Terlingua.\"<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/dreamer-a-tribute-to-kent-finlay-mw0002916063 |title=Various Artists: Dreamer: A Tribute to Kent Finlay |work=AllMusic }}</ref>\n\n== Artist discography ==\n*''[[General Store (album)|General Store]]'' (1997)\n*''[[Passing Through (Owen Temple album)|Passing Through]]'' (1999)\n*''[[Right Here and Now]]'' (2002)\n*''[[Two Thousand Miles]]'' (2008)\n*''[[Dollars and Dimes]]'' (2009)\n*''[[Mountain Home (album)|Mountain Home]]'' (2011)\n*''[[Stories They Tell]]'' (2013)\n*''[[Rings on a Tree]]'' (2023)\n\n== Writer discography ==\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n|-\n! Lively\n|People\n|Co-Writer (Phantom Pain)\n|-\n|-\n|2024\n|[[Gretchen Peters]]\n|If It Weren't for You\n|Co-Writer (Watch It Shine)\n|-\n|-\n|2024\n|Kelley Mickwee\n|Everything Beautiful\n|Co-Writer (Force of Nature)\n|-\n|}\n\n== See also ==\n*[[Music of Austin]]\n\n== References ==\n{{reflist}}\n\n== External links ==\n*[http://www.owentemple.com Official Website]\n*[{{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p519188|pure_url=yes}} Entry on Allmusic]\n*[http://www.myspace.com/owentemple Owen Temple Myspace Page]\n{{Owen Temple}}\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Temple, Owen}}\n[[Category:Singers from Austin, Texas]]\n[[Category:American male singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from Texas]]\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Writers from Austin, Texas]]\n[[Category:1976 births]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:21st-century American singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Country musicians from Texas]]\n[[Category:21st-century American male singers]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"First_Aid_Kit_(band)","to":"First Aid Kit (band)"}],"pages":{"27653926":{"pageid":27653926,"ns":0,"title":"First Aid Kit (band)","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|Swedish folk duo}}\n{{use dmy dates|date=October 2017}}\n{{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject Musicians -->\n| name                = First Aid Kit\n| image               = File:Coachella18W1-208 (42057786281).jpg\n| image_size          = 300px\n| caption             = First Aid Kit performing live at [[Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival|Coachella]] in 2018\n| origin              = [[Svedmyra]], Stockholm, Sweden\n| genre               = {{flatlist|\n*[[Folk music|Folk]]\n*[[indie folk]]<ref name=\"Dolan\"/>\n*[[Americana (music)|Americana]]\n*[[country folk]]}}\n| years_active        = 2007\u2013present\n| label               = {{flatlist|\n*[[Rabid Records|Rabid]]\n*[[Wichita Recordings|Wichita]]\n*[[Columbia Records|Columbia]]}}\n| website             = {{URL|firstaidkitband.com}}\n| current_members     = {{plainlist|\n*Johanna S\u00f6derberg\n*Klara S\u00f6derberg\n}}\n}}\n'''First Aid Kit''' is a Swedish [[Folk music|folk]] duo consisting of the sisters Johanna and Klara S\u00f6derberg, born in 1990 and 1993 respectively.<ref name=\"bookofriends\"/> When performing live, they are accompanied by a drummer, a guitarist and a keyboard player. First Aid Kit started to become internationally known in 2008 with their YouTube uploaded cover of the [[Fleet Foxes]]' song \"Tiger Mountain Peasant Song\".<ref name=\"Dolan\">{{cite magazine|magazine=Rolling Stone|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-news/the-10-most-killer-cover-songs-of-the-past-decade-97886/|title=The 10 Most Killer Cover Songs of the Past Decade|last=Dolan|first=Jon|date=3 September 2013|access-date=1 February 2022}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.seattleglobalist.com/2012/03/13/stockholm-sisters-tribute-to-fleet-foxes-arrives-in-seattle/1559|title=Stockholm sisters' tribute to Fleet Foxes arrives in Seattle|last=Joko-Fujimoto|first=Claire|date=2012-03-13|website=The Seattle Globalist|access-date=26 May 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2008/dec/10/new-band-first-aid-kit|title=New band of the day \u2013 No 447: First Aid Kit|last=Lester|first=Paul|date=10 December 2008|website=the Guardian|access-date=2016-05-26}}</ref> In 2012 ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' magazine had their song \"Emmylou\" as 10th on their \"Single of the Year\" list.<ref name=\"Emmylou_RollingStone\">{{cite web|title=Rolling Stone Music: 50 Best Songs of 2012: First Aid Kit, 'Emmylou'|date=5 December 2012 |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/lists/50-best-songs-of-2012-20121205/first-aid-kit-emmylou-19691231|publisher=Rollingstone.com|access-date=6 March 2014}}</ref> First Aid Kit has released five albums, four EPs and several singles. In [[Brit Awards 2015|2015]], they were nominated for a [[Brit Awards|Brit Award]] as one of the five [[Brit Award for International Group|best international groups]].<ref name=\"Brit2015\">{{cite web |url=http://www.brits.co.uk/winners/ |title=The Brit Awards winners 2015 (archived) |date=25 February 2015 |access-date=22 September 2017 |url-status=bot: unknown |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150227214946/http://www.brits.co.uk/winners/ |archive-date=27 February 2015}}</ref> They were nominated again in [[Brit Awards 2019|2019]] and [[Brit Awards 2023|2023]].<ref name=\"Brit2019\">{{cite web|url=https://www.brits.co.uk/nominees|title=Brit Awards 2019 Vote for your favourite|work=brits.co.uk|access-date=12 January 2019|archive-date=11 January 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200111194725/https://www.brits.co.uk/nominees|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref name=\"Brit2023\">{{cite web|url = https://www.brits.co.uk/news/2023-international-group-of-the-year-nominees-announced|title= 2023 International Group of the Year nominees announced |work=brits.co.uk|access-date=12 January 2023}}</ref>\n\n==Early history==\nSisters Johanna (born 31 October 1990) and Klara (born 8 January 1993) S\u00f6derberg are from [[Enskede-\u00c5rsta-Vant\u00f6r|Enskede]], in [[Stockholm]].<ref name=\"bookofriends\">{{cite web|title=Book of friends, Swedish Radio P3, 9 July 2013 |url=http://static-cdn.sr.se/sida/images/3849/2909375_1200_674.jpg |publisher=Sverigesradio.se |access-date=22 September 2017}}</ref> Their father Benkt S\u00f6derberg was a member of the Swedish rock pop band [[Lolita Pop]],<ref name=\"SommarP1\">{{cite web|url=http://sverigesradio.se/sida/artikel.aspx?programid=2071&artikel=5127784|title=Klara och Johanna S\u00f6derberg - Sommar & Vinter i P1, 8 July 2012|publisher=Sveriges Radio|date=2012-07-08|access-date=2015-04-05}}</ref>{{rp|at=3:20\u20134:03}} but quit before Johanna was born and became a teacher of history and religion.<ref name=\"Radar\" /> Their mother teaches cinematography.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/music/rockandpopfeatures/9678475/First-Aid-Kit-interview-musical-pain-relief.html|title=First Aid Kit interview: musical pain relief|date=20 November 2012|publisher=telegraph.co.uk|access-date=6 December 2017}}</ref>\n\nFrom childhood, Klara and Johanna were eager singers, giving concerts using a [[jump rope]] as a pretend microphone.<ref name=\"SommarP1\" />{{rp|at=0:40\u20132:40}} Klara's favorite songs were [[Judy Garland]]'s songs from ''[[The Wizard of Oz (1939 film)|The Wizard of Oz]]'' and [[Billie Holiday]]'s version of \"[[Gloomy Sunday]]\", which she sang without much understanding of the English lyrics.<ref name=\"Sonic2011\">{{cite web|url = http://sonicmagazine.com/2018/03/25/tvarsemot-tiden/|title= Tv\u00e4rsemot tiden (originally published in Sonic #60 in December 2011)|date=March 25, 2015|publisher=sonicmagazine.com|access-date=February 1, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160306053316/http://www.sonicmagazine.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=4788&Itemid=117&mosmsg=Item+saved+successfully |archive-date=6 March 2016}}</ref> Klara wrote her first song, \"Femton mil i min Barbiebil\" [Fifteen [[Scandinavian mile|Scandinavian miles]] in my Barbie car], when she was six.<ref name=\"gulliga\">{{cite web|url = http://www.svd.se/first-aid-kit-vill-inte-vara-gulliga_1143199|title= First Aid Kit vill inte vara gulliga|date=17 April 2008|publisher=svd.se|access-date=6 December 2017 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150723131112/http://www.svd.se/first-aid-kit-vill-inte-vara-gulliga_1143199|archive-date=23 July 2015}}</ref>\n\nKlara and Johanna both attended the [[Internationella Engelska Skolan]] ( International English School ) of Enskede.<ref name=\"School\">{{cite news|title=First Aid Kit tillbaka d\u00e4r allt b\u00f6rjade, 27 March 2012|newspaper=Dagens Nyheter |date=27 March 2012 |url=http://www.dn.se/kultur-noje/musik/first-aid-kit-tillbaka-dar-allt-borjade/|publisher=dn.se|access-date=12 April 2015}}</ref> Klara applied for admission to [[Adolf Fredrik's Music School]], but was not accepted.<ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.dn.se/kultur-noje/musik/succesystrarna-fran-svedmyra/|title=Succ\u00e9systrarna fr\u00e5n Svedmyradate=19 January 2010|publisher=dn.se|access-date=7 December 2017 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160412162900/http://www.dn.se/kultur-noje/musik/succesystrarna-fran-svedmyra/|archive-date=12 April 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Klara S\u00f6derberg: \"Jag kom inte in p\u00e5 musikskolan\", 14 October 2014|url=http://www.svt.se/skavlan/first-aid-kit-och-lena-endre-i-skavlan/|publisher=Sveriges Television|access-date=12 April 2015}}</ref>\n\nIn 2005, when Klara was 12, a friend introduced her to the band [[Bright Eyes (band)|Bright Eyes]].<ref name=\"Sonic2011\" /> This led her to country and folk music stars such as [[Johnny Cash]], [[Bob Dylan]], [[Leonard Cohen]], the [[Carter Family]], [[Louvin Brothers]], [[Townes Van Zandt]], [[Gram Parsons]] and [[Emmylou Harris]]. The same year, she received a guitar as a Christmas present<ref name=\"Radar\">{{cite web|title=Interview in Under The Radar, 18 October 2010|url=http://www.undertheradarmag.com/interviews/first_aid_kit/|publisher=Undertheradarmag.com|access-date=13 May 2014}}</ref> and quickly learned to play it.\n\nJohanna enjoyed a wide range of music, from [[Britney Spears]] to [[Techno|German techno]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Interview in It's Nice That, 16 April 2015|url=http://www.itsnicethat.com/articles/first-aid-kit|publisher=itsnicethat.com|access-date=19 April 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Interview in Mashable, 16 October 2014|date=16 October 2014 |url=http://mashable.com/2014/10/16/first-aid-kit-band/|publisher=Mashable.com|access-date=23 October 2014}}</ref> When she saw the film ''[[O Brother, Where Art Thou?]]'' and listened to its soundtrack, she was inspired to sing \"[[Down in the River to Pray]]\" with Klara. Fascinated by the result, the two began to sing together, first at home and then as street singers in the [[Stockholm metro]] and in front of liquor stores.<ref name=\"SommarP1\" />{{rp|at=16:10\u201317:55}}<ref name=\"WorldCafe2015\">{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/world-cafe/2015/07/31/428150148/world-cafe-sense-of-place-stockholm-first-aid-kit|title=Interview (audio): World Cafe Sense Of Place \u2014 Stockholm: First Aid Kit, 31 July 2015|publisher=WXPN & npr.org|access-date=2015-08-02}}</ref>{{rp|at=2:55-4:35}} Klara chose the name for their band at age 13 by looking through a dictionary. She found the term \"first aid kit\" and thought it best described what she wanted her music to be.<ref name=\"Radar\" />\n\nKlara and Johanna began to write their own country-folk songs inspired by [[Devendra Banhart]] and [[CocoRosie]], among others,<ref name=\"Sonic2011\" /> without much influence from their parents, who were fonder of [[Patti Smith]], [[Velvet Underground]] and the [[Pixies (band)|Pixies]].<ref name=\"Radar\" /> Their father has said that he was astonished and a little jealous of the ease his daughters had in producing their music.<ref>{{cite web|title=S\u00e5 \u00e4r det att ha en popstj\u00e4rna som barn, 21 March 2011|url=http://sverigesradio.se/sida/artikel.aspx?programid=4067&artikel=4413437|access-date=4 April 2015}}</ref>{{rp|at=8:20\u20138:55}} The most important advice their father gave them was to sing so loud that even somebody behind a wall could hear it.<ref name=\"Sonic2011\" />\n\n==Career==\n\n===2007\u20132009: Beginnings and ''Drunken Trees'' EP===\nIn April 2007, the sisters began to upload their self-made songs to the social networking site [[MySpace]].<ref name=\"gulliga\" /> They also sent a demo of their song \"Tangerine\" to  Swedish radio.<ref>{{cite web|title=First Aid Kit at Wichita website in 2009 (archived) |url=http://www.wichita-recordings.com/index.php/artists/detail/first_aid_kit/ |access-date=21 September 2014 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090118014829/http://www.wichita-recordings.com/index.php/artists/detail/first_aid_kit/ |archive-date=January 18, 2009 }}</ref> It immediately went on air and was listed as one of the best songs of the summer 2007,<ref>{{cite web|title=B\u00e4st juli 2007 (archived)|url=http://sverigesradio.se/sida/artikel.aspx?programid=2945&artikel=1473208|publisher=sverigesradio.se|access-date=19 April 2015 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304000935/http://sverigesradio.se/sida/artikel.aspx?programid=2945&artikel=1473208 |archive-date=4 March 2016}}</ref> which led to requests for live performances and even some offers from record companies. The first official performance as First Aid Kit was at PUNKTmedis library in Stockholm on 6 October.<ref name=\"School\" /><ref>{{cite web|title=Stor publik p\u00e5 PUNKTdemo 6 oktober|url=http://punktmedis.blogspot.fi/2007/10/|publisher=PUNKTmedis|access-date=4 September 2017}}</ref> More performances followed, but as Klara was 14 and still at school, they could only play during weekends.\n\nCoincidentally, their younger brother attended the same kindergarten as the daughter of [[Karin Dreijer]], half of Swedish electronic duo [[The Knife]], also known as [[Fever Ray]].<ref name=\"gulliga\" /> Their mother asked Dreijer to check out her daughters' songs on MySpace.<ref name=\"Sonic2011\" /> The band subsequently signed with [[Rabid Records]], a label co-owned by The Knife, with conditions that allowed the duo to have full control over their music and album art.<ref name=\"Radar\" />\n\nIn April 2008, the band released their debut EP ''[[Drunken Trees]]'' in Sweden, and made their first appearance on Swedish TV.<ref name=\"gulliga\" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rabidrecords.com:80/firstaidkit/default.html|title=First Aid Kit|publisher=rabidrecords.com|access-date=7 December 2017|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080328230710/http://www.rabidrecords.com/firstaidkit/default.html|archive-date=28 March 2008}}</ref> The EP was produced by their father, and was a re-recorded collection of songs from their MySpace, originally entitled \"Cross Oceans\".\n\nThe duo was relatively well known in Sweden by August 2008, when they uploaded a cover version of \"Tiger Mountain Peasant Song\" by [[Fleet Foxes]] to YouTube. [[Robin Pecknold]], frontman and lead guitarist for Fleet Foxes, praised the cover on his band's webpage, causing a surge in popularity for the video.<ref name=\"Radar\" /><ref name=\"SommarP1\" />{{rp|at=32:40-34:30}} This exposure led to international recognition, and by the end of 2008, the duo had signed a record deal with [[Wichita Records]].\n\n[[File:First Aid Kit Wiesbaden 2009 double.jpg|thumb|right|Johanna (left) and Klara S\u00f6derberg in [[Wiesbaden]] in 2009]]\nDue to international touring, Johanna quit high school in the autumn of 2008 (and Klara never started).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DtE9P57vBAA  |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211215/DtE9P57vBAA |archive-date=2021-12-15 |url-status=live|title=LADYGUNN TV / First Aid Kit Interview |date=20 April 2014 |publisher=YouTube |access-date=2014-06-06}}{{cbignore}}</ref> Their father took a leave from his job as a teacher and accompanied them on tour. First Aid Kit's first show outside [[Scandinavia]] took place on 22 November 2008 at the [[Crossing Border Festival]] in Netherlands. Fleet Foxes performed the day before, and when Pecknold spotted the duo standing at the edge of the stage, they were spontaneously asked to join to sing \"Tiger Mountain Peasant Song\".<ref name=\"SommarP1\" />{{rp|at=34:30\u201335:10}}<ref name=\"WorldCafe2015\" />{{rp|at=6:15\u20137:35}}\n\nWichita re-released ''Drunken Trees'' on 23 February 2009 as an enhanced EP, with \"Tiger Mountain Peasant Song\" added as a bonus track, along with several videos.\n\n===2010\u20132011: ''The Big Black and the Blue''===\nThe duo released their first album, ''[[The Big Black and the Blue]]'' on 1 February 2010.<ref>{{cite web |title=The Big Black And The Blue (Limited Edition CD) |url=http://www.wichita-recordings.com:80/shop/music/the-big-black-and-the-blue-2.html |access-date=6 December 2017 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100410162919/http://www.wichita-recordings.com/shop/music/the-big-black-and-the-blue-2.html |archive-date=10 April 2010}}</ref> As with the ''Drunken Trees'' EP, the album was again produced by their father.
